DOC.HEAD: Study Shows up to Half of Vietnamese Children Malnourished
DOC.TEXT: A national survey has found that up to 50 percent of Vietnam's children are malnourished, according to the official Vietnam News Agency reports. Fifteen percent of the malnutrition cases are serious or very serious, says the recent government survey of nearly 13,000 households in 20 provinces and cities, the agency reported Monday. It said the survey found that 62 percent of men and 38 percent of women were underweight. The study said the average Vietnamese had the world's highest rate of rice consumption, but the diet lacked sufficient protein, fat, vitamins and minerals. Vietnam's economy is one of the world's poorest, and the majority of its 65 million people work the land. The economy was hurt by rigid communism until recent reforms, and by a Western aid embargo after Vietnam invaded Cambodia in late 1978. There are clear signs the reforms have produced good results. Vietnam has harvested its second good rice crop in a row, and its target of producing some 22 million tons of food this year is attainable, the Vietnam News Agency said. It said farmers reaped nearly 12 million tons of rice in the summer and autumn harvests, up by 400,000 tons from last year. The report also said inflation ``remains under control'' although it continued at 3.3 percent per month during this year's first three quarters.

DOC.HEAD: Mail For Troops Clogged By Well-Wishers, But Help Is At Hand
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Along with the bullets, guns and food the military needs to wage war, there's a precious commodity that links the troops in Saudi Arabia to home - the mail, 70 tons a day of it. But the system's becoming clogged with boxes of cookies, books, newspapers and letters to ``any soldier'' from stateside well-wishers, courtesy of ``Dear Abby'' campaigns and drives by churches and schools. With Christmas around the corner, it's going to get wrse. ``I think we're getting so much of it that it bogs down the mail from loved ones,'' said Sgt. J.W. Allen, postmaster for the 1st Tactical Fighter Wing. ``We're getting to the point of maximum utilization. We're constantly filling up,'' said Air Force Capt. Philip Jewitt at the military's main sorting center. ``To be honest, I don't know anybody who'd rather get a newspaper in exchange for a loved one's letter.'' But, with Christmas in mind, reinforcements are on the way. Maj. Gen. William Pagonis, who heads the Army Support Command for Operation Desert Shield, said he plans to activate two more reserve postal units to help the four units, not counting volunteers, now carrying the mail. That will boost the total of people working in the mail system to 450. ``We're handling 70 tons a day. That's killing us. The United States is going super-patriotic,'' said Pagonis. ``It wouldn't be fair to say the system doesn't have some problems. We're improving conditions every day,'' he said. ``When was the U.S. Army ever set up across miles of desert?'' Pagonis is aiming for a delivery time of less than 10 days for letters or packages for troops in the desert. Soldiers are sending four tons of mail back home every day, officers said. Some troops are getting so many old newspapers, books and cookies from well-meaning strangers that they send them back from the desert to the mail room, said Staff Sgt. Russ Lewis of Newark, Calif. ``We'll try to throw them on the trucks, but a lot of people don't want them,'' he said. However taxed the system is, Pagonis says the letter-writing campaigns are not interfering with keeping the fighting men supplied with essential needs. ``I never allow mail to interupt supply. I'm not going to let that happen. Supplies get priority,'' he said. ``I know the mail's just as important to the troops ... When I see the mail interrupting something, I put more guys on supply.'' And the general's not about to ask for a slowdown in the ``Dear Abby'' and other volunteer operations. ``For the one soldier who gets that letter, it's going to be worth it,'' Pagonis said. One Marine was tickled to get 300 birthday cards from the students at R.W. Kershaw School in Mount Ephraim, N.J. ``At least we know somebody's thinking about us,'' said Cpl. Dominic Guinto, of the 1st Battalion, 3rd Marine Regiment, 1st Marine Expeditionary Force. He'll celebrate his 21st birthday on Nov. 1 - in the desert. Meanwhile, supply lines that stretch 12,000 miles back to the United States are working at full throttle. The total tonnage is unavailabe, but the system has unloaded 42,000 pieces of equipment, ammunition pallets and food crates from 101 ships and 677 air force transports in 80 days. ``That's probably unheard of in history,'' said Pagonis, who has 6,000 soldiers under his command. ``In Vietnam, it took five or six years to have this many troops on the ground. We've done it in 80 days.'' Until now, cargo has been limited to everything that is combat essential. Now, supply ships are bringing in spare parts, stockpiles of ammunition, recreation gear, things that make living in the desert a little easier. That includes winter gear such as sweaters and space heaters because the temperatures are beginning to cool. ``There's been no chokepoint at this time,'' Pagonis said. ``We have fresh fruit in every foxhole.'' But some in the field worry that the desert grit is taking its toll on tanks, trucks and helicopters as soldiers train for war. ``We're going through so many parts right now while they're doing their exercises that my biggest concern, if the real thing happens, is rnning out of parts,'' said Sgt. Charles Owen, 35, of Mobile, Ala., who works in the Marine Combat Service Support Detachment. ``There's usually equipment going down every day. It takes a lot to get it going again,'' Owen said. What's important is to stockpile critical parts, said Col. Alex Powell, commanding officer of the Marines' Direct Support Group. ``Instead of just ordering a part that happens to go bad, like a starter on a tank, we'll assume that we've got 100 tanks, look at what's happened so far and say that in 90 days we're going to need 150 of these starters,'' he said. Despite gripes about late mail and lack of parts, the troops say they're well supplied. ``Maybe not everything we want, but everything we need,'' said Maj. John Bates of the 3rd Marine Regiment. Asked what he wanted that he didn't have, Bates said: ``Beer and ice water.''

DOC.HEAD: Lebanese Reunite After Green Line Comes Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BEI1 Oct. 29.
DOC.TEXT: Since the government began tearing down the Green Line that divides Beirut into Christian and Moslem sectors, hundreds of people have reunited with long-lost friends or relatives. Associated Press reporter Mohammed Salam, a Sunni Moslem, recently tracked down a Christian friend, Nicolas Sayegh.

Nicolas and I fell into each others' arms when we met for the first time in 11 years. ``Thank God I survived to see you alive,'' he said. Niclas, a 52-year-old telecommunications employee, and I have been friends for 22 years. We last saw each other in 1979, when he was no longer able to cross from Christian east Beirut to the telecommunications authority in Moslem west Beirut because of fighting. I ventured into east Beirut to find my old pal. When Nicolas recognized me, he knelt down and kissed the ground in a traditional gesture of thanks. Then he hugged me, choking back sobs, saying: ``I want to be sure you are not a dream.'' He introduced me to his wife, Mary, their two daughters and their son, telling them: ``I want you to meet my Moslem brother.'' We talked for an hour about the old days, recalling the girlfriends we had before we got married. And we talked about the future. ``When we knew each other it made no difference whether you were Moslem and I was Christian,'' Sayegh said. ``Do you think these barriers that have separated the Lebanese for 15 years will ever be removed?'' Our reunion was a scene that has been repeated hundreds of times in the two weeks since President Elias Hrawi's government began tearing down the Green Line, the five-mile wall of fortifications that has divided Beirut during 15{ years of civil war. Many Moslem parents are taking their children on tours of the Christian hinterland north of the capital, a part of Lebanon the war generation youngsters have never seen. The Green Line, the most potent symbol of Lebanon's sectarian divisions, started coming down after Syrian troops backing Hrawi crushed rebel Christian Gen. Michel Aoun to end an 11-month mutiny against the government. In eight hours of fighting on Oct. 13, more than 750 people were killed. It was the fiercest battle since the war began in April 1975. Hrawi is struggling to implement an Arab League-brokered peace plan. He has already secured the agreement of the main Christian and Moslem militias to pull out of Beirut and create a military-free zone. Under the peace plan, the Maronites, the main Christian sect which has dominated politics since independence from France in 1943, will surrender many privileges and share power equally with the Moslem majority. Hrawi's next move will be to disband the militias and absorb some of their fighters into a reconstituted national army, which years ago fractured along sectarian lines. That will be easier said than done. Sectarian rivalries remain deep-rooted. Already, Druse Moslem warlord Walid Jumblatt is trading insults with Christian chieftain Samir Geagea. Jumblatt, whose 200,000-strong community is one of the smallest and therefore vulnerable sects, is also highly critical of the peace plan. Despite Hrawi's advances and the initial euphoria of seeing the Green Line fall, the Lebanese have been down this road before. They have seen peace efforts collapse in bloodletting. Many Maronites, longtime enemies of Syria, resent the Syrians' return to east Beirut. ``We want the Lebanese army to extend their authority over the whole of Lebanon,'' said Christian saleswoman Nancy Khoury. ``We don't want the Syrians.'' Aoun's loyalists fear reprisals by Geagea's rapacious militiamen, who fought the general's forces earlier this year. ``Who's going to protect us against Geagea?'' asked Aoun supporter Raffoul Tayan. ``To the Syrians, we and Geagea's men are enemies. They won't mind seeing both of us get slaughtered. ``I don't feel safe at all,'' said Tayan, 25, a mechanic at a garage in Hazmiyeh, east of Beirut. Marlene Taber, a Christian housewife, compared the situation in Aoun's former enclave to what happened when Israel invaded Lebanon in 1982. ``When the Israelis came, our Christia militiamen entered Moslem areas behind them and behaved like conquerers,'' she said. ``The Moslems didn't take it for long. They fought back and peace collapsed,'' Mrs. Taber said. ``Now pro-Syrian militias who entered our areas are behaving like conquerers. This can't last for long. Someone will fight back.'' But many Lebanese are daring to hope that this time it will be different. They believe that with the Lebanese army strengthened and the Syrians apparently determined to enforce peace, it could just work. In Syrian-policed Moslem west Beirut and much of the Christian enclave, life is as normal as it has ever been in the last 15 years. The value of the Lebanese pound, usually a reliable barometer of confidence, has recovered nearly 50 percent since Aoun's defeat. The currency, which was at 1,200 to the dollar when Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2, closed at 720 to the dollar on Beirut's money market late last week. Restaurants, casinos, night clubs and entertainment centers are packed with Lebanese, who have learned to enjoy themselves while they can. Electricity for most of Beirut, which was cut off for nearly two months, is back three hours a day and government officials hope to soon restore it completely. City water supplies are trickling back. People who once lived near the Green Line are returning to their homes - or what's left of them. ``My house is in ruins. But truly, I'm very happy the war is over,'' said auto dealer Samir Tabish as he cleaned debris from the apartment in the Moslem Ras el-Nabeh district that he fled 13 years ago. ``We're dying to move back. But the repairs will cost $15,000 and we don't have that kind of money,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Many German Firms Helped Build Iraq's Arsenal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: ``Made in Germany'' appears on much of Iraq's mighty arsenal, from missiles to poison gas, rocket fuel to helicopters. Six Iraqi poison gas plants were built with German help, according to an independent report commissioned by German authorities. Other companies allegedly delivered technology and know-how that helped Iraq upgrade Soviet-made missiles, obtain parts for a supercannon and acquire equipment needed to produce nuclear weapons. Reports by German media and foreign groups about the involvement of German companies aroused anger in foreign capitals, including Washington, and among Jewish groups at home and abroad. Opposition politicians in Germany demand stronger export controls, even a ban on arms deliveries outside NATO countries. Prosecutors are investigating dozens of companies and some arrests have been made. Two company officials have confessed to helping Iraq obtain the technology to make chemical weapons. The government, already tainted by the scandal two years ago of German involvement in a Libyan poison gas factory, says it is considering steps to curb illegal arms exports. That will not be easy in a country whose economy is based on exports. ``There is no doubt that German companies participated in the Iraqi rocket program,'' said Norbert Gansel, a member of Parliament from the oppositon Social Democrats and an expert on arms exports. ``I am not saying that the government wanted it to be that way,'' he told The Associated Press. Gansel said the government had taken intelligence reports on involvement in illegal weapons sales to Iraq ``all too lightly.'' German law forbids arms exports to areas of tension. Gansel said German companies convicted of illegal dealings with Iraq should have their arms producing licenses revoked. Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann has proposed milder steps. He wants each company to name a manager of weapons exports who could be held responsible if export laws were broken. Other countries also delivered war material to Iraq, but the level of technology provided by German companies allowed Saddam to pursue poison gas and missile programs, according to reports in Der Spiegel, a weekly news magazine. A report commissioned by the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles lists 86 German companies that helped Iraq become a military power. Raymond Seitz, assistant U.S. secretary of state, told Congress this month there were ``German footprints'' all over equipment shipped to Iraq in recent years, but acknowledged it ``is not exclusively a German problem.'' In a fact sheet published six days after Iraq seized Kuwait on Aug. 2, the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute said Germany was far behind some other nations in providing military hardware to Iraq in the last decade. It said the Soviet Union, France and China, three permanent members of the U.N. Security Council, were the main suppliers in that period. The moral question is especially troubling for Germany. Saddam has threatened to attack Israel with chemical weapons. Poison gas was developed and used by the Germans during World War I, and was used to kill Jews in Nazi gas chambers. Spiegel said a German company helped Iraq develop a high-performance fuel that increased the range of its rockets. Ian Anthony, a co-author of the Stockholm institute's report, sad it was hard to stop illegal exports from Wetern Europe. ``There are virtually no border controls in the European Economic Community,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``It is very, very difficult for governments with rather limited resources to enforce the regulations that exist.'' A high official of Germany's federal customs office said 98 percent of arms exports are shipped in parts, making them difficult to track. Many goods also fall in the ``dual-use'' category, allowing companies to claim they did not know their equipment was destined for military use, the official said, on condition of anonymity. He said Iraq often ordered equipment from small firms that had financial problems, but some of Germany's best-known companies also have been implicated. According to Spiegel, Messerschmitt-Boelkow-Blohm helped Iraq obtain the ``fuel air explosive'' bomb, which sprays fuel into the air and ignites the mixture of fuel and air, creating a huge fireball and a shock wave comparable in strength to a small nuclear explosion. The company, a major defense contractor, denied the allegations. It said a study was conducted for the Egyptian government but the project was discontinued in 1988. Spiegel said Iraq obtained the study through Egypt. Much of Spiegel's reporting has been based on a confidential report delivered to Parliament in August by Haussmann, the economics minister. According to the magazine, Haussmann's report said medium-sized German companies were deeply involved in supplying Iraq with parts and the know-how to upgrade Soviet-made Scud-B rockets. Another company named by Spiegel was Water Engineering Trading GmbH of Hamburg, which it said supplied Iraq with chemicals to produce nerve gas. Two managers at the company have admitted to prosecutors that they helped Iraq obtain equipment to make poison gas. Both also had spent several years with German intelligence.

DOC.HEAD: Ban on Abortion Advice to be Argued Before Supreme Court
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulations that bar the staffs of government-subsidized family planning clinics from discussing abortion with their clients are coming under Supreme Court scrutiny. Although fueled by the continuing struggle over abortion, the legal dispute being argued before the court today more directly involves free speech rights rather than women's right to end their pregnancies. At stake is the information available to the 5 million low-income women who depend on family planning clinics and similar health care providers. Several anti-abortion organizations are urging the justices to use the family clinic case to overturn the 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision that legalized abortion. Justice Department lawyers, defending the regulations at issue, said the Bush administration still favors reversal of the 1973 decision. But they did not say this was the appropriate case for such court action. Federal regulations imposed by the Reagan administration in 1988 called for the ban on counseling about abortion, but court challenges have kept the rules from being enforced virtually everywhere. A federal appeals court upheld the 1988 regulations, but other federal courts have ruled them an unconstitutional infringement on free speech rights. The justices are expected to resolve the conflicting rulings by next July. Last year, about 4,000 family planning clinics nationwide received about $140 million in federal assistance. The family planning clinic program, enacted by Congress as Title X of the Public Health Service Act, pays for creating and operating the clinics. For most clinics, federal money accounts for only a portion - perhaps 10 percent - of their budgets. Challengers of the regulations say they represent a kind of ``viewpoint discrimination.'' ``Women who have come to rely on Title X for medically sound advice will be misled,'' they told the court in written briefs. ``The silence of a trusted doctor on the subject of abortion will lead many women to believe that abortion is not an appropriate or medically indicated option for them.'' But Bush administration lawyers argue that the government may choose to favor childbirth over abortion when deciding how to spend taxpayer money. The clinics always have been banned from using federal money to perform abortions, but regulations originally let the clinic staffs - doctors and counselors - tell women about the abortion option and make referrals. After those regulations drew criticism from anti-abortion groups, the Reagan administration said the clinics may not ``encourage, promote or advocate abortion as a method of family planning'' or distribute written materials about abortion. Under the 1988 regulations, a woman who visited a federally funded family planning clinic and asked about abortion would have to be told that the clinic staff ``does not consider abortion an appropriate method of family planning.'' Staff members then could offer help in obtaining prenatal care. The high court has not been the sole battlefield. Legislation to sweep away the counseling ban was introduced in Congress last week and is expected to be reintroduced when the new Congres convenes in January. ``I don't think this is so much a pro-choice or pro-life question,'' said Rep. John Porter, R-Ill., a sponsor of the House bill to lift the ban. ``It's a question of counseling, of providing full information.''

DOC.HEAD: Zoo Animals May Be Left Homeless By State Budget Cuts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX1 Oct. 28.
DOC.TEXT: A 1,200-pound polar bear called Major will lose his home next month. So will elderly orangutans Stanley and Betty, and a skinny Siberian tiger named Sasha. The 85-year-old Stone Zoo is closing because of state budget cuts. ``You can't help (but) develop attachments to the animals,'' said Mark Goldstein, the zoo's director. ``You think of them as individuals.'' The zoo in this Boston suburb was already running on a shoestring, when its budget was slashed by 30 percent from last year because of the state's financial problems. Zoo officials decided to close Nov. 12 rather than house the animals in shoddy conditions. ``There are things worse than no zoo, like a bad zoo,'' Goldstein said. About half the zoo's 200 or so residents will find homes at the Franklin Park Zoo, the larger of the two facilities run by MetroParks Zoos. Some will be moved to other zoos around the country. But some are just too old or too big to relocate easily. ``For some, it will take months to find them a good home,'' Goldstein said. ``But we won't let them end up in private collections. And we hope none will have to be euthanized.'' Large meat-eaters are expensive to feed and maintain, said John Linehan, curator of mammals for the MetroParks Zoos. That doesn't help Major, who eats about 14 pounds of meat and biscuits a day - when he's on a diet. Sasha has an enzyme problem that leaves her a little on the skinny side. And though lions and tigers are increasingly scarce in the wild, they are actually fairly abundant in U.S. zoos. Orangutans Stanley, 31, and Betty, 30, look like a pair of sad-eyed, rust-haired Buddhas sitting quietly in their separate glass enclosures. But they are more mischievous than tranquil. ``Betty steals tools and you have to trade them back,'' Linehan said. ``She gets a brush and starts scrubbing the walls like we do. She won't go through doors she wants you to go through. She demands a lot of attention.'' The two primates have been together 20 years and produced four offspring. But they'll probably be separated when the zoo closes. Stanley may return to Brookfield Zoo near Chicago, his first home, but Betty's future is less clear, since she is old, fat and has an abdominal cyst that has left her unable to reproduce. But don't think the separation will leave either orang heartbroken, keepers said. ``Betty steals Stanley's toys,'' Linehan said. ``Stanley is nice, except when he wants to have his way with Betty. They won't miss each other.'' Wherever he ends up, Stanley will be ``happy to have females around,'' said Linehan. ``He's pretty feisty for his age.'' Goldstein hopes that Stone Zoo can reopen someday. A bill in the Legislature would take the zoo out of state control and make it a public, non-profit corporation, similar to a structure used by most other successful zoos nationwide. But for now the outlook isn't bright, for the zoo's animals or its patrons. Thelma Dennis, 69, has been a volunteer zoo tour guide for children for the past 11 years. ``Of course I'm awfully sad,'' Dennis said. ``This is the real thing, or next to the real thing. Kids can't get the same feeling for an animal on TV that they can seeing them here.'' ``We're trying to get kids off the streets and we're taking away the zoos, the museums,'' said Goldstein. ``You can be 75 years old and want to take a 3-year-old out for the day,'' he added. ``I challenge you to find something else you'd both enjoy.''

DOC.HEAD: New Forecast Of Persistent Rise In Global Air Traffic
DOC.TEXT: International air traffic is expected to increase by about 8 percent this year and more than 6 percent in each of the next four years, with the Far East experiencing the most growth, the leading industry group says. Guenter Eser, the German director general of the International Air Transport Association (IATA), said Sunday that the forecasts were set before the effects of the Persian Gulf crisis on passenger traffic became clear. Regardless, he said the industry's major problem ``continues to be the lack of airport and airspace capacity and this is likely to be the case for a number of years to come.'' The problem remains most severe in Europe, but is rapidly increasing in the Far East, Eser said in his report to association's annual assembly. The gulf crisis, which has raised fuel and insurance costs, tightened a profit squeeze on the industry, he said. Overall profits by member airlines on international scheduled flights dropped sharply last year to 0.4 percent on revenues of $144.5 billion, the lowest margin since 1986. ``It is impossible to forecast the outcome for the full year (1990), but the industry aggregate result is probably not going to be very good,'' said Eser. IATA member airlines carried nearly 212 million international passengers last year, a 7 percent rise. Traffic is expected to grow 8 percent this year, 6.9 percent in 1991 and remain at about 6.5 percent annually through 1994, latest IATA figures showed. The Far East is the fastest expanding area, with nearly 10 percent average annual growth forecast for northeastern Asia and 8.8 percent for the southeastern region. IATA, which groups 200 airlines worldwide, helps coordinate fare levels, ticketing and other areas of airline operations.

DOC.HEAD: Ukrainian Miner, Though Prosperous, Wants Out
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The temperature in the coal mine 3,900 feet down had hit 100 degrees when Volodya Kyechin's vision started to blur. Then the rock floor became rubbery, and the dimly lit shaft went black. Kyechi awoke hours later on the surface, with a case of heat stroke. Over the next nine years, the stout Ukrainian developed high blood pressure, lost half his pay and began dreaming of leaving the mines for good. The average life expectancy of a Soviet coal miner is 48 years. They can retire at 55, but only 5 percent reach that age. ``The work conditions are hard, and I've come to the conclusion that I should leave the mine,'' said the 40-year-old Kyechin, sitting with his wife, Tanya, at a table in his apartment on the outskirts of this industrial city. Soviet miners are relatively well paid, earning an average of 375 rubles a month, 50 percent more than the national average. But no matter what the pay, Kyechin said, ``What's the point ... to go underground where, each time, nobody knows what will happen?'' Miners from across the Soviet Union echoed that sentiment at a five-day congress in Donetsk last week. Accusing the state-run union of failing to represent their interests, they voted to form the country's first independent nationwide labor union. Among their principal demands are safety improvements and a say in the operation of their mines. Kyechin, a miner for nearly 20 years, said he would wait to see what the new union promises before joining. ``I need to know what they would do for me,'' he said. A television flickered in the comfortable two-bedroom apartment as the couple poured out their lives over a feast that included caviar and vodka, both difficult to find in stores. As a department store manager, Tanya is plugged into a network of contacts who help each other obtain the latest goods whenever and wherever they show up. ``If we come across a can of fish, we buy not one, but 10,'' and distribute them among friends, she said. The walls and floors of most rooms were covered with valuable Bukharan rugs - ``it's better to put your money into such things,'' Kyechin said - and a china cabinet stretched across the living room wall, jammed with a half-dozen sets of fine, hard-to-find dishes. The Kyechins and their two daughters, ages 14 and 6, live in a block of pre-fabricated apartment buildings on the outskirts of Donetsk, a sprawling city of 1.2 million. There are some 40 mines within the city limits, and about 80 others scattered across the hilly coal basin. With lax enforcement of safety rules and unreliable medical care, mining is one of the country's most hazardous jobs. An average of 800 Soviet miners die on the job every year; 55 died in the United States in 1988. Among other problems, the extreme depth of many Soviet mines makes it difficult to ventilate them and lower the heat generated by churning machinery and the earth itself. Most countries prohibit mining when the heat reaches a certain level. Soviet miners say their bosses ignore such rules in a heedless drive to win bonuses for fulfilling plans or avoid punishment for failing. ``The deputy director of the mine told the doctor not to write down heat stroke,'' Kyechin said bitterly, recounting his collapse in 1981. ``He said, `Let it be an ordinary case of accidental trauma.''' If heat stroke had been reported, Kyechin explained, a committee would have questioned the mine's supervisers about it. ``And of course, they would catch hell from their superiors and would make less money.'' Kyechin said he protested at first, then capitulated, deciding his relations with the mine director were too important to be risked. ``If you are against them, you are nothing,'' he said. After the heat stroke episode, Kyechin began to suffer high blood pressure. Over the next nine years, he was transferred from mine to mine around the Donetsk basin. On Aug. 6, while working in a ventilation shaft, he suffered heat stroke again, Kyechin said. He was hospitalized for nearly a month with high blood pressure, then released with an ``occupational disease'' and given a job as a tunneler, which pays 260 rubles a month (about $480). Even with additional compensation for his illness, Kyechin's salary is now little more than half the 700 rubles that he once earned as a chief engineer, and that allowed him to fill his apartment with valuables. Because of his long absence from work, he also lost a chance to buy a car through the official union. Fed up with his treatment by superiors, all members of the Communist Party, Kyechin ended his 20-year party membership. ``The party does nothing. There's nothing in it for our future,'' he said. Now, Kyechin has his eye on a new career. An engineer by training, he has a dream of forming a cooperative to repair and remodel apartments. ``I was even thinking of buying a shop,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Republican Drops Out of Governor's Race After Woman's Affair Claim
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 14th graf, `His wife ...' to UPDATE with comment by Taylor. Picks up 15th graf, `Leon Oistad ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MP2
DOC.TEXT: Republican Jon Grunseth dropped out of the Minnesota governor's race Sunday amid allegations that he had an affair while he was married to his first and second wives and that he tried to get teen-age girls to swim nude with him in 1981. ``There are three things that are extremely important to me - my wife, my family, first and foremost; the Republican Party, the people of Minnesota,'' Grunseth said from his home 20 miles east of Minneapolis. ``And the events of the last three weeks have put enormous pressure on the family and I think on the political process and on the people of Minnesota,'' he said. ``I therefore decided to withdraw as the Republican candidate for governor.'' It was not immediately clear whether there would be a replacement Republican candidate on the ballot in the Nov. 6 election. Grunseth's campaign was thrown into turmoil Oct. 15 when it was reported that two women said in sworn statements that he tried to get them to swim nude with him during a 1981 pool party at his home. The women, who were then 13 and 14, said they refused but that Grunseth, his teen-age daughter and a 16-year-old girl took off their bathing suits. One of the women also said Grunseth tried to pull down her bathing suit top and touch her breast. Grunseth denied the allegations. Grunseth nearly withdrew from the race Thursday but changed his mind several hours later. On Saturday, Grunseth acknowledged to the Star Tribune newspaper he had a ``romantic'' relationship with 32-year-old Tamara Taylor of Minnetonka, but said it ended ``a long time ago - in the early '80s.'' Grunseth, 44, divorced Katharine Winston in 1983 and married his second wife, Vicki, in 1984. Taylor claimed she had an intermittent sexual relationship with Grunseth from 1980 to 1989 while he was married to his first and second wives. Grunseth said his affair with the woman ended before he remarried in 1984. He has denied the nude-swimming allegations. Later Sunday, Grunseth told reporters he had over the last two weeks been on the verge of quitting the governor's race. ``It's wear and tear, it's just simply pure wear and tear,'' Grunseth said. ``The whole thing becomes sickening. It's exhaustion, is what it is. Mental, physical, emotional exhaustion. ...At a point there's an end. You just say, `Man, it's more than I can bear.''' His wife said she believes her husband's contention that he ended the affair before they married. She said she did not try to dissuade him from dropping out of the race. Taylor said in a statement Sunday she disclosed her affair with Grunseth to prevent his ``further deceptionof the voters ... in regard to his past antics, his character, and what ruthless actions he is willing to take in order to be elected governor.'' Leon Oistad, Grunseth's campaign manager, had vowed Saturday that Grunseth would remain in the race. Oistad blamed the latest controversy in the Republican's bid to unseat Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich on a witch hunt led by the Star Tribune, which published Taylor's story Sunday. Grunseth said his withdrawal from the race will be effective as soon as the necessary paperwork was processed. Perpich is seeking a fourth term and state Auditor Arne Carlson, the runner-up in the Sept. 11 GOP primary, re-entered the race as a write-in candidate last week. The state GOP executive committee can name a replacement for Grunseth on the ballot. However, party co-chairwoman Barb Sykora said it was uncertain whether the committee can be convened in time before Friday's deadline for candidates to be formally named if they are to appear on the ballot. ``It looks like we should support Arne Carlson,'' Sykora said. ``Arne's very well qualified to be governor. Can the party survive? We have to survive. We have terrific candidates running at all levels.'' Grunseth said Republicans should unite behind his successor. ``They've got a superb opportunity to defeat Rudy Perpich even though it's a very short period of time,'' he said. ``As I've said before, the road to the defeat Rudy Perpich has been paved with my reputation and the tears of the Grunseth family, and I think it's wide open for the Republicans to take,'' Grunseth said. Carlson said he was surprised that Grunseth was pulling out. ``I'm sad for Jon and his family. One doesn't revel in another person's difficulty,'' Carlson said. ``I'm going to spend a lot of time now to make sure we heal the wounds,'' he said. ``I have to reach to all areas of the Republican Party to bring this together so we can put together a winning election.''
DOC.HEAD: Ms. Taylor said she had come forward with her allegation of an
DOC.TEXT: affair with Grunseth because she believed she was the one person who could prevent Grunseth's ``further deception of the voters.'' ``Most troubling to me, knowing what Jon had told me about his personal life in the past, was the fact that he was willing to go to such great lengths to publicly try to exonerate himself in order to forge ahead with his campaign with total disregard to the knowledge that he was seriously affecting the reputations and future of these two women by calling them liars,'' Taylor said in a statement Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Golf Becomes Big Business in Thailand; Japanese Flock In
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The golf-crazy Japanese are flocking to Thailand to enjoy low greens fees, friendly caddies and courses laid out by some of the world's top designers. Thailand is in a golf boom. Mana Sookbank, honorary secretary of the Thailand Golf Association, said there are 60 courses in operation, 40 under construction and many more planned. For the Japanese, golfing in Thailand costs a fraction of what it does at home. They are joined by burgeoning ranks of domestic players, from corporate climbers to Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan, who conducts a lot of political business on the links. Players soon will be able to tee off near the River Kwai, where Allied prisoners died by the thousands building a railway for the Japanese in World War II, and in the hills of the infamous Golden Triangle opium region. A complex of courses, hotels and an airstrip billed as Asia's largest golf development will stretch along the Gulf of Siam southwest of Bangkok. It is to include a meditation center. ``Thailand's boom comes at a fortunate time,'' said Desmond Muirhead, a leading golf course designer. ``Instead of building second-rate courses by themselves, like the Japanese did after World War II, the Thais are getting top foreign talent.'' Muirhead, a Briton based in the United States, said he plans to design at least five courses in Thailand and has begun work on the Century Country Club in the eastern coastal province of Rayong. The $100 million project includes individual homes, condominiums, a hotel and two golf courses, one by Muirhead and the other by top-ranked professional Nick Faldo. Among the other big names at work in Thailand are Jack Nicklaus, Arnold Palmer and Greg Norman. ``People are going to beat a path from all over to play these courses,'' Muirhead said in an interview. ``We expect them to be more visually pleasing than those in the United States.'' While genuine interest in the sport is behind the boom, many who wouldn't know a birdie from a bogey are getting in on the action. Acquiring golf club memberships for speculation, as if they were commodities futures, has become a lucrative business. Mana, of the golf association, said a membership at Green Valley Golf Course had gone up nearly 700 percent in three years to 800,000 baht, or $32,000. Even so, club memberships remain cheaper than in Japan, Taiwan, Singapore, and Hong Kong. Golfers and investors from those countries are lining up for the leading Thai clubs, some of which have had to place quotas on foreigners. Golf was introduced by Thai royalty in the 1920s. It has attracted the elite ever since, and spread to other classes because of economic prosperity, tourism and the sport's growing worldwide popularity. The Japanese, including members of the large expatriate community, frequently describe playing here as ``being in golfer's heaven.'' Greens fees at luxurious, uncrowded clubs are about $40 and low labor costs permit levels of course maintenance and service that are rare in other countries. Many golfing parties have a trail of caddies, often young women who carry portable stools, umbrellas, cold drinks and towels as well as clubs. At home, Japanese golfers must reserve playing time far in advance, then battle weekend traffic to reach congested courses. At clubs in the Tokyo area, non-members pay at least $240 for 18 holes, meals and transportation. South Korea and Taiwan, closer than Thailand, still are favored foreign destinations for Japan's 15 million golfers, but the Thais expect their traffic to grow. Travel agencies in Japan offer five-day, all-inclusive golf tours for about $1,600, the cost of half a dozen rounds at home. Critics of the golf explosion say valuable farm land is being lost and the environment harmed in some areas. Officials have questioned whether investing millions in a sport for the wealthy is appropriate for a developing nation. Promoters argue that golf courses provide more, higher-payed jobs than the same land devoted to agriculture. They say courses are environmental assets in urban areas, serving as the green belts that government planning has not provided.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds of Thousands of Yemenis Forced Home By Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The latest wave in the sea of refugees created by the Persian Gulf crisis is cresting here in this small nation. For some, it is a sad and bitter homecoming to a land that no longer feels like home. In the wake of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, the Yemenis were cast out of their promised land - Saudi Arabia, where they had earned good wages and made new lives for themselves. Some spent decades there. In the past five weeks, up to 750,000 Yemeni nationals have returned to their mountainous homeland at the tip of the Arabian peninsula, where North and South Yemen reunited earlier this year to form the new nation of Yemen. They bring with them what they can, in cars and trucks piled high as parade floats. But they leave much behind. Saudi officials have said Yemenis were stripped of their right to stay because of President Ali Abdullah Saleh's sympathies for Saddam Hussein and anti-Saudi demonstrations in San`a, the Yemen capital. Yemen denies it sided with Saddam, although it failed to support U.N. resolutions against him soon after the invasion. The total number of those returning, based on Saudi and Yemeni figures, could not be determined accurately since many families crossed the border here on a single document, and individuals were not counted. The numbers dwindled after Saudi authorities recently extended until late November the deadline for 1 million to 2 million Yemenis to find a local sponsor - or get out. But a new wave is expected. ``This was not a reasonable decision,'' said Jamal Mohammed Saad, 35, standing amid his remaining possessions after 16 years in Saudi Arabia. ``People had no time to time to sell their houses or property. It is impossible.'' Departing Yemenis were allowed to transfer bank deposits and take out property. But Saudi authorities, trying to curb smuggling, have been confiscating some goods. ``They have my tires, 70 tires,'' wailed Mohammed Sultan, who said he abandoned his automotive shop for lack of a buyer and piled his stock onto a truck. Saudi officials said he had no vouchers for the tires. Another man, jostling for attention among a crowd of people waiting at a border post in the baking sun, said plaintively: ``They took my box of apples.'' Col. Ahmed Mohammed Shamrani, head of the Saudi border post near here, said about 350,000 Yemeni passports had been stamped since Sept. 18. Another 100,000 people were cleared without documents. And tens of thousands returned via other crossings, he said. Since many passports listed several family members, the overall total was believed in the range of 750,000. Few returnees reported any serious maltreatment, and most seemed to take the disruption to their lives with a certain fatalism. But the distress was plain to see. Ramshackle settlements of burlap and plywood sprouted on the highway, housing people who had lost touch with families during their time in Saudi Arabia. Some had been away for as long as 40 years. In Saudi Arabia, the impact of the Yemeni exodus has been severe in sectors of retail trade and some services. Along roads in Jiddah and Riyadh, rows of shops are bolted shut. Many companies arranged to sponsor their Yemeni employees, but a number of returnees said that Saudis were afraid to back them for fear of official reprisals. Saudi authorities deny this. At the Yemenis' old bedouin silver souk in Saudi Arabia at Khamis Mushet, Khalid Haji was the last to go. He sold off heirlooms at giveaway prices. ``We've made our life here, not there, and I have nothing to do with politics, but what choice is there?'' he said. Asked when he came to settle in Saudi Arabia, he smiled ruefully and tapped out the digits on his calculator: 1957. In Jiddah, a luggage merchant who asked to be called only Hamid was packing up in bags from his own shop. ``Saudis and Yemenis have always been like this,'' he said, interlocking his fingers. ``Why are we suddenly thrown out like enemies?'' Yemeni authorities said the influx would burden Yemen's fragile economy, but insisted the long-term effect would be healthy. However, remittances from Yemenis living in Saudi Arabia had made up one-third of the gross national product, well over $1 billion, counting unofficial transfers. Already, college graduates here can wait six months for a job. At the port city of Hodeidah, the Sagear family stopped to rejig the mountains of luggage atop two sedans: bedding, tires, tricycles, suitcases, a television. They have been away 20 years. Ali Sagear, 15, has never seen Yemen. Ayshe Sagear, 23, said Saudi Arabia is their home, but ``if they don't want us, we'll find something here.'' Yahya Ali al-Jouri, sent home from Mecca after 35 years, was bitter. He sold his grocery business at a fourth of its value and counted himself lucky to get that much. Now he passes time in the a San`a tea room in an ancient mud building. ``When the Saudis need us, we are welcome,'' he said. ``When they don't, we are nothing to them.''

DOC.HEAD: Specter of Vietnam Haunts Operation Desert Shield
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DHA4 Oct. 28.
DOC.TEXT: Lance Cpl. Juan Baca, hunkered down in the belly of a U.S. Marine assault vehicle lurching across the night desert, asked about the demonstrations back home against Operation Desert Shield. ``It ticks me off,'' said Baca, 20, of Lubbock, Texas. ``This isn't Vietnam. This is a totally different situation.'' Vietnam was long ago and far away, but the conflict is much on the minds of young soldiers in Saudi Arabia. Word of antiwar demonstrations back home has trickled back to the troops here, who are the tip of the military spear pointed at Saddam Hussein's forces. They are mindful of the hostile reception that greeted Vietnam veterans a generation ago when they came home from an unpopular war. They fear a loss of public support for the deployment of U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf region could bring similar anger down on their heads. ``I'd feel betrayed if people turned against us,'' said Cpl. John Vaughn, 23, of Bravo Company of the 3rd Marine Regiment, based in Hawaii. Vaughn, from Detroit, is nicknamed ``Lifer'' - the military slang for a career military man. Vietnam was America's longest war, the only war America lost, a war marked by campus riots and draft card burnings, bitterness and shame. The scars are still apparent. ``I would hope people would put it aside and learn from it, but not judge every conflict by what happened in Vietnam,'' said Baca. ``We'd like it a whole lot better if people were patting us on the back.'' Several soldiers approached reporters to ask about support on the home front for the troops in the gulf. Public backing for the deployment was initially high, but there has been increasing criticism of President Bush's actions as the high cost of the operation sinks in, and people face up to the prospect of a shooting war in the region. Some of the soldiers in Saudi Arabia have firsthand memories of Vietnam - and painful ones. Maj. John Bates, 44, of Little Rock, Ark., an executive officer for a Marine battalion, was wounded in the conflict. He was shot in the lung. From his standpoint, the American people misdirected their anger at the fighting men in Southeast Asia, instead of targeting the politicians who sent them there. ``The military doesn't make policy. We only enforce it,'' said Bates, in a mess tent set up in the sand. ``People were pointing the finger in the wrong direction.'' Vietnam memories are still strong for 1st Sgt. Chuck Woodruff, 38, of Oroville, Calif. He was on the second-to-last helicopter that left the roof of the U.S. Embassy when Saigon fell on April 30, 1975. ``The question keeps coming up because there's nothing to compare this to except Vietnam. This is the biggest military operation since then,'' said Woodruff, who has the Marine Corps emblem tatooed on his left arm. ``I think it will take generations and decades before people forget.'' Support from home means a lot to troops huffing, puffing and sweating it out under a relentless Saudi sun, 7,000 miles from the East Coast. Staff Sgt. Charles Woods, 31, of North Glenn, Colo., said the troops could deal with the conditions, ``as long as they know the American people are behind them.'' Woods, fresh from a tactical exercise in which Marines practiced assaulting a fortified bunker, was quick to point out how much the troops appreciate letters from schoolchildren, churches and individuals who write encouraging notes addressed just to any soldier. Vietnam veterans make their presence felt in other branches of the military as well. At the U.S. Navy's Fleet Hospital No. 5, a sign on one desk read ``Vietnam Veteran and Proud Of It.'' Another Vietnam veteran is Col. Jim Gass, 48, of Carney, Okla., an artillery unit commander in the Army's 1st Cavalry Division. ``No soldier wants to go somewhere away from home and have the country not support him,'' Gass said. ``Today's soldiers want to know their causes are just.''

DOC.HEAD: Egypt Reaps Rewards from Gulf Involvement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Egypt's military involvement in the Persian Gulf crisis is proving to be a financial windfall for President Hosni Mubarak's government. Its U.S. and Arab allies are moving to write off $14 billion in debts - almost a third of a $50 billion obligation to foreign creditors that for years has crippled the Egyptian economy. Aid worth hundreds of millions of dollars also is pouring in, and prospects are considered bright for agreement with the International Monetary Fund to reschedule the remaining foreign debt. Mubarak is reaping political benefits as well. Egyptian commentators are praising his handling of the gulf crisis that began Aug. 2 with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Mahfouz el-Ansary, editor of the government's Al-Gomhuriya newspaper, hailed Mubarak's ``determination and skill,'' his ``patience, wisdom and hard work.'' At the onset of the crisis, it hardly looked as if Mubarak would emerge a winner. He was humiliated by the failure of a last-minute bid to stave off the Iraqi invasion - an effort that Saddam Hussein let him believe had succeeded right until the Iraqi president sent tanks into Kuwait. Back then, Egypt had looked likely to be a big financial loser in the conflict. It faced losses estimated at $4.5 billion in the form of a ruined tourism industry, reduced Suez Canal revenues and dwindling remittances from Egyptians working in gulf countries. What turned the tide was Mubarak's strong, quick response to the Iraqi takeover. He muscled through an Arab League summit a resolution condemning Iraq, demanding withdrawal from the emirate, and authorizing dispatch of troops to the gulf region. Then, he sent nearly 16,000 Egyptian troops to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. They were there to help defend those Arab states, but more importantly, the Arab involvement made the presence of the multinational force in Saudi Arabia far more politically palatable. The United States has an estimated 220,000 troops in the gulf. Mubarak has made repeated efforts to find a diplomatic solution to the crisis, but he said Sunday he was ready to send more troops as well as military planes to Saudi Arabia if they were requested. ``With peace efforts, that does not mean we can relax military action,'' the Egyptian president said at a news conference. Mubarak spent four days in the gulf region last week, visiting four states allied with him against Iraq. At the end of the tour, it was announced that Saudi Arabia, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait's exiled government were writing off more than $7 billion that Egypt owes them. In the United States, forgiveness of a $6. billion Egyptian debt was part of the foreign aid program that Congress approved and sent to President Bush before adjourning early Sunday. Bush, in Honolulu, said Sunday he would sign the measure. Prime Minister Atef Sedki said Saturday that interest on the military debt alone amounts to almost $1 billion annually. As for other debt relief, Egypt has been trying to negotiate a new package with the International Monetary Fund since a 1988 rescheduling agreement expired. Western economists in Cairo say Egypt and the IMF have ironed out most of their differences and expect to sign a new pact early next year. That will pave the way for Cairo's main creditors, the Paris Club, to convene and arrange rescheduling. A well-informed economist, speaking on condition he not be further identified, said Egypt has agreed to reduce subsidies further on basic food items, a key IMF reform demand. Additionally, he said, Cairo will further devalue the Egyptian pound and raise bank interest rates. But he said signing will be delayed because some of the commitments must be ratified by the People's Assembly, Egypt's parliament, which is presently dissolved. A new parliament will be elected in late November and seated in December.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Katharine Hepburn says that getting old is ``a bore'' and that death will be a relief from reporters. Asked if she fears death, the 83-year-old actress told People magazine in its Nov. 5 issue: ``Not at all. Be a great relief. Then I wouldn't have to talk to you.'' So why did she agree to an interview? ``Soon it will be too late, and I'd rather do this myself than have others do it after I'm dead. They never get things straight,'' she said. Getting old, she said, is a ``B-O-R-E, when you find you've begun to rot.'' A book of photographs shot over the last 15 years by John Bryson, ``The Private World of Katharine Hepburn,'' will be published in November. Hepburn also is hard at work on an autobiography, which she calls ``a bunch of stories.'' It is due out in August. --- BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. (AP) - ``Crocodile Dundee'' star Paul Hogan and his bride, Linda Kozlowksi, have bought a $6.5 million English-style home with a stone waterfall. Hogan and Kozlowski, co-stars in the two ``Dundee'' films, married in May after starring in ``Almost an Angel.'' The comedy comes out in December. The two-story Beverly Hills house has three bedrooms, four baths and two maids' quarters. It also has a tennis court, pool and spa. --- RADNOR, Pa. (AP) - Peter Horton, who plays Gary on ABC's ``thirtysomething,'' predicts the show will last no longer than another season. ``There's just so much this bucket of `thirtysomething' can give out,'' said Horton in the Nov. 3 issue of TV Guide. ``We've been mining it for more than three years, and we're starting to scrape bottom. I don't know how much more there is to say about this group of people.'' But Horton, who plays a college professor who has trouble coming to grips with responsibility, said breaking up will be hard to do. ``We have a huge, almost visceral attachment to the show and to each other,'' he said. ``We'll all still be friends, but we'll drift apart. It's sad to think about.'' --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Kirstie Alley says she's willing to pay the supermarket tabloids for the names of people who leak information to the reporters of Tinseltown. ``Those sleazeballs who write this crap are so slimy they'll gladly inform on their informants for money,'' the star of ``Cheers'' and the new movie ``Sibling Rivalry'' said in Sunday's The Tennessean. ``I'm about to get a list of the people at Paramount who are feeding them stuff. I'll make sure they won't work there again.'' ``No way will I dignify those people by suing them,'' she said. ``I try to ignore everything, hoping people will realize what total lies they are telling.'' --- RADNOR, Pa. (AP) - Rap star Kurtis Blow says he's playing it cool working as a consultant on a rap music story line for ABC's ``All My Children.'' ``There has been a lot of pressure from the network brass to keep our songs clean and commercial,'' Blow said in the Nov. 3 issue of TV Guide. ``Rap's been getting a bad rap lately, so we are being very careful not to offend. ``When I started out, rap was positive and fun,'' said Blow, whose ``Christmas Rappin' '' went gold in 1979. ``Somehow, the press zoomed in on the hard-core, negative stuff and it all got out of balance.'' Blow is writing tunes, coaching actors and approving costuming and the lighting for club sequences on the soap opera.

DOC.HEAD: Maronite Power Near Its End
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The clout of this country's Maronite Catholics, who have dominated its politics for a half century, is rapidly crumbling amid blood feuds and a new Moslem ascendancy. The end of an era is looming for the only Christians in the overwhelmingly Moslem Middle East to have controlled a state since the Crusaders in the Middle Ages. The Gemayels, Chamouns and Franjiehs - the clans that have ruled fractious Lebanon since independence from France in 1943 - are entangled in a new round of vendettas that will probably seal their fate. The Oct. 21 slaying of Maronite political leader Dany Chamoun and most of his family was the latest. ``No one listens to the voice of reason,'' Papal Nuncio Pablo Puente lamented recently. ``Christians are destroying Christians in senseless bloodbaths.'' The nearly 1 million Maronites, the main Christian sect in Lebanon, have suffered more from their own feuds than from conflict with Moslems in the nation's 15-year-old civil war. Under a proposed Arab League-brokered peace plan, the Maronites would have to share power with Moslems, who now comprise a majority of the 3.5 million people in a nation where Islamic fundamentalism is on the rise. But many Maronites are reluctant to give up their privileges. ``I'm afraid we're going to go back to even worse times if the Maronite establishment fails to respond to the winds of change,'' warned Elie Hobeika, a Syrian-backed leftist Maronite at odds with the dominant right-wingers of his sect. Hobeika foresaw the need for the Maronites to give ground or eventually perish and signed a Syrian-brokered peace treaty with the main Moslem warlords in 1985, when he headed the Christians' main militia, the Lebanese Forces. But he was ousted by right-wing diehards the next year and fled to territory controlled by the Syrians, who have about 40,000 troops in Lebanon. Hobeika returned to the Christian heartland northeast of Beirut after Syrian and government troops crushed rebel Maronite Gen. Michel Aoun on Oct. 13, removing the main obstacle to the new peace plan. The return of Hobeika, 34, has raised fears of a showdown between him and Samir Geagea, the right-wing Maronite who ousted him in 1986 in a shootout that claimed the lives of 350 Christians. But even without the feuding, the power of the Maronite political dynasties has ebbed. Christianity has been on the retreat in the Middle East for years. Christian leaders noted at a recent conference in Cyprus that Christian emigration from the region, including Lebanon, is growing amid rising Islamic fundamentalism. There are an estimated 12 million Christians in the Middle East compared with about 120 million Moslems. The Maronites - named for St. Maroun, a 5th century Syrian-born monk who settled in the pine-covered Lebanese mountains - have seen themselves as part a centuries-old fight for survival against Islam. Yet their reluctance to share power with Moslems helped ignite the civil war, which has left more than than 150,000 people dead. ``They're the only Christian community with a distinct political history,'' said Prof. Kamal Salibi, who teaches history at the American University of Beirut. ``They fear being overwhelmed. If the system is democratized, they'll be outvoted and they can't carry the day.'' Of Lebanon's three great Maronite patriarchs, only 79-year-old Suleiman Franjieh is alive. His rivals, Pierre Gemayel and Camille Chamoun, survived several assassination attempts and died of natural causes. Now their heirs are at each others' throats. Patriarch Nasralla Sfeir, the Maronite's spiritual head, has proved helpless in efforts to try to reconcile them. His appeals for cease-fires and threats of excommunication have gone unheeded, a far cry from the days when Maronite politicians took their instructions from the patriarch. Two days after Aoun was crushed, gunmen killed Dany Chamoun, his wife and two small sons at their home east of Beirut. Chamoun was a staunch supporter of Aoun and the slayings appeared to be aimed at ending the political legacy founded by Chamoun's father, Camille. Other scores have also to be settled among the Maronite clans. Phalangist militiamen loyal to Pierre Gemayel's youngest son, Bashir, attacked Franjieh's domain in north Lebanon on June 13, 1978, and slaughtered his son and political heir, Tony, along with his wife and daughter and 21 bodyguards. Geagea led the assault and the elder Franjieh, a close friend of Syrian President Hafez Assad, vowed revenge. So far, the massacre has gone unanswered. Bashir Gemayel made no secret two years later that he ordered his men to slaughter more than 300 members of Chamoun's Tigers militia north of Beirut. Gemayel was elected President Aug. 23, 1982, with Israel's backing. But he was assassinated in a bombing at Phalange headquarters in Beirut on Sept. 14, 1982, a week before he was to be sworn in. The bombing was blamed on a leftist pro-Syrian faction dominated by Greek Orthodox Christians. Gemayel's elder brother, Amin, was elected as his successor. But when Amin's violence-ridden term ended in 1988, he fled to self-imposed exile in Paris, signaling the end of the Gemayel dynasty. Tony Franjieh's son, Suleiman Jr., 23, contends his father was not avenged by Bashir Gemayel's death. He is reported to be waiting in the Franjieh's power base of Zghorta to send his 2,000-strong militia against Geagea.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Farouk Nassar, the chief correspondent in Beirut for The Associated Press, has covered Middle East politics for 20 years.

DOC.HEAD: Tiny Group of Islands Causes Trouble in in Northeast Asia
LaserPhoto HK1 of Oct. 28
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CLARIFY that Sunday referred to is Oct. 21, SUB 4th graf, `Two fishing ...' ^By DAN BIERS
DOC.TEXT: A rekindled dispute over specks of inhospitable rock in the East China Sea is feeding anti-Japanese sentiment in quarters already fearful that Tokyo is drifting away from pacifism. The five tiny islands - the largest only 2.5 miles in diameter - and three rocks are claimed by Japan, China and Taiwan. The area is considered a rich fishing ground and is believed to contain oil. Japan calls the archipelago the Senkakus, but China and Taiwan know the islands as the Diaoyutai. After a decade in abeyance, the argument over them was revived by reports in Taiwan that a right-wing Japanese group planned to renovate a lighthouse on the main island. Two fishing vessels carried Taiwanese politicians and athletes to the islands on Oct. 21 in an attempt to reinforce Taiwan's claim, but were turned back by patrol boats of the Japanese coast guard. In Hong Kong, about 10,000 people turned out for a rally and march to demand that Japan give up its claim to the islands. The confrontation comes at a sensitive time for Tokyo. Many Asian nations that were brutally occupied by Japan during World War II already have expressed concern about a government proposal now before Japan's parliament to send noncombat troops to the Persian Gulf. That bill would allow the first overseas deployment of Japanese soldiers since the war. Many believe sending the troops would violate Japan's postwar constitution, which forbids it to use force in international disputes. Taiwan and China, usually at loggerheads because of their rival claims to be the legitimate government of all China, have objected strongly to Japan's sending coast guard vessels to the disputed islands, which are 120 miles northeast of Taiwan and 95 miles northwest of Nishiomotejima, a Japanese island. Protesters in Taiwan, which was a Japanese colony for 50 years until World War II ended, have burned the Japanese flag, thrown eggs outside Japan's representative office in Taipei and vow to launch another voyage to the islands. ``Japan has to recognize the Diaoyutai Islands are our territory,'' protest leader Lee Ching-hwa said last week. ``They should stop expanding militarism.'' Pro-Beijing newspapers in Hong Kong, which reverts from British to Chinese sovereignty in 1997, have printed emotional editorials on the islands that recall Japan's expansionist past. ``China has been a victim of Japanese militarism,'' the Ta Kung Pao said. ``There still exists a widespread sentiment among the Chinese people opposing militarism.'' A full-page newspaper advertisement by the Hong Kong Professional Teacher's Union made a clear connection between the island dispute and fears of renewed Japanese militarism. ``Protect Diaoyutai; Teach the next generation,'' it said. The ad included photographs of Chinese slaughtered by Japanese soldiers in World War II. Japan has repeatedly denied any intention of reviving militarism. It incorporated the islands in 1895. The United States administered them from the end of World War II until 1972, when they were returned to Japan. China has claimed the chain since ancient times. The Chinese Nationalist government, now on Taiwan, contends the islets came under its sovereignty in 1945 when Japan was defeated. A 1968 United Nations report said large oil deposits may lie in nearby seabeds. Japan shelved a joint exploration plan with China in 1979 because they were too far apart on the sovereignty issue. The Foreign Ministry says fishermen recently refurbished the 12-year-old light and want it to be designated an official navigation beacon, but that the Maritime Safety Agency has made no decision on the application. The ministry said it knew of no plans by any right-wing group to make further changes. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu has been quoted as saying Japan would ``act prudently'' on the lighthouse matter. Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe has said there are no plans to have the navy patrol the islands. In Taiwan, Chang Lung-yi of the Institute of International Relations said he did not see the island incident as a sign of Japan becoming a military power, but added: ``Japan could easily transform its well-developed industries to making weapons and people are concerned that it would quickly build up its military power.'' Some commentators in Tokyo question whether fear of Japanese militarism is the main factor. Yozo Yokota, professor of international law at International Christian University, believes China may see a chance to reinforce its claim to the islands while Japan is trying to project a world image of peacemaker. Taiwan, which has been isolated diplomatically because of its claim to China, may want to demonstrate that it is a regional power, some Japanese academics believe. They say Taiwan also may be trying to portray itself as the champion of Chinese nationalism.

DOC.HEAD: Historic Mill's Last Workers Reunite
DOC.TEXT: For 120 years, the machinery at Cheshire Mills turned out textiles and helped weave the fabric of a community. On Sunday, about 50 former employees gathered to remember that community spirit, and how that fabric was torn when the decline of the textile industry in New England forced Cheshire Mills to close 20 years ago. ``It cast a tremendous pall over the town when it happened,'' said Warren Thayer, who was office manager when the mill closed. ``It was like your security blanket was gone.'' Well-preserved and still housing a descendant business of the Cheshire Mills, the mill buildings and much of the center of the small town - population of fewer than 1,000 - were designated a national historic landmark in 1977. Thayer, who took part in the reunion organized by a historic preservation group, said he joined the company full time in 1956, 50 years after his father went to work at Cheshire Mills. For a time, his family lived in mill housing. ``You lived with this for many years. ... It was a very paternalistic organization,'' he said. ``We always felt that there'd always be Cheshire Mills.'' The Thayers were one of many families who sent multiple generations to work at the mill or at Harris Mill next door. Even Cheshire Mills' president at its closing, John Colony Jr., was a descendant of Josiah Colony, who founded the mill about 1850. Colony said it was hard to shut the mill that was practically the sole source of employment in Harrisville. ``It was a working plant and it was the spine of the town,'' Colony said. ``A lot of people around here working in the mill were fifth, sixth generation. We felt we had a unique responsibility to them.'' But the U.S. textile industry suffered in the face of cheap foreign labor after World War II, much as the British textile industry suffered from American competition that peaked during the Civil War, said Colony's son, John ``Chick'' Colony III. ``We did it to the British and the Japanese did it to us,'' he said. The closing came as a shock to the 30 to 50 employees still working at the mill that once had employed about 300. Colony said he called shop overseers into his office one by one in early October 1970 and sent them out to tell the workers the company would shut down in two weeks. The employees retired, moved away or went to work elsewhere in the area. A few found work at Harrisville Designs, founded by the Colonys the year after Cheshire Mills closed. It continues to carry on mill work in a small way. Harrisville Designs, which employs about 25 and is housed in some of the old Cheshire Mills and Harris Mill buildings, makes looms and yarn for home weavers. The yarn is made on some of the same machines that spun thread for Cheshire Mills fabrics. ``Every year (for nearly 150 years), woolen yarn has been spun in this town,'' Chick Colony said. ``It's a tradition.''

DOC.HEAD: Mystery Continues Two Months After Slayings
DOC.TEXT: Police are questioning and taking thumbprints from people passing through neighborhoods where five college students were slain two months ago. The American Civil Liberties Union said it may challenge the practice in court. ``We're stopping people in the area if there are any questions why they're there and (taking thumprints) if they arouse suspicion. This is not being done in an accusatory way,'' state Highway Patrol spokesman Maj. Ernie Leggett said. Robyn Blumner, executive director of the ACLU of Florida, said the group wants to talk to people who have been stopped and may challenge the patrols. They violate constitutional protections against unlawful searches and seizures, she said. Leggett said in Friday's The Gainesville Sun that officers question and take prints from people on foot, bicycles, mopeds or motorcycles. The newspaper earlier reported that investigators believed the killer rode a bicycle to at least one of the crime scenes. Leggett said he did not know when the patrols began and refused to say whether they had provided any clues. ``It doesn't sound as though they can articulate any objective criteria for suspicion,'' Blumner said. ``They have to articulate some reasonable suspicion to even stop someone.'' Two University of Florida freshmen, both women, were found slain Aug. 26 in the apartment they shared near campus. A few hours later, a student at Sante Fe Community College was found decapitated in her apartment. The next day, two more university students were found slain. Investigators have followed up some 5,000 leads but made no arrests. A $941,639 federal grant paying for the investigation is about to run out, leaving authorities scrambling for money, said Sgt. Dick Gerard. Although students remain apprehensive, most have returned to classes. University Professor Anne Jones had planned to begin the semester teaching ``Paris Trout,'' a novel about a string of murders in a small Georgia town. She postponed the assignment, figuring the book hit too close to home. Last week, ``Paris Trout'' author Pete Dexter spoke to Jones' students. The book won the 1989 National Book Award. Although the campus seems to have returned to normal, fear lurks below the surface, he said. ``That guy represents a force of nature,'' he said. ``It's like something blowing in off the ocean. It's hard to even hate the guy doing this - it's so foreign, it's so unreasonable, it's so unnegotiable.''

DOC.HEAD: Warsaw Pact Foreign Ministers to Meet Next Month
DOC.TEXT: Warsaw Pact armament experts have agreed on the number of tanks and cannon each member nation may maintain under an agreement with NATO. The state news agency CTK announced Sunday that the pact's foreign ministers would meet Nov. 3 in Budapest to sign the agreement. The 23 NATO and six Warsaw Pact countries are expected to sign a conventional arms treaty in Paris during a summit meeting of the 34-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe that opens Nov. 19. There had been concerns that the Warsaw Pact nations would not be ready to sign the comprehensive East-West agreement, and President Bush has said he will not attend the meeting if the treaty is not ready. While overall quotas for NATO and the Warsaw Pact had been accepted by both sides, there had been disagreement within the pact on how its allotment should be divided among member nations. Agreement Saturday seemed to rest on a compromise between the Soviet Union and the five other pact members, formerly Moscow's subservient allies but now increasingly favoring the alliance's dissolution. About 490 tanks had to be scrapped to be within the Warsaw Pact's agreed total of 20,000. The Soviet Union agreed to cut its force by 150, reducing the number of its tanks to 13,150, while the other nations made corresponding reductions, said Robert Harenciar, Czechoslovakia's deputy foreign minister. Soviet artillery was reduced by 500, he added, without going into further detail on the negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Bush: U.S. Not Looking for War, But It Won't Back Down
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Graf 6-9 NEW to UPDATE with Bush signing stopgap legislation to keep government running through Nov. 5. PICKUP 7th pvs, ``Bush addressed xxx.'' ^By TERENCE HUNT
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Sunday the United States is not looking for war in the Persian Gulf but vowed to a cheering military audience that ``we will not walk away'' from the showdown with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. ``It's clear that the strength of our arms and the strength of our will is up to the challenge that we all face in the Persian Gulf,'' he told thousands of members of the armed forces and dependents at Hickam Air Force Base. He assured the families: ``We want every single American home. No American will be kept in the gulf a single day longer than necessary, but we will not walk away until our mission is done.'' Bush has sent more than 200,000 U.S. forces to the gulf to counter Saddam, whose troops invaded the tiny oil-rich nation of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Bush has ruled out any concessions for Iraq, and said as recently as Saturday ``there's nothing to negotiate'' until Baghdad bows to United Nations resolutions demanding his withdrawal and setting terms for solving the crisis. The speech wrapped up a two-day visit here that blended a GOP campaign appearance with a meeting with 11 Pacific island leaders. Bush also found time for jogging, swimming, a catamaran boating excursion and golf. After his speech, Bush flew to San Francisco, where he signed a stopgap spending measure to keep the government operating through Nov. 5. The president will use the intervening days to review the various appropriations bills Congress has passed for spending in specific categories, Bush spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Bush signed the stopgap measure after arriving for a political stop. He is to attend a private fundraiser Monday for Republican Sen. Pete Wilson's race for governor. He will stop in Oklahoma later Monday to campaign for GOP gubernatorial candidate Bill Price at the Cowboy Hall of Fame. The president, who had spent the weekend in Hawaii, will sign the deficit reduction package sometime after he returns to Washington Monday night. Bush addressed the crowd at Hickam from a tarmac platform in front of the gleaming new Air Force One, a blue and white 747 jumbo jet. The appearance came as the United Nations neared a vote on a resolution holding Iraq liable for war damages and economic losses. Bush said his appearance at Hickam, next to Pearl Harbor, brought back personal memories from World War II when he was stationed in the Pacific. ``No member of that generation can ever forget the clarion call that Pearl Harbor represented,'' the president said. ``Things changed instantly. The country came together. And like you here today, we each knew our duty.'' He said the situation in the Persian Gulf is ``a challenge of perfect clarity ... good and evil, right and wrong.'' Bush said America's determination in the gulf is unwavering. ``America never went looking for a war. But in World War II, the world paid dearly for appeasing an aggressor who could have been stopped,'' the president said. ``Appeasement leads only to further aggression and ultimately to war. And we are not going to make the mistake of appeasement again.'' Referring to the deployment of forces to the gulf, Bush said, ``Make no mistake: the decision for this deployment was not made in Washington. The decision for this deployment was made by the men in Baghdad.'' He ticked off an indictment of four crimes that he said are punishable under international law. ``Saddam Hussein will be held accountable,'' Bush said. ``Iraq has waged a war of aggression, plundered a peaceful neighbor, held innocents hostage and gassed its own people,'' he charged. In his meeting Saturday with the Pacific island leaders, Bush pledged that Johnston Island southwest of Hawaii will not be used as a permanent incinerator for chemical weapons and hazardous waste. Critics have questioned the facility's safety and reliability. Bush said it would be used only to destroy the 300,000-piece munition stockpile already stored there and 100,000 nerve gas artillery shells en route from Germany. With $240 million invested in the Johnston plant, the island leaders appeared resigned to his decision. ``We wish you could tell us that you would break down (the facility) tomorrow,'' said Cook Islands Prime Minister Geoffrey Henry. ``We know of course that cannot be done. That is not sensible.'' They also expressed skepticism about the administration's cautious approach about global warming. Bush said he was committed to a $1 billion annual program to study the issue.

DOC.HEAD: 1989-90 Congress: The Main Accomplishments Came at the End
DOC.TEXT: The 101st Congress was wracked by ethics scandals and ridiculed for a budget process that seemingly wouldn't end.
