But by the time it was over, lawmakers managed to pass legislation that had eluded enactment for many years. ``People ought to take some hope from that process instead of dumping all over it,'' said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash. ``We have persevered on a hard, unpleasant, difficult process up to the very week before election.'' In its final days before adjournment Sunday - during a time when all previous Congresses would have been home campaigning - the 101st Congress made its biggest accomplishments: -A huge tax hike and spending cut package which, combined with spending restraint, promises to reduce the federal deficit nearly $500 billion over the next five years. -A child care package including a new grant program and increased tax credits for low-income families with children. -The first overhaul of the federal clean air law in 13 years, which would require new pollution controls on automobiles, factories and utilities. -The first major revision of the nation's immigration system in 25 years, providing more visas for families and those with special job skills. -Passage of all 13 of the annual spending bills for federal agencies, none of which was completed by the Oct. 1 deadline. In a major reversal from the Reagan years, defense spending will be heading down over the next five years while domestic spending increases. -A five-year farm bill designed to contain costs and address environmental concerns. Congressional leaders held multiple news conferences during the weekend to boast about those accomplishments and others. They acknowledged some legislative failures - no major bills on crime, education, health care or campaign reform. But what really marked the 101st Congress was the ugly political infighting and the ethics scandals. ``I think our Congress leaves Washington with a renewed sense of purpose as it relates to fulfilling our responsibilities to people who questioned our motives and questioned our integrity,'' said Rep. Vic Fazio, D-Calif. It started last year with Senate rejection of President Bush's nomination of John Tower for secretary of defense, because of his reputation as a boozer and womanizer. Then there was the pay raise. In round one, a torrent of public criticism killed a proposed 50 percent boost in congressional salaries. The House became embroiled in a historic ethics scandal that culminated in the resignations of Speaker Jim Wright and Majority Whip Tony Coelho. Both were accused of ethical lapses in their personal finances. After taking over as speaker at midyear, Foley parlayed the demand for tighter ethics rules into a new pay raise plan. Lawmakers would get a big salary boost if they'd agree to give up taking special interest money for making speeches. The House approved it, while the Senate decided to stick with the lobbyists' bucks. House salaries, which were $89,500 last year, will soar to about $125,000 in January, while the Senate will settle for a cost-of-living adjustment. This year, one House member was disciplined and a second forced to resign in sex scandals. One did favors for a homosexual lover; the other was convicted of having sex with a teenage girl and was accused of sexually harassing a congressional employee. In the Senate, a group of lawmakers became known as the Keating Five, all under investigation for their ties to the head of a failed savings and loan institution. Meanwhile, for most of its existence, legislation in this Congress crawled. An attempt at a meaningful bipartisan budget deal last year collapsed into a nasty, partisan fight over President Bush's proposed capital gains tax cut. Until this month, the biggest legislative successes were an increase in the federal minimum wage, ending aid to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua, an oil spill prevention bill, and the Americans With Disabilities Act, giving new rights to people with impairments. Democrats defeated Bush's proposed constitutional amendment to ban flag burning. But the Democratic Congress couldn't overcome the president's veto of legislation guaranteeing workers six weeks of paid leave for childbirth or family medical emergencies. The 101st Congress never overrode any of 16 Bush vetoes. The debate through the spring, summer and into the fall of this year was dominated by the budget. Even with Bush abandoning his no-new-taxes pledge, progress was slow. Finally, at the end of September the White House and congressional leaders signed a budget pact calling for a $500 billion reduction in federal deficits over the next five years. But rank and file lawmakers of both parties rebelled at the 12 cent gasoline tax, deep cuts in Medicare subsidies, and dozens of other new fees or service reductions. On Oct. 5, the day Congress had been scheduled to adjourn, the House killed the deal. A government shutdown and legislative chaos ensued. But from the wreckage, a new package slowly emerged - one less to Bush's liking but still acceptable to him. It had higher taxes on the wealthy, only a nickel in new gas taxes, and a lighter hit on Medicare. The Senate gave it final congressional approval on Saturday. With the budget moving, legislators put other bills into place including the clean air bill, child care, and the long-delayed annual spending bills. They'll be back in January.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Shifting Support Effort to End in Afghanistan Conflict
DOC.TEXT: The administration is adopting a new tactic in Afghanistan, reflecting a determination to end one of its last proxy wars against the Soviet Union. Officials and experts say the United States has shifted support away from the exiled Afghan political leadership in Pakistan to the rebel commanders inside Afghanistan who are fighting the Soviet-armed government. U.S. officials hope the rebel commanders can break the stalemate in the fighting and clear the way to a peace agreement with Moscow and its surrogate government in Kabul. The rebels, armed by the United States and Saudi Arabia, have failed to fulfill predictions they would defeat the Kabul government after it lost the support of the Soviet troops, who invaded Afghanistan in 1979 and went home 20 months ago. But the commanders recently set up a new council, and earlier this month 40 commanders from around Afghanistan met to coordinate an offensive against provincial capitals. ``For the first time since the Soviets withdrew, the mujahedeen (Islamic holy warriors) are pulling together,'' said one U.S. official. Both the United States and the Soviet Union want out of Afghanistan, just as they are trying to extricate themselves from supporting rival factions in the protracted civil wars in Cambodia and Angola. ``The United States has made a decision at the highest levels that we make a deal with the Soviets and get out,'' said Barnett Rubin, an Afghanistan expert at Columbia University. Soviet and U.S. officials say they are near agreement on Afghanistan but they still differ over what role, if any, Soviet-installed President Najib will play in an interim government. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze are scheduled to hold more talks next month. Initially, the United States had high hopes for a seven-faction Afghan Interim Government set up in Pakistan last year to oversee rebel operations against Kabul and prepare for a transition to democratic rule. But the administration was forced to re-evaluate due to continued fighting, divisions among the AIG factions, U.S. disagreements with Pakistan, and growing pressure from Congress to cut aid to the rebels. The administration now is pinning its hopes on the newly organized council of guerrilla commanders to put military pressure on the Kabul government and strengthen the U.S. position at the bargaining table. ``There has definitely been a tilt toward dealing directly with the commanders,'' said Zalmay Khalilzad, a researcher with the Rand Corp. and a frequent adviser to the State Department. ``They came to the conclusion that the real power lies with the commanders who control territory,'' he said. ``They matter more than the political leaders (exiled) in Pakistan.'' The commanders' council represents broad segments of the population inside Afghanistan - unlike the AIG, whose constituency was narrow and generally excluded more secular and liberal elements, U.S. officials say. But the once-solid congressional support for covert aid to the mujahedeen has cracked. Congress this year cut $30 million from last year's $280 million covert aid package. The Soviets, too, have cut their support for the Afghanistan government in response to a severe budget crunch: from $5 billion last year to $2 billion this year, U.S. officials say. The administration, which asked for $300 million for the rebels, argued that now is not the time to let up the pressure on the Soviets. Continued arming of the rebels, it argued, could help the commanders win more territory before winter arrives and enhance the U.S. position at the bargaining table. But many supporters of the mujahedeen in Congress doubt the new strategy will be any more successful than the old one as long as Pakistan's military intelligence services serve as the conduit for the weapons. Lawmakers who closely follow the Afghan conflict have repeatedly accused the intelligence service of favoring radical Moslem factions within the mujahedeen over the more moderate, pro-Western groups. Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, the most radical of the seven AIG leaders, has received most of the arms delivered by the Pakistani intelligence service, congressional sources said. The State Department has been pressing the Pakistanis in recent months to stop playing favorites, the sources said. The urgings have resulted in increased weapons deliveries to moderates, but Hekmatyar still receives a disproportionate amount, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Reporter's Notebook: And Now, Time for a Dip
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, noted for his devotion to the sporting life, did not miss the chance to make his two-night stay in the nation's island paradise into a rolling opportunity for fun. Sandwiched in with the more tedious business of political fund-raising, conferring with Pacific island leaders and giving a foreign affairs speech, Bush managed two morning runs on Waikiki beach and two dips in the ocean, a catamaran cruise out of Honolulu Harbor and 18 holes of golf at Hickam Air Force Base before leaving Sunday for San Francisco. His dawn outings on the beach at the Hilton Hawaiian Village hotel attracted dozens of tourists, who tend to rise early in the balmy climate. On Saturday night, Bush gathered about 30 staff members, political supporters and ambassadors for a twilight cruise on a catamaran owned by his longtime supporter Fred Zeder, head of the Overseas Private Investment Corp. Bush sported a splashy print Hawaiian shirt and told reporters that his attire was ``getting very good reviews.'' He said he had come to the harbor fresh from telephone conversations with congressional leaders in Washington, who had finally toiled to a finish on the budget agreement that he has agreed to sign. The chipper, smiling Bush indicated as the catamaran pulled away from shore that he got the impression the lawmakers weren't having much fun. ``Everyone was very tired - but they're glad'' to be done, he said. The boaters returned after dark, their cruise topped off by an offshore view of the shimmering Waikiki skyline in the background, and Bush headed off for dinner in an elegant restaurant. On Sunday, after his 6:30 a.m. swim in the ocean, Bush changed into his golf togs and headed out to Hickam's palm-tree dotted links by the sea. He invited two of the 11 Pacific Island leaders with whom he met on Saturday - Prime Minister Geoffrey Henry of the Cook Islands and Fiji Prime Minister Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara. Others in the two groups of three were Bush's national security adviser and frequent golfing buddy, Brent Scowcroft, Zeder and the commander of U.S. Pacific operations, Adm. Huntington Hardisty. Rain began to fall about an hour after they teed off, and Bush's new partners learned that it takes more than rain to get him to come in off the course. In any event, the sun returned and they completed the 18 holes. It was unclear whether Henry got the chance to press again his public comments of Saturday, when he said the pool of good will islanders felt toward the United States had begun to dry up since World War II. He also spoke of a ``gulf of misunderstanding and misinformation'' on the issue of global warming, a matter of great concern to the islands because any rise in the ocean caused by fossil fuels warming the Earth's atmosphere would greatly affect their lives. While some scientists predict harmful climate changes and other effects from global warming, the Bush administration notes other scientists say the trend is not firmly proven and that more study is needed before dramatic action is taken.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: The Dangers of Saying `No'
DOC.TEXT: The final budget that emerged from Congress has such a strong Democratic stamp that it will remind Republicans for years to come of the perils of saying ``no.'' The House GOP abandoned President Bush when he asked for its votes three weeks ago for a bipartisan deal. Democrats also rejected their leaders' appeals, as a majority of both parties in the House voted against it. So both Bush and the Democratic leaders who participated in the budget summit were embarrassed. The difference was the House Democrats knew where they could look for votes. ``This was not rocket science,'' said a top Democratic aide. ``The (budget) summitteers knew the defects of the package.'' They reduced the Medicare cuts of $60 billion nearly in half. Ditto the proposed increase in the gasoline tax. They eliminated a proposed tax on home heating oil and a two-week delay in unemployment benefits. In their place were inserted big new levies on the wealthy which fit in perfectly with some well-practiced ``soak-the-rich'' rhetoric. ``We have to change the debate from tax (increases) to who gets taxed and the fairness of it,'' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt. With recession fears high, what the class-conscious debate Democrats had been trying for years suddenly worked. The White House, meantime, was hamstrung. It was too late for a veto strategy. The next best tool for moderating the package, Republican votes, was taken away by deep divisions between those willing to accept some taxes to cut the deficit, and those who wouldn't. ``I see 50 (members) on my side, on the extreme right, who wouldn't vote to tax prostitution,'' said Rep. Robert Michel, R-Ill., the House GOP leader. ``When we're a divided minority party, we've got no strength at all.'' Michel's deputy, House Minority Whip Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., led the opposition to the original, bipartisan plan. For members of a minority party used to saying ``no,'' his was an easy position to accept. But this time it backfired. When the final package was shoved down their throats with even more taxes - skewed in favor of the Democrats' constituency - some lawmakers began referring to the difference as ``the Newt tax.'' ``Without Gingrich, this budget could have been a setback rather than an uplift,'' the Democratic aide said. The final negotiation necessarily moderated the Democratic plan, since in the Senate both Democratic and Republican votes were needed for passage. And there was a lot of vote-buying at the end; for example, dropping a provision that forces public employees in a handful of holdout states to enroll in Medicare. But with the unwitting help of Republican renegades, the Democrats won a shift away from the policies of the Reagan years. Everyone pays, but the focus of the tax increases is on the wealthy. There are Medicare cuts, but not nearly so deep as Bush proposed. Medicaid, the health program for the poor, is expanded. Domestic programs will grow while the Pentagon's share of the pie shrinks. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said Democrats had managed to ``stop a trend that started in the past decade and began to reverse it.'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., heralded ``a new era in dealing with fiscal problems in the country.'' Of course, Republicans who voted against the plan will find plenty in it to attack, including tax boosts for beer and gasoline, Medicare premium hikes, and income tax increases for the wealthy. Out campaigning for Republican candidates, Bush has been attacking the very plan that he will sign into law. Rep. Sander Levin, D-Mich., compared Bush's stance to the old comedy routine of Flip Wilson. ``The devil made me do it! The devil made me do it!'' said Wilson's character Geraldine. All because the Republicans would only say ``no,'' Bush was forced to accept more taxes on the wealthy, fewer cuts in Medicare, a smaller gas tax increase, and numerous other changes from the original package. ``Mr. President, the Democrats made you do it,'' Levin said. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Steven Komarow covers Congress for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Democrat Tries Tying GOP Rival to Bush and Budget Mess
DOC.TEXT: The federal budget mess couldn't have come at a better time for Democrat Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr., who wants to be Ohio's next governor. Celebrezze, the state attorney general, has trailed Republican George Voinovich, the popular former mayor of Cleveland, throughout the campaign. But now Celebrezze is gaining ground as he ties Voinovich to the unpopular Washington establishment and to a Republican Party the Democrats painted as the protector of the rich in the month-long budget battle. ``It gets to what I've been saying that in Washington, for the last 10 years, people have been creating a very wealthy class in this country, and then the rest of us,'' Celebrezze says. Voinovich rejects the idea that the president's problems are rubbing off on him. He says the public is blaming Democrats and Republicans alike for the disarray in Washington. ``George Bush is not hurting me one bit,'' Voinovich said. ``The general public ... thinks that they're all not being very responsible right now.'' Independent polls have showed Voinovich holding a double-digit lead through most of the race. But Celebrezze last week said his internal polls showed him in the lead. A GOP poll put Celebrezze within 4 percentage points. A Gallup poll released Sunday showed Voinovich was favored by 47 percent of those surveyed and Celebrezze by 39 percent, with 14 percent undecided. The survey, sponsored by The Blade of Toledo and TV stations WTOL in Toledo and WLIO in Lima, had a margin of error of 4 percentage points. Pollsters said interviews with respondents to the Gallup poll suggested that Celebrezze has gained in popularity as public resentment toward the Bush administration has grown. But Voinovich spokesman Curt Steiner said GOP polls offer no evidence that the Democratic attack has hurt Voinovich. ``We are still getting half of the blue collar vote,'' he said. His campaign strategy has been to tie Celebrezze to alleged corruption and mismanagement during the eight-year tenure of Democratic Gov. Richard Celeste, who was barred from seeking re-election. ``The Celeste-Celebrezze administration is the most corrupt, scandal-ridden, unethical in our memory,'' Voinovich said at a recent debate. At one debate, Voinovich told Celebrezze there was ``a right way and a wrong way'' to manage state government. ``Tony, I want to say to you, you and Dick Celeste have done it wrong for the last eight years,'' he said. Celebrezze's new populist theme includes attacks on a string of fancy Voinovich fund-raisers featuring Bush and other GOP luminaries. Taking a swipe at one $25,000-per-couple Bush fund-raiser, Celebrezze asked a crowd at a union rally: ``How many people in this room make over $200,000 a year? How many people in this room can afford to write a check for $25,000 to spend 20 minutes with George Bush?'' Voinovich, 54, has proved himself adept at capturing Democratic votes during 10 years as mayor of Cleveland in heavily Democratic Cuyahoga County. He is credited with helping to pull Cleveland out of a financial morass and revitalize its downtown. Abortion has been the single biggest point of difference between the two candidates. Celebrezze last December abandoned his long-held opposition to abortion and said women should have the right to choose. Voinovich opposes abortion except in cases of rape, incest or a threat to the life of the mother. He has criticized Celebrezze for flip-flopping. ``Isn't it unbelievable what some politicians will do to get voters?'' one Voinovich ad asks. Voinovich last week was mentioned as a possible successor to Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole, who is resigning. Democrats seized on the reports as a chance to suggest Voinovich's campaign could be in trouble. ``We thought it was very nice for President Bush to offer our opponent a consolation prize two weeks before the election,'' said Celebrezze spokeswoman Melinda Swan. Voinovich said his campaign knew nothing about the search for possible successors to Mrs. Dole. His campaign said Sunday that Voinovich had picked up additional newspaper endorsements, giving Voinovich the support of all the state's largest newspapers and many smaller dailies and weeklies. The Ohio race is one of 14 gubernatorial contests around the country that are too close to call. The others are in California, Texas, Florida, Alabama, Massachusetts, Nebraska, Kansas, Maine, Illinois, Vermont, Alaska, Oregon and Oklahoma.

DOC.HEAD: Private Banks Sending USDA Bill For Guaranteed Loans
DOC.TEXT: Private banks have begun asking the Agriculture Department to make good on $2 billion worth of credit guarantees for the sale of wheat, rice and other commodities to Iraq. Not all of the $2 billion is coming due at once, however. The loans are spread out, some of them running through 1995 or later. The guarantees mostly involve two ``export credit'' programs called GSM-102 and GSM-103 that are operated by USDA to boost sales of farm products to selected overseas buyers. Unlike concessional or long-term programs such as Food for Peace, these are for shorter periods involving commercial loans underwritten by private banks. The GSM-102 program provides credit and repayment over six months to three years. A wide variety of U.S. farm products are exported to dozens of foreign countries with these arrangements. Under GSM-103, an intermediate program, loans can run from three to 10 years and focus on products with longer economic lifetimes, such as breeding livestock. The programs are backed up by the department's Commodity Credit Corp. and are administered by the Foreign Agricultural Service. The CCC also is the financing agency for all federal commodity support programs. No money is lent directly by the department. Once a country is approved for the guarantee, private lenders and exporters work out a plan with the foreign buyer, subject to USDA approval. Larry McElvain, director of CCC operations for the Foreign Agricultural Service, said claims ``are coming in now every day'' from lenders who want their payments for grain sold to Iraq. No estimate of the number of credit guarantee claims or amounts was readily available. ``What you want to understand about the claims is that we don't just pay out the $2 billion'' all at once, he said. ``That is because (lenders) can't file a claim until it comes due.'' Iraq had been buying U.S. farm commodities with credit guarantees since 1983 and had ``an excellent'' record of repayment, McElvain said. ``There has never been a claim filed or paid on Iraq until this situation here,'' he said. ``This situation'' began Aug. 2 when Iraq invaded Kuwait. As a result, President Bush severed all trade with Baghdad, including further credit sales of farm commodities. The annual credit line under the guarantee program was at a peak of slightly more than $1 billion in fiscal 1989. For 1990, the year that ended Sept. 30, Iraq had been cleared for $500 million, with another $500 million available, subject to further review. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Moderately strong demand for high-protein meal and vegetable oil is helping bolster soybean prices this season, according to Agriculture Department analysts. A major factor, however, is the size of the 1990 soybean harvest, currently estimated at 1.82 billion bushels, a slight decline from 1989 output. ``Overall, yields (bushels per acre) are expected to be near average and about the same as last year's,'' the department's Economic Research Service said in a recent outlook report. ``Accounting for the drop in production is a reduction in acreage planted in 1990 - more than three million under the 1989 level.'' Soybean use in the 1990-91 marketing year that began Sept. 1 is expected to be up slightly from last season. The total crush by processors to make meal and oil is estimated at 1.18 billion bushels, up 3 percent, the report said. Exports of beans are expected to drop slightly this season to 615 million bushels. The domestic use of soybean meal in 1990-91 is expected to rise further from last season's record level. ``A profitable livestock production outlook aided by moderate grain prices should boost meal use,'' the report said. ``In the export market, expected soybean meal sales to the Soviet Union and Latin America account for a nearly 10 percent surge in exports over last year to 5.5 million tons.'' The domestic use of soybean oil is forecast to match last year's record, although oil exports are expected to trail 1989-90, the report said. Economists projected the farm price of soybeans in 1990-91 at an average of $5.70 to $7 per bushel, up $5.70 last marketing year. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The nation's hens produced an estimated 5.53 billion eggs in September, according to a monthly report by the Agriculture Department. An average of 268 million layers were at work during the month, a fractional increase from September 1989. Those birds averaged 2,062 eggs per 100 layers, compared with 2,037 a year earlier, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Klan Rallies; 43 Counter-Demonstrators Arrested
LaserPhotos WX6-7
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of police officers provided security as a Ku Klux Klan march and rally drew about 30 robed and hooded members to the nation's capital. Forty-three counter-demonstrators were arrested and 14 people were injured. The rally at the Capitol on Sunday was the second in as many months. More than 5,000 officers from three police departments prevented a few thousand counter-demonstrators from coming face-to-face with the Klansmen. Six protesters were treated at a local hospital for minor injuries, according to local police. Eight police officers were hurt, most suffering minor injuries in confrontations with the counter-demonstrators, said city police spokesman Sgt. Joe Gentile. A female officer suffered a serious neck injury when she was struck by a rock, according to Ed Wilson, another police spokesman. Gentile said the Metropolitan Police arrested 40 demonstrators. Three others were held by the U.S. Capitol Police on charges of disorderly conduct, demonstrating after revocation of a permit and disobeying the orders of a police officer, said spokesman Dan Nichols. ``We knew this was going to happen,'' District Police Chief Isaac Fulwood Jr. said at a news conference afterward. Referring to a federal judge who rejected a city bid to restrict the march to a shorter path, he added, ``We thought that the judge erred. I thought he used poor judgment.'' Several officers struck counter-demonstrators with clubs, but Fulwood said he did not believe they used excessive force. None of the Klan members was hurt. ``K-K-K, we're here to stay,'' shouted the Klansmen as they marched the 11-block route from the Washington Monument to the Capitol. Even before the march began, police dressed in riot gear along Constitution Avenue were pelted with bottles, cans and sticks by counter-demonstrators. The counter-demonstrators chanted slogans including ``Hey, get down, we're going to run the Klan out of town.'' At the Capitol, a Klan leader exhorted his followers to remove from office all senators and representatives who voted to override President Bush's veto of the Civil Rights Act of 1990. ``They tried to override the veto, but thank God it was kept out of law,'' an unidentified Klansman said during the 30-minute rally. ``Vote the hypocrites out,'' he added. Virgil Griffin of Shelby, N.C., leader of the Christian Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, said he was pleased with his group's success. ``We've done good,'' Griffin said. He criticized police for not arresting counter-demonstrators who confronted police along the march route. ``They should have arrested the people making threats against the Klan,'' he said. ``They would have arrested me if I made threats against the Communist Party.'' The Capitol Police deployed ``just about every uniformed officer'' in its ranks, about 800, to the four-block perimeter surrounding the rally site, said Nichols. Officials said all 4,750 city police officers were dispatched Sunday at an estimated cost of $800,000. They were assisted by about 300 U.S. Park Police and some National Guardsmen who directed traffic around areas blocked by police. On Labor Day weekend, D.C. police escorted 44 Klan members to the Capitol grounds where they held a rally. Earlier this week, police said they couldn't guarantee the safety of the marchers if they walked to the Capitol from the Washington Monument. City officials went to court to try to restrict the marchers to a path along the perimeter of the Mall around the Washington Monument. But after the American Civil Liberties Union challenged the city on constitutional grounds, U.S. District Judge Louis Oberdorfer ordered the march to proceed along Constitution. The city won a temporary reversal of that order Saturday when a three-judge appellate panel sent the matter back to Oberdorfer, but he reaffirmed his order.

DOC.HEAD: Crimes Motivated by Prejudice Likely to Increase as Economy Declines
DOC.TEXT: Crimes motivated by racial, religious and cultural prejudice are increasing and likely will escalate faster if the nation's economy continues to deteriorate, experts say. ``As economic conditions decline, the civility of society declines also,'' Jeffrey Ross, director of campus affairs for the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, told a conference of the Washington Journalism Center. ``At the very least things will get worse before they get better,'' he said. Ross said the league received reports of anti-Semitic incidents on six college and university campuses in 1984 and the figure increased to 51 in 1989. ``Things seem to be heating up,'' he said. Other experts at the conference agreed that incidents of bigotry are increasing and are likely to be stimulated by a declining economy. Some attribute it to the pressure of competition for jobs among blacks, whites and other racial or religious groups. ``The increase in anti-Semitism is clearly related to an increase in bigotry in general on campus,'' Ross said. ``You also have increased numbers of assaults upon blacks, upon Hispanics, upon Asians, upon gays and lesbians.'' He said most of the anti-Semitic crimes were directed against property, whereas the assaults on gays and lesbians were against people. Adele D. Terrell, acting executive director of the Baltimore-based National Institute Against Prejudice and Violence, said, ``We don't know how much of it goes on. We just know there is a lot of it. We know there appears to be an increase.'' ``We are in very tight economic times,'' Ms. Terrell said. ``We know that the blue collar jobs just aren't there. Whenever we have tight economic times, we have scapegoating and blaming. We know that we've got lots and lots of immigrants coming into this country, and historically each and every wave of immigrants that has ever come into the United States has been greeted by violence. ``There is lots and lots of violence motivated by prejudice, lots and lots of harassment motivated by prejudice, and my feeling is that given our demographic and economic circumstances it cannot help but increase,'' she said. ``Most of these incidents are perpetrated by individuals or small informal groups of individuals,'' she said. ``The majority of the acts are not, in our opinion, committed by organized hate groups.'' Steven Salmony, a psychologist from Chapel Hill, N.C., who has studied the Ku Klux Klan and similar groups, said their activity may also be bolstered in economic hard times. ``I am concerned that the financial uncertainty and the economic insecurity might cause some especially vulnerable people to turn to groups like the Klan for support, for protection, for security,'' he said. ``This is a distinct possibility.'' Jack McDevitt, associate director of the Center for Applied Social Research at Northeastern University in Boston, said, ``There are hundreds of thousands of people who feel some resentment, and when to this resentment we add in the economic difficulties we are going through, it can lead to a variety of intolerant acts. People really feel threatened, and they are looking for a way to do something about it.'' He said raciall motivated incidents may increase in Boston this year after several years of declining or remaining steady, and ``I fear it is the beginning of a trend.'' ``It is poor whites against poor blacks, and that is where the friction is coming from,'' he said. Lisa Navarette, public information director of the Hispanic rights group National Council of La Raza, said, ``There is a feeling among blacks that immigrants take jobs away from blacks and that this lowers wages. This has fortified the anti-Hispanic sentiment in the black community.'' She said La Raza is worried that this will intensify ``as the economy worsens and if we do go into a recession.'' ``There is a real correlation between downturns in the economy and anti-immigrant feeling,'' Ms. Navarette said.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Approves New Child Care Aid, Immigration Law Revision
DOC.TEXT: More than 750,000 children will be helped in the first year of a new system of federal grants and higher tax credits for child care, say sponsors of the program approved as Congress adjourned for the year. The child care benefits were part of a massive budget agreement completed before lawmakers left Washington for the campaign trail early Sunday. Also completed in the session's waning hours were a major immigration law rewrite, a foreign aid bill, watered-down crime legislation and a ban on offshore oil drilling. The child care bill marked the first time since World War II that the federal government has supported child care for working parents outside of welfare and employment programs, said Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., one of its authors. It also will require states to establish health, safety, registration and quality requirements. Church-run day care centers will be eligible for the federal subsidies, a recognition that churches play an important role in child care in many areas. In other major legislation, Congress approved a substantial boost in the number of immigrants who will be allowed into the United States each year. The bill, the first major rewrite of immigration law in a quarter-century, would boost the current limit of 490,000 a year on legal immigrants to 645,000 in each fiscal year through 1994, and 675,000 thereafter. The measure keeps reuniting families as its primary test, but also would open the door to foreigners with special skills, those who are wealthy and even some shunned for years for political or medical reasons. President Bush on Sunday night signed a stopgap spending measure to keep the government operating through Nov. 5. He will use the intervening days to review specific bills approved by Congress, Bush spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Bush signed the stopgap measure after arriving for a political stop in San Francisco. The president, who had spent the weekend in Hawaii, will sign the deficit reduction package sometime after he returns to Washington Monday night. As they ran for the exits, lawmakers also: -Slashed military aid to El Salvador, hoping to pressure the Salvadoran government and leftist FMLN rebels to negotiate an end to their 10-year war. President Bush said he will sign the $15.5 billion foreign aid bill that includes the restrictions, apparently because it also includes $6.7 billion in debt forgiveness for Egypt as a reward for its leadership in the Persian Gulf crisis. -Voted 313-1 for a stripped-down anti-crime bill, leaving out contentious issues like the death penalty and a ban on assault weapons. Left in were provisions toughening penalties for certain white-collar crimes, including possible life terms for certain savings and loan fraud cases. The bill also for the first time makes possession of child pornography a federal offense. -Banned offshore oil drilling along coastlines from Alaska to New England for another year. The moratorium on offshore oil leases along thousands of miles of coast was in the 1991 spending bill for the Interior Department. -Endorsed a mildly worded admonition against obscene art. The provision governing the National Endowment for the Arts ended efforts to take more stringent action, including banning federal support for works that denigrate religious symbols or beliefs. -Approved a new departure fee of up to $3 for airline passengers, which could add as much as $12 to a round-trip ticket that includes connecting stops. The provision also would require air carriers to retire their noisiest jetliners by the end of the decade.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0436, ADDS Bjt designator.
Republican Candidates Distancing Selves From Bush, Budget Deal
DOC.TEXT: With voters angry and their party plummeting in the polls, Republicans who face congressional elections a week from now are running hard - away from their president. ``I don't like to go against what the president is saying,'' said Rep. Tom Tauke, a Republican who is running for the Senate in Iowa. ``But my judgment is that, in this case, the president has a different job than I have.'' GOP candidates who share Tauke's task - getting elected - are trying to put as much daylight as possible between themselves and the Republican occupant of the White House. The focal point for conflict is the $496 billion budget package Congress approved this weekend before adjourning to the campaign trail. The five-year deficit reduction bill, which President Bush has said he will sign, includes $137 billion in new taxes and the rest in spending cuts and reduced interest payments on the debt. But that mix isn't sitting well at home, Tauke said in an appearance Sunday on CBS's ``Face the Nation.'' Iowans ``certainly aren't interested in sending a whole lot more money to Washington,'' he said. In Nebraska, GOP Senate candidate Hal Daub wasted no time in attacking the package. ``This new budget will give Nebraskans an idea of how a small country feels being overrun by a larger power,'' he said. And Rep. Claudine Schneider, a Republican running for the Senate in Rhode Island, was asked how she felt about Bush's inability to make another trip to her state to campaign for her before Nov. 6. ``That's fine,'' she said. Schneider said voters ``are going to vote for me, not for the president, in this next race. And so they do see the distance between the two of us.'' Bush's budget director, Richard Darman, admitted the deficit reduction package approved by Congress on Saturday was not popular but said it was needed nonetheless. ``It's regrettable that it's come in the middle of an election,'' Darman said. ``But the president is doing the right thing.'' Darman and White House Chief of Staff John Sununu turned to a tried-and-true line of attack: blaming Democrats for tax hikes in the new budget and crediting Republicans for the spending cuts. Sununu called the tax increase ``ransom'' that Bush had to pay to Democrats to get the spending cuts he wanted, conceding that it had temporarily hurt the president's popularity. ``He cashed in some of his political capital for the benefit of the country,'' he said on ABC's ``This Week with David Brinkley.'' But making that argument is complicated by Bush's acceptance of both aspects of the five-year, $496 billion budget deal reached just before the 101st Congress left town for the campaign trail. Democrats moved quickly to tie the knot linking Bush to the deal even tighter. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., noted in the waning moments of the congressional session that Bush has ``seemed ambivalent and then angry'' about the budget package. ``The public should not be confused by the president: He was a central player when this budget was written, and it would never have gone forward without his approval of every item in it,'' Gephardt said. The comment was a pointed reminder that Bush had abandoned his no-new-taxes pledge last summer. And Democratic National Committee Chairman Ron Brown, also appearing on ABC, pounded home his party's fairness theme. Democrats shaped the tax package to put more of the burden on the wealthy, ``the only ones who really made out'' during the 1980s, he said. ``Because Democrats have been in the Congress fighting, the middle class ended up better off'' with the new budget, Brown contended. Vice President Dan Quayle, who has campaigned widely for Republicans in recent weeks, said he senses Americans ``are fed up to here'' with government and incumbents, and predicted that will work for the GOP on Election Day. ``I think you're going to see a major sea change in this election because people have had it,'' Quayle said on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press.'' ``The Democratic Congress has a lot of explaining to do.'' But the difficulty came when Quayle sought to defend Bush as a successful president by citing a list of accomplishments, all of which Congress either was closely involved in or approved of: deficit reduction, a rewrite of the Clean Air Act, Persian Gulf policy, democracy in Nicaragua.

DOC.HEAD: Mine Workers Hope to Work on Political Problems from Inside
DOC.TEXT: United Mine Workers members, tired of working from the outside, are trying to get inside the legislatures of West Virginia, Alabama and Illinois. The UMW traditionally has supported candidates through its Coal Miners Political Action Committee and has been a lobbying force in some coal states. But this year brings a new strategy for dealing with politics from the inside. ``I know the ins and outs of the state legislative body,'' said Gene Claypole, a Mine Workers district president and a candidate for the West Virginia Senate. ``It seems that we have quite a few attorneys that are elected to those positions and quite a few businessmen elected to those positions. And I saw labor on the outside,'' he said. ``We need to have somebody from the working class to present the views of the workers. I don't know anybody who would represent labor any better than somebody in labor,'' Claypole said. Two other Mine Workers members are running for the West Virginia House of Delegates and two more are running for re-election to the state House. Two UMW members also are running for the state House in Alabama and one is running for the Illinois House. All the UMW candidates are Democrats. The campaigns follow last year's surprising victory by District 28 President Jackie Stump in Virginia, who won a last-minute write-in campaign as an independent for the state's House of Delegates. He defeated longtime Rep. Donald McGlothlin Sr., the father of a circuit judge who had fined the UMW heavily for activities during the Pittston coal strike. At last month's UMW convention in Florida, union leaders urged members to become involved in state politics, pointing to the success of Canada's labor-affiliated New Democratic Party, which has sent several union members to Parliament. The UMW is hoping for the same success in this country to enact a national health care plan and a law prohibiting companies from hiring permanent replacement workers during a strike. The new political goal was ratified in a report adopted by UMW delegates at Miami Beach. ``The delegates said that basically if there isn't a candidate in either party willing to stand up for the working men and women of this country, they will seek through all appropriate channels candidates outside of those parties who are willing to stand up for those working men and women and their rights,'' said union spokeswoman Kirsty Smith. UMW members also are becoming more actively involved in local races, running for county and city posts, Smith said. ``The union's looking at political involvement at all levels and they're looking for politicians who are going to live up to their campaign promises to help working men and women,'' Smith said.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Congress Wrapup, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are the highlights of action Congress took over the weekend before it adjourned:
DOC.HEAD: BUDGET-TAXES
DOC.TEXT: Congress gave final passage, and sent to the White House, a package of tax increases and spending cuts aimed at lowering the federal deficit over the next five years. It includes increased income taxes on upper middle-income and rich people, higher levies on gasoline, alcohol and cigarettes and steeper costs for Medicare recipients.
DOC.HEAD: CLEAN AIR
DOC.TEXT: The Clean Air Act, a historic bill aimed at attacking airborne toxic pollutants, was passed by the Senate and sent to President Bush for his signature. It was the most significant environmental bill enacted in Congress since 1970 when the act was passed.
DOC.HEAD: CHILD CARE
DOC.TEXT: New federal programs were established for child care and increased tax credis will be available for this need under legislation that got final congressional clearance. Sponsors said the measure would provide assistance to 750,000 children in the first year.
DOC.HEAD: AIRPORT NOISE
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Aviation Administration will work to phase out the noisiest aircraft at the nation's busiest airports under a provision of the deficit-reduction package. It also will permit airports to levy passenger facility service fees to raise money for easing congestion.
DOC.HEAD: IMMIGRATION
DOC.TEXT: The House sent to President Bush a hallmark revision of immigration law, keeping family reunification as its cornerstone but opening America's door to individuals of wealth, special skills and even those long shunned for political or medical reasons. The vote was 264-118.
DOC.HEAD: OFFSHORE OIL
DOC.TEXT: Congress agreed to renew for another year a ban on offshore oil drilling along thousands of miles of U.S. coastline in areas including Alaska and New England. The moratorium on the sale of offshore oil leases was contained in the Interior Department's fiscal 1991 appropriations bill approved by the House and Senate.
DOC.HEAD: FOREIGN AID
DOC.TEXT: The House completed congressional action on a $15.5 billion foreign aid bill, including language forgiving $6.7 billion in Egyptian military debt and tying future El Salvador aid to peacemaking efforts in that country. The measure passed on a 188-162 vote.
DOC.HEAD: ARTS-OBSCENITY
DOC.TEXT: Congress passed legislation accepting a mildly worded admonition against obscene art funded by the National Endowment for the Arts. It dropped provisions that would have banned federal support for any works that denigrate religious objects or beliefs.

DOC.HEAD: Five Candidates Certified to Run for Lukens' Seat
DOC.TEXT: Five candidates are certified to run in a special election to fill the last few weeks of Ohio Republican Donald Lukens' term in the U.S. House. The Butler County Board of Elections on Sunday certified the petitions of four Republicans and one Democrat who filed for the special primary vote on Nov. 6. A special general election for the remainder of Lukens' term is scheduled for Nov. 21. Lukens resigned last week to avoid an investigation of a new allegation of sexual misconduct. He was convicted last year of contributing to the unruliness of a minor who said she had sex with him. Lukens lost his re-election bid last May, so he would have been leaving Congress in January even if he had not resigned. Gov. Richard Celeste ordered a special election last week to fill the rest of this term. The candidates running for the unexpired term include Republican John Boehner and Democrat Greg Jolivette, who also are running for the term that begins in January. Celeste's order for a special election was required under state law, even though Congress is not expected to meet in November or December. Officials in Washington have said that Lukens' interim successor will be paid, but likely will not be sworn into office.
DOC.HEAD: Election Could Create Mother-Son Team in Missouri Senate
DOC.TEXT: Missouri Sen. Pat Danner remembers taking her first legislative oath in 1983 with a politician's pride and a mother's misery. She was missing the simultaneous swearing-in of her son, Steve, as a freshman Missouri representative. Mrs. Danner hopes to stand side by side with her son in January when state senators are sworn in for the next term. ``At work, we'll be senators, with senatorial courtesy,'' Mrs. Danner says. ``After work, we'll be mother and son.'' The younger Danner first must turn back a hard-fought re-election bid by Republican Sen. David Doctorian. The incumbent says his polls show him leading Danner. The National Conference of State Legislatures says Steve Danner's election would create the United States' only mother and son combination in a legislative chamber. ``I don't see any problems following in my mother's footsteps,'' says Steve Danner. ``Fathers and sons do it all the time. It shouldn't be anything strange.''
DOC.HEAD: Poll Shows GOP Candidates Favored in NH Governor, Senate Races
DOC.TEXT: Republican candidates for governor and the U.S. Senate in New Hampshire have the edge over their Democratic challengers, according to a poll of likely voters. In the gubernatorial race, GOP Gov. Judd Gregg was favored over Democrat Joe Grandmaison, 61 percent to 28 percent. For the U.S. Senate, 51 percent favored U.S. Rep. Bob Smith, compared to 35 percent for former U.S. Sen. John Durkin, a Democrat. The poll, which had a 4 percentage point margin of error, was published in the Boston Sunday Globe. The survey of 600 likely voters was conducted last week by KRC Communications Research of Newton, Mass. The survey found a closer race between House candidates Bill Zeliff, a Republican, and Democrat Joe Keefe. Thirty-eight percent of those surveyed favored Zeliff and 32 percent backed Keefe, with 29 percent undecided. That margin of error for that race was 6 percentage points. The two candidates are vying for Smith's House seat.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Share Prices Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Nikkei, dollar closing. Picks up 5th pvs, `Dealers said ...'
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was weaker against the yen in Tokyo on Monday, while share prices firmed. The dollar closed at 127.35 yen, down 1.15 yen from Friday's 128.50-yen finish. It opened at 127.45 yen and ranged narrowly between 127.25 yen and 127.65 yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average closed at 25,329.31, up 323.67 points or 1.29 percent from Friday's close of 25,005.64. In bond dealings, the price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds was trading at 84.99 points, up from Friday's close of 84.25. Their yield was 7.700 percent, down from 7.870 percent. Persian Gulf crude oil prices were higher. Dubai Crude oil for December delivery was valued at $29.20-$29.30 a barrel, or about $1 above the level in New York late Friday. Dealers said the dollar's slide was due in part to diplomatic moves seeking a peaceful settlement of the Persian Gulf crisis, including a meeting in Paris between Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and French President Francois Mitterrand, said Minori Takeuchi of Chemical Bank. On the stock market, dealers attributed the rise in share prices to a recovering yen and firmer bond prices that kept the market mood calm, despite some concern about overseas stocks, which were weak Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Accidental Shooting Another Blow to Police Force
LaserPhoto CX2
DOC.TEXT: The accidental shooting death of a young stockbroker by an officer looking for a burglar is one more strike against a police force already struggling with allegations of brutality and racism. Terry D. Barnes, 24, was shot between the eyes in his apartment. Police said an officer investigating a report of a prowler had entered the apartment at 3:30 a.m. and fired after Barnes got out of bed to see what was wrong. It was the seventh shooting death involving Kansas City police officers this year. In the previous three years, five people were shot and killed. ``I just hope that this case will draw the line on where the police can kill an innocent man. Where do you draw the line?'' said roommate Andy Brez, 23, who was sleeping in another bedroom when police entered on Saturday. Barnes was white, as is the officer who shot him; however, other recent incidents of alleged excessive force involved black citizens. Police said they were told the prowler might have run to the floor on which Barnes lived. Two police officers, whose names were not disclosed, noticed the door to his apartment was not tightly shut and entered, authorities said. An officer encountered Barnes, unarmed, in a T-shirt and boxer shorts, standing in his bedroom, police spokesman Sgt. Greg Mills said. Barnes made ``a kind of lunging motion,'' and the officer fired from about 5 to 8 feet, Mills said. Friends of Barnes questioned whether his apartment door was ajar and whether he would have lunged at the officer. ``We are defending the officers being in that apartment,'' Mills said. ``As for the shooting itself, we will make no assessment of the propriety of that until after the investigation.'' The department has suffered a string of complaints about excessive force and racism since the spring. Police Chief Steven Bishop said before the latest slaying that the department's standing has fallen in the community, and a ``behavior modification'' program is being developed for offending officers. ``We're part of the problem out there on the street, and we've got to get back to good, basic police work,'' Bishop said after Barnes' death. In June, several white officers bloodied a Nigerian-born Roman Catholic priest with nightsticks as he lay on the ground. The Rev. Joseph Okoye said officers who stopped him on suspicion of drunken driving mistook his foreign accent for drunken speech. In May, another black clergyman was hit on the head with a shotgun by a white officer while lying on the ground. Police said a youth in the car of the Rev. William Fountaine matched the description of an armed robber. Neither clergyman nor the passenger in Fountaine's car was charged. Both clergymen alleged racism; Bishop suspended some of the officers involved in the May incident. In another case, three undercover officers were suspended for a shooting this spring that left a young black man crippled. The officers and the victim accused each other of starting the fight that led to the shooting. Also this year, four oficers riddled a man brandishing a barbecue fork with 15 bullets, killing him. And an officer killed a man who was spraying him with a fire extinguisher. No officer involved in the two killings was charged. The officer who shot Barnes was a two-year veteran of the force. He was placed on paid leave pending a police investigation and that of a grand jury. ``This is a tragic chain of events that is regrettable for Mr. Barnes' family and for this officer,'' Bishop said. ``The officers were reacting appropriately to a number of circumstances which together led them to that apartment.'' ``Terry was a good man. He would have been a good husband and a good father,'' said Barnes' fiancee, Alison Brady. They had planned to marry in June.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Back on Security-Conscious Cairo's Streets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to CORRECT that red berets carry sidearms, not automatic weapons, purses searched only at some restaurants, and that Cairo population is 12 million, sted 6 as sent. Picks up 7th, `Many Egyptians ...'
DOC.TEXT: The red berets are back. They stand at street corners and patrol outside the hotels and at the Pyramids, sidearms wrapped in white holsters - a reminder that the Persian Gulf crisis could erupt in terror in Cairo at any time. Egypt, often accused of talking a lot but doing little about its problems, seems to be taking security seriously since the country's parliament speaker was assassinated on a downtown street Oct. 12. The red berets are military police. They were last seen on the streets of this city of 12 million in February 1986, after the army suppressed riots by police draftees angered by rumors that their tours of duty had been lengthened. Special police security units are also out in force, wearing black uniforms and combat helmets. Traffic policemen are wearing sidearms again. Purses are searched at the entrances to floating restaurants on the Nile. Many Egyptians began to worry about terrorist attacks early in August, when President Hosni Mubarak committed troops to the Persian Gulf to check Iraq, which had just invaded Kuwait. But there were few visible signs that the threat of attack - from Iraqi, Palestinian or Islamic fundamentalist agents - was being taken seriously. More worrisome was the economy. Egypt faced losses estimated at $4.5 billion in the form of a ruined tourism industry, reduced Suez Canal revenues and lost remittances from an estimated 500,000 Egyptians who had to return home from the gulf. The financial picture has brightened somewhat. Egypt's U.S. and Arab allies are moving to write off $14 billion in debts, aid worth hundreds of millions of dollars is pouring in, and there are good prospects for agreement with the International Monetary Fund to reschedule the remaining foreign debt. But security suddenly took the forefront on Oct. 1, when gunmen ambushed Rifaat el-Mahgoub, killing the speaker, his driver and five security men. So far at least 10 suspects have been arrested on suspicion of involvement in el-Mahgoub's murder. Two other suspects were shot to death in a street gunbattle on Saturday. Police have ordered security checks at hotels in the downtown area, near where el-Mahgoub was assassinated. Security trucks now guard entrances and exits at sporting clubs frequented by diplomats and foreigners. Police details have been reinforced at Cairo American College, an international school in Maadi, at the Sphinx and Giza Pyramids. But traditions of lax security die hard. The opposition newspaper El-Wafd reported last week that its reporter and a photographer talked their way through Cairo International Airport checkpoints and walked up the gangway, and into the cockpit of an empty airliner. Government newspapers the next day reported a new program of television monitors and other security steps.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Refugee Describes Terror, Despair
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Kuwaitis are counting on war to end the terror of life under Iraq's occupying forces, a refugee says. ``It is not only the brutal Iraqi treatment or the doings of the Iraqi death squads that makes us terrified to step out of our homes,'' he said Sunday. ``The very living is horrible desolation.'' The man, a public employee in his mid-30s, arrived in Bahrain after leaving via Saudi Arabia last week. He spoke on condition of anonymity to prevent reprisals against friends left behind. The man, who said he had lost 30 pounds since the invasion, sent his wife and children out a month earlier but stayed on until he could no longer stand it. ``From the very young to the very old, we all hoped for war,'' the Kuwaiti said. ``We don't mind dying, we want the hell ended.'' Iraqis control government offices and schools, and many Kuwaitis refuse to go to work or send their children to school, he said. He said resistance has died down in the city but continued on its fringes. ``Resistance was of two types, and the enthusiastic youth have been destroyed since about a month ago by torture and killing,'' he said. ``Now it is the second type, an underground resistance that goes for ambushes of military posts in the desert.'' Underground fighters are well aware of the risks, he said. Iraqi death squads bring young men they suspect of resistance acts to their family homes, call the family members out ``and then shoot the youth in the head, heart and foot, and leave the dead bodies at their feet.'' He said the number of Iraqi troops had declined in the heart of the city. The number of checkpoints also had decreased and some mines had been removed from facilities. ``But what does it mean? I can't tell,'' he said. ``The Iraqis are very tricky. One Iraqi soldier will tell a Kuwaiti, `Look, I am removing a mine as we are leaving.' Another Iraqi soldier will tell another Kuwaiti, `We will never leave Kuwait.'''

DOC.HEAD: Trial to Determine Who Owns Jack Ruby's Gun
DOC.TEXT: The gun Jack Ruby used to kill Lee Harvey Oswald is at the center of a nearly 24-year-old dispute on the court docket this week. A trial was to begin today in Probate Court to determine distribution of Ruby's assets and consider a petition to remove Jules Mayer as executor of his will. The most valuable asset by far is the .38-caliber Colt Cobra revolver that Ruby, a Dallas nightclub owner, used to kill the assassin of President Kennedy in 1963. Mayer, a lawyer who knew Jack Ruby, and Ruby's brother, Earl Ruby, have been fighting nearly 24 years since Ruby died. This is at least the fifth time Earl Ruby has gone to court in attempts to unseat Mayer. Jack Ruby was convicted of murder in 1964 and sentenced to death in the electric chair. An appeals court overturned the conviction in 1966, but Ruby died in 1967 at age 55 before a new trial could be held. Earl Ruby claims his brother, from his deathbed, told him that Mayer had been instructed to tear up the will in which he had named Mayer executor. Jack Ruby bought the revolver for $62.50 in a Dallas gun shop and used it to shoot Oswald two days after Kennedy was assassinated. Mayer has estimated the gun, which he keeps in a safe deposit box, would bring $125,000 from a collector. Mitch Martin, a board member of the JFK Assassination Information Center, put the amount at no more than $50,000. Other than the gun, that estate includes only the clothing and jewelry Ruby wore at the time he shot Oswald, some personal papers and other clothing. Whatever the value of the gun, Mayer has contended that proceeds from its sale must be used to pay Ruby's debts - among them, $65,000 in expenses he claims he has incurred in handling the estate and fighting Ruby's lawsuits. Earl Ruby, who lives in Boca Raton, Fla., counters that Mayer is trying to make money off the estate. The struggle over the estate isn't the only bizarre aspect of Ruby's legacy. Last year, 22 years after Ruby died, the Internal Revenue Service entered the case, contending that when Ruby died, he owed $17,000 in back taxes. That amount, the IRS said, has now accrued to $86,010 with interest and penalties. Earl Ruby contends the IRS sacrificed any claim by waiting so long.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down In Tokyo, Stocks Firm
DOC.TEXT: The dollar declined against the Japanese yen today, while share prices firmed. The dollar closed at 127.35 yen, down 1.15 yen from Friday's 128.50-yen finish. It opened at 127.45 yen, and stayed in a narrow range between 127.25 yen and 127.65 yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average closed at 25,329.31, up 323.67 points, or 1.29 percent, from Friday's close of 25,005.64. The benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds were trading at 84.94 points, up from Friday's close of 84.25. Their yield was 7.710 percent, down from 7.870 percent. Dealers attributed the dollar's slide partly to diplomatic efforts reported in Paris, Baghdad and elsewhere seeking a peaceful solution of the Persian Gulf crisis. ``The diplomatic move toward resolving the gulf crisis boosted the yen,'' said Minori Takeuchi of Chemical Bank. She was referring to a meeting in Paris between Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and French President Francois Mitterrand, and Soviet envoy Yevgeny Primakov's visit to Baghdad. The yen firms whenever tension in the Middle East seems to ease these days, Ms. Takeuchi said. Trading was cautious as the market waited for the release of U.S. third-quarter gross national product figures on Tuesday and U.S. employment figres on Friday, she added. On the stock market, traders said share prices firmed on the strength of the higher yen and the firmer bond market. Gainers outnumbered losers 678 to 306, with 141 issues unchanged on the first section. Volume on the first section was estimated at 500 million shares, little changed from 498.2 million on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Non-Communist Coalition Wins Georgia's Legislative Elections
With PM-Soviet-Miner, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A non-communist coalition that wants full political independence for Soviet Georgia appears to have won the southern republic's legislative elections, an election official said today. Sunday's was the first true multiparty vote in Soviet history. The Round Table-Free Georgia coalition appeared likely to win 60 percent to 70 percent of the vote, said David Dzhaparidze, a member of the central election commission. The Round Table, led by Zviad Gamsakhurdia, won majorites in all 26 districts in the capital of Tbilisi, Dzhaparidze said. ``This is great,'' said Robert Petriarshvili, a spokesman for the coalition. He said the vote would give Round Table 110 out of the 250 seats in the Supreme Soviet. Dzhaparidze said the Communist Party appeared to be doing well in areas where non-Georgian ethnic groups hold a majority, and it was expected to win 20 percent to 25 percent of the legislative seats. The remainder would be split among smaller parties, he said. Among the 15 Soviet republics, all but Kirgizia have declared some form of sovereignty or independence. The three Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia were the first to make the move, but they are still negotiating with Moscow. Gamsakhurdia, interviewed over the weekend, predicted that Georgia's transition to political independence would take about two years, and that the republic would maintain extensive economic relations with the Soviet Union. It also seems likely that Georgia will rely on the Soviet Union in national security matters, he said. About 35 parties, most grouped by coalition, took part in Sunday's election. Non-communists have won election in several cities and republics elsewhere in the Soviet Union, but Georgia's vote was the first in which formal parties, created under new Soviet laws, were listed on the ballot. Long lines snaked from polling sites in the capital, Tbilisi, as well as the surrounding countryside. About 3 million people were eligible to vote. Official results were not expected until the end of the week, the official Tass news agency reported. Runoffs in close races are set for Nov. 11. Maguli Latariya cast her ballot swathed head to foot in black mourning clothes. Her 16-year-old daughter was one of 19 Georgians killed on April 19, 1989, when Soviet troops broke up a peaceful nationalist protest in Tbilisi. The killings strengthened independence aspirations. Even the ruling Communist Party of Georgia was forced to advocate independence from Moscow as part of its platform. Mrs. Latariya wept as she voted, saying it was ``as if my daughter's voice was telling me what to do.'' She said she voted for the Round Table coalition, a bloc of seven political parties. Under the election law, a party must get at least 4 percent of the republicwide vote to gain representation in the legislature. That provision was designed to encourage coalitions and large parties, and to discourage splintering into small factions. Tass reported that the elections were observed by experts from the United States, France, Belgium, Germany, Sweden, Austria, Spain and Finland. Many voters, interviewed as they left polling stations, said the Communists had gained ground in recent months because they represented stability. ``We would like life to be peaceful again,'' said Nari Chanturia, complaining about the uncertainty and violence that have gripped Georgia in recent months. Some politicians boycotted the election, claiming it was not democratic. One of them, the leader of the National Democratic Party, Gia Chanturia, was shot in the arm Saturday as he left a political meeting. Chanturia and others formed a 200-seat National Congress of Georgia to act as a shadow parliament and push for independence. Two members of the National Democratic Party, Gia Kobakhedze and Irakli Tsereteli, spoke on Georgian television and accused Gamsakhurdia, the Round Table head, of organizing the shooting of Chanturia on orders from Soviet authorities. Gamsakhurdia denied the charges.

DOC.HEAD: Crazy Critters' Conduct Closes Maryland Park
DOC.TEXT: Aggressive squirrels have driven humans from of a playground. In the past two weeks, two squirrels have bitten children at Montgomery County's Wheaton Regional Park. On Thursday, a man bludgeoned a squirrel with a stick because it was annoying him, said park maintenance worker Kathy Lowe. Park police have closed the playground until further notice. Visitors to the playground were greeted Saturday with the yellow tape used at crime scenes, and a sign that read: ``Playground closed due to over aggressive squirrels.'' ``The squirrels are just acting squirrelly now,'' said Lowe. ``They are so busy burying acorns they are aggravated at the people.'' A bumper crop of acorns over the past two years has produced a bumper crop of gray squirrels, who are gathering food with particular fervor, Lowe said. When park patrons offer food, as was the case with the children who were bitten, the animals move in close and don't take no for an answer, Lowe said. The children were not seriously hurt, but park recommended they see a doctor to determine whether they should undergo treatment for rabies.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Hanged During Haunted House Stunt
DOC.TEXT: A 15-year-old staging a gallows scene at a Halloween party accidentally hanged himself when the noose somehow tightened, authorities said. William Anthony Odom of Charlotte, N.C., was pronounced dead Friday night amid fake spider webs and plastic bats decorating an aunt's home. Odom and several of his friends had staged a haunted house in the basement. A week ago, a 17-year-old died while staging a similar Halloween hangman gag along the route of a hayride in Lakewood, N.J. Odom had crouched inside a wooden cupboard, said his grandmother Hattie Carpenter. He was dressed as a pirate, wearing black trousers, a red shirt and a gold earring. Around his neck was a 3-foot length of nylon rope. ``It was a slip-knot-type noose; the more pressure you apply, the tighter it gets,'' Coroner Jim Chapman said. ``Evidently, it was tight enough to cause some problems with his breathing, and he either passed out or panicked.'' Chapman said he's unsure how the rope tightened. Odom could have slipped and lost his balance or was playing with the knot, causing it to tighten, Chapman said. The coroner said it's also possible that the knot gradually tightened and reduced blood to the brain, causing him to faint and then suffocate. ``What was really sad was that the kids thought we were going to be able to revive him, but it was too late. They were scared when we got there, but then they became hysterical,'' Chapman said.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Candidate for Governor Drops Out in Minn.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Jon in lead, ADDS quote from Grunseth's wife.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MP1
DOC.TEXT: Allegations that Jon Grunseth cheated on his wives and swam nude with teen-age girls combined to drive him from the governor's race and plunge the Republican Party into turmoil nine days before the election. Citing ``enormous pressure'' on his family, the political process and the state, the 44-year-old business executive called it quits late Sunday and apologized to supporters and contributors. ``I always haven't been a perfect person. I think I'm a pretty decent guy, but I've made some mistakes and I feel badly about that, too,'' Grunseth said at his home about 20 miles east of Minneapolis. Grunseth was accused of having an affair during both of his marriages and of skinny dipping with teen-age girls in 1981. He denied the nude-swimming allegations and said the affair ended before his second marriage in 1984. Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich is seeking an unprecedented fourth term. He had no immediate comment. Republican state auditor Arne Carlson, who placed second in the Sept. 11 GOP primary, launched a write-in campaign a week ago as pressure mounted on Grunseth to drop out. His name will go on the Nov. 6 ballot if the party fails to name someone else by Friday afternoon. ``There's no question he (Carlson) is in the best position, but right at this moment, I'm not saying I'm supporting Arne Carlson,'' said state GOP Chairman Bob Weinholzer. ``If someone else can show me how they can put a campaign together in one week and win, I'd be receptive to take a look at it.'' Carlson, a moderate who supports abortion rights, is unacceptable to the religious, conservative faction that controls the state party. ``I'm going to spend a lot of time now to make sure we heal the wounds,'' he said. ``I have to reach to all areas of the Republican Party to bring this together so we can put together a winning election.'' Republicans had begun the year with high hopes of unseating Perpich, who had been derided as eccentric and put on the defensive about living too grand a style, with a luxury car and bodyguard. In the most recent independent poll, conducted Oct. 19-21, Carlson was favored over Perpich 51 percent to 41 percent. The statewide Star Tribune-KSTP Minnesota Poll of 601 likely voters had a margin of error of four points. Grunseth's campaign was crippled Oct. 15 after two women made sworn statements alleging Grunseth tried to get them to swim naked with him during a 1981 pool party at his home. The women, who were 13 and 14 at the time, said they refused but that Grunseth, his teen-age daughter and a 16-year-old girl took off their bathing suits. One of the women claimed Grunseth tried to pull down her bathing suit. On Sunday, the Star Tribune of Minneapolis reported that 32-year-old Tamara Taylor of Minnetonka claimed to have had a sexual relationship with Grunseth on and off from 1980 to 1989. Grunseth divorced Katharine Winston in 1983 and married his second wife, Vicki, in 1984. Grunseth acknowledged having a romantic relationship with Taylor but said it ended ``a long time ago - in the early '80s.'' Taylor said she spoke out to prevent Grunseth's ``further deception of the voters ... in regard to his past antics, his character, and what ruthless actions he is willing to take in order to be elected governor.'' Grunseth said Sunday he had been on the verge of quitting the race for two weeks. ``It's wear and tear, it's just simply pure wear and tear,'' he said. ``The whole thing becomes sickening. It's exhaustion, is what it is. Mental, physical, emotional exhaustion. ... At a point there's an end. You just say, `Man, it's more than I can bear.' '' Mrs. Grunseth said she believes her husband's contention that he ended the affair before they married. She said she did not try to dissuade him from dropping out of the race. The accusations, she said, prove ``there's no floor in the decency scale anymore about what people will write or say.''

DOC.HEAD: Historic Hotel Attracting Ghost Watchers
DOC.TEXT: The rich and famous flock to the Hotel del Coronado for its lavish service, beautiful view and world-class reputation. Alan May seeks less earthly delights. He's looking for a ghost. On Halloween, he's got plenty of company. The employees and many guests at the Victorian seaside resort know all about the black-clad ghost that haunts room 3312. Some - including May - claim to have seen it. ``Anytime Halloween comes around, the phones just won't stop ringing off the hook and people come in looking for the ghost,'' said hotel spokeswoman Nancy Weisinger. ``It's almost like this lady is doing her own publicity.'' Steve Miller, the hotel's front desk manager, said many guests who stayed in the room ``felt like there were eyes looking at them all the time.'' Although more than one tale circulates, the most famous involves Kate Morgan, a 24-year-old pregnant woman who checked into the hotel on Thanksgiving Day 1892 under the name of Lottie Bernard, had an abortion and, according to a coroner's report at the time, committed suicide on the steps leading to the beach. May, a 48-year-old defense attorney from San Francisco, has written a book that gives the legend a different twist. He says Morgan was murdered by her estranged husband. May, who has stayed in room 3312 more than a dozen times, has claimed to have encountered the ghost twice. He said she stared at him from a TV set, brushed against his cheek and appears in his dreams. ``I think she just wanted her story told,'' he said. This is his version: Tom Morgan married Kate Farmer in 1885 in Hamburg, Iowa, after winning her from her father in a poker game. The couple traveled throughout the country, using numerous aliases. The marriage was stormy, especially when Kate became pregnant, and they separated often. Wearing a black lace dress and shawl, Kate checked into the Hotel del Coronado in 1892. She induced an abortion and waited in vain for Morgan, who had promised to meet her there. Four days later, she bought a gun and searched for him at other hotels. The next morning, she was found dead. May claims Tom Morgan shot Kate as she slept, destroyed some letters that would have implicated him and dumped the gun and body outside to make it look like suicide.
