DOC.HEAD: Ethnic Minority Attempts to Block Militia From Their Region
DOC.TEXT: Minority Gagauz militants in the Moldavian republic have set up cordons to prevent Soviet troops from entering their region and enforcing state-of-emergency measures, Tass reported today. The Moldavian parliament imposed the state of emergency and Soviet troops were standing by, ready to move in under the command of Gen. Yuri Shatalin if lawmakers issue the order, the official news agency said. A provisional parliamentary committee was monitoring the standoff from Chimishlia, a small town in southern Moldavia bordering on the Gagauz territory, which was declared a state-of-emergency zone on Friday. ``Although there were no clashes between Moldavian and Gagauz volunteers, representatives of Gagauzes set up cordons to prevent the (Soviet troops and republic militiamen) from entering,'' Tass said. The Gagauz are a close-knit group of about 150,000 people, all descendants of Christians who fled to Moldavia from Turkey because of religious persecution about 160 years ago. Worried by rising Moldavian nationalism and angry over a law that made Moldavian the republic's official language, the Gagauz claimed the southern corner of the republic last week and began holding elections for an autonomous government. Brigades of Moldavian volunteers, said by various sources to number between 12,000 and 50,000, streamed into the area to try to stop the independence movement. Gagauz youths in turn formed defensive units, aided by some ethnic Russians, who also oppose Moldavian nationalism. Negotiators for both sides were trying to defuse the crisis. Soviet officials holding negotiations with representatives of the Gagauz provisional committee in the southern city of Komrat called for the withdrawal of militant Gagauz volunteers from the emergency zone, Tass said. ``If this condition is complied with, Moldavian volunteer detachments will be withdrawn from areas adjacent the state-of-emergency zone,'' the news agency said. On Sunday night, the chairman of the executive council of the disputed Komrat region appealed in a television broadcast for peace. ``The inter-ethnic conflict in the republic has reached the point beyond which there will be bloodshed and the deaths of innocent people,'' he said. According to Tass, the two sides have agreed to set up a joint commission for the mutual inspection of the volunteer units in preparation for their withdrawal.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Doctors Not Needed by Gulf Forces, Team Members Say
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese medical team sent to the Persian Gulf amid intense debate over Japan's role there has found its services aren't needed by U.S.-led multinational forces, members said today. Instead, the medical team could be useful in helping refugees in the region, according to a recent assessment given to the government by a 17-member advance team sent to the gulf region in mid-September. ``U.S.-led forces have their own medical services and will treat their own soldiers,'' Dr. Shigemi Teramoto, head of the team, said in an interview. Teramoto said the Japanese team, originally set to be expanded to 100 members, will be stationed 210 miles from the Kuwaiti border and consult with the Saudi Arabian Ministry of Health on how it can serve. Sending a medical corps to assist the multinational forces arrayed against Iraq in the region is part of the government-sponsored U.N. Peace Cooperation bill now being debated in Parliament. The bill, which calls for the deployment of Self-Defense Forces abroad, has encountered widespread opposition because of Japan's constitutional ban on using force overseas. Its passage is in doubt, lawmakers have said. A member of the advance medical team said U.S. and Saudi hospitals were so well staffed and equipped that Japan's contribution ``might just result in confusing the already established medical system of the forces,'' the newspaper Asahi Shimbun reported.

DOC.HEAD: Forecaster: Organic Coffee In, Home Videos Out for 1991
DOC.TEXT: Organic coffee and ``retro-chic'' appliances will be big hits in 1991, but the popularity of New Age religions and baseball doubleheaders will fade, ``The American Forecaster 1991'' predicts. Other anticipated hits are ``success surgery'' for executives, field trips for kids and ``gourmet'' ice. Home videos and the Southwestern interior design style will bomb. Kim Long, 41, of Denver, began compiling the book on what's in and what's out in 1983. It sells about 10,000 copies a year. Organic coffee, grown without pesticides, ``has all the makings of a major food fad,'' Long said. ``People are becoming a lot more literate about what they put into their mouths,'' he said. ``They're willing to spend more money for the details.'' He predicts that the boxy appliances that marked the dawn of the post-World War II era will reappear next year. ``It's the visual appeal, so solid and heavy - the beginning of the atomic era,'' he said. Long says more executives will have cosmetic surgery and workers will eat at their desks so they can be more productive, signs of Americans' intensified interest in their work. The ideal look will be ``relatively small noses, not a prominent chin, but a chinless look is unacceptable, and wrinkles would be out,'' he said. However, 1991 will not be the year for workaholics. ``I think the '90s is going to be a fun decade,'' said Long. ``Most people in the big `baby boom' age group will be in their 40s and 50s. They will have earned a living and raised families. I think that equates to a potential situation where people will look to do fun things, to worry less about what the neighbors think or families think.'' A trend that has hit Japan and is expected in the United States is the popularity of ``gourmet'' ice. The ice, reportedly up to 10,000 years old, is chipped from Alaskan ice floes and valued for its purity. Next year will bring a reduced interest in New Age religions: ``It won't die. But my observation is that it will just be less faddish.'' Long predicts a revival of interest in millenialism as the year 2000 approaches, generating a fascination with ``crackpot religions.'' Interest in home videos, a fad that soared this year with the success of television's ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' will also wane, Long said. The Santa Fe fashion look, including laughing coyotes and cactus cutouts, has been overmarketed and will no longer be hip, the Forecaster says. Long, a newspaper columnist, said he researches trends by reading numerous newspapers and magazines, keeping files on particular topics, and monitors computer data bases.

DOC.HEAD: Dry Weather Prevails Across Country
DOC.TEXT: Dry weather prevailed across much of the United States early today, and temperatures dipped into the low 30s in parts of the Midwest, South and East Coast. Today's forecast called for the first snow of the season in the mountains of New Hampshire and Maine, with up to 6 inches expected. Strong winds are likely from the mid-Atlantic region to the central New England states. Unseasonably cool temperatures are expected in the Southeast. Afternoon showers are likely on the eastern shore of Florida. Record warmth is expected on the western edge of the central Plains, as winds from the Southwest combine with a northern bulge in the jet stream. Mostly sunny weather is likely across the West, although evening rains are forecast for the Pacific Northwest. DOC.HEAD: Norwegian Government Resigns Over Trade Dispute
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with new details, resignation formally submitted, number of seats in Parliament. No pickup. ^By DOUG MELLGREN
DOC.TEXT: The country's year-old coalition government resigned today after the uneasy center-right alliance split over how much Norway should open itself to trade with the European Economic Community. Conservative Prime Minister Jan P. Syse told Parliament that his government could not agree on the country's position in talks between the EEC and the six-nation European Free Trade Association, of which Norway is a member. The talks are to center on the creation of a joint economic region. Syse had worked through the weekend, seeking common ground that would allow his coalition of the Conservative, Center and Christian Democratic parties to remain in power. But the anti-trade bloc Center Party, with strong support from the country's subsidized farmers, rejected the idea of sweeping changings in Norwegian laws that protect domestic industry and resources. During talks on the creation of the joint economic region, the European Community has pressed for changes in the Norwegian laws. The EEC claims the laws discriminate against foreigners. The Center Party, the governing coalition's smallest member, wants continued border controls and some protection of domestic argriculture, fishing grounds and other resources. Syse's government will remain in office until a new government is formed, which could take several days. Norway's parliament was divided into nearly equal blocs of socialist and non-socialist blocs after Sept. 11, 1989 national elections, and news reports have said that the near deadlock has made both sides reluctant to govern. Anders Talleraas, the Conservative's parliamentary leader, said the party has enouraged Syse to form a new single party government because of the small non-socialist majority. ``I am prepared to form a new government,'' Syse said before delivering his government's formal resignation to Crown Prince Harald. Norway's figurehead monarch, King Olav V, is recovering from a stroke. Syse would need backing from all four non-socialist parties. Without it, he will likely ask former Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland to form her third Labor Party government since 1981. Her left-leaning party is the country's largest. In addition to socialist allies, it would need backing from the Center Party to form a government. ``It is still not clear how the new government will be made up,'' Brundtland said in a television interview. She said Labor is ``in a clear observer role, waiting to see what happens.'' When the coalition agreed on a joint platform and toppled Brundtland last year, the sensitive European Economic Community issue was left vague. The pro-EEC Conservatives had said they would not allow discord within the coalition to hamper talks. The conflict may have been aggravated last week when neighboring Sweden strongly hinted that it would seek EEC membership, prompting calls in Norway for both countries to join the community. Anne Enger Lahnstein of the Center Party said the issue was no longer the joint economic region negotiations, but a battle over EEC membership. News reports speculate that a purely Conservative government would probably be short-lived. The next government will be the Norway's sixth since 1980. Leaders have expressed fears the country could suffer frequent government changes, due to the nearly deadlocked Parliament and no provision for calling new elections. Public disenchantment has increased due to tough austerity programs, intended to pull Norway's oil dependent economy out of a four-year slump that has brought record unemployment. Labor controls 81 seats in the 165-seat Parliament, including 63 of its own, 17 from the Socialist Left and one independent. The Conservatives have 37 seats, the Christian Democrats' 14 and the Center's 11. For a majority, the non-socialists would have to depend on the the right-wing Party of Progress, which soared from two to 22 seats in the last national election. The Center Party was reportedly more willing to support a new socialist government than allow the Progressives, which was viewed as too extremist to be invited into the Conservative-led coalition.

DOC.HEAD: Eye of the Storm: Calm at Shrine Claimed By Hindus and Moslems
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with death reported in Lucknow, Hindu fundamentalists say thousands of followers are hiding near disputed site. Pickup 5th graf pvs, ```Communal tension..'
DOC.TEXT: Bored policemen shoo monkeys and glance sleepily at closed-circuit television cameras as they enforce a curfew in this town whose name has become a battle cry in India's latest political and religious crisis. About 100 people have been killed throughout India in the past week in riots caused by Hindu plans to build a temple on a dusty hilltop where a Moslem mosque now stands. The latest death was reported today in Lucknow, capital of Uttar Pradesh state 75 miles west of Ayodhya. Police officials said Hindu crowds surged through a Moslem neighborhood throwing bricks. The religious feud has precipitated a political crisis that has brought Prime Minister V.P. Singh's government to the brink of collapse. But the firestorm raging elsewhere in the country is masked by inactivity and tight security in Ayodhya, where Hindu fundamentalists vow they will get through roadblocks and start building their temple to the god Rama on Tuesday. The fundamentalists said today in a handwritten communique that thousands of followers were hiding near Ayodhya and were ready to start building. ``Communal tension will flare up all over the country, but an Ayodhya resident will not let a drop of blood be spilled because then Rama's name will be sullied,'' said Mudit Sharma, who works for a Hindu charity near the disputed site. ``Moslems of the area are not any diferent from Hindus,'' Sharma said. ``They participate in our festivals. We go to their house during Islamic festivals. All these fights are because of political loafers.'' The fundamentalist cause has been espoused by the Hindu right-wing Bharatiya Janata Party. Its top leaders are among the more about 80,000 people arrested in the last week while trying to march to Ayodhya, 300 miles east of New Delhi. The arrests prompted the party to withdraw its support for Singh's coalition government, leaving him without the parliamentary majority needed to stay in office. Singh, who plans to face Parliament for a vote of confidence on Nov. 7, wants the temple-mosque dispute settled in court. The fundamentalists claim the mosque stands atop the very spot where Lord Rama was born and therefore is a religious matter, not a legal one. Moslems, a minority in officially secular but predominantly Hindu India, fear the displacement of one mosque could jeopardize hundreds of other Islamic sites across the country. The mosque, called the Babri Masjid, was constructed in the 16th century when Mogul armies conquered northern India. Hindu fundamentalists claimed the Moslem conquerors destroyed a Rama temple on the spot where the mosque now stands. The Hindu World Council, backed by the Bharatiya Janata Party, has organized the campaign to build the temple by either moving or demolishing the little mosque. On Friday, the government of Uttar Pradesh state imposed an around-the-clock curfew in Ayodhya to keep temple advocates from reaching the disputed hilltop. Trains to the area were halted and roads blocked by police and paramilitary troops. ``They have made Ayodhya into a cantonment for political gains. Let them arrest us, but thousands of devotees will come to Ayodhya tomorrow,'' said Tara Kant Jha, secretary of the World Hindu Council's local office in Ayodhya. The council and the Bharatiya Janata Party claim the government's tough stand on Ayodhya is only a bid to win Moslem votes. Moslems make up 12 percent of India's 880 million people, of whom 82 percent are Hindu. In Uttar Pradesh state, where the government is allied with Singh, Moslems account for about 30 percent of the 120 million people. Hindu-Moslem clashes occur periodically in other parts of Uttar Pradesh, but no one can remember trouble around Ayodhya or its twin town of Faizabad, three miles down the road. About a quarter of the area's population is Moslem. ``There never has been any communal tension in Faizabad or Ayodhya. And I don't think there will be after Oct. 30,'' the date deemed auspicious by Hindu astrologers to start building the Rama temple, said District Commissioner Madhukar Gupta, the top civil administrator of the area. Most residents agree. They seem unconcerned about the curfew, but business is suffering. Ayodhya is a major Hindu pilgrimage site. There are about 6,000 temples in the town of 45,000 people on the banks of the River Saryu. Most people live on the business generated by tens of thousands of Hindu pilgrims who arrive every year in October for a Hindu festival. About 20,000 security troops deployed around Ayodhya have prevented pilgrims from entering Ayodhya this week, fearing Hindu activists may infiltrate the town. Elaborate security arrangements include closed-circuit television cameras and iron gates every 20 yards on the lane leading to the disputed hilltop.

DOC.HEAD: Two Injured, 300 Arrested In Pre-Halloween Party
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of revelers celebrated Halloween early with a weekend of partying that left two people injured. More than 300 people were arrested, authorities said. Up to 20,000 partiers, some dressed in costumes, brought traffic to a standstill in this normally quiet beach town near the University of California at Santa Barbara campus Saturday night as they walked from one house party to another, Sheriff's Lt. Ken Shemwell said Sunday. Sheriff's deputies arrested 111 people Friday night and about 200 Saturday night, mostly for alcohol violations, he said. Of that total, 69 were booked into the county jail, he said. One young man was seriously injured when he fell 40 feet off a cliff, Shemwell said. Another man suffered head injuries while slam dancing, during which dancers hurl themselves at each other. Shemwell said officers expected another large crowd Wednesday night. ``We expect to have our hands full,'' he said. ``But we've been doing this for years. We'll be ready.'' Last year, more than 30,000 people roamed the streets and there were 600 arrests on Halloween.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Approves Anti-Noise Plan, New Passenger Fees
DOC.TEXT: Airlines would be required to retire their noisiest jetliners by the end of the decade under legislation passed by Congress just before it adjourned for the year. Under another provision of the legislation, airline passengers could pay as much as $12 more for a roundtrip ticket. Both requirements were part of a budget package that was lawmakers' last major act Sunday before leaving Washington. The legislation requires that airlines replace about 2,350 noisy aircraft, or about half of the nation's commercial jetliner fleet, with quieter jetliners by the year 2000. In some cases, planes may be equipped with ``hush kits'' that reduce engine noise to comply with the new requirements. The Transportation Department estimated that as many as 3 million people are subject to significant airport noise levels near the nation's airports. In some cases, the number of people exposed to such noise could drop 80 percent to 90 percent, the department said. Airport officials have long sought the authority to impose passenger fees, saying they need the money for expansion projects and for noise-reduction programs that include soundproofing nearby schools and other buildings. The passenger departure fee of up to $3 at an airport could generate more than $1 billion annually. On a connecting flight, the fees could mean as much as $12 added to the roundtrip cost. The tax comes along with an increase in the ticket tax from 8 percent to 10 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Media, Unleashed, Takes on Cuba
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs lead to CORRECT subject-verb agreement.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet media have shelved their previous unswerving support for Cuba and are becoming downright irreverent in discussing the island's policies, its Marxist system and even Fidel Castro himself. Although relations remain cordial at the official level, newly liberated Soviet reporters are feeling no compunction about saying what they think. The latest and perhaps most notorious example touched on an area that has been sacrosanct for 30 years - Castro's personal life. Komsomolskaya Pravda, a new wave, glasnost-era daily, said recently that Castro has 32 houses, a personal security contingent of 9,700 and five children by his ``present wife.'' So far as the Cuban public knows, there has been no change in Castro's marital status since he was divorced 35 years ago. Such subjects are taboo in Cuba, and during the heyday of Soviet-Cuban relations, the Moscow press was respectful of Cuban sensitivities on the subject. But no longer. Other examples of Soviet media deviationism: -Disputing Cuban claims of a 2-million-ton shortfall this year in Soviet oil deliveries to Cuba, Komsomoskaya Pravda said in September the deficit was only 580,000 tons. The Cuban daily Granma called the allegation ``lies.'' Cuba has cited the fuel deficit in justifying severe austerity measures imposed in recent months. -A letter published in the same Soviet publication also criticized the treatment given 250 Soviet children who were sent to Cuba after becoming ill from the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear accident. No special medical treatment was offered to the children, some of whom had to be hospitalized from the tropical heat. The rest ``languished'' in their ``army-style huts,'' it said. -Izvestia, implying criticism of both Moscow and Havana, has complained that Soviet aid often is used inefficiently. ``The large volume of unfinished construction projects, the enormous heap of uninstalled equipment (which becomes obsolete even before it is placed in operation), the obsession with gargantuan projects that ignore the island's size and needs - all this has existed and continues to exist,'' it said. -Izvestia also published a letter from a Tashkent man who said of Cuba: ``Pluralism is needed. Socialism has led to people's not giving a damn about anything, not even about trouble knocking on the door.'' -The Cuban economy, says the Soviet magazine Literaturnaya Gazeta, resembles ``someone crippled from childhood who is doomed to move about using the crutches of foreign aid.'' -The Moscow News had kind words for the Cuban exile community in Miami, who are perhaps the most outspoken critics of the Cuban system. Although portrayed by Cuban authorities as criminals, bandits and paid agents of imperialism, a Moscow News correspondent who visited Miami found the exiles to be people ``with a taste for enterprise, the creative and technical intelligentsia.'' Gillian Gunn, a Cuba expert at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said there seems to be competition now among Soviet journalists to see ``who can out-glasnost the other.'' She said there is an element of genuine criticism of the situation in Cuba and also an element of rebellion against the ideologically based reporting of the pre-glasnost years. Cuba considered Moscow News and another Soviet publication, Sputnik, to be so distasteful that both were banned from the island last year. ``They publish formulas that favor anarchy,'' the Communist Party daily Granma said. The Soviet media criticism of Cuba reflects increasing doubt among many Soviets about the propriety of continuing aid to Cuba - $5 billion annually, according to U.S. estimates - at a time of growing economic deprivation at home.

DOC.HEAD: New Leader in New Zealand Faces Daunting Task
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Jim Bolger's National Party swept to power by promising to cut unemployment in half, keep inflation under 2 percent, balance the budget and spur the economy. But the new conservative prime minister is already seeking to diminish the expectations he raised during the campaign that led to his party's election Saturday. Bolger now says New Zealand voters should be happy if he fulfills three out of four of those campaign promises. That still remains a tall order for Bolger who also hopes to patch up ties with Washington after six years of Labor Party government. Bolger was swept to power in the biggest election rout in New Zealand's 50 years of two-party government, but analysts said the size of the victory could hurt the traditionally divisive National Party. The National Party expects 68 of Parliament's 97 seats, with Labor falling to 28 seats and the New Labor Party holding the remaining seat. Former Labor Prime Minister David Lange said the National Party will find it difficult to achieve party consensus with such a broad base of support. ``You cannot satisfy the bulk of people with offers ... and this is a party with considerable inner divisions,'' Lange said. Critics said the National Party vote came mostly from people disenchanted with Labor and the nation's difficult economic problems. Unemployment, at 7.9 percent, is at its highest level since World War II. The budget deficit is projected at up to $1.8 billion in the next fiscal year. Party pledges to cut unemployment in half, keep inflation under 2 percent, balance the budget and spur a growth rate of 3 percent per year appear daunting. He also says he would like some reconciliation with Washington, which would appear to be a major diplomatic task. Nine months ago, the National Party reversed itself and said it would maintain Labor's 1984 ``no nuclear'' policy of refusing to allow port calls by U.S. warships because they would not say whether they were carrying nuclear weapons. In response to the policy, the United States in 1986 cut high-level contacts with New Zealand and dropped the country from the ANZUS military alliance, which also includes Australia. Bolger, 55, earned a reputation as a tough negotiator while serving as labor minister for six years until 1984, when Labor handed the National Party a devastating election loss. He took over the party's reins in 1986 and led it to a narrow loss in 1987. Bolger is the son of Irish immigrants. Like the man he succeeds, Mike Moore, he left school at 15 to work the family's North Island dairy farm. A devout Roman Catholic, he and his wife, Joan, have nine children. He has consistently opposed women's access to abortion.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Sends Bush Overhaul of Nation's Immigration Laws
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is expected to sign an overhaul of the nation's immigration laws that will substantially boost the number of immigrants allowed into the United States each year, especially those with special job skills. The first major rewrite of immigration law in a quarter-century was approved by Congress late Saturday as it rushed to adjournment. White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen said the legislation had the president's support. The bill would boost the current limit of 490,000 a year on legal immigrants to 645,000 in each fiscal year through 1994, and 675,000 thereafter. The measure keeps reuniting families as its primary test, but also would open the door to foreigners with special skills, those who are wealthy and even some shunned for years for political or medical reasons, such as AIDS. The measure assigns the first 465,000 visas each year to the ``family preference'' category, with an estimated 220,000 of those going to immediate relatives of U.S. citizens. At the same time, it earmarks 40,000 visas for individuals from Italy, Poland, Ireland and other traditional immigrant sources who have been virtually shut out for the past 20 years. It also would remove bans on immigration for persons because of homosexuality. In that period, U.S. immigration priority has been extended to those from Asia and Latin America, with few coming from Europe, Africa or other regions. The bill also would relax political restrictions dating to the 1950s, when Sen. Joe McCarthy, R-Wis., fought to ban many categories of immigrants as part of his crusade against communism. The secretary of state still will be able to bar individuals for political reasons, however. The government also would be allowed to remove AIDS and other diseases from the medical list for which a person may be denied entry. Any decision on whether to do so is up to the Bush administration.

DOC.HEAD: Rich But Beleaguered: German Communists to Disclose Assets
DOC.TEXT: In a desperate effort to recoup from a big money scandal, the former East German Communist Party says it will disclose details of its assets and turn some over to a national trustee. Party leader Gregor Gysi told a news conference in Bonn today that the party has about $1.3 billion in assets. The party, now named the Party of Democratic Socialism, may be the richest in Europe, but its political punch has plummeted since it lost total control in East Germany a year ago and tested itself in free elections. Two party members were arrested Friday for allegedly funneling $72 million in party funds to an account in Moscow. Party leaders declared over the weekend that they would submit their assets to an independent review and relinquish all but what was needed to satisfy obligations and continue political activities. Its leaders concede the scandal is a serious crisis for the party as it approaches German elections Dec. 2, the first national vote since East and West Germany united on Oct. 3. Party directors affirmed their support for Gysi, a 41-year-old lawyer and Communist reformer who took over after the hard-line bosses were ousted by a peaceful democratic revolt. But Gysi was deeply embarrassed by the huge amount of money involved, and by the fact that he went to Moscow to look into the matter after police raided his party headquarters in Berlin on Oct. 19 looking for evidence that led to Friday's arrests. Gysi was quoted today as telling the mass-circulation Bild Zeitung that if he had known about the manipulation behind the money transfer, he would not have flown to Moscow and ``made myself look like an ape for a week.'' Other politicians derided the former Communist Party, saying it had shown itself to be corrupt and a mere continuation of the old hard-liners. There is widespread belief that Communist figures salted away huge amounts of property and other assets in the waning days of their rule in East Germany. Gysi told a campaign rally Sunday in Alexanderplatz, the main square in East Berlin, that there had to be a radical departure from the party's past. A party statement admitted ``political mistakes'' and promised a wide debate on the party's future. Gysi had offered earlier to resign as leader but decided against it on the ground it would only damage the standing of the left in German politics. German news commentators questioned whether the party would ever reform. ``By remaining in his post, the talented politician Gysi just makes himself unworthy of belief,'' the conservative Frankfurter Allgemeine said in a front-page commentary. Die Welt, another conservative daily, said the fragments that have come to light ``smell strongly like organized criminality.'' Gysi told reporters today in Bonn, where he is a member of the German parliament, that the legislature needs a leftist opposition. In March, when East Germany held its first free elections, the former Communists finished third. After the two Germanys united, the renamed and supposedly reformed party won a number of seats in the Oct. 14 elections for state governments in the former East Germany. The state election results gave the party hope to win at least slender representation in parliament in the Dec. 2 election, but the money scandal will make their campaign more difficult. The former communists apparently are getting no help from their comrades in Moscow. German authorities praised Soviet police for their cooperation in looking into the Moscow end of the money transfer.

DOC.HEAD: Moderate Nationalists Finish First in Basque Region
DOC.TEXT: The moderate Basque Nationalist Party was the top finisher in regional elections, according to results announced today. The outcome was seen as a rejection of a radical independence movement. The Basque Nationalists won 22 seats in the 75-member regional parliament. The Socialists, their governing partners for the past four years, won 16 seats. Between them, the two parties have 38 seats, enough for a one-seat majority. Previously, the Socialists had the larger bloc of seats in the coalition. The Herri Batasuna or Popular Union party, widely considered the political arm of the Basque nationalist terrorist group ETA, finished with 13 seats, the same number it had already held. Several Basque newspaper editorials called the results a vote of confidence for the current coalition government and an endorsement of the strategy of seeking greater autonomy but not independence from Madrid. There were no reports of political violence during Sunday's voting in the northern three-province region. All the parties except Herri Batasuna formally renounced violence in 1987. During the campaign, the Basque Nationalists and Socialists both stressed political stability and economic recovery over the autonomy issue. In Sunday's voting, the Basque Nationalists gained five seats over their share from the last regional elections in 1986, while the Socialists lost three seats. In other results, the conservative Popular Party, the chief opposition party in the national parliament, won six seats, gaining four. The conservative Union Alavesa, formed recently from nationalists within the Popular Party, won three seats. The biggest losers were two leftist nationalist parties. Eusko Alkartasuna lost four seats to finish with nine, and Euskadiko Ezkerra's share dropped from nine to six seats. The Madrid-based Democratic and Social Center party, led by former Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez, virtually disappeared from the political map. The party, which won two seats in the 1986 election, garnered less than 1 percent of the vote and failed to win a single seat. Officials said 61 percent of the 1.8 million registered voters cast ballots.

DOC.HEAD: Man Opens Fire In Church Basement, Wounds Seven People
DOC.TEXT: A gunman opened fire in a crowded church basement, wounding seven of the 300 people gathered for a social event. Police Constable Bruno Vaillancourt said three women and four men were shot early Sunday, but that none was critically injured. The shootings occurred at St. Pascal Baylon Roman Catholic Church. Police did not identify the gunman or the victims. Constable Charles Morrisseau said the investigation is proceeding slowly because many witnesses will not talk to the police. ``Nobody wants to say anything,'' he said. Vaillancourt said three people already had been taken to the hospital by the time police arrived at the church shortly after 1:30 a.m. Sunday. The most seriously injured person suffered a bullet wound behind the ear. The others were wounded in the abdomen, hands and feet. While the police said they did not know the reason for the shootings, the church pastor suggested rival gangs might be involved. The Rev. Louis Levasseur said fighting among rival black groups has been a problem for the eight years he has been at the church. The elderly priest also said the problems only occur when English-speaking black groups rent the hall for special events. ``We rent the hall to Latin-Americans, Asians and Haitians and never have any problems,'' Levasseur said. The race and language of the group that rented the hall at the time of the shootings were not immediately reported. ``This is not the first time there have been gunshots and people hurt,'' said Levasseur. Shots were fired in the hall five or six months ago, but no one has been injured in about a year and a half, he said. He suggested the church may have to stop renting the hall to English-speaking black groups ``at the risk of being labeled racist. ''

DOC.HEAD: Texas' Eighth Area Code Goes into Effect Sunday
DOC.TEXT: Residents and businesses north and east of Dallas get a new area code Sunday. About 600,000 Southwestern Bell Telephone customers will change to the 903 area code, the eighth new area code for Texas. Dallas and nearby cities will remain 214. There are about 7.9 million possible seven-digit phone numbers within each area code, said Southwestern Bell spokesman Jim Patillo. Without the change, population growth in the current 214 area would have used up all available numbers by the end of 1991, he said. The greatest impact will be to customers living in Louisiana, Oklahoma and Arkansas along the northeast Texas line. Those residents frequently call businesses and residences in north Texas, Patillo said. The change will not affect rates, Patillo said, although long distance carriers may charge a penny or two more for access charges. California has the most area codes with 10, followed by Texas and New York with eight.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS NEW YORK-dated item on Hexter to CORRECT spelling, sted Hexler.
DOC.TEXT: Maurice Hexter, a major fund-raiser for Jewish causes in British-mandate Palestine and across the United States, died Sunday in his sleep at age 99. Hexter joined the the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York in 1938 on his return from Palestine, and by 1967 as executive vice president distributed nearly a half billion dollars to its health and welfare agencies. In 1929, he moved to Jerusalem to administer the Palestine Emergency Fund, which collected millions of dollars worldwide to rebuild homes wrecked by rioting between Arabs and Jews. He was a former executive director of the Milwaukee Federation of Jewish Charities.

DOC.HEAD: 22 Koreans Sue for Apology, Compensation
DOC.TEXT: A group of 22 South Koreans filed suit in Tokyo District Court today, demanding a public apology and compensation from the Japanese government for victims of World War II, the court said. The Koreans said they or their family members had been drafted by Japan and forced to work as laborers or soldiers during the war. Tens of thousands of Koreans were drafted into Japanese service while Korea was under Japanese colonial rule from 1910 to 1945. Japan has recently expressed regrets for some of its actions during the colonial era. A court official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the group did not specify the amount of compensation sought. He did not say when the court would start hearing the case. A Foreign Ministry official, also speaking on condition of anonymity, said Japan's position is that all questions of compensation were resolved by agreements between Japan and South Korea in 1965. The mass-circulation newspaper Asahi Shimbun quoted the Korean plaintiffs as saying the fates of many Koreans drafted into the Japanese army remain unknown, and they want an investigation. ``Whatever talks were held at the governmental level, a real settlement could not be made without the people concerned,'' the Koreans were quoted as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Hear Black Lung Benefits Disputes from Pennsylvania, West Virginia
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to resolve a dispute over black lung benefits that may affect $650 million in claims by coal miners and their families. The court said it will decide how difficult it should be for mining companies to challenge claims by as many as 3,500 miners. The court was asked to settle conflicting rulings from federal appeals courts that have studied the issue in cases from Pennsylvania and West Virginia. The Bush administration sided with the coal companies in seeking to limit the ability of some workers and their families to receive benefits. Justice Department lawyers said coal mine operators should be allowed to show that disabled or deceased miners did not suffer from black lung disease, or that work in the mines did not cause their disability. The government also noted that black lung benefits may exceed $185,000 per miner or family. The disease, also called pneumoconiosis, is a lung disorder caused by breathing coal dust over a long period of time. The Supreme Court, in a related 1988 ruling, spared the coal mining industry from paying potentially billions of dollars in benefits to as many as 155,000 miners. The justices barred reopening claims that were denied in the late 1970s and early 1980s. But that ruling left open the issue raised in the dispute acted on today - the validity of Labor Department regulations making it easier for mine operators to deny benefit claims. The regulations give the companies the opportunity to dispute evidence that miners are suffering from black lung or that they were incapacitated by their work in the mines. Earlier regulations adopted by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare said the only way the benefits could be denied is with proof a miner is still working, is capable of working in the mines or is doing comparable work. Some federal appeals courts have upheld the Labor Department rules. Others have said they conflict with a 1977 federal law aimed at helping disabled miners. Congress created a special fund to pay off claims by miners with the disease, and required mine operators to contribute to the fund. The cases are Pauley vs. Bethenergy Mines, 89-1714; Clinchfield Coal Co. vs. Office of Workers' Compensation, 90-113; Consolidation Coal Co. vs. Workers' Compensation Program, 90-114.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Palestinians Strike, Stay Away From Jobs in Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with army sources concluding soldier's death probably a suicide. Pickup 11th pvs, `Today's strike...'
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Palestinians stayed home from their jobs in Israel today during a general strike marking the anniversary of a 1956 massacre of Arab villagers by Israeli soldiers. The strike came a day after Israel lifted a four-day closure of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and hundreds of Arabs found they had been replaced in their jobs by Israelis. Tensions were briefly raised among Israelis today after an Israeli Arab soldier was found shot to death. But police and army sources concluded the 19-year-old Druse soldier probably committed suicide. Last week's attacks on Israelis - which included the fatal stabbing of a woman soldier and knifing of two other women soldiers - led to the four-day closure of the occupied territories. Leaders of a 34-month-old Palestinian uprising have repeatedly urged slayings of Israels as revenge for the Temple Mount shooting deaths of 20 Arabs on Oct. 8. The dead soldier was identified by a military spokesman as Cpl. Hareb Hatham, 19, of Beit Jann village in northern Israel, which is predominantly Druse. The Druse are a minority Arab sect that is loyal to Israel. Unlike most Israeli Arabs, their men serve in the armed forces. A police commander, Albert Musafia, said the shooting late Sunday was probably a suicide. Army sources initially said there was evidence Hatham could have been killed by guerrillas, but later agreed with the suicide theory. The body was found at the Golani junction, about 10 miles north of the occupied West Bank. Today's strike in the West Bank and Gaza Strip paralyzed commerce in the territories. It was called by the Moslem fundamentalist movement Hamas, or Zeal, to mark 34 years since the killing of 49 Israeli Arabs by soldiers in Kfar Qassem. The killings occurred during the 1956 Suez War, in which Israel attacked Egypt in an effort to break a two-year Egyptian blockade of its southern ports. At the time, curfews were imposed on most Arab areas in Israel. Troops opened fire on orders to shoot curfew violaters, but their Arab victims were mostly workers returning home from jobs, unaware of the restrictions. There were some vain attempts by Palestinian activists to call off today's strike to avoid having more Arabs fired because of prolonged absences from work. But Arab labor leaders claimed the strike hurt Israel as well since its economy still depended on the work force of about 150,000 Palestinians. Hundreds of Palestinians found Sunday that they had been replaced during the four-day closure of the territories. Israel closed the lands because of attacks on Israelis in revenge for the Temple Mount killings, in which police opened fire on stone-throwing Arabs.

DOC.HEAD: Court Lets Stand Ruling on Kansas City Desegregation
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today let stand a ruling that boosted a federal judge's power to order predominantly white suburban schools to accept inner-city black students. The justices, without comment, rejected an appeal by three Kansas City, Mo., suburban school districts facing such a desegregation order. The case is an outgrowth of a longstanding court battle over desegregation of Kansas City's public schools. The fight led last April to an important Supreme Court ruling that federal judges may order local officials to raise property taxes to help desegregate public schools. That 5-4 ruling upheld key features of a 1985 decision by U.S. District Judge Russell Clark in a 1977 lawsuit by black parents seeking to reverse the decline of the city's predominantly black schools. The case acted on today grew out of Clark's 1985 order that Missouri officials pay for transportation and tuition of black students in Kansas City who choose to transfer to predominantly white suburban schools. Clark described the plan as voluntary on the part of the suburban schools and the black students. But school officials in the suburban districts of North Kansas City, Lee's Summit and Independence said they are being coerced into accepting the black transfers. They asked the high court to overturn a May ruling by the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals that said Clark's 1985 order is being ignored unlawfully. Since 1985, the appeals court said, ``not a single suburban school district has admitted a single black student from (Kansas City) pursuant to a plan negotiated by the state and the suburban school districts. Further delay cannot be countenanced.'' The appeals court noted that 134 black students from Kansas City applied for admission into the three suburban school districts in 1988. The appeals court said the suburban districts did not admit the students, apparently due to worries the state would not reimburse the costs. After the black students were denied admission, they filed a new lawsuit that was assigned to U.S. District Judge Joseph E. Stevens Jr. Stevens threw out the suit last year. But the 8th Circuit court, in its May ruling, reversed Stevens and reassigned the case to Clark with instructions to come up with a plan for transferring black students to the suburban schools. The appeals court said the previous refusal of the suburban schools to admit the blacks raised questions about whether they were practicing unlawful racial bias. In the appeal acted on today, the suburban school officials said their districts have no history of racial bias, and said it is unfair to use their refusal to admit students from another city as evidence of discrimination. The appeals court is ``using sheer force to impose its values'' on public schools that have no record of racial bias, the officials said. The Supreme Court in 1974 struck down a Detroit-area school desegregation plan that required students to be bused across ity boundaries. The justices said such remedies are inappropriate unless all districts involved contributed to the segregation. The case acted on today is Lee's Summit vs. Naylor, 90-391.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Hear Appeal of Virginia Death Row Inmate
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to hear the appeal of Virginia death row inmate Roger Coleman, convicted of killing his sister-in-law nine years ago. The justices said they will use Coleman's case to study further how easy it should be for death row imates to challenge their state court convictions in federal court. Coleman was found guilty of killing Wanda Fay McCoy in Buchanan County in 1981. Police said Coleman slashed her throat after a sexual attack. The case is Coleman vs. Thompson, 89-7662.

DOC.HEAD: New York Utilities Can't Force Customers to Subsidize Charitable Contributions
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to let any New York utility force customers, through the rates they pay, to subsidize its charitable contributions. The justices, without comment, let stand a ruling by New York's highest court that said allowing publicly regulated utilities to include such charitable giving in their rates violates customers' rights. Lawyers for the New York Telephone Co. and Rochester Gas and Electric Corp. told the justices the state court ruling ``creates a revolutionary new federal right'' with ``alarming national implications.'' About half the states and even some federal regulatory agencies deem reasonable levels of charitable contributions ``ordinary business expenses'' that may be built into a utility company's customer rates. The New York Public Service Commission, which regulates utility rates in that state, first allowed charitable giving to be included in the ratebase in 1970. Joseph Cahill, a resident of Fishkill, N.Y., and a New York Telephone customer, challenged the commission's policy. So did state Attorney General Robert Abrams in a separate lawsuit against Rochester Gas and Electric. The suits were combined, and a state trial judge ruled that policy allowing charitable contributions to be included in the ratebase violates cusomers' free-speech rights. The New York Court of Appeals upheld that ruling last May. ``Ratepayers are entitled to protection against forced financial support for causes and messages personally distasteful to them,'' the state court said. ``The utilities have not fulfilled their burden of justification for imposing on their ratepayers, rather than on their shareholders, the bill for their selected philanthropy.'' The state court relied heavily on a 1977 Supreme Court ruling in which the justices barred unions from using mandatory fees collected from non-members they represent for anything unrelated to collective bargaining. The 1977 ruling was one in a series of decisions in which the high court said the Constitution's First Amendment not only protects the right to speak and associate freely but also the right not to speak or associate. Documents submitted in the New York case appeared to disagree over just what charitable contributions were at issue. Lawyers for New York Telephone said the company ``does not engage in political, religious or ideological giving.'' But the state court's ruling last May said New York Telephone and Rochester Gas and Electric had contributed to ``numerous charities, including politically and religiously active organizations.'' Cahill's lawyers said he is a lifelong Roman Catholic who objected, among other things, to charitable contributions made to organizations that advocate abortion rights. In a ``friend-of-the-court'' brief, United Ways of America urged the justices to reverse the state court ruling. United Ways said that $55.8 million of the $682 million in corporate contributions it received last year came from utility companies. The case is New York Telephone Co. vs. Cahill, 90-255.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Let New York Authorities Give Short Haircuts to Rastafarians
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to let New York prison authorities give short haircuts to newly arrived inmates belonging to a Jamaica-based religion called Rastafarians. The court, without comment, left intact a ruling that the haircut policy violates the inmates' religious freedom. Rastafarians, adherents of a Jamaica-based religion founded on a belief that the late Ethiopia Emperor Haile Selassie is God, have religious scruples against men cutting or combing their hair. They wear their hair in ropelike strands known as dreadlocks. At New York prisons, all incoming inmates are required to get a short haircut and have an identification photograph made. The photograph is to be used in the event of an escape. After the photo is taken, however, inmates are free to grow their hair to whatever length they please. Rastafarian inmates challenged the haircut policy in 1979, and for nearly six years negotiated with prison officials in search of a settlement. A federal judge in 1986, and in subsequent rulings, barred prison authorities from enforcing the initial haircut policy. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the haircut policy ban last May. ``Accepting the existence of reasonable security concerns, we find there is an alternative that can accommodate both parties,'' the appeals court said. It noted that U.S. District Judge Louis L. Stanton had found that pulling an inmate's hair back in a ponytail while taking the identification photo would meet a prison's security needs. Prison officials had argued that Stanton was wrong about that, but the appeals court said the officials ``failed to establish that the accommodation here has more than a (minimal) effect on valid penological interests.'' In the appeal acted on today, New York prison authorities said the appeals court ruling conflicts with a pair of 1987 Supreme Court decisions on inmate rights. In one, the court gave states sweeping power to prevent inmates from corresponding with inmates in other prisons. In the other, the justices ruled that prison officials acted properly when forbidding some Muslims from attending weekly prison worship services. The case is Coughlin vs. Benjamin, 90-307.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Loses Appeal in Suit Against Kansas City Pharmaceutical Company
DOC.TEXT: An 11-year-old boy who won, and then lost, a $95 million award against the maker of an anti-nausea drug his mother took during pregnancy lost a Supreme Court appeal today. The justices, over one dissenting vote, let stand a ruling that threw out Sekou Ealy's legal victory over Marion Merrell Dow Inc. Justice Byron R. White voted to hear arguments in the case, but four votes are needed to grant such review. Sekou's mother, Sandra, took the drug Bendectin while pregnant, and he was born with defects in his hands and arms. Sekou has three fingers on one hand and four on the other, and no thumbs. His arms are underdeveloped and locked at the elbows. According to court papers, Sekou has undergone weekly psychiatric therapy to address his mental fixation that his parents cut off his fingers to punish him for being naughty. Bendectin was marketed between 1957 and 1983 by Richardson-Merrell Inc., now Marion Merrell Dow based in Kansas City, Mo. More than 30 million women used the drug. The company stopped selling Bendectin in 1983, although the Federal Drug Administration never has rescinded approval of the drug. After a federal court trial in the District of Columbia, where the Ealys lived, a jury awarded Sekou $20 million in compensatory damages and $75 million in punitive damages. U.S. District Judge June L. Green set aside the punitive-damages award but let stand the $20 million compensatory-damages award. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here overturned that award last March. The appeals court ruled that the expert testimony used in an attempt to link Bendectin to the birth defects ``was without scientific foundation.'' ``It may well be that future scientific research will generate ... an adequate basis for an expert's opinion that Bendectin ... caused a plaintiff's birth defects,'' the appeals court said. ``Until that day, the existing body of published epidemiological studies, all finding no significant statistical association between ingestion of Bendectin and birth defects, must be recognized as the measuring stick for the admissibility of expert testimony on this issue,'' the appeals court said. In the appeal acted on today, lawyers for Sekou said the appeals court's treatment of testimony by expert witnesses conflicts with how nine other federal appeals courts have dealt with expert testimony. The appeal argued that the appeals court at least should order a new trial, rather than throw out the suit against the drug manufacturer. The case is Ealy vs. Richardson-Merrell, 90-225.

DOC.HEAD: Court Asks Bush Administration for Views on Arkansas Voting Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today asked the Bush administration for its views of an appeal by black voters in a rural Arkansas County who say the election system in party primaries and countywide general elections is racially biased. The court said it wants to hear from Justice Department lawyers before saying whether it will decide if the runoff election systems violates the Voting Rights Act of 1965. Lower courts said it does not. The Justice Department response may take months. Under Arkansas law, a candidate for a political party's nomination or for a countywide office must receive a majority of the votes cast in a primary election to win a political party's nomination. If no candidate wins an outright majority, a runoff election is held two weeks later between the top two vote-getters. The justices were told that Arkansas is one of 10 states employing such a system, ``all of them in the South and all of them with a long history of purposeful racial vote dilution.'' The other states were identified as Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, Texas and Oklahoma. The runoff system, as it operates in Phillips County, Ark., was challenged as illegal by black voters who say their voting power is being diluted. Their lawsuit also alleged that the runoff requirements were adopted and maintained for the purpose of blunting black voting power. Blacks comprise 52 percent of the population in Phillips County, located on the Mississippi River, but only 47 percent of the county's voting-age residents are black. No black candidate ever has received the Democratic or Republican nomination for, or been elected to, any countywide office in Phillips County since the turn of the century. In the two most recent election years, four black candidates received the highest percentage of votes in their Democratic primary races but were defeated in runoffs by white candidates who had trailed them in the first election. By contrast, no white candidate who has come out on top in a first primary without winning a majority of all votes has ever lost the ensuing runoff. Black voters who challenged the election system cited as major reasons for such results the lack of access to motor vehicles and telephones for many black residents. Only 9 percent of white households in Phillips County have no vehicle available, and 10.9 percent have no telephone, the justices were told. But 42 percent of black households have no vehicle and 30 percent have no telephone. A federal trial judge threw out the black voters' suit, ruling that they could not invoke the Voting Rights Act because blacks comprise a majority of the county's population. A three-judge panel of the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals reversed the trial judge's ruling by a 2-1 vote, and said the runoff system had violated the federal law in Phillips County. But the entire 8th Circuit court last May voted 5-5 to uphold the trial judge's ruling - killing the suit. The case is Whitfield vs. Clinton, 90-383.

DOC.HEAD: Longtime President Headed For Victory; Opposition Leader Claims Fraud
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th pvs, `But the...' to CORRECT that opposition claiming a narrower lede in its count: 51 percent to 49 percent. Pickup 5th pvs, `He called...'
DOC.TEXT: President Felix Houphouet-Boigny appeared bound for overwhelming victory today in the country's first contested presidential election, which the opposition said was stolen through massive fraud. It was the first time a leader of one of Africa's one-party states was being challenged at the polls since a wave of protests and rioting for democracy began sweeping sub-Saharan Africa early this year. With about one-third of the ballots counted by midday today, Interior Ministry official Claude Regnier said Houphouet-Boigny had captured about 85 percent of votes. The count was being done at the ministry. But the 85-year-old president's sole challenger - socialist-minded history Professor Laurent Gbagbo - said a computer count by his Popular Front gave Gbagbo a lead of 51 percent to Houphouet-Boigny's 49 percent. He called the election a ``masquerade'' of democracy and said his supporters were being rounded up and arrested. The government denied the charges of fraud. Abidjan was tense but calm today, with armed soldiers guarding the Interior Ministry. Gbagbo's followers appeared to be awaiting the final results. In the working-class suburb of Yopougon, opposition militants reportedly barricaded a street in front of their party office, and soldiers dismantled the barricade and broke down the office door. But they went away without making any arrests. Gbagbo produced hundreds of ballots marked for Houphouet-Boigny, which he said had come from one of dozens of boxes stuffed to rig the elections. His supporters said they had smashed ballot boxes to halt voting Sunday at several polling stations. They claimed boxes were stuffed with votes for Houphouet-Boigny before the polling started. In London, prices of cocoa dropped as news spread that Houphouet-Boigny would apparently retain power. Ivory Coast is the world's biggest cocoa producer, and experts say its crop helps determine whether the world market remains in surplus. Gbagbo said the Democratic Party of Houphouet-Boigny, who has ruled since Ivory Coast's independence from France in 1960, also publicized voting stations that did not exist and set up balloting stations that were not advertised. There were also reports of disorganization at several voting stations, where ballot papers and electoral lists did not arrive or were delivered hours late. Interior Minister Leon Konan Koffi called the opposition accusations lies. He told reporters Gbagbo's supporters destroyed ballot boxes to stop elections they knew they would lose. Konan Koffi said the opposition forced nine voting stations in Abidjan to shut. Gbagbo confirmed his ``party militants'' halted elections in 50 stations of one Abidjan suburb alone, and at numerous other places nationwide. Government officials first said preliminary results were expected Sunday night, but later said they were delayed by difficulties getting results from remote villages. Gbagbo said he would decide whether to accept the election results after they were announced, but regardless, he said, the election was worth it. ``Nobody ever thought we would get multiparty democracy while Houphouet-Boigny was in Ivory Coast,'' he said. ``It was time to put a stop to the system of there being just a single candidate.'' Legislative elections are scheduled next month. Some 26 political parties have sprung up since Houphouet-Boigny was forced to legalize political opposition after weeks of rioting led by students and joined by the urban poor.

DOC.HEAD: Court Won't Kill Suit Against Prison Medical Director in Indiana
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to kill a lawsuit against the medical director of a federal prison in Indiana accused of deliberately neglecting the health needs of inmates. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the official may be sued by the heirs of a prisoner who died after an asthma attack. The 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled last year that Dr. Robert Brutsche, the medical director, is not automatically immune from being sued over Joseph Jones' death in 1975. The appeals court said that by 1975 prison officials were on notice that depriving inmates of adequate health care was a violation of their rights, even though there was no nationwide legal precedent on the issue then. ``We believe that a failure to correct systemic deficiencies in the delivery of health care services at a prison violated clearly established law in 1975,'' the appeals court said. ``A clear trend in the case law'' then showed ``a controlling precedent was merely a question of time,'' the appeals court said. Jones died soon after he was admitted to the Terre Haute prison hospital with difficulty breathing. Robert DeGracias, the prison doctor, prescribed a drug over the telephone and ordered Jones sent to a local civilian hospital. Jones was the fourth inmate at Terre Haute who died of medical causes during the first eight months of 1975. After Jones died, Brutsche ordered an investigation that led him to recommend improved medical care for inmates. Jones' mother sued, accusing Brutsche and DeGracias of deliberate indifference to her son's health. A federal judge refused to dismiss the suit, ruling there were numerous questions to be answered about care of inmates in life-threatening emergencies. The 7th Circuit court noted that in 1982, the Supreme Court held that public officials are shielded from suit unless they violate a clearly established right. The appeals court said in Brutsche's case there were at least three federal appeals court rulings that indicated ``a clear consensus had been reached that a prison official's failure to remedy systemic deficiencies in medical services ... constituted deliberate indifference.'' The Bush administration urged the Supreme Court to reject Brutsche's appeal, even though it said it disagrees with the appeals court ruling. Justice Department lawyers said further examination of the case by lower courts could be helpful. For example, the government said, Brutsche should not be made a scapegoat if there is evidence the conditions at Terre Haute were caused by a scarcity of competent personnel. The high court on Oct. 15 agreed to study a related issue surrounding immunity for public officials from such suits. The issue in that case is whether the suits must be dismissed at the outset when the alleged official misconduct is based largely on a subjective interpretation of events by those doing the suing. The case acted on today is Brutsche, vs. Cleveland-Perdue, 89-1167.

DOC.HEAD: Escapee Charged in Assault, Death of 2-Year-Old
DOC.TEXT: A missing toddler was found dying under the bed of a man who had escaped from prison while serving a sentence for sexual battery. Yoanna Maria Noda, who would have been 2 Wednesday, was discovered Sunday after a police search of the apartment of Alcides Medina Quiles, 27. Officers tried to revive the girl, but she was pronounced dead at Jackson Memorial Hospital, police spokesman Bobby Navarro said. An autopsy was scheduled to determine the cause of death. Quiles was being held without bond pending a court appearance today on charges of first-degree murder, kidnapping and sexual battery. Police said an FBI fingerprint check identified Quiles as an escapee from a state prison in Hartford, Conn. He was serving an 18-year sentence on sexual battery charges when he escaped in August, the FBI said. Police canvassed the western Miami neighborhood Sunday morning after the child's family called to say she was missing. A witness told detectives she had seen a child playfully chasing a chicken down the street. The witness said she saw a man she assumed was the girl's father lead the child off the street and out of sight, police said. The search eventually led to Quiles' apartment building. Quiles twice let investigators look through his rooms, which police said he rented about two weeks ago under a false name. ``He took the police into his apartment, not once, but twice. And he sat right there while they were looking,'' said detective Ronnie Ilhardt. ``But when the body was found, he ran out the door.'' Quiles was captured after a short chase, said homicide detective Oscar Tejeda.

DOC.HEAD: Ruling Stands that Norfolk, Va., Voting System Violates Rights of Blacks
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today let stand a ruling that the at-large system used in Norfolk, Va., city council elections violates the rights of black voters. A federal appeals court panel last Aug. 18 ordered the city to switch to a single-district election system that will ``remedy the vote dilution arising out of the at-large election system.'' The Norfolk City Council has seven members, elected to staggered four-year terms. Elections for three or four of the council seats are held every two years. Candidates with the most votes citywide win, and do not need a majority of the votes cast. A group of black voters and the local chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People sued in 1983, contending that the at-large system used since 1918 illegally blunted the political clout of black voters. Norfolk, one of Virginia's largest cities, is 35 percent black in population. Blacks also comprise 35 percent of the city's registered voters. The city council did not have a black member until 1968, and since then has had one black member most years. The NAACP and black voters who sued said if city council members were elected from seven single-member districts, black voters would be in the majority in three of the seven districts. The city's voting dispute reached the nation's highest court once before, and in 1986 was sent back to lower courts for more study. U.S. District Judge J. Calvitt Clarke Jr. in Norfolk ruled in 1988 that the at-large election system did not violate the federal Voting Rights Act, but a three-judge panel of the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals reversed his ruling. The panel, by a 2-1 vote, said the at-large system gives black voters ``less opportunity than other members of the electorate to participate in the electoral process and to elect representatives of their choice.'' The panel said those who sued ``do not seek proportional representation, and the act does not require it.'' But it said the lack of success blacks have had in winning more ``token representation'' on the city council show the existence of ``white bloc voting ... in Norfolk.'' The appeals court panel ordered Clarke to block all future at-large elections and to require the city to come up with a new election system in a ``reasonable, specified time'' to be reviewed under Voting Rights Act standards. ``If the city fails to enact a legal plan, (Clarke) should prepare a single-district plan for the conduct of future elections,'' the appeals court panel said. The full 4th Circuit court split 5-5 in refusing to review the three-judge panel's decision. The panel's decision was held in abeyance pending today's action by the Supreme Court. The panel's ruling that the city elections system must change now will take effect. In their appeal, city officials said the August decision forcing a change ``is nothing more than a decision to require ... proportional representation.'' ``If that ruling is correct,'' the appeal said, ``then all at-large election systems are imperiled.'' Asked for its views, the Bush administration told the court to reject the city's appeal. ``Although the court of appeals' analysis is not without flaws, the court's errors ... either do not affect the outcome of the case orare too closely tied to its particular facts to be of general significance,'' Justice Department lawyers said. The case is Norfolk vs. Collins, 89-989.

DOC.HEAD: Global Warming Conference Opens With Warnings of `Catastrophic' Threat
DOC.TEXT: A United Nations conference on global warming opened today, and a top U.N. official warned that only radical changes can save the world from a climate disaster. Mostafa K. Tolba, the head of the U.N. Environment Program, said the threat of global warming is ``potentially more catastrophic than any other threat in human history.'' Such warming could trigger famine by disrupting agriculture, and coastal areas could be flooded if sea levels are raised by melting of glaciers and the Greenland ice sheet. Scientists believe about half of global warming is caused by carbon dioxide gas from fossil fuel burning. Other ``greenhouse gases'' are methane, nitrous oxide, and chemicals called chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs. The gases increase the atmosphere's tendency to trap heat, like a greenhouse. ``Nothing short of action which affects every individual can forestall global catastrophe,'' Tolba said. ``Nothing less than a complete change in attitudes and lifestyles will succeed.'' The gathering brought together about 500 scientists from around the world, who are to chart a comprehensive new program with proposals on how to counter global warming, or the greenhouse effect. The conference will wind up with a two-day meeting of about 80 government ministers. Several heads of government, including Britain's Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and French Prime Minister Michel Rocard, are to attend. The United States, still opposed to mandatory restrictions on emissions of the chemicals involved, is represented by a lower-ranking official, John Knauss, head of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The opening of the Geneva conference coincided with a meeting of environment ministers of the 12-nation European Community to address carbon dioxide emission controls. At the Geneva session, a final declaration on Nov. 7 will provide the basis for the first formal negotiations on an accord on fighting global warming. The pact is to be ready for signing in mid-1992. Tolba said the convention must spell out specific commitments to cut emissions. But he said the industrialized nations, which emit three-fourths of all man-made greenhouse gases, must act now and not wait for the agreement. ``The longer we delay, the worse the disaster will be for our children, and for our children's children,'' he said. Curbing emissions ``will cost vast sums and will demand great changes in economic, legal and institutional systems,'' Tolba said. But he said the cost of inaction would be far greater. Developing nations, he said, would need more time, funds and access to Western technology to reduce emissions. During the past two years, more than 1,000 scientists from 70 countries have compiled a bulky report for the conference which list grim scenarios of what might happen unless action is taken to reduce global warming. They predict that continuing on the current course would send global temperatures up 5.4 degrees Fahrenheit by the end of the next century, the fastest rise in 10,000 years. Barring countermeasures, global sea levels would rise by about two feet, the report said. In the next century, rising sea levels could flood tens of thousands of miles of densely populated shorelines. The warming trend would also disrupt agricultural production worldwide. But the U.N. Food and Agriculture Administration, in a position paper prepared for the Geneva conference, said the overall effect on global farming could actually be positive because of the opening up of arable lands toward the poles. But in some vulnerable regions, the effect ``may be very serious,'' it added. Experts generally agree that the trend toward a warmer Earth cannot be stopped but could be mitigated by a shifting to other forms of energy and stopping the destruction of forests around the world. They agree much more research on the problem is needed.

DOC.HEAD: Riot Police Fire at Students in Zimbabwe
DOC.TEXT: Police fired warning shots over the heads of rioting students today, the third day of violent protests against tighter state control over the country's university. Teachers, also angered that the University of Zimbabwe has lost much of its autonomy under a 4-day-old bill, said they would mount their own peaceful demonstration on Tuesday. Police said at least five students have been arrested, including the president of the Student's Representative Council, Christopher Giwa. The students were taken in on Friday after refusing to disperse in downtown Harare. They are to appear in court to face charges of breaching the peace. Since the latest round of anti-government protests began Thursday, students have stormed the university, smashed windows and set fire to gardens and trees. Classes have been boycotted and year-end examinations, scheduled to begin this morning, disrupted. Today, riot police guarding university buildings fired warning shots to disperse students hurling bricks and stones. Elsewhere on campus, police fired tear gas to break-up hostile student groups. The students are protesting amendments to the University Act passed by parliament on Thursday. The amendments give the state-appointed vice chancellor of the university sweeping disciplinary powers. The bill also empowers the higher education minister to interfere in running the university. It will become law if signed by President Robert Mugabe, who is titular chancellor of the university and a critic of student demonstrators. ``The amendments are clearly intended to bring the university under the direct political control of the government,'' said Tony Reeler, secretary of the 120-member Association of University Teachers. ``This current legislation will destroy the university,'' he said. In recent years, the university has been a hub of government opposition. While students supported Mugabe at the time of independence 10 years ago, they have recently charged his leadership with corruption, mismanagement and authoritarianism. Under state-of-emergency regulations in October, the government closed the university for six months following violent clashes with police. More than 480 students in that anti-government protest were arrested. The emergency was lifted, under extreme opposition pressure, in July.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Squelch Tacoma, Wash., Rape Victim's Suit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 5-16, In other action, with other cases. Note last graf, with case citations, includes last names of rape victims.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to squelch the lawsuit of a Tacoma, Wash., woman who says she was raped after a policeman left her stranded in a high-crime area late at night. The justices, without comment, left intact a ruling that will force a trial on the woman's allegations against Washington State Trooper Steven Ostrander. In a separate case, the court refused to reinstate a $750,000 award won, and then lost, by a woman raped in a Cleveland-area public transit system parking lot. The Tacoma woman's 1985 civil rights suit contends Ostrander violated her constitutional right by placing her in danger and failing to provide any protection. In other action, the court: - Let stand a ruling that boosted a federal judge's power to order predominantly white suburban schools to accept inner-city black students. The justices, without comment, rejected an appeal by three Kansas City, Mo., suburban school districts facing such a desegregation order. The case is an outgrowth of a longstanding court battle over desegregation of Kansas City's public schools. - Agreed to resolve a dispute over black lung benefits that may affect $650 million in claims by coal miners and their families. The court said it will decide how difficult it should be for mining companies to challenge claims by as many as 3,500 miners. - Allowed a state to automatically impose longer sentences for criminals who used guns. The court, without comment, let stand a Montana law used to add 10 years to the 30-year prison sentence given a man who brandished a gun during a pizza shop robbery. In a separate case, the court refused to let police in Massachusetts stop and search someone solely because that person reportedly was carrying a handgun in public. - Let stand a ruling that the at-large system used in Norfolk, Va., city council elections violates the rights of black voters. A federal appeals court panel last Aug. 18 ordered the city to switch to a single-district election system that will ``remedy the vote dilution arising out of the at-large election system.'' - Refused to kill a civil rights lawsuit against a Texas city that cracked down on ``cruising'' teen-agers five years ago. The court, without comment, left intact a ruling that forces DeSoto, Texas, and nine members of its police department to defend themselves at trial against allegations of illegal arrests. In the Tacoma rape case, at about 2:30 a.m. on Sept. 23, 1984, Ostrander stopped a car driven by Robert Bell because its headlights were on high-beam. After speaking to Bell, Ostrander arrested him on drunken-driving charges and called for a tow truck to impound the car.
