The Tacoma woman claims Ostrander, after ordering her out of the car, simply got into his patrol car and drove away. He claims he offered to call a friend or relative who could give her a ride home, but that she declined his offer. Bell's car had been stopped in the Parkland area of Pierce County, south of Tacoma and about five miles from the woman's home. Court records indicate the area has the highest violent-crime rate in the county outside of Tacoma. The temperature was 50 degrees, and the woman as wearing only a blouse and jeans. She says that after walking a half-block toward her home and having turned down several ride offers from strangers, she accepted one from an unknown man. The woman's suit says the driver took her to a secluded area and raped her. Her lawyers said the rape impregnated her, and resulted in the birth of a child. A federal judge dismissed the suit but a three-judge panel of the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, voting 2-1, reinstated it. The woman ``has raised a genuine issue of fact tending to show that Trooper Ostrander acted with deliberate indifference to (her) interest in personal security under the 14th Amendment,'' the appeals court panel said. The appeals court panel discounted the fact that a 24-hour gas station and a 24-hour convenience store, both well-lighted, were located within two blocks of where Ostrander left the woman. ``It is for the trier of fact to determine whether a reasonable person should have regarded a gas station or a convenience store, located in a high-crime neighborhood, as some kind of safe haven where she would have been given assistance or permitted to stay until daybreak before walking five miles home,'' the appeals court said. The woman's suit said she could not call her parents for help because both are disabled. In the Cleveland case, the court, without comment, let stand a ruling that overturned the award against the transit system. The Cleveland woman was attacked the evening of Jan. 15, 1985, after getting off a train at a station in East Cleveland. Her assailant later confessed to raping her, as well as another woman at the same station the previous night. The woman sued the Greater Cleveland Regional Transit Authority for negligence. She said the public agency failed to provide adequate security for passengers, particularly in light of the rape the previous night. A state court jury awarded her $750,000 after also hearing evidence that numerous violent crimes were committed at the station from 1975 to 1985. A state appeals court threw out the award last year. The appeals court relied on an Ohio Supreme Court ruling that police may not be sued for failing to protect the public against crimes - unless it can be shown they ``owed a special duty of care'' to a crime victim. The appeals court said it saw no difference between a regional transit agency and a city police department. --- The cases are Ostrander vs. Wood, 89-1409, and Shelton vs. Greater Cleveland Regional Transit Authority, 90-430.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Suggests Saddam's Stance Shifting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with more quotes from news conference. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today the latest mission to Baghdad by a Soviet envoy indicated there were some shifts in the position of Iraq's Saddam Hussein. Gorbachev, at a news conference following talks with French President Francois Mitterrand, said he had received a telegram from the envoy, Yevgeny Primakov, who met Sunday with Saddam. But he did not elaborate. Primakov traveled on to Saudi Arabia for meetings today with King Fahd. At the news conference, Gorbachev said the time was right for Arab nations to embark on a new initiative to resolve the crisis, possibly under Saudi Arabian leadership. ``It seems to me that the Iraqis could be ready for this,'' he said. ``If we were to have an inter-Arab meeting, this would be the quickest way to a settlement.'' Gorbachev also urged tougher sanctions against Iraq and suggested that Saddam is beginning to yield to economic pressure. ``Under the pressure of sanctions - which have to be stepped up, of course -some signs are emerging that Iraq's leadership may be heeding the will of the United Nations,'' he said. Gorbachev stressed the importance of maintaining a united front against Iraq. If Saddam is counting on a split in the alliance against him, he is ``building his policy on a mistake,'' the Soviet president said. ``We must not permit the Iraqi regime to hope there will be a division, a weakening of positions,'' he said. Gorbachev said he hoped the crisis, which was set off by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, could be solved without war. ``I think it's unacceptable to have a military solution,'' Gorbachev said. But he insisted that Iraq comply with United Nations calls to free foreign hostages and withdraw from Kuwait. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, who has accompanied Gorbachev on the trip, had said on Sunday night that Primakov's visit to Baghdad did not appear to have been fruitful. ``For the moment there are not many reasons for optimism'' regarding Primakov's talks with Saddam, the Soviet minister said. But he added that Moscow still held out hope for a negotiated settlement. Mitterrand, also at the news conference, said French and Soviet positions on the gulf were in harmony. ``We will defend the the same principles and the same positions in the framework of the Security Council,'' he said. France's Foreign Ministry said today that French diplomats would leave their besieged embassy in Kuwait and return to Paris along with about 300 freed French hostages. After the invasion, Iraq ordered embassies in Kuwait to close down and move their diplomats to Baghdad. A few foreign missions in Kuwait, including that of the United States, are still holding out. ``I express the joy of all the French people to those coming home,'' Mitterrand said. ``But we will rejoice fully only when the other hostages can return to their own countries.'' Mitterrand and Gorbachev spoke to reporters after signing a cooperation agreement pledging French assistance as the Soviet Union shifts to a market economy. France also promised to help Moscow arrange accords with the 12-nation European Community as a step toward creation of a pan-European confederation. The presidents signed the accord at the chateau of Rambouillet, 33 miles southwest of Paris, following private talks on the gulf and other issues. Gorbachev arrived Sunday evening after a three-day visit to Spain, where he secured $1.5 billion in guaranteed loans to help ease the transition away from a centralized economy.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Kill Suit Against Texas City in `Cruising' Crackdown
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to kill a civil rights lawsuit against a Texas city that cracked down on ``cruising'' teen-agers five years ago. The court, without comment, left intact a ruling that forces DeSoto, Texas, and nine members of its police department to defend themselves at trial against allegations of illegal arrests. In the early 1980s, DeSoto's Hampton Road became a popular cruising spot on weekend and summer nights for teen-agers from Tarrant, Dallas and Ellis counties. On those nights, hundreds of vehicles would drive up and down the road and hundreds of teens would congregate in business parking lots. There was some vandalism, but the biggest problem was litter. Evictions, warnings by police, distribution of leaflets and speeches about trespass laws had little effect. On the night of May 3, 1985, DeSoto police accompanied by Dallas County sheriff's deputies and constables descended on several parking lots and arrested about 50 people. Six arrested teens sued the city and nine police department members in federal court. The suit, seeking monetary damages, alleged the teens' civil rights had been violated by illegal police arrests. A federal judge threw out the suit, ruling that the city and its police department were entitled to a qualified immunity from being sued. But the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals reinstated the suit last May. In a biting opinion, the appeals court said the case should proceed to trial. ``No doubt some of the arrestees had received prior warnings and deserved little sympathy for what happened to them that evening,'' the appeals court said. ``The same cannot be said for everyone. Take, for example, the girls on the Grand Prairie softball team.'' The appeals court noted that four high school girls from Grand Prairie in DeSoto for the first time to play in a softball tournament had pulled into a parking lot two minutes before the police sweep began. The girls, who cooperated at all times with police and other authorities, were arrested, handcuffed and forced to spend the night in jail. ``It did not stop there,'' the 5th Circuit court wrote. ``The (trespass) charges were taken up by the criminal district attorney of Dallas County. To prove how resolute that office is against the forces of crime, these girls were indicted ... and prosecuted vigorously in criminal court. ``When matters finally reached the hands of sensible people, the jurors, the girls were acquitted,'' the appeals court said. ``After three trials ended in acquittals, the remaining indictments were dismissed.'' Two of those girls - Kathy Kuehler and Lisa Blair Bishop - are among the six who sued. The others who sued are Douglas Morgan, Kerry Curby, Troy Hall and Jeffrey Escue. In the appeal acted on today, lawyers for DeSoto argued that the city and police should be immune from being sued over events stemming from the cruising crackdown. The case is DeSoto vs. Morgan, 90-393.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING FOR ALL NEEDING
Surviving Year One
PART II: Pregnant and Addicted
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Originally transmitted for Mondy AMs as b0360-b0361 of Oct. 23; Eleonore in 4th graf is cq.
With LaserPhoto, AP Graphic, Series Logo
DOC.TEXT: Few people face greater stigma than a pregnant woman burdened by drug addiction. But as Midwest Regional Reporter Sharon Cohen finds in the second of a three-part series, ``Surviving Year One,'' few drug addicts get less help in battling their habits. ---

Wanda Kaigler is having her seventh baby and this time, she has a new goal in life - to become a mother again, and a drug addict no more. She wants to start over, to break free of the crack, heroin, pills and weed that consumed her for 21 years and robbed her of everything precious: her health, her pride, even her six children. ``All I ever wanted was to get married and have kids and take care of them,'' she says quietly. ``I got married, I got kids. He died. The kids got taken. And I'm a drug addict.'' She's working to change that at the Eleonore Hutzel Recovery Center, one of a few comprehensive programs in the nation providing medical care, counseling and housing for pregnant and other addicted women. ``I know that if I can keep drugs out of my system, I can keep the baby,'' she says. ``There's still a chance I can get my kids back - maybe.'' ``I want to give up on myself but I know I can't,'' she adds tearfully. ``I want to be drug free and I know I can do it. ... Sometimes, I don't know how to go about it.'' For most pregnant addicts in America, the problem isn't how, but where. Public drug treatment programs, in short supply nationwide, are rarer still for these women, experts say. Traditionally, most are designed for men. ``It's three strikes against you,'' said Ruth Hudicek, head of Chrysalis House, a residential substance abuse program in Maryland. ``The first is you're an addict. The second strike is you're a female. If a female addict happens to be pregnant, in the eyes of most of the country, you're at the bottom of the heap.'' In fact, some proecutors, citing concerns for the children, have charged pregnant drug users with crimes, sometimes jailing them. Since 1987, more than 50 criminal cases have been filed against women for drug abuse during pregnancy, about 80 percent of them minorities, the American Civil Liberties Union says. Civil libertarians argue that this drives addicts away from prenatal care. ``Prosecutors are telling them to get clean or be arrested and they'll take away their kids,'' said the ACLU's Isabelle Pinzler. ``There aren't the places for drug treatment and the places that exist frequently won't take them.'' ``It forces them to make a Sophie's choice - either getting healthy or abandoning the child in foster care or a dysfunctional family from which they themselves came,'' said her colleague, Lynn Paltrow. More than 5 million women of childbearing age use illegal drugs, including more than 1 million who take cocaine, the National Institute on Drug Abuse said in 1988. Up to 375,000 babies may be exposed to drugs annually, according to the National Association for Perinatal Addiction Research and Education. While those numbers indicate the scope of a problem exacerbated by the crack epidemic, others suggest glaring inadequacies in treatment. Consider: -Some 280,000 pregnant women nationwide needed drug treatment, yet less than 30,000 received care, according to a 1990 survey by the National Association of State Alcohol and Drug Abuse Directors. -Two-thirds of 18 big-city hospitals surveyed last year by a U.S. House committee had no place to send pregnant women for drug treatment. -A New York study found 54 percent of treatment programs excluded expectant women; 87 percent rejected pregnant Medicaid recipients addicted to crack. ``They think there will be a terrible malpractice problem,'' because of potential pregnancy complications, speculates Dr. Wendy Chavkin, the author and an associate professor at the Columbia School of Public Health. All of this is especially frustrating, experts say, because pregnancy often motivates women to seek help. ``If they don't find a program out there, chances are we've lost them,'' Mrs. Hudicek said. ``Some die. Some end up in hospital emergency rooms giving birth to crack-addicted babies.'' ``Part of the American way is motherhood and apple pie,'' she added. ``The stigma that women face ... admitting they're addicted to drugs is incredible.'' Cynthia, a Chrysalis House resident and new mother, knows the feeling. ``You already have low self-esteem,'' said the recovering cocaine-heroin addict, who asked that her last name not be used. ``Finally you do humble yourself to say ... `I have a problem,' and there's a bunch of excuses. ... They say, `We can't help you now. Come back in 30 days.' You may die, you may get incarcerated.'' Or you may get sick. Cocaine, doctors say, increases the risk of premature delivery and life-threatening hemorrhages and can cause physical and neurological damage to babies. Pregnant addicts often ignore their health. One Michigan woman said it was easier to walk four houses to buy crack than take a bus four miles for prenatal care. Others sell furniture, food stamps, even themselves for drugs. About 180 addicts are in Hutzel's 21-year-old program; about half are pregnant and 50 percent of those women take methadone to prevent miscarriages. Hutzel provides counseling, child care, lunch, transportation and prenatal care. The residential recovery program houses women and their young children in a former convent. Many have long histories of addiction. Wanda Kaigler, now 37, says her drug use began at age 16. She nearly died six years ago from bad heroin, and though she survived and even quit once, her habit has stripped her bare. ``It makes you lose your friends, your family, your furniture, your home, your respect for yourself,'' she said. ``You feel terrible afterwards. As long as you do it, you feel good.'' A widow for three years, Miss Kaigler also lost her six children, ages 2 to 17, when they were removed by authorities. She wants them back, proudly noting two are honors students. ``I love my kids,'' she said. ``They don't think so. Sometimes, I don't think so.'' Kelly Barrington's concern for her baby, coupled with the threat of losing her 9-year-old daughter, led her to Hutzel. ``God knew the only way I was going to stop is if I got pregnant,'' said Miss Barrington, a drug abuser for 15 of her 31 years who switched to crack from heroin after her veins collapsed. ``I couldn't live with the fact that I hurt an innocent baby.'' She, too, had hit bottom. She was jailed briefly, lost everything and was so desperate she'd drag her daughter to dope houses, explaining she was sick and ``that was the medicine I needed.'' Her daughter responded by repeatedly breaking her crack pipes. ``I try to forgive myself and say I was a sick person,'' said Miss Barrington, her purse adorned with badges for every month she has been drug-free. ``I feel great that God gave me another chance to turn things around.''

DOC.HEAD: DETROIT: things around.''
DOC.TEXT: Eighty percent to 85 percent of the women complete Hutzel's pregnancy program, which serves about 250 females a year. About a quarter continue in recovery, but more than half of those who inquire never show up. Some fear prosecutions will deter even more. A Massachusetts judge this month threw out an indictment charging a 24-year-old mother with drug distribution for cocaine found in her infant son. ``By imposing criminal sanctions, a woman may turn away from seeking prenatal care for fear of being discovered, thereby undermining the state's asserted interests,'' Boston Superior Court Judge Suzanne V. DelVecchio said in her ruling. But some prosecutors say they must help the children - even if means charging and jailing pregnant women. ``Innocent children are horribly damaged by the use of cocaine. If that's not child abuse, I don't know what is,'' said Charles Condon, a South Carolina solicitor who helps run a program in which pregnant users must enroll in treatment or risk arrest. ``We don't want them to be prosecuted,'' he said, but ``you really have to give them consequences for their behavior.'' At Hutzel, Wanda Kaigler knows all about consequences. But she plans to stay clean and dreams of living with her kids ``away from drugs.'' ``Anything you have faith in and believe in,'' she said, ``you can have.''

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Scores in Georgian Election
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Non-Communist parties won elections in Georgia on a platform calling for independence from the Soviet Union, private ownership of land and a capitalist economy, officials said Monday. ``We are certainly going to have a majority in parliament,'' said Zviad Gamsakhurdia, leader of the victorious Round Table-Free Georgia bloc of political parties. With about 90 percent of the regions reporting, Gamsakhurdia claimed victory in about 70 percent. He protested what he called ``gross violations'' of the election law and said Communist authorities ``terrorized the non-Georgian population'' along the borders of the mountainous southern republic, which is dotted with pockets of Azerbaijani and other ethnic groups. A member of the central election commission, Alexander Kobalia, said that preliminary results showed a slightly less sweeping victory for Gamsakhurdia's Round Table, with the bloc winning about 60 percent of the vote versus 30 percent for the Communist Party. The final results will be ready on Wednesday, and a runoff will be held for close races on Nov. 11, he said. No date has been set yet for convening the Georgian Supreme Soviet legislature, which is expected to declare independence from the Soviet Union. Among the 15 Soviet republics, all but Kirgizia have declared some form of sovereignty or independence. Gamsakhurdia said he was unable to specify what his first proposal would be in parliament. ``I can't decide that alone,'' said Gamsakhurdia, an imposing 51-year-old with a history of arrests and opposition to Communist rule dating back to the 1950s. Another Round Table spokesman, Georgi Makaridze, said the victory would translate into about 120 seats in the 250-member Supreme Soviet. ``Along with other non-Communist parties, we will have a working majority in parliament,'' Makaridze said. In a weekend interview, Gamsakhurdia predicted that Georgia's transition to independence would take about two years, and that the republic would maintain extensive economic relations with the Soviet Union. It also seemed likely that Georgia would rely on the Soviet Union in national security matters. About 35 parties, most grouped by coalition, took part in Sunday's election, the first true multiparty vote in Soviet history. Non-Communists have won elections in several cities and republics elsewhere in the Soviet Union, but the Georgian balloting was the first in which formal parties, created under new Soviet laws, were listed on the ballot. Some politicians boycotted the election, claiming it was not democratic. One of them, the leader of the National Democratic Party, Gia Chanturia, was shot in the arm Friday as he left a political meeting. Two National Democratic Party members, Gia Kobakhedze and Irakli Tsereteli, spoke on Georgian television and accused Gamsakhurdia of organizing the shooting on orders from Soviet authorities. Gamsakhurdia denied responsibility for the shooting, and accused authorities in an interview Sunday of trying to sabotage the election by not telling people where to vote. Under a complicated election system, each voter was given two ballots, one listing individual candidates and the other listing political parties and blocs. Half the members of the legislature were to be chosen from the lists of individual candidates to represent various districts. The rest were to be chosen at large, in proportion to the number of votes cast for each party or bloc throughout Georgia. Under the republic's election law, a party must get at least 4 percent of the republic-wide vote to gain representation in the legislature. That was a provision designed to encourage coalitions and large parties, and to discourage splintering into small factions.

DOC.HEAD: Time-Zone Activists Want to Make Winter Brighter
DOC.TEXT: The harsh cold of a Chicago winter is bad enough, but seeing the sun go down before you even get off work makes it worse. The { Hour Time Zone Lobby says it's found a way to make winter a little brighter. The solution is splitting the wide Central Standard Time zone in half, and moving up the clock - effectively delaying sunset - by half an hour in Chicago and the rest of the zone's eastern portion, says Ken Peterson, the group's leader. ``Chicago hasn't recognized that it's at a severe disadvantage,'' said Peterson, a 49-year-old architect from the suburb of Forest Park. The sun sets an hour earlier for Chicagoans, on the eastern edge of the zone, than for residents of Bismarck, N.D., at the western edge. Combine that with the shorter days of winter and the end of daylight-savings time, and Chicagoans don't need sunglasses after work. ``It all goes back to why do people hate Chicago in the winter,'' Peterson said. ``We hate it because it's dark when we go home. ``Rush hour is bad enough. But when it's dark, it's really bad. Then, when you add sleet, snow and hail, it's a real downer.'' Under the lobbying group's plan, when it's 5 p.m. in Bismarck, it would already be 5:30 p.m. in Chicago and workers would have had a chance to see the sun after leaving the office. The group says that extra dose of sunlight might be enough to help cure winter doldrums. The group placed an ad in a newspaper this week asking for public feedback on their proposal. Peterson, who began organizing the group this month, knows some might scoff at his solution, but he's standing by his principles. ``People can label me a loony and the idea may go nowhere,'' he said. ``But people have a right to know they can have more sunlight in the afternoon.''

DOC.HEAD: Turn Off the Jukebox, Church Services Are About To Start
LaserPhoto upcoming
DOC.TEXT: The preacher wears jeans and a western shirt. The worshipers sit on bar stools. The offering plate is a cowboy hat. It's the Nashville Cowboy Church, which holds services in a hotel lounge. Harry Yates, 47, the minister-founder of the church, says cowboys attended church services in saloons, so since late September he's been preaching every Sunday in the hotel lounge. ``We've been called a few names here and there about meeting in the bar and dressing the way we do,'' Yates said. ``I seem to remember that Jesus was called a wine bibber. I think we're in good company. We're supposed to preach the gospel everywhere.'' Yates' clerical garb for the non-denominational service is jeans, western shirt, bolo tie and cowboy hat - the collection plate. ``We're not doctrinal, and I just preach a short message, 15 or 20 minutes,'' he said. Yates, ordained in the Independent Assemblies of God, doesn't rail against drinking and carousing and the like. ``We don't preach against things. We just preach the gospel of Jesus Christ.'' A couple of guitar players supply the music. When services are over, worshipers get $2 off the price of brunch at the hotel restaurant. ``It's an incentive,'' Yates said. Attendance has averaged more than 30 even though the church is just getting started. Roughly half are tourists, many of whom spent the night before listening to cry-in-your-beer country music at the Grand Ole Opry three miles down the road. ``Tourists come to town and don't bring suits and ties,'' Yates said. ``At our services, you can dress any way you like. We're trying to take away excuses for not going to church.'' Bob Darmos, a manager for a Nashville trash company, has been attending the church regularly. ``I was skeptical at first, going to a saloon and being so casual. But you can relax, be yourself and worship. It puts you in the right frame of mind.'' ``I can go in a shirt and jeans and no one looks down his nose at me,'' he said. ``The pastor is dressed the same way I am. There are no false airs.''

DOC.HEAD: Sacramento Merger Would Create Seventh-Largest City
DOC.TEXT: Voters could turn this tranquil capital into the nation's seventh-largest city if they approve a plan to merge with the county. If approved Nov. 6 by county voters, the proposal would create a sprawling, 1,000-square mile city with a population estimated at 1.04 million - slightly more populous than Dallas and a shade less than San Diego. The nation's 10 largest cities would be New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, Houston, Philadelphia, San Diego, Sacramento, Dallas, Detroit, and San Antonio. Sacramento County, which includes the city, has grown by 32 percent during the past decade, from a population of 786,000 in 1980 to 1.04 million this year. The city alone has about 350,000 residents. But while many here relish the thought of putting this city once known largely for its politicians and hot summers on the map - and in top-10 lists - they disagree sharply over the merger's economic merits. Consolidation has been rejected twice by Sacramento County voters, most recently in 1974. Surveys this time show opinion closely divided. Several other cities have merged with counties, including Portland, Ore., Nashville, Tenn., and Minneapolis. Modern-day San Francisco is the product of merger accomplished in 1856. Proponents, including environmental, business and good-government groups, say the merger would allow the county to get a handle on runaway growth and development and make possible more efficient, centralized decision-making. ``The idea behind it is to create a more efficient provider of services,'' said Paul Hahn, deputy executive director of a local government commission appointed two years ago to study the issue. ``Right now, there is a lot of duplication of effort - two police departments, two public works departments, a police and sheriff's department. They don't always coordinate with each other,'' he said. Foes of the plan include independent developers and those who have led efforts in recent years to incorporate new cities in fast-growing Sacramento County. Sacramento City Councilman Tom Chinn argues that the plan ``would add another 100 politicians to the county'' and probably would lead to higher taxes. Creating a new city would force the removal of about 125 California Highway Patrol officers from area roads, he said. Highway officers are charged by law with patrolling state and county highways, but not city streets. The merger would combine fire, law enforcement and planning agencies and create a new 12-member Council of Supervisors - 11 members elected by district, plus the mayor. Twenty local town councils also would be created, each with five elected members, with land-use powers over local projects. Exempted from the new government would be three of the county's four current incorporated cities: Folsom with 26,000 people, Galt with 7,500 and Isleton with 925. A streamlined merger would save about $20 million annually. The county's current budget is about $1 billion; the city's is about a third of that. Hahn, citing a hired consultant's report, said the merger could result in the loss of about 400 of 7,000 full-time city-county positions. But the losses would occur through attrition,not by layoffs, during the first two to three years, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Stranded Tourists Wait for Ferries off Islands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with traffic today, ADD background on islands; Picks up 10th graf pvs., `Some of ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XNAG1
DOC.TEXT: Tempers flared as tourists stranded on North Carolina's Outer Banks by a bridge collapse waited in a 600-car backup for ferry rides back to the mainland. By late this morning, about 275 cars were left. Volunteers eased the tension early today by handing out snacks and blankets to motorists waiting in the dark in 40-degree weather. ``People in the community have brought God knows how many sandwiches, and coffee and spiced tea and such,'' said Julia O'Neal, who works in the Ocracoke Island ferry office. ``It means a lot when you've got something hot in your hand.'' Lines which had stretched up to six miles Sunday from the jumping off point on Ocracoke Island dwindled to 275 cars today. Officials expected to empty Ocracoke of outbound traffic late today. While tourists groused about long lines, some natives complained that visitors were using up gasoline and other supplies. Relief efforts got into full swing Sunday, with the National Guard flying in 1,500 meals. Other emergency supplies, including fuel, water, blankets and food, were brought onto Hatteras Island, which has 5,000 permanent residents. Hatteras and Ocracoke islands were cut off from the mainland Friday when a dredge, dragging an anchor in heavy winds and waves, rammed the Herbert C. Bonner Bridge over Oregon Inlet. A 370-foot section of the 2{-mile span collapsed. About 8,000 people live on the two islands. State Sen. Marc Basnight said Sunday that the bridge may be repaired in 45 working days. Officials earlier estimated the work would take at least six months. Four ferries, capable of moving 150 cars every six hours, are the only means off the two islands. People have had to take one ferry for the mile trip to Ocracoke Island, then another 30 miles to the mainland. The complete trip takes about 3{ hours. Some of those who rushed to the Ocracoke-bound ferries did not realize they did not go straight to the mainland. ``How can we get to the governor about this?'' Dorothy L. Salmon of Greensboro. ``They should have told us on Hatteras we were going to be here all night. There's diabetics out there with no sweets. There's babies with no blankets.'' Robert Ashwell, a visitor from Virginia, was disgusted that so many cars were allowed onto Ocracoke, considering the limited capacity of the ferries. ``It doesn't take upper-level math to figure this out,'' he said. Generators were hooked up Sunday on Hatteras, providing limited electricity to three island towns. The accident also knocked out telephone service. Officials encouraged those waiting in line to return to the Hatteras shelter, which has power from a generator, hot food and Red Cross workers. About 1,000 Hatteras residents held a meeting Sunday. One speaker was frustrated by vacationers wanting precious gasoline to run four-wheel-drive vehicles on the beach. His request that tourists get off the island was met with applause. Ted S. Midgett, co-owner of the Midgett Bros. Service Station in Hatteras Village, said tourists were limited to $10 worth of gasoline at his pumps. Still, he expected to run out shortly and did not know when or how his next shipment would arrive. Residents of the tourism-dependent islands also worried about the exodus. R. Stewart Couch, general manager of Hatteras Realty, said residents really wanted the tourists gone only until things were back to normal. ``We need to get our house in order,'' he said. ``Then we will invite them back.''

DOC.HEAD: Spilled Catfish Cargo Salvaged by Food Bank
DOC.TEXT: A food bank salvaged at least a ton of frozen catfish that spilled after a refrigerated truck crashed. ``It's a blessing,'' said Joyce Rothermel, executive director of the Greater Pittsburgh Community Food Bank. ``Donations that are high in protein, like fish, are very rare.'' The driver, Tim Cardwell, 28, of Marianna, Ark., told police his foot slipped off the brake pedal Sunday and hit the accelerator. The truck slammed into a wall of an overpass above Point State Park. The cab came to rest beside the wall, but the truneration of those born in Cuba but raised for the most part in the United States. Others include pop music star Gloria Estefan, actor Steven Bauer, Oakland A's slugger Jose Canseco, Miami Mayor Suarez, Florida Democratic Party chairman Simon Ferro and Marty Urra, head of the South Florida AFL-CIO. The young Cuban-Americans sometimes call themselves ``yucas.'' That stands for Young Upscale Cuban-Americans and is a takeoff on the potato-like yucca that is a staple of Cuban diets. They often move in and out of mainstream American life and personal lives that emphasize their native culture. They usually describe themselves as patriotic toward both Cuba and the United States. State Sen. Lincoln Diaz-Balart, 36, spends much of his day speaking English in the Legislature or his Coconut Grove law firm, but tries to speak only Spanish at home to his children, ages 5 and 7. Many afternoons find him slipping away at lunchtime to meet one or more of his three brothers - they include a banker, a state representative and the weekend anchor on a leading English-language television station - at La Hacienda restaurant for the day's special, always with fried bananas and black beans over rice. ``I never actually separated being a Cuban-American from being American,'' Diaz-Balart says. ``I was always proud of my roots, proud of Cuba. And I was always proud of the United States, the land of freedom and hope.'' Diaz-Balart's first name evinces the affinity Cubans long have had for the United States, which intervened in the Cuba's war for independence that exiles smilingly note is called ``the Spanish-American War'' in U.S. history. He is eager to help rebuild a Cuba he says has been devastated by his uncle. Castro was married to Diaz-Balart's aunt and Castro's son, Fidelito, is a first cousin. ``Diaz-Balart says very few Cubans would move back to Cuba permanently after three decades here. However, many will be involved in a post-Castro Cuba. ``There's going to be a lot of duality,'' Suarez says, with Cuba only 90 miles from Florida's southern tip. ``There will be people with homes in both places, investments in both places ... trade, tourism. A lot of people are going to feel very comfortable here but also want to spend part of the time there.'' Castro has vowed to maintain his system in Cuba, but excitement over his potential downfall is as high here as perhaps anytime since before the failed U.S.-backed Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961. Around Miami there is a new sign: ``Christmas in Cuba.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Expected Before Nov. 19; Gorbachev Visit Still Up In The Air
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is expected in Germany sometime before Nov. 19 but plans for a visit by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev are still up in the air, the government said Monday. Government spokesman Norbert Schaefer said it had originally been ``assumed'' that Gorbachev would visit Germany Nov. 4-6. He said, however, ``there is still no confirmation by the Soviet side.'' Carrying out complex plans for a Gorbachev visit could be difficult at this late date, but there were no indications the trip might be called off. Schaefer said Bush is expected in Germany sometime before the Nov. 19-21 Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which is to be held in Paris. Schaefer said it would be a ``short, private visit'' and would likely take place at Chancellor Helmut Kohl's home in Oggersheim, and not in Bonn.

DOC.HEAD: Sailors Earn College Credits While Protecting Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Sailors aboard U.S. ships and submarines in the Persian Gulf are shooting for college credits in the midst of the military standoff, poring over textbooks and videotapes in the middle of the night while keeping an eye on Iraq, Nearly 200 combat-ready officers and sailors aboard at least five surface ships and several submarines are enrolled in courses ranging from English and economics to physics and psychology. For most, it's their first college experience. Sailors have special work areas aboard the ships where they operate computer videos they can use for course tutors, for ``homework'' assignments with feedback and for quizzes to test comprehension. Textbooks and study guides are used, too. Optional materials include audiocassettes and anthologies. ``The key thing is that when there are fairly stressful operational kinds of requirements - such as the gulf, where the available free time is likely to be limited to bits and pieces throughout the day - it works very well,'' said Bruce Wilburn, president of Middlesex Research Center, which developed the software for the program. ``We find that the most popular time to study is from midnight to 4 a.m.,'' he said. ``They all stand watches and that is the watch with the least going on.'' College credits can be earned at George Washington University in the nation's capital and the University of Oklahoma in Norman, Okla., which helped develop the curriculum along with Coastline Community College in California. Wilburn said the program has produced outstanding results in other ombat-ready situations, and expectations are high for the sailors in the gulf. George Washington University professor Michael Bradley, who helped develop the economics course, said, ``I think on the average these people are more motivated because they are self selected.'' ``They only take this because they want to, whereas a typical college freshman takes it because its required or parents told them they had to take economics.'' Bradley said the materials are similar to those used in regular classes ``with the exception that these are just a little bit more real world oriented.'' For example, Bradley said an economics video on ``supply and demand'' may include interviews with farmers or others as illustrations. Classes aboard ship begin when the sailors leave port. With most ships deployed for six-month intervals, Navy personnel are able to take classes for two semesters. ``On submarines, when the hatch closes the class starts and when they open the hatches, the sailors should be done,'' said Wilburn. Fifty percent of those taking telecourses are sailors ages 19 to 20 who have been in the Navy for one to two years. The other 50 percent primarily are career Navy officers and upper-level enlisted men. The Annenberg-CPB program, created by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting with a gift in 1981 from the Annenberg School of Communications, has five telecourses used by the Navy. They are ``Economics U$A, The New Literacy, The Write Course, Mechanical Universe and Planet Earth. Other groups offer about 25 other college courses, including English, mathematics - including trigonometry, pre-calculus and calculus - physics, geography, political science, Spanish, economics, business and history. Psychology is the most popular course, said Wilburn. The sailors pay for the books, while the Navy provides the equipment and software and pays the school fees that range from under $200 per semester to as much as $500. When the program first began, Wilburn said the completion rate was around 50 percent. Officials have since tightened eligibility requirements and now estimate the courses have an 81 percent completion rate. The average grade is ``C plus,'' he said. ``These courses are not easy and require a lot of time and effort to complete. The key to their success has been the commitment of each ship's highest officers to the value of a college education for his personnel,'' said Annenberg director Mara Mayor. Since 1987, more than 4,000 enlisted U.S. Naval personnel on as many as 70 surface ships, aircraft carriers, and submarines have enrolled in telecourses. Courses currently are available on more than 220 U.S. Navy ship deployments out of four Atlantic Coast ports, including Norfolk, Va.; Charleston, S.C.; Groton, Conn. and Kings Bay, Ga.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Inductees For Rock Hall Of Fame Announced
DOC.TEXT: The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame today announced 10 inductees, including the Byrds, Ike and Tina Turner and Wilson Pickett. They will be inducted Jan. 16 in New York, where the first five induction ceremonies have been held. More than $40 million has been raised for the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum in Cleveland but construction has not begun. The inductees in the artists category are: - La Vern Baker, best known for a string of pop and rhythm and blues hits in the 1950s and 1960s. - The Byrds, a popular group of the 1960s that had such hits as `Mr. Tambourine Man'' and ``Eight Miles High.'' - John Lee Hooker, an influential guitarist. - The Impressions, whose songs included ``Gypsy Woman'' and ``People Get Ready.'' - Wilson Pickett, who recorded ``In the Midnight Hour.'' - Jimmy Reed, whose song ``Baby What You Want Me to Do,'' was recorded by Elvis Presley. - Ike and Tina Turner, best remembered for the remake of ``Proud Mary.'' In the early-influences category, the single inductee is Howlin' Wolf, who died in 1976. Wolf wrote ``Sitting on Top of the World,'' popularized by the group Cream. Producers Dave Bartholomew and Ralph Bass will be inducted in the non-performing category. Bartholomew headed the New Orleans Rhythm and Blues Explosion in the 1950s. He discovered Fats Domino and co-wrote many of his hits. Bass discovered James Brown and helped to start the Platters on their career.

DOC.HEAD: Stangeland Re-Election Bid Going Down to Wire
With AM-Minnesota Governor, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: No one's betting the farm on Republican Rep. Arlan Stangeland's political career. Not after the budget problems in Washington and the questions about his late-night phone calls to a Virginia woman. Stangeland, a burly 60-year-old ex-farmer, is asking voters for a seventh full term against a backdrop of scandal, anti-incumbent fervor, Depression-era grain prices and shrinking federal farm subsidies. But the GOP congressman has been a study in resilience. And his challenger, accountant Collin Peterson, is short on money, disliked by many in his own Democratic party and has lost to Stangeland twice before. ``This is a race that you won't know the outcome until the votes are counted,'' Stangeland said. Polls show the race is a dead heat even though Stangeland won re-election two years ago by a reasonably comfortable majority - 55 percent. That was before jokes about Stangeland started making the rounds of 7th District coffee shops. The St. Cloud Times reported in January that Stangeland used his congressional credit card to pay for 428 long-distance calls to and from a Virginia woman's home. Some of the calls were made early in the morning and late at night. Some people took to calling Stangeland ``Adam.'' The Virginia woman's first name is Eve. Stangeland, a married father of seven who campaigns as a protector of family values, denied any impropriety. But Democratic leaders filed a complaint with the House ethics committee and the issue dogs the campaign. And now Stangeland has an added worry: Voters turned off by the state's gubernatorial campaign may stay away from the polls. Republican Jon Grunseth was running neck and neck with Gov. Rudy Perpich until allegations surfaced that he swam nude with some teen-age girls nine years ago. Grunseth dropped out of the race on Sunday and the state GOP is in a tumult about picking a successor to challenge Perpich. ``A light voter turnout ... will hurt,'' Stangeland said. Peterson, 46, says he has no plans to raise the issue of Stangeland's late-night phone calls. He has problems of his own stemming from his previous races for Stangeland's seat. Peterson lost the 1986 election by 121 votes, but proclaimed himself congressman-elect, demanded a recount, prepared to open a temporary office in Washington and went through freshman orientation. After the six-week recount was completed, Stangeland's victory stood. Peterson irked his party again in 1988 when he announced he would challenge the endorsed candidate. ``You don't run three times without causing some problems,'' Peterson said. ``Somebody's always going to be unhappy with you.'' For 13 years, Stangeland has had solid support from area farmers, who have made the fertile Red River Valley into one of the most prosperous agricultural regions in the country. But Peterson has pounded away at Stangeland's poor environmental record and hopes to take advantage of farm angst over depressed wheat prices and the congressional budget cuts. The deficit-reduction package assembled by Congress reduces farm spending by 25 percent over the next five years. The price of wheat already is down a dollar a bushel this fall, while the black Red River Valley soil is bone dry after three years of drought. Peterson favors a less marke-oriented farm policy that would count on increased export subsidies and higher price supports. Stangeland has devoted much of his legislative energy to protecting the government's sugar and dairy programs and he hopes to retain strong support from farmers despite the coming cutbacks in the farm payments.

DOC.HEAD: Underdog Democrat Seeks Boost From GOP Rival's Abortion Gaffe
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Ron Twilegar can thank his GOP rival for helping reintroduce abortion as an issue in Idaho's sleepy U.S. Senate race. Twilegar, the underdog in the race, began running ads critical of Rep. Larry Craig's opposition to abortion after the congressman gave a puzzling response in a debate two weeks ago. Craig seemed to change his position when asked if he would ask his wife, Suzanne, to carry a pregnancy to term if it resulted from rape or incest, even if she wanted to have an abortion. ``That would be a very, very tough choice,'' Craig replied. ``I have said this is a personal issue. ... But I will tell you my wife is my wife, but she is also an individual, and I have never blocked her decisions or her right to make decisions. I think that is very important for her and her ability to handle it.'' Twilegar, who entered the race to give voters a pro-choice option, applauded Craig for what he called ``a change of his mind for the better.'' ``So how about it, Congressman Craig,'' Twilegar asked. ``Is Suzanne Craig the only woman in America who gets a choice?'' Right to Life leaders expressed immediate alarm at Craig's comments, wanting to know ``what in the world he's talking about,'' and Craig quickly initiated damage control. Three telephone conversations between Washington and Idaho convinced anti-abortion leaders to issue a statement reaffirming their support for Craig. The congressman blamed ``headline writers'' for the controversy and refused to elaborate on a statement saying he had not changed his position. Craig and Twilegar are vying for the Senate seat being vacated by GOP Sen. James McClure, who is retiring. The debate flap prompted Twilegar to start airing TV ads stressing the congressman's position on abortion. ``We didn't put abortion back into the news and the voters' minds,'' said Twilegar campaign manager Richard Callow. ``Congressman Craig did. He made them think, and we're reminding them that they do.'' Twilegar's ad accuses Craig of wanting to return American women to the days of illegal, life-threatening back-alley abortions. It shows a woman walking toward an alley door, followed by a conveyor belt of coat hangers. However, it appears the ad may have generated more opposition than support for Twilegar among Idaho voters. Abortion put Idaho in the national spotlight last March when state lawmakers approved what would have been the nation's most restrictive state abortion law. The measure was vetoed by Democratic Gov. Cecil Andrus. Within a few weeks, the issue had cooled and abortion became a relatively minor factor in the 1990 campaign. Twilegar's abortion ad was among several his campaign had completed just prior to the debate but he hadn't decided which ones the cash-short campaign would put on the air. ``Congressman Craig's debate performance made our decision very easy,'' Callow said. ``What we're concentrating on is the extremism. ... We'll let the force of Craig's denial that he has changed his mind serve as the power for our ad.''

DOC.HEAD: Radical Iranian Daily Critical Of Saudi Envoy's Visit
DOC.TEXT: A senior Saudi envoy's visit to Iran indicates Tehran and Riyadh may be close to re-establishing ties cut when hundreds of Iranian pilgrims were slain in Mecca in 1988, Tehran sources said Monday. The Saudi deputy foreign minister's arrival Friday, in the first Saudi official visit since ties were severed, caps weeks of efforts by Riyad to narrow the rift with Iran, the sources said. The Saudis cut their ties with Iran in the closing stages of the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war, in which they bankrolled Baghdad's war effort. Now they are in a confrontation with Baghdad over Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The invasion Aug. 2 has accelerated efforts by both Saudi and Iranian moderates to end the rift. Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani wants to end his country's isolation by improving ties the West and his Arab neighbors. His hard-line opponents oppose that but lately have been unable to change Rafsanjani's policies. Riyadh, seeking to cement the coalition against Iraq, has in recent weeks been wooing Iran, urging it to tone down its anti-Saudi rhetoric. Last month, Iran resumed ties with Britain after an 18-month break, despite objections by the anti-Western hardliners. Iran's state radio and television, run by Rafsanjani's brother, Mohammed Hashemi, have given the visit of the Saudi envoy, Abdul-Rahman Mansuri, little coverage. But the Farsi-language Jomhuri Islami daily, close to the hard-line opposition, asked Monday: ``What is Saudi Arabia's purpose in its recent move and what is it after?'' Jomhuri Islami's commentary was carried by Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency and was monitored in Nicosia. The daily stressed Riyadh would have to meet two conditions before a resumption of diplomatic relations - remove the U.S.-dominated multinational force and allow Iranian pilgrims to stage political rallies at Moslem shrines in Saudi Arabia. The Saudis requested the multinational force to defend the kingdom after Iraq invaded Kuwait. The presence of the Western forces in Saudi Arabia, the paper said, ``is similar to the military occupation of Kuwait by Iraq, and is even worse.'' The daily also demanded that Iranian Moslems on the annual pilgrimage to the Saudi cities of Mecca and Medina, Islam's holiest shrines, be allowed to stage political demonstrations. The Iranians have insisted that staging protests demonstrating ``antipathy towards pagans,'' is a cornerstone of the hajj, or pilgrimage. The Saudis, who consider the pilgrimage a purely religious rite, have banned political demonstrations. Riyadh's decision to sever ties with Tehran came after more than 400 pilgrims, most of them Iranians, were killed in a clash in 1988 with Saudi security forces. The Saudis say the trouble was instigated by the Iranians, and cut off ties with Tehran, citing terrorism and subversion. Tehran accused the Saudis of deliberately killing Iranian pilgrims.

DOC.HEAD: CBS to Honor William S. Paley, Its Founder, With One-Hour Special
DOC.TEXT: CBS will recall some of its greatest moments with a one-hour special broadcast on William S. Paley, who built up CBS from a small chain of radio stations into a giant communications company, the network said Monday. Paley, 89, died Friday. The special, ``William S. Paley: Tribute to a Broadcasting Giant'' will be anchored by Dan Rather and will include reports by Walter Cronkite, Charles Kuralt and Morley Safer. The Wednesday night special will preempt the regularly scheduled broadcast of ``48 Hours.''

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Mayor Appeals for Japanese Loans to Support Perestroika
DOC.TEXT: Moscow Mayor Gavril Popov appealed Monday for Japanese loans to help the Soviet capital convert its state businesses into private enterprises. Moscow plans to begin the shift to private ownership by allowing its residents to own their own homes, but the mayor said foreign loans would be used mostly to support ``parts of the economy directly governed by the Moscow city government,'' such as the retail distribution system. Only shops deemed healthy enough to succeed in repaying the loans would receive the aid, said Popov, a radical economist who quit the Communist Party in July. He spoke at the Foreign Correspondents Club of Japan. Popov said the economic reform plan adopted this month by the Soviet legislature would fail, threatening the future of democratic forces in the Soviet Union. The plan calls for such steps as encouraging small private business and ending many state monopolies. Popov predicted the Soviet leadership would adopt more radical free market measures if the plan does not take hold within a few months. He said he might ``passively resist'' the conservative restructuring program and carry out a more radical economic program in his city. He said he would not ask foreigners to extend loans directly to his city. Loans should go through the central government, but with their recipients and use clearly specified, he said. Popov joined others in the Soviet Union in calling for Japan to extend economic aid before resolving the issue of several disputed islands. The group of islands stretching north from Hokkaido was seized by Soviet troops in the final days of World War II. The dispute has kept Tokyo and Moscow from signing a peace treaty and has curtailed Japanese investment in the Soviet Union. ``As far as I know, the Russian federation is ready to begin negotiations,'' he said. Earlier this month, Japanese media reported that a Soviet official suggested to a senior Japanese politician that Moscow might return two islands. Moscow later denied the story. Popov said he is in Japan on vacation, but has met with Tokyo government officials to discuss establishing a sister city relationship.

DOC.HEAD: Lottery Ticket Left As Bar Tip Produces $25,000
DOC.TEXT: Keith Thomlinson is used to getting pretty decent tips as a bartender at a restaurant near the Newport beaches, but it took a little luck to earn a $25,000 gratuity. Russell Clark, a frequent patron at the Greenhouse Inn and Restaurant just off Newport's First Beach, left Thomlinson an instant lottery ticket as a tip Wednesday. When Thomlinson finally got around to scratching off the numbers on the instant ``Baseball'' game, he discovered he had won the $25,000 grand prize. After about $5,000 in federal taxes and $1,200 for the state, he carried home nearly $19,000. ``It sat there for almost two days until I scrubbed it off,'' Thomlinson said Monday. ``I was just shocked.'' Thomlinson, 42, shared his good fortune. He gave $1,800 to Clark and $5,000 to his parents, Raymond and Marguerite of Detroit. ``She's going to pay bills,'' Thomlinson said of his mother. ``Dad's retired. They don't have a real big pension.'' Clark said he probably would use his $1,800 to buy more lottery tickets. He said he likes to leave more than just a cash tip at restuarants, and often gives candy, flowers or lottery tickets. ``It's just something I do,'' he said. But Clark, 60, does have some second thoughts. ``If I figured I would be passing out $25,000, I might d NICOSIA, Cyprus - The visit to Iran by a senior Saudi envoy indicates that Tehran and Riyadh may be close to re-establishing ties cut when hundreds of Iranian pilgrims were shot down in Mecca in 1988, Tehran sources said Monday. DOC.HEAD: GLOBAL WARMING: GENEVA - A United Nations conference on global warming opened Monday, and a top U.N. official warned that only radical changes can save the world from a climate disaster. AM-Global Warming.
DOC.TEXT: The AP

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
French Hostages Leave for Home; U.N. Adopts Another Anti-Iraq Measure
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines urgents series, UPDATES with French Foreign Ministry now saying more than 260 French people on the flight, including French diplomats.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY8
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi Airways jetliner carrying more than 260 French citizens left Baghdad for Paris today on a flight that ended their grueling hostage ordeal. At nearly the same time, the U.N. Security Council overwhelmingly approved a resolution demanding that Iraq make reparations for the suffering that has occurred as a result of its invasion and occupation of Kuwait. The resolution holds Iraq liable for human rights abuses, war damages and economic losses caused by its military aggression. The measure also demands that Baghdad allow food, water and other supplies to be sent into the Western diplomatic missions in Kuwait, which are besieged by Iraqi guards. Thirteen nations voted for the resolution in New York, the 10th since the invasion on Aug. 2. Cuba and Yemen abstained. Regarding the hostages, the French Foreign Ministry said in Paris that the Boeing 747 departed Baghdad at about 12:30 p.m. EST and would be in the French capital by midnight local time if all went smoothly. The ministry also said French diplomats had been ordered to pull out of their embassy in Kuwait, where they had endured siege-like conditions for weeks. The seven diplomats were aboard the jetliner when it flew into Baghdad from Kuwait with more than 50 freed hostages. That group was joined by about 210 French citizens waiting at the Baghdad airport. The plane also carried nine Greeks, four Britons, two Filipinos, one German and one Spanish citizen freed by Iraq, according to a witness at the airport. More than 60 French citizens believed to be in Iraq and Kuwait were not aboard the plane. Western diplomats said some may have left on their own and others chose to stay behind. ``I can say now that all French citizens who wanted to go home have gone home,'' French charge d'affaires Andre Janier said in Baghdad. Daniel Bernard, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, confirmed France will honor Iraq's demand to fill the plane with a cargo of medicine for the return flight. Medicine is excluded from the U.N. embargo of Iraq and occupied Kuwait. President Francois Mitterrand of France cautioned against celebration as long as hundreds of Westerners remain captive in Iraq and Kuwait. ``I express the joy of all the French people to those coming home,'' Mitterrand said. ``But we will rejoice fully only when the other hostages can return to their own countries.'' Mitterrand spoke at a news conference outside Paris with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev after the signing of a Franco-Soviet cooperation treaty. Gorbachev said Iraqi President Saddam Hussein should not to expect a split in the international alliance opposed to Iraq's Aug. 2 seizure of Kuwait. ``We must not permit the Iraqi regime to hope there will be a division, a weakening of positions,'' Gorbachev said. He called Iraq's use of hostages ``amoral.'' The Soviet leader urged sanctions against Iraq be stepped up and said the time was right for Arab nations to embark on a new initiative to resolve the crisis, possibly under Saudi leadership. ``It seems to me that the Iraqis could be ready for this,'' Gorbachev said. ``If we were to have an inter-Arab meeting, this would be the quickest way to a settlement.'' Gorbachev said he had received a telegram from his envoy, Yevgeny Primakov, indicating after a visit to Baghdad and a meeting with Saddam that there were some shifts in Saddam's positions. The Soviet leader did not elaborate. Earlier, the Soviet foreign minister said Primakov's talks were cause for ``little reason for optimism.'' Saddam told Cable News Network today that he had a ``wide-ranging, deep and very useful'' dialogue with Primakov. The Iraqi president said it would be incorrect to assume nothing was accomplished in his talks with Primakov. Oil prices shot up more than $1 per barrel in New York today because of trader's concern that Primakov had made little progress. Some traders said, however, that they were waiting to hear Saddam's remarks on CNN. Saddam is holding hundreds of foreigners as ``human shields'' at strategic sites in Iraq to deter possible attack. Although he has allowed selected groups of the thousands of foreigners to leave, many others are being held. European Community leaders meeting in Rome pledged not to send representatives to try to win freedom for hostages held in Iraq and occupied Kuwait, reasoning that to do so would only support Saddam's efforts to try to divide the alliance arrayed against him. The decision followed a trip to Baghdad by former British Prime Minister Edward Heath, who helped secure the release of more than 30 British hostages. France, the United States and Britain have been the only Western countries to maintain embassies in Kuwait since Iraq overran the emirate. In August, Iraq cut off water and electricity to all embassies that defied its orders to close. France had been considering withdrawing its diplomats from Kuwait for several weeks because of the extremely arduous living conditions under Iraqi occupation. It had refrained from doing so to allow the diplomats to support the French hostages in Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Foreigners Still In Crisis Zone
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a breakdown of the number of foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait as of Monday. Most estimates are based on embassy registrations. Some 600 U.S., British, West German citizens and other nationals are being held in Iraq and Kuwait as human shields at some 30 strategic targets. An estimated 2,000 Westerners are hiding in Kuwait. According to State Department figures, more than 900,000 of the estimated 3 million foreigners who were in Kuwait and Iraq on Aug. 2 have left. Most of the remaining 2 million are expected to try to leave. Some foreigners, mostly women married to Iraqis or Kuwaitis, have elected to stay. Some governments or independent figures have negotiated the release of their nationals. --- AUSTRALIA - Before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, 127 Australians were in the two countries. There are now 44 in Iraq and 50 in Kuwait. --- AUSTRIA - Before Aug. 2, 70 Austrians were in Iran and the same number in Iraq. One remains in Kuwait and 3 or 4 in Iraq, all of Arab background. --- BANGLADESH - About 110,000 Bangladeshis were in Kuwait and Iraq when the invasion occurred. About 15,000 remain, including 2,000 reported to be working as ``forced labor'' at Iraqi military camps in Kuwait. --- BELGIUM - Before the crisis 38 Belgians were in Iraq and 21 in Kuwait. Now 38 remain in Iraq, 5 in Kuwait. --- BULGARIA - There are 690 Bulgarians in Iraq and Kuwait and 430 are expected to be allowed to leave soon. The pre-invasion figure is not known. --- BRAZIL - There were 450 Brazilians in Iraq and Kuwait on Aug. 2. Eleven have chosen to stay in Iraq. --- BRITAIN - Before the invasion there were about 3,000 Britons in Kuwait and 1,000 in Iraq. About 650 remain in Kuwait, mostly in hiding, and about 850 in Iraq. Some 340 are held as human shields in Iraq and 70 in Kuwait. --- CANADA - Of the 800 Canadians in Iraq and Kuwait before the invasion, about 50 remain in Kuwait and 50 in Iraq. --- CHINA - About 10,000 Chinese were in Iraq and Kuwait before the invasion. About 5,000 have been evacuated. --- CYPRUS - Thirty-five Cypriots were in Iraq and Kuwait before Aug. 2. Twenty remain voluntarily. --- CZECHOSLOVAKIA - Of the 470 Czechoslovaks in Iraq and Kuwait Aug. 2, only six women married to Kuwaitis remain in Kuwait. About 60 Czechoslovaks remain in Iraq. --- DENMARK - Some 35 Danes remain voluntarily in Kuwait, with 35 in Iraq. About 100 were there Aug. 2. --- EGYPT - Some 363,000 Egyptians have left Iraq and Kuwait, out of more than 1.3 million in Iraq and 300,000 in Kuwait before the invasion. --- FINLAND - There were 23 Finns in Iraq and 23 in Kuwait. Thirteen remain in Iraq and two in Kuwait. --- FRANCE - Before the invasion, there were 270 French citizens in Kuwait and 290 in Iraq. Some 100 remain in Kuwait and about 230 in Iraq, including 70 who had been held as human shields. Saddam has said he will free all French hostages, and hundreds of them left Monday on a plane to Paris. --- GERMANY - Of the pre-invasion total of 1,000 in Iraq and Kuwait, some 400 remain in Iraq, including about 75 held at strategic locations, with 13 still in Kuwait. --- GREECE - About 127 Greeks were Kuwait and Iraq. Twenty-four were in Iraq as of Monday, although the Greek government said 10 left on a flight later that day. --- HUNGARY - There were 178 Hungarians in Kuwait and Iraq. Thirty-two remain in Iraq, with none in Kuwait. --- INDIA - An estimated 16,000-18,000 remain in Kuwait with 6,000 in Iraq, from a pre-invasion total of 190,000. --- IRELAND - About 220 Irish citizens, mostly nurses, are in Iraq, and 34 in Kuwait. The pre-invasion total was 380. --- ITALY - About 160 Italians were in Kuwait and 380 in Iraq. Some 300 remain in Iraq and six in Kuwait. --- JAPAN - About 790 Japanese were in Kuwait and Iraq at the time of the invasion and 305 are still in Iraq, 139 as human shields, and eight in Kuwait. --- LEBANON - Of the estimated 50,000 Lebanese in pre-invasion Kuwait, about 5,000 have left. --- NETHERLANDS - Two hundred Dutch nationals were in Iraq and Kuwait. Now 164 remain in Iraq, with 5 in Kuwait. --- NEW ZEALAND - Seven New Zealanders remain in Iraq and 11 in Kuwait out of a combined pre-invasion total of 36. --- NORWAY - One Norwegian remains in Kuwait and 26 in Iraq, out of a pre-invasion total of 46. --- PAKISTAN - About 130,000 Pakistanis were in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion, and some 90,000 remain. --- PHILIPPINES - About 90,000 Filipinos were in Kuwait and 3,000 in Iraq. Some 2,300 remain in Iraq, with an estimated 2,000-3,000 in Kuwait. --- POLAND - There were 3,123 Poles in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion, and 1,213 remain in Iraq, mainly workers fulfilling project contracts. --- PORTUGAL - About 40 Portuguese have left Kuwait and Iraq, mostly masons who had been working on Saddam Hussein's palace in Baghdad. Eight to 10 remain in Iraq. --- ROMANIA - About 640 Romanians remain out of a pre-invasion total of 3,055. --- SOUTH KOREA - About 1,327 South Koreans were in Kuwait and Iraq, with 140 left in Iraq and 9 in Kuwait. --- SOVIET UNION - Nearly 10,000 Soviets were in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion. About 3,000 remain in Iraq, mostly oil workers and construction specialists and 206 military advisers. There are none in Kuwait. --- SPAIN - Six diplomats remain in Iraq, of a pre-invasion total of 183 Spaniards in Kuwait and Iraq. --- SRI LANKA - About 150,000 Sri Lankans were in Kuwait and Iraq. Some 65,000 remain in Kuwait. There are 125 in Iraq. --- SWEDEN - Out of a pre-invasion total of about 200, only a handful remain in Kuwait, with about 90 in Iraq. --- SWITZERLAND - Before the invasion, there were 97 Swiss nationals in Kuwait and 71 in Iraq. None remain in Kuwait and about 80 in Iraq. --- THAILAND - There were 7,000 Thais in Kuwait and some 1,150 in Iraq before Aug. 2, with 874 still in Iraq and 20 in Kuwait. --- TURKEY - There were 3,000 Turks in Iraq and 1,000 in Kuwait. Almost all have returned home, leaving about 60 in Iraq and about 40 in Kuwait, mostly women married to Kuwaitis. --- UNITED STATES - Of the pre-invasion total of about 3,500 Americans in Iraq and Kuwait, around 600 remain in hiding or are held in Kuwait and around 330 in Iraq, including 104 men held as human shields. --- VENEZUELA - There were 38 Venezuelans in Kuwait and Iraq. Twenty-eight remain. --- VIETNAM - An estimated 17,000 Vietnamese were in Iraq. About 1,000 have left and others are trying to get out. There are no figures available for Kuwait. --- YUGOSLAVIA - There were some 9,000 Yugoslavs in Iraq and about 1,000 in Kuwait. Some 1,000 remain in Iraq and 300 in Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: New Outbreak of Faction Fighting, Terror Charges Against ANC Members
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-six blacks were killed in weekend factional fighting that erupted after a month of relative calm in black areas, police said Monday. Also, nine African National Congress members were charged with terrorism and the illegal possession of weapons in a case that could further strain relations between the government and the black opposition movement. One of the nine, Mac Maharaj, is on the ANC's national executive committee and also is a top official in the closely allied South African Communist Party. The nine, all in detention since July, were not asked to plead at the Durban Regional Court. They have accused police of torture and threatening them with death. The worst weekend violence was in the Soweto township outside Johannesburg, where 16 people were killed and 33 wounded in a spate of attacks Sunday night, said police Col. Tienie Halgryn. Police said the violence may have been in revenge for attacks Saturday in Soweto on supporters of the Inkatha Freedom Party. One man was killed and two were injured. Fighting between Zulu supporters of Inkatha other blacks tied to the ANC has claimed almost 800 lives in the Johannesburg area during August and September. There have been only sporadic incidents this month. Police said they did not know if any of the dead and wounded were connected to the ANC. Halgryn said it appeared gunmen had gone on a random revenge spree after the Inkatha supporters were attacked. Police said Monday an unidentified man, allegedly a member of the ANC youth wing, had been arrested in the killing of the Inkatha supporter. The killings came after thousands of Inkatha supporters, many carrying spears, clubs and shields, paraded through central Johannesburg on Saturday. The marchers presented a petition to police accusing security forces of working against Inkatha. The ANC has accused police of assisting Inkatha. The ANC and Inkatha both oppose the apartheid system of racial segregation, but are divided over tactics and plans for a future South Africa. The white-led government and the ANC have been holding periodic peace talks since May, but both sides have been accusing one other of acting in bad faith. Many of the charges and counter-charges have focused on the township violence and the detention of ANC members such as Maharaj. Police also said Monday that weekend faction fighting between rival Xhosas and Sothos at a gold mine in the Orange Free State left nine workers dead and 42 injured. The fighting broke out at a workers hostel Saturday night at Rand Mines' Harmony Gold Mine in Virginia, 160 miles southwest of Johannesburg, and continued into Sunday, the company said. The mine was reported quiet Monday as management officials talked to the rival groups. Police said mine officials did not know what sparked the fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Storms Damage Former Imperial Capital; Ancient Carvings Found
DOC.TEXT: A series of tropical storms has seriously damaged ancient palaces and temples in Hue, the former imperial capital of Vietnam, the official Vietnam News Agency reported. Another report by the news agency said Monday that archaeologists had discovered a site containing ancient stone carvings in the northern province of Hoang Lien Son. It was the first time Vietnamese archaeologists had come across a site of such significance, it said. The carvings included pastoral scenes and human figures and bore traces of ancient writing in the form of pictographs, according to the report. In Hue, the storms blew the roofs off palaces and temples, said a report dated Wednesday and seen in Bangkok on Monday. It said the Noon Gate, the Thai Hoa Court hall, the Thai and The temples, the Cien Tho Palace, and royal tombs were damaged. It also said about two dozen bridges in the temple complex were destroyed or damaged. Hue, an ancient town of temples and palaces, was rebuilt by the emperor Gia Long in the 19th century to replicate the Forbidden City in Beijing, where his Chinese patron ruled. The city was heavily damaged by artillery and air attacks during the Vietnam War.

DOC.HEAD: Country's Oldest Newspaper `on the Verge of Collapse'
DOC.TEXT: The oldest newspaper in the country, El Dia, published an edition of only eight pages Monday and told readers it is on the verge of collapse. The 104-year-old paper began to slide economically a decade ago when the military government in power then ruled it must pay the same taxes as other businesses. Recently, El Dia has suffered labor problems. Last month, it was shut down four days by a strike. ``We don't know how much longer'' the 15,000-circulation paper will continue to publish, an article stated. ``Today we find ourselves on the verge of collapse.'' Many Uruguayan papers are hurting from the nation's economic problems, but El Dia, firmly tied to the centrist Colorado Party, seems to be hit the hardest. El Dia was founded by the man who would twice be elected president and become one Uruguay's best-known and best-loved politicians, Jose Batlle y Ordonez.

DOC.HEAD: `Peter Pan' Star in Hospital for Tests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf to CORRECT last name of Gaynor's husband to Gregory sted Gardner
DOC.TEXT: Actress Mary Martin, who starred in such musicals as ``Peter Pan,'' ``The Sound of Music'' and ``South Pacific,'' has been hospitalized for tests, a spokesman said Monday. Richard Grant, publicist for Miss Martin's son, actor Larry Hagman, refused to say where the actress was hospitalized or the reason for the tests. ``Miss Martin has been in the hospital for tests. That is all I will confirm,'' Grant said. ``In this case we just don't choose to give out information.'' Miss Martin became a star of New York theater with her 1938 appearance in the musical ``Leave It to Me.'' She also played nurse Nellie Forbush in ``South Pacific'' and Maria in a Broadway version of ``The Sound of Music.'' She first played Peter Pan on Broadway in 1954. Miss Martin was seriously injured in a 1982 taxi-van collision that left her manager, Ben Washer, dead. Actress Janet Gaynor and her husband, producer Paul Gregory, were severely injured in the crash.

DOC.HEAD: Conference Considers Ban on Toxic Ocean Dumping; US Wants More Study
DOC.TEXT: Delegates from more than 60 nations met Monday to debate a proposed global ban on the ocean dumping of toxic industrial waste. But the United States intends to seek further study before agreeing to a ban. The proposal from Denmark, Iceland, Finland, Norway and Sweden calls for industrial dumping at sea to be phased by out 1995. It will be debated Tuesday by the nations at the meeting, signatories to the London Dumping Convention, or LDC. The 20-year-old convention regulates the hauling of industrial waste to sea on ships. The so-called Nordic proposal calls for such dumping to be stopped and to do so without increasing pollution to other parts of the environment and without exporting waste to other countries that have not signed the treaty. The proposal asks signatory nations to encourage and promote cleaner industrial processes, recycling, the treatment of waste on land and more research and development on alternative and environmentally sound means of waste disposal. The five-day London meeting will be closely watched by governments, industry and environmentalists because the group is the only international body dealing with marine pollution. If it can reach consensus on the current agenda, it will bode well for future negotations on broader, more complex marine issues such as land-based pollution of the sea. Most regulation of ocean pollution is carried out by individual nations or by regional groups. As the problem of seaborne pollution has increased, so have calls for a coordinated global response. Delegates will consider whether to expand the scope of the current treaty by beginning work on a new global convention on marine pollution. About 80 percent of ocean pollution is generated on land, with 10 percent coming from industrial waste disposal and the rest thrown or discharged from ships. The leader of the U.S. delegation, Robert Reinstein, said more study was needed before the United States could support the ban. Reinstein is deputy assistant secretary of state for environment, health and natural resources. ``We just want to look at all the options and assess them on their merits,'' he said. Britain, Ireland, Canada, Japan, France and Switzerland also have expressed reservations about the ban. Environmentalists accuse the United States of foot dragging and of taking a position in international negotiations contrary to U.S. domestic law. In 1988, Congress passed the Ocean Dumping Ban Act prohibiting the ocean disposal of any industrial or municipal waste. The legislation also forbade ocean-based incineration and set deadlines for a number of East Coast cities to stop dumping municipal sewage. The U.S. law is one of strictest in the world on ocean dumping of toxic waste. ``The State Department idea seems to be to keep the options open for future dumping in case domestic law can one day be changed,'' said Clifton Curtis, an observer at the meeting from the Glands, Switzerland-based International Union for the Conservation of Nature. He spoke before the conference opened. Reinstein defended the decision to call for more study. ``Our general postion on several aspects of waste disposal is that we want a good scientific basis ... for the decisions we take, not as a way of delaying decisions on an environmental threat, but just as a general principle.''

DOC.HEAD: Khmer Rouge Guerrillas Claim They Seized District Capital
DOC.TEXT: Khmer Rouge guerrillas claimed Monday they had seized a district capital in western Cambodia. The guerrillas overran the district seat of Svay Leu in Siem Reap province on Friday, the guerrilla radio said. The guerrilla faction of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, which is allied with the Khmer Rouge, said Friday its forces began attacking Svay Leu two days earlier and killed 11 government troops. Vietnam installed the Phnom Penh government after invading Cambodia in 1978 and ousting the Khmer Rouge. Thailand backs the guerrillas and is the main conduit for the arms reaching them. The Khmer Rouge is the largest of the guerrilla factions. It was responsible for the deaths of hundreds of thousands of Cambodians during its 3{-year rule starting in 1975. According to Western intelligence sources and guerrilla commanders, the Khmer Rouge was recently supplied with 24 tanks by its main backer, China, and planned to use them in attacks on Siem Reap. The radio did not say if tanks were used at Svay Leu. The capital of Siem Reap province, also called Siem Reap, is some 150 miles northwest of the national capital, Phnom Penh.
