Recent efforts to end the war have failed because the factions have been unable to agree on the leadership of a council intended to represent the country's sovereignty under a U.N. peace plan. In Bangkok on Monday, Thai Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan discussed the war with Vietnam's Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Boat Latest Seized For Poaching Off Indonesia
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese boat has been seized for alleged illegal fishing off Indonesia's easternmost province, the latest in series of foreign vessels captured by authorities, an official report said Monday. The Shiyo Maru No. 51, with a crew of 10, was seized 15 miles offshore from Irian Jaya province, the Antara news agency quoted Maj. L. Simandjuntak of the regional police command as saying. The ship was carrying about 15 tons of tuna, Simandjuntak said. It was captured Friday near Manokwari, about 1,850 miles northeast of Jakarta, the capital. Recent reports said local authorities in the country's northernmost province of Aceh have captured at least 10 Thai fishing boats with 96 crew members. The 96 Thais have been detained in a prison in East Aceh, pending further investigation.

DOC.HEAD: First Lady Speaks On Senator's Behalf at Fund-Raiser
LaserPhotos PD1
DOC.TEXT: First lady Barbara Bush on Monday came to the aid of embattled Sen. Mark Hatfield, saying his work has brought millions of federal dollars to Oregon. While Hatfield was speaking, two hecklers were hustled out of the Hilton Hotel ballroom by security guards. The protesters, who shouted about homosexual rights, were charged with trespass and one was charged with disorderly conduct, said police spokesman Dave Simpson. Mrs. Bush urged more than 1,100 people who attended the $100-a-plate breakfast to do whatever they could to ensure that Hatfield is elected to a fifth term. ``Make that extra phone call, ring that extra doorbell and stuff that extra envelope,'' she said. The first lady said Hatfield, as the ranking Republican on the Senate Appropriations Committee, has helped bring millions of federal dollars to Oregon for such projects as the Hatfield Marine Science Center at Newport. The Republican senator is locked in a tight race against Democrat Harry Lonsdale, a Bend businessman who has attacked Hatfield as a Washington insider who's beholden to special interests.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Babies Experiments Halted After WHO Probe
DOC.TEXT: The Health Ministry has halted controversial experiments being conducted on 83 babies infected with the AIDS virus, hospital officials said Monday. The decision followed an investigation by a commission from the World Health Organization, which visited last week to look into the research conducted by a five-man British team. The team, led by David Hughes, had been administering periodic injections of an experimental AIDS drug called FLV23/a to the patients at Bucharest's Colentina Hospital since September, with Health Ministry approval. Although the WHO commission's conclusions were not made public, they were presented to the Health Ministry at the end of last week and the ministry decided to halt the experiments, the officials said. They asked not to be named. Word that the experiment had been halted was preceded by a Health Ministry statement. ``The data from the clinical trial ... are not sufficient to determine the safety or efficacy of FLV23/a,'' the statement said. The hospital officials said the next series of injections, scheduled for Tuesday, would not be administered. This was confirmed by British volunteers also working at the hospital. No comment was available from Hughes or members of his team. Sice the December revolution that ousted Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, some 800 babies have been diagnosed nationwide as having the disease that kills by attacking the body's immune system. Ceausescu was obsessed with increasing Romania's population of 23 million and forbade abortions and birth control. Tens of thousands of mostly unwanted babies were left at state institutions, where some contracted AIDS through blood transfusions. Newborns were often given blood transfusions in Romania in the belief it would make them stronger. Needles were in short supply and routinely used hundreds of times. Some of the mothers whose babies were undergoing the experiments said Monday they opposed stopping them. ``I want the experiments to continue,'' Daniela Dumitrescu said in an interview. ``My child is feeling well, he has stopped vomiting and has gained weight.'' Doctors at the hospital said that none of the babies had died since the beginning of the injections, while several died before. British Embassy sources said the British Foreign Office sent Romanian authorities a telex last month warning them against Hughes. The sources said Hughes, who arrived in Romania some five months ago, was ordered by the Malawi authorities to leave that country after conducting similar experiments there. They suggested that Hughes, who is not a medical doctor, had been seeking Romanian approval for his drug, which would have made it easier to sell internationally. After suspending the treatment in September, the Romanian Drug Commission decided to approve it again earlier this month despite the warnings.

DOC.NOTE: For Release at 3:30 p.m. EDT ^With PM-Bush
DOC.HEAD: Baker Warns Iraq on Use of Chemical, Biological Weapons
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said today Iraq would suffer ``the most severe consequences'' if President Saddam Hussein decides to use chemical or biological weapons. Baker said said while the United States is exhausting every diplomatic avenue to achieve a peaceful solution, no option has been exluded. ``Let no one doubt: We will not rule out a possible use of force if Iraq continues to occupy Kuwait,'' Baker said. ``Saddam Hussein's way is not the way of peace. His is a prescription for war. And I will say this bluntly: If his way of doing business prevails, there will be no hope of peace in the area,'' Baker said. His remarks were prepared for delivery to the Los Angeles World Affairs Council. He said U.S. military forces have been sent to the Persian Gulf region to provide an ``effective and decisive military response'' if the situation warrants it. ``Saddam Hussein must realize there is a limit to the international community's patience. He must also realize that should he use chemical or biological weapons, there will be the most severe consequences,'' Baker said. Baker also said that conflicts in the Middle East have profound consequences far beyond that region. ``There can be no hope of resolving other problems in the region unless peaceful change becomes the wave of the future in the Middle East and the gulf,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Recommending Ways to Save Energy
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Carry maps. Get into the bathtub faster. These, and some more commonplace suggestions, are among ways the government is encouraging Japanese to save energy this winter. If the Persian Gulf crisis worsens, the government will consider adopting stronger measures to save oil. In the meantime, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry has adopted guidelines that encourage stores to reduce the hours they stay open and suggest that homes and offices be no warmer than 68 degrees Fahrenheit. The ministry also advised residents to drive less, and said they could save gasoline by avoiding quick stops and starts. Carry maps, the ministry urged, and avoid getting lost. In Japan, the nightly bath is an institution, with a large tub filled to the brim and used in turn by the whole family. The ministry's conservation guidelines advise Japanese to jump into the tub shortly after drawing the water so it will have to be reheated less often.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Meet With Congressional Leaders About Gulf Buildup
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 8-9 EMBARGOED for use at 3:30 p.m. EST - to UPDATE with Baker comments
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he would not hesitate to use force in the Persian Gulf if provoked. ``History is replete with examples when the president had to take action'' without consulting Congress, he added. Bush said he would meet Tuesday with congressional leaders about the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf, a deployment that could expand while Congress is adjourned. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney raised the possibility last week that up to 100,000 more American troops could be added to the U.S. presence in the region. Some lawmakers have raised concerns about dramatic changes being made in the U.S. deployment without their input. ``I'm looking forward to having talks with members of the leadership tomorrow,'' Bush told reporters. ``But history is replete with examples when the president would have to take action. I've done this in the past, and certainly - somebody mentioned provocations - we'd have no hesitancy at all'' he said. Bush ordered U.S. forces into Panama last December when Congress was out of town. Asked if he was trying to prepare the country for war, Bush said, ``I'm just doing my job as president of the United States. I'm not preparing anybody for anything.'' But he also said, ``I am as determined as I ever have been that this aggression will not stand.'' ``We have a lot of troops there, they are well-trained and they are highly motivated. That alone is sending a strong message to Saddam Hussein,'' Bush said.
DOC.HEAD: Following 2 grafs embargoed for 3:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III, meanwhile, said today Iraq would suffer ``the most severe consequences'' if President Saddam Hussein decides to use chemical or biological weapons. Baker, in remarks prepared for delivery to the Los Angeles World Affairs Council, said other problems in the Mideast can only be resolved through peaceful change. ``But Saddam Hussein's way is not the way of peace,'' Baker said. ``His is a prescription for war. And I will say this bluntly: If his way of doing business prevails, there will be no hope of peace in the area.''
DOC.HEAD: End embargoed material
DOC.TEXT: Bush also described the infighting over the budget approved last weekend as ``class warfare.'' ``This class warfare, taxing the rich, is really an attack on the working people of America,'' he said. Bush made appearances today on behalf of Sen. Pete Wilson, whose neck-and-neck gubernatorial bid against Democrat Dianne Feinstein is the Republican Party's top state priority in next week's elections. Bush has visited the state several times to stump for Wilson. After attending a breakfast for Wilson at a private residence, Bush later today headed to Oklahoma to campaign for GOP gubernatorial candidate Bill Price at the Cowboy Hall of Fame. The president arrived in San Francisco after a weekend in Honolulu where he also did some politicking, met with Pacific Island leaders and spoke to large crowd of military personnel and families at Hickam Air Force Base. Referring to Iraq's Aug. 2 military invasion of Kuwait, Bush said, ``Today in the Persian Gulf, what we are looking at is good and evil, right and wrong ... The invasion of Kuwait will not stand.'' With U.S. troop strength at more than 200,000 and still growing in the Persian Gulf region, Bush promised, ``No American will be kept in the Gulf a single day longer than necessary. But we will not walk away until our mission is done.'' Bush told his audience that he empathizes with their worries. ``Those in uniform will always bear the heaviest burden. Perhaps I know something of what you endure. The waiting, the uncertainty, the demands of family and professional life. We want every single American home,'' he said. Bush said Iraq ``waged a war of aggression, plundered a peaceful neighbor, held innocents hostage and gassed its own people.'' Those acts are punishable under 1945 war crimes principles, Bush said, raising anew the specter of holding Iraqi President Saddam Hussein accountable to some international forum. ``We're standing up for civilized values,'' he said. At Hickam, located next to Pearl Harbor, Bush said he was reminded of his own World War II tour of duty in the Pacific. ``No member of that generation can ever forget the clarion call that Pearl Harbor represented,'' the president said. ``Things changed instantly. The country came together. And like you here today, we each knew our duty.'' While Sunday's speech was to a military audience, Bush also has been calling for solidarity behind his Persian Gulf policy in his campaign appearances around the country. Bush's coast-to-coast traveling comes as a Newsweek poll out this weekend showed a dramatic plunge in the public's approval rating for his job performance. The drop coincides with public worries over the worsening economy and Washington's sluggish attempts to deal with it. Lengthy wrangling over a deficit reduction pact finally concluded over the weekend with Congress approving a budget deal while Bush was in Hawaii. The president promised to sign it. After arriving in San Francisco Sunday night, Bush signed a stopgap spending bill to keep the government operating through Nov. 5. He will use the intervening days to review the various appropriations bills Congress has passed for spending in specific categories, Bush spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Bush tonight was to return to a capital emptied of lawmakers who went home to campaign.

DOC.HEAD: New York to Boston Train is on Fast Track
DOC.TEXT: Amtrak has initiated a faster passenger train between Boston and New York, the New England Express, that is intended to make the 230-mile trip in under four hours. The first trip Sunday almost met the mark. The Express left Boston's South Station at 11:15 a.m. and arrived at Penn Station in Manhattan at 3:18 p.m., eight minutes late, for an average speed of 57 mph, including stops. ``Not bad for a first try,'' said Clifford Black, an Amtrak spokesman. The trip has taken about four hours and 40 minutes in the past, for an average speed of about 45 mph. By comparison, Japan's ``bullet'' trains travel at about 130 mph, and France's high-speed trains hit about 200 mph. Both have exclusive use of all-new tracks. Amtrak officials have saved some time on all lines by making track and bridge repairs. The New England Express, scheduled for 12 trips a week each way, also skips some stops included in other rides. To shorten the ride even more, Amtrak officials want to electrify the entire Boston to New York route. At present, the route is electrified only from New York to New Haven, Conn., where trains must switch from diesel to electric power, or vice versa. Congress has proposed spending $125 million to begin work on electrifying the entire line. Amtrak officials estimate the cost of completing the job will be about $400 million. The ultimate time goal is a trip under three hours. The New England Express requires reservations, but the fare remains the same as other scheduled service: $90 round trip for coach and $154 for first class. Amtrak currently serves about 2 million passengers a year between New York and Washington, D.C., on a faster, all-electric line, on which the fastest combination of tracks has an average speed of 90 mph. Train officials believe there is an even bigger market for the Boston-New York route. ``It is one of the biggest business travel corridors in the country,'' Black said.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Official Urges Steps To Curb Global Warming
DOC.TEXT: The top U.N. environment official on Monday urged immediate steps by industrialized countries to curb global warming, saying delay will only worsen a disaster looming over future generations. Mostafa K. Tolba, head of the U.N. Environment Program, said a ``complete change in attitudes and lifestyles'' is needed to avert a danger ``potentially more catastrophic than any other threat in human history.'' A decade of research has made clear that only drastic reductions in emissions of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping ``greenhouse gases'' will stop warming of the planet, Tolba told the opening of a U.N. climate conference. He said ``large gaps in our knowledge'' about the phenomenon should not be an excuse for inaction. About 500 scientists attending the 10-day conference are expected to draft a new program proposing ways to fight the so-called greenhouse effect. A final meeting of about 80 ministers is expected to draw several heads of government, including Margaret Thatcher of Britain and France's Michel Rocard. The United States, still opposed to binding emission cuts, has sent a lower-level delegation. The conference is supposed to launch formal negotiations on an international convention against global warming, to be ready for signing by mid-1992. Ministers are expected to provide the basis for the talks in a final declaration Nov. 7. But Tolba said industrialized nations, which contribute three-quarters of all man-made greenhouse gases, must cut emissions even before a convention is in place. ``The longer we delay, the worse the disaster will be for our children, and for our children's children,'' he said. He said curbing emissions will be costly and require great changes in ``economic, legal and institutional systems.'' Developing countries would need more time and Western help. A conference report by more than 1,000 scientists from 70 countries outlines the climate upheaval likely if nothing is done: -Global temperatures could rise up to 5.4 degrees Fahrenheit by the end of the next century, the fastest rise in 10,000 years. -Sea levels may rise far enough to flood tens of thousands of miles of shoreline, sending millions of people fleeing inland. The U.N. Food and Agriculture Administration, in a position paper prepared for the conference, said the overall effect on global farming ``could be positive'' because arable lands may open up toward the poles. But ``the impact on some of today's vulnerable regions, like the Sahel, may be very serious,'' it added.

DOC.HEAD: Dukakis: Media May Be Too Hard on Bush's Drop in Polls
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis said Monday the media exaggerated the popularity of the man he ran against for president in 1988, but now may be too hard on President Bush as his popularity drops in the polls. Dukakis, whose own popularity in his home state is at a historic low, made it clear his sympathy for Bush didn't indicate a change of heart about the Republican president's domestic policies. ``I think part of the problem is that George Bush doesn't believe in much domestically,'' Dukakis told reporters. ``He's much more comfortable in foreign policy.'' But Dukakis said the media have made too much of Bush's popularity on both ends of the scale. `You guys exaggerated his popularity on the way up and you're now beating him over the head on the way down,'' Dukakis said. Dukakis said presidents and governors must be prepared sometimes to take actions that are unpopular. ``The sense I have these days is the White House takes a poll every night before they do anything. You just can't do that,'' Dukakis said. ``His popularity will probably drop some more. So what. So what. The question is are we doing the right thing, are we biting the bullet, are we dealing with these very difficult fiscal problems that have been in the making for the last 10 years?'' Newsweek magazine recently released the results of a poll by the Gallup Organization showing Bush had slipped to the lowest approval rating of his presidency. The poll showed 48 percent approved of Bush's handling of his job, down from 57 percent on Oct. 19.

DOC.HEAD: T-Bill Rates Down Again
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities fell in Monday's auction to their lowest level in more than two years. The Treasury Department sold $9.8 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.12 percent, down from 7.20 percent last week. Another $9.8 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.13 percent, down from 7.16 percent. The rates were the lowest since three-month bills sold for 7.05 percent on Aug. 15, 1988, and six-month bills averaged 7.09 percent on July 25, 1988. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors - 7.35 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,820.00, and 7.50 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,639.50. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 7.50 percent last week from 7.58 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Latest Anti-Iraq Resolution
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of Security Council Resolution 674 on Iraq's violations of international law, adopted on Monday.

The Security Council, Recalling its resolutions 660 (1990), 661 (1990), 662 (1990), 664 (1990), 665 (1990), 666 (1990), 667 (1990) and 670 (1990), Stressing the urgent need for the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of all Iraqi forces from Kuwait, for the restoration of Kuwait's sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity, and of the authority of its legitimate government, Condemning the actions by the Iraqi authorities and occupying forces to take third state nationals hostage and to mistreat and oppress Kuwaiti and third tate nationals, and the other actions reported to the Council such as the destruction of Kuwaiti demographic records, forced departure of Kuwaitis, and relocation of population in Kuwait and the unlawful destruction and seizure of public and private property in Kuwait including hospital supplies and equipment, in violation of the decisions of this Council, the Charter of the United Nations, the Fourth Geneva Convention, the Vienna Conventions on Diplomatic and Consular Relations and international law, Expressing grave alarm over the situation of third states in Kuwait and Iraq, including the personnel of the diplomatic and consular missions of such states, Reaffirming that the Fourth Geneva Convention applies to Kuwait and that as a High Contracting Party to the Convention Iraq is bound to comply fully with all its terms and in particular is liable under the Convention in respect of the grave breaches committed by it, as are individuals who commit or order the commission of grave breaches, Recalling the efforts of the Secretary-General concerning the safety and well being of third state nationals in Iraq and Kuwait, Deeply concerned at the economic cost, and at the loss and suffering caused to individuals in Kuwait and Iraq as a result of the invasion and occupation of Kuwait by Iraq, Acting under Chapter VII of the United Nations Charter, Reaffirming the goal of the international community of maintaining international peace and security by seeking to resolve international disputes and conflicts through peaceful means, Recalling also the important role that the United Nations and its Secretary-General have played in the peaceful solution of disputes and conflicts in conformity with the provisions of the United Nations Charter, Alarmed by the dangers of the present crisis caused by the Iraqi invasion and occupation of Kuwait, directly threatening international peace and security, and seeking to avoid any further worsening of the situation, Calling upon Iraq to comply with the relevant resolutions of the Security Council, in particular resolutions 660 (1990), 662 (1990) and 664 (1990), Reaffirming its determination to ensure compliance by Iraq with the Security Council resolutions by maximum use of political and diplomatic means, (A) 1. Demands that the Iraqi authorities and occupying forces immediately cease and desist from taking third state nationals hostage, and mistreating and oppressing Kuwaiti and third state nationals, and from any other actions such as those reported to the Council and described above, violating the decisions of this Council, the Charter of the United Nations, the Fourth Geneva Convention, the Vienna Conventions on Diplomatic and Consular Relations and international law; 2. Invites states to collate substantiated information in their possession or submitted to them on the grave breaches by Iraq as per paragraph 1 above and to make this information available to the Council; 3. Reaffirms its demand that Iraq immediately fulfill its obligations to third state nationals in Kuwait and Iraq, including the personnel of diplomatic and consular missions, under the Charter, the Fourth Geneva Convention, the Vienna Conventions on Diplomatic and Consular Relations, general principles of international law and relevant resolutions of the Council; 4. Reaffirms further its demand that Iraq permit and facilitate the immediate departure from Kuwait and Iraq of those third state nationals, including diplomatic and consular personnel, who wish to leave; 5. Demands that Iraq ensure the immediate access to food, water and basic services necessary to the protection and well being of Kuwaiti nationals and of nationals of third states in Kuwait and Iraq, including the personnel of diplomatic and consular missions in Kuwait; 6. Reaffirms its demand that Iraq immediately protect the safety and well being of diplomatic and consular personnel and premises in Kuwait and Iraq, take no action to hinder these diplomatic and consular missions in the performance of their functions, including access to their nationals and the protection of their person and interests and rescind its orders for the closure of diplomatic and consular missions in Kuwait and the withdrawal of the immunity of their personnel; 7. Requests the Secretary-General, in the context of the continued exercise of his good offices concerning the safety and well being of third state nationals in Iraq and Kuwait, to seek to achieve the objectives of paragraphs 4, 5, and 6 and in particular the provision of food, water and basic services to Kuwaiti nationals and to the diplomatic and consular missions in Kuwait and the evacuation of third state nationals; 8. Reminds Iraq that under international law it is liable for any loss, damage or injury arising in regard to Kuwait and third states, and their nationals and corporations, as a result of the invasion and illegal occupation of Kuwait by Iraq; 9. Invites states to collect relevant information regarding their claims, and those of their nationals and corporations, for restitution or financial compensation by Iraq with a view to such arrangements as may be established in accordance with international law; 10. Requires that Iraq comply with the provisions of the present resolution and its previous resolutions, failing which the Council will need to take further measures under the Charter; 11. Decides to remain actively and permanently seized of the matter until Kuwait has regained its independence and peace has been restored in conformity with the relevant resolutions of the Security Council; (B) 12. Reposes its trust in the Secretary-General to make available his good offices and, as he considers appropriate, to pursue them and undertake diplomatic efforts in order to reach a peaceful solution to the crisis caused by the Iraqi invasion and occupation of Kuwait on the basis of Security Council resolutions 660 (1990), 662 (1990), and 664 (1990), and calls on all states, both those in the region and others, to pursue on this basis their efforts to this end, in conformity with the Charter, in order to improve the situation and restore peace, security and stability; 13. Requests the Secretary-General to report to the Security Council on the results of his good offices and diplomatic efforts.

DOC.HEAD: Vandals Mutilate Two American Pop Art Paintings
DOC.TEXT: Vandals slashed two recent pop art works by Roy Lichtenstein and James Rosenquist on display at the International Contemporary Art Fair, organizers of the exhibition said Monday. The vandals, shouting anti-imperialist slogans, mutilated the paintings Saturday with knives and dropped pamphlets before they were arrested. Lichtenstein's ``Reflections on Senorita,'' (1990) estimated at $1 million, and Rosenquist's ``Venturi Correction,'' (1990) estimated at $350,000, were on show at the booth of the Leo Castelli gallery in New York. Castelli, 83, was shaken by the incident but said he did not hold anyone responsible. ``These are unpredictable things that happen and can't be prevented. For me the affair is closed,'' he was quoted as saying in Le Figaro. One of Castelli's employees said that following the incident, a security guard had been posted inside the stand at the gallery's request. The fair, considered the first major commercial art event of the season, is expected to draw some 140,000 visitors to 155 stands displaying the world's best contemporary paintings, drawings and sculpture. Some gallery owners have complained of a lack of security. Last week, a small painting by Philippe Favier was stolen. ``There are no barriers between the art and the visitors, which means that in this enormous department store of art and sculpture, you can caress a work with the palm of your hand,'' said Nathalie Obadia of the Templon gallery. A spokeswoman for the one-week fair, which closes Thursday, said security was adequate. ``There are enough guards to do the job. Besides, we can't put a guard behind every work,'' she said on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Surgeon General Asks Beer Industry To Do More To Stop Drinking By Minors
By LeROY TILLMAN
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: The Surgeon General on Monday issued a pre-Halloween warning to the beer industry, saying it should avoid advertising practices that encourage drinking among minors. ``The beer industry should not capitalize on a season that youngsters look forward to with great anticipation to push their products,'' Dr. Antonia Novello said. ``Halloween and hops do not mix.'' Dr. Novello said breweries and their advertising agencies were sending the wrong message to minors, that alcohol consumption was acceptable for children under the legal drinking age. She said they should put larger warning labels on containers and revise advertising practices. ``We would like the industry to share in the responsibility,'' she said. ``Children can either consciously or unconsciously be affected by both print and electronic ads'' that for the most part never show the harmful effects of alcohol consumption. Alcohol abuse was ``the number one substance abuse problem among American youth,'' and indications were that the situation was getting worse. Children were being enticed by advertisements for so-called ``soft liquors,'' including beer, wine and wine coolers, she added. The alcohol industry annually conducts its most intensive advertising campaign between October and January. The National Coalition on Television Violence estimated that before the average American child turns 16, he would see 75,000 television scenes where alcohol is consumed or its use encouraged. ``On radio and television and even at supermarket check-out counters, we are being bombarded with exhortations ... this may be the year that witches meet the wine cooler,'' Dr. Novello said. But James C. Sanders, president of the Beer Institute, said that the Surgeon General's attack had become an annual harbinger of the Halloween season and that there was no indication that more minors were consuming alcoholic spirits. ``No amount of false accusations, or shoddy unverified research can disprove the fact that all alcohol advertising, including Halloween advertising, is carefully produced and placed to reach adult audiences as mandated by the industry's stringent guidelines,'' he said in a statement. Dr. Novello said there were indications that more children, some as young as age 13, were illegally purchasing alcoholic beverages, especially wine coolers that are frequently available at convenience stores. According to the National High School Senior Survey conducted by the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse, more than 4.5 million school aged teenagers had a drinking problem. The survey added that 43 percent of college students, 35 percent of high school seniors and 26 percent of 8th grade students take as many as five drinks a week. Dr. Novello said her office was working with educators nationwide to steer teenagers and pre-teens away from consuming liquor.

DOC.HEAD: Conservative Coalition Resigns in Trade Dispute
DOC.TEXT: The center-right government resigned Monday after the junior member of the year-old coalition refused to support increased ties to the European Economic Community. ``I think it is deeply regrettable for the country,'' Conservative Prime Minister Jan P. Syse told national television moments after the small Center Party quit his three-party alliance. Syse had hoped to form a minority government after his coalition split over Norway's position in talks between the community and the six-nation European Free Trade Association, of which Norway is a member. The talks are to center on the creation of a joint economic region. The Center Party, backed by farmers who fear a cut in subsidies with freer trade policies, opposed the issue. It quit the coalition and refused to back a single-party Conservative minority government. Center's leader, Anne Enger Lahnstein, said the dispute had moved beyond the trade issue and involved EEC membership itself. Syse, who supports eventually joining the EEC, said the issue was fundamental to his government. ``A government must stand united in such a case, especially when it concerns protecting Norway's interests in international negotiations,'' Syse told Parliament as he announced the coalition's resignation. Syse had hoped to form a new government because there is a slim rightist majority among the six major parties in Parliament and no elections are legally possible for three more years. Public disenchantment has increased due to tough austerity programs, intended to pull Norway's oil dependent economy out of a four-year slump that has brought record unemployment. Former Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland was expected to form her third Labor Party administration - Norway's sixth government since 1980. But no party holds a majority in the 165-seat Parliament. The Labor Party controls 81 votes, 63 of its own, 17 from the Socialist Left and one independent. Center did not indicate it would give its 11 votes to Labor on all issues. But Center leaders indicated they would agree on the issue of the EEC. Center's 11 votes in Parliament are usually counted in the non-socialist bloc's 84 votes. The Conservatives have 37 seats, the Christian Democrats' 14 and the Party of Progress has 22. The Party of Progress was excluded from Syse's coalition, with Center and others viewing it as too extremist. The conflict between the Conservatives and Center may have been aggravated last week when neighboring Sweden strongly hinted that it would seek EEC membership, prompting calls in Norway for both countries to join the community. The EEC considers some of Norway's protectionist laws discriminatory towards foreigners.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Supports Montana Law On Crimes Using Guns
With AM-Scotus Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday allowed a state to impose longer sentences automatically for criminals who used guns. The court, without comment, let stand a Montana law used to add 10 years to the 30-year prison sentence given a man who brandished a gun during a pizza shop robbery. In a separate case, the court refused to let police in Massachusetts stop and search someone solely because that person reportedly was carrying a handgun in public. Over a dissenting vote by Justice Harry A. Blackmun, the court let stand a ruling by Massachusetts' highest court that investigatory stops by police are unlawful if sparked by nothing more than ``the mere possession of a handgun.'' The Montana law was attacked as unconstitutional because Thomas Krantz never faced any gun-possession charges. State courts did not consider his use of the gun as a separate crime, but merely as a ``sentencing factor.'' The Montana Supreme Court upheld the state law last March, by a 5-2 vote. Krantz was convicted of holding up a Missoula pizza shop, and of driving the getaway car for a holdup at a Missoula motel a week later. Prosecutors said Krantz was the masked gunman who staged the first robbery. Convicted, he was sentenced to 30 years on the robbery charges. But the presiding judge added 10 years to the sentence because Krantz had used a gun. In its ruling last March, the state Supreme Court rejected Krantz's arguments that prosecutors never presented such a charge to a jury, or proved it beyond a reasonable doubt. In the Massachusetts case, two Lowell police officers, Gary Richardson and Steven Morril, received a radio report that a convenience store clerk had seen a man with the handle of a pistol protruding from his pocket. The clerk had given police a description and license number of the pickup truck the man had left in, and the two officers stopped the vehicle. Richardson ordered the man, Paul Couture, out of the truck and then searched the driver's compartment while Morril detained Couture. Richardson found a small .38 caliber pistol for which Couture said he did not have a license. A state trial judge barred prosecutors from using the seized gun as evidence, and the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court upheld that ruling. Stopping Couture and searching his truck violated his Fourth Amendment protection against unreasonable police searches, the state court ruled.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Clears the Way for Woman to Sue Trooper
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court cleared the way Monday for a Tacoma, Wash., woman to sue a state trooper she says left her stranded in a high-crime area the night she was raped. The justices, without comment, let stand a ruling that Trooper Steven Ostrander is not immune from being sued by the woman. At the same time, the court refused to reinstate a $750,000 award won, and then lost, by a woman raped in a Cleveland-area public transit system parking lot. The justices, again without comment, left intact a ruling that the transit system owed the woman no ``special duty of care'' even though another woman had been raped in the same parking lot the previous night. In other action Monday, the court: -Rejected a constitutional attack against a Montana law that automatically imposes longer sentences for criminals who used guns. -Refused to let police in Massachusetts stop and search someone solely because that person reportedly was toting a handgun in public. -Let stand a federal judge's order requiring three suburban Kansas City, Mo., school districts to accept black students from inner-city schools. -Let stand a ruling that the at-large system used in Norfolk, Va., since 1918 to elect city council elections violates the rights of black voters. InThe average price for strict low middling 1 & 1-16 inch spot cotton declined 15 points to 71.04 cents a pound Friday for the seven markets, according to the New York Cotton Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Over 95 Percent Survived Chemical Weapons, Says Expert
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. military's top expert on the medical effects of chemical warfare said Monday that history shows over 95 percent of those hit by nerve and mustard gas have survived. ``I think the threat of chemical warfare is very real. ... But you're not talking about some devastatingly effective weapon,'' said Col. Michael Dunn, commander of the U.S. Army Medical Research Institute of Chemical Defense. His message to 95 doctors, nurses and medics finishing a three-day course on treating victims of chemical warfare attacks was simple: ``There are very effective things you can do to deal with chemical casualties.'' For the 350,000-strong multinational force gathered in the Persian Gulf region following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the biggest fear is the possibility that Saddam Hussein will use chemical weapons if war breaks out. ``We hope it doesn't happen, but if it does, we'll be ready,'' said Spec. 4 Robert Staklinski, 22, of Darlington, S.C., a medical corpsman. He had just played the victim of a simulated chemical attack, twitching and moaning on a stretcher as half-dozen doctors and medics hovered over him with a five-minute deadline to make a diagnosis and initiate treatment. Dr. Mark Lawson, a 36-year-old Navy gastroenterologist from St. Petersburg, Fla., said he knew ``next to nothing'' about chemical warfare victims when he came to the gulf but now feels confident he can treat them and protect himself. ``This (course) has taken away a lot of the fear of the unknown, especially when you realize that less than 5 percent die,'' he said. Dunn, the senior U.S. member of a NATO panel on medical-chemical defense, said his greatest concern is for troops within 25 miles of the front who are within range of Iraqi artillery and short-range rockets used in the past to launch chemical weapons. During the eight-year Persian Gulf war, when Iraq regularly used chemical weapons against Iran, more than 45,000 people were attacked by mustard gas, he said. Only about 3 percent died, mainly from obstruction of the respiratory system. To a lesser degree, the Iraqis also used nerve agents, mainly Tabun and Sarin, with about a one in 20 fatality rate. ``Ever since World War I, right up until the end of (the Persian Gulf war) in 1988, chemical warfare agents which have a reputation of being lethal are really a greater cause of non-fatal injuries than they are of fatal injuries,'' Dunn, of Clarksville, Md., said. ``Over 95 percent of chemical casualties are living chemical casualties who aren't going to die but who stand a chance of being disabled or having a prolonged recovery,'' he said. The aim of the 15 three-day courses being held in the Desert Shield area for American, Saudi Arabian and other allied medical personnel, is to ensure that they have the best equipment and information ``to maximize recovery,'' Dunn said. The last American soldier to be attacked by chemical weapons was in World War I. Ironically, the Iraqis, along with the Iranians, have provided the Americans with much of their insight into the modern treatment of chemical warfare victims. Last December, Dunn said, he attended an international conference in Kuwait City and discussed chemical casualty care with Iranian and Iraqi doctors. ``There was a very free exchange of information so there are no secrets,'' he said. ``They have a very effective chemical casualty care system that they learned at high human cost and our objective here is to get better than they are without having to pay that human cost,'' Dunn said. The Iraqis were most effective using chemical weapons against civilians and the Iranian revolutionary guards whose beards, worn for religious reasons, prevented a tight seal on their gas masks, he said. All U.S. combat forces in the gulf are drilled repeatedly in quickly donning protective masks, and in injecting themselves with antidotes in case of attack. The course for medical personnel, being given at a U.S. Marine Corps hospital, is a compressed version of a five-day course given in the United States, which about 80 percent of physicians pass. Dunn said over 98 percent of the doctors here pass the final. ``What you're looking at here is a sense of immediacy and urgency of purpose,'' he said. ``Back in the States you take this stuff for granted,'' said medical corpsman Joe Campbell, 26, of Pensacola, Fla. ``But here your life depends on it, so you take it alittle more seriously.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Official: Int'l Pressure Could Stop Arctic Nuclear Tests
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union's environment minister on Monday appealed for international pressure on Moscow to stop nuclear explosions in the arctic. ``If it was up to me I would stop the tests immediately. What we need is an international moratorium,'' Nikolai Voronchov said at the start of an international environment conference. ``We have appealed to the highest authorities in the Soviet Union ... but what we need is international pressure to stop the tests, from the public and the press,'' the Soviet official said. The Soviet Union exploded a nuclear device on Wednesday in the island group of Novaya Zemlya, less than 500 miles from Finland and Norway. The explosion came after a two-year break in Soviet nuclear tests on the islands. Voronchov said he had not been informed of the test beforehand and that he could not guarantee that no others would take place. ``But I don't think it is the start of a new series,'' he said. The Nordic countries formally protested the test to Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Viktor Karpov in Moscow on Monday, Finnish national radio reported. In the protest note, Finland, Sweden, Norway, Denmark and Iceland urged the Soviet Union to allow Nordic experts to view conditions at the test site, the report said. Voronchov said he would do his utmost to help win permission for Finnish experts to visit the island. He also gave his backing to the idea of an international nuclear test-monitoring group. ``If Finland, as a neutral country, proposed such a group I am sure the nuclear powers would take note,'' Voronchov said. The two-day Ministerial Meeting on Technology and Financing for the Environment was attended by more than 120 representatives from nine countries in the Nordic region and Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Consortium Contributes To Freer Gallery Renovation
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese consortium has pledged $1.5 million toward renovation of the Freer Gallery of Art, a national museum of Asian art and the Smithsonian Institution's first art museum, gallery officials announced Monday. The gift is the largest received by the gallery since it opened in 1923 with a bequest from Detroit industrialist Charles Lang Freer, who gave the Smithsonian his art collection, a building fund and an endowment. The Japanese gift will be used to finance reinstallation of the original Freer collection of 13,000 objects, most of them Asian art but also including the world's most important collection of works by American painter James McNeill Whistler. A $21 million renovation and expansion of the Freer museum began in late 1988 and is scheduled for completion in late 1992. The Japanese gift leaves $4.5 million still to be raised, officials said. The Japanese consortium consists of Prof. Ikuo Hirayama, a painter and president of the National University of Fine Art and Music; the Nomura Securities Co. Ltd. and the Nomura Cultural Foundation of Tokyo.

DOC.HEAD: High-Tech Ship is Only One of its Class in Operation Desert Shield
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The commander of this U.S. cruiser expressed confidnce Monday that even if Iraq launched dozens of jets and missiles simultaneously, his crew could keep track of them all. ``If it's in the sky flying around, we can find it,'' Capt. Lawrence Eddingfield said at an news conference aboard the USS Antietam in the Persian Gulf. The Antietam, a Ticonderoga-class guided-missile cruiser, is in charge of anti-air warfare in the gulf, he said. As such, ``we keep track of everything that's flying in the central and northern Persian Gulf,'' including military and civilian aircraft, said Eddingfield. The Antietam is the ``highest state-of-the-art ship the Navy has,'' said Lt. Mark Wenzel, 30, of Fort Walton Beach, Fla. Its radar and sonar electronics are integrated with a sophisticated missile system, he said. The cruiser is equpped with the Aegis radar and weapons system, including four Spy-1 radar shields that flank each side of the 567-foot vessel. The ship carries a crew of more than 370 men. In 1988, during the Iran-Iraq war, the Vincennes, another Aegis-equipped cruiser on patrol in the Persian Gulf, accidentally shot down an Iranian civilian aircraft, killing all 290 people aboard. U.S. investigators concluded that the pressure of first-time combat caused Vincennes radar operators to misinterpret crucial computer data, and recommended stress and the ``human factor'' be studied for future training purposes. ``Everybody learned a few lessons, including people flying commercial airliners,'' said Eddingfield. He dismissed any danger of a potential repeat incident. The Antietam is the only ship of its class deployed to support Operation Desert Shield. The United States has a naval armada and more than 220,000 troops amassed in the region in the standoff with Saddam Hussein over his Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait. Other Aegis cruisers are on station in the Mediterranean and Red Seas. The Antietam can fire surface-to-surface Tomahawks and Harpoons, or surface-to-air Standard missiles. So far the Antietam has been involved in 167 interceptions, but no boardings, as part of the sea blockade of Iraq. Atop the ship's bridge, Assistant Fire Ensign Robert West, 25, of St. Louis, strained to hear radio communication between an American ship and an unidentified merchant vessel on a course to Jubail, Saudi Arabia. Operation Spec. 1st Class Calvin Carter, 35, of Washington, D.C., was seated at his station in the darkened Combat Information Center (CIC) in another part of the ship. He keeps a watchful eye on four brilliant blue radar screens. The screens are maps of Saudi Arabia and outlaying regions dotted with symbols indicating aircraft, ships, or submarines. CIC is the heart of the entire Aegis radar system. ``This is where all the information of the Aegis system and other ships merges. It is also our watch center that directs aircraft, as well as our own folks that operate the weapon system,'' said Wenzel. Specialist Carter said that in the event of an emergency, about 50 personnel would be manning the computer stations inside CIC.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used a0720, AM-Congress-Look Back transmitted Oct. 28 under a Washington dateline, are asked to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press erroneously reported on Oct. 28 that family leave legislation, passed by Congress and vetoed by President Bush, would have guaranteed workers six weeks of paid leave for childbirth or family medical emergencies. The bill would have guaranteed workers up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave for the care of a new child or an ill child, parent or spouse.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf at a Glance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT:
Here, at a glance, are Monday's developments in the Persian Gulf crisis:
Hundreds of French citizens left Baghdad on a flight to freedom after three months as hostages of Saddam Hussein. Among the Frenchmen were the last seven diplomats who endured an arduous siege of their embassy in occupied Kuwait. --- Freed hostage Patrick Moniodde said he met at least a dozen American and British hostages and noted they were ``very depressed.'' ``The Iraqis constantly move hostages from one site to another,'' said Moniodde. ``There was no hygiene,'' he said. ``Toilets were very dirty, but we always got medical care. Sure, Iraqis do not want to lose any hostages. We are free today, but it is terrible for others.'' --- The U.N. Security Council voted to hold Iraq liable for damages caused by its seizure of Kuwait. The resolution, the 10th since Iraq overran Kuwait on Aug. 2, was approved by 13 nations. Cuba and Yemen abstained. The new resolution also demands that Baghdad allow food, water and other supplies to be sent to Western diplomatic missions in Kuwait. --- Campaigning in San Francisco, President Bush said he would not hesitate to use force in the Persian Gulf if provoked. ``History is replete with examples when the president had to take action'' without consulting Congress, he added. Bush said he would meet Tuesday with congressional leaders about the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf, a deployment that could expand while Congress is adjourned. --- The European Community nations said that the gulf crisis has not caused a decline in oil supplies and that their strategic stocks exceed three months of normal consumption. The EC energy ministers said oil prices ``remain high, basically for emotive or speculative reasons.'' --- Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said that if Iraq's Saddam Hussein thinks he can divide the international alliance opposing him, he is wrong. The Soviet leader also said the latest mission to Baghdad by his envoy, Yevgeny Primakov, indicated there were some shifts in Saddam's positions. He did not elaborate. Primakov met Sunday with Saddam. --- Saddam told the Cable News Network it would be wrong to say nothing was accomplished by Primakov's visit. He said he told Primakov ``how the solutions could be reached to many of the issues in the region.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet, French Leaders Sign Friendship, Cooperation Pact
DOC.TEXT: Presidents Mikhail Gorbachev of the Soviet Union and Francois Mitterrand of France signed a friendship pact Monday providing for immediate consultations if either country feels threatened by conflict. The two leaders signed the Treaty of Friendship and Cooperation after an overnight visit to Paris by the Soviet leader. ``In the case of situations which, in the view of one of the parties, create a threat to peace, a breach of peace or provoke international tension, the governments of France and the Soviet Union will enter into contact without delay to coordinate all aspects of such situations,'' the treaty said. The treaty fell short of a non-aggression pact, similar to the treaty Moscow concluded recently with Germany. French officials say France will adhere to its commitments to NATO and the European Community, making a non-aggression clause unnecessary. The treaty was the first between the countries since a friendship pact in 1944, and France's first bilateral treaty in 27 years. It was signed at the chateau of Rambouillet, 33 miles southwest of Paris. ``We have done a great deal of work in a short time,'' Gorbachev said at a joint news conference with Mitterrand. ``This reflects the new level of cooperation and understanding between the leadership of our two countries which enables us to obtain results.'' The broad agreement calls for regular political consultations. It also provides for cooperation in energy, non-military nuclear science, transportation, high-definition television and telecommunications. France and the Soviet Union pledge to ``reinforce European solidarity'' and seek the creation of a European confederation. The treaty promised French assistance as the Soviet Union shifts to a market economy, and French help in arranging accords between Moscow and the 12-nation European Community. The treaty also provides for reimbursement by the Soviets to holders ofbonds issued by the Czarist governments of Russia from 1822-1917, said Alexei Glukhov, a member of the Soviet delegation. More than 250,000 people and institutions in France, including the government, hold such bonds, theoretically worth billions of dollars. Glukhov said details of the repayment plan remained to be worked out. The two leaders said at a joint news conference that their views were in harmony, including on the Persian Gulf crisis. Gorbachev suggested tightening of U.N. economic sanctions against Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait, but said he saw indications the sanctions were beginning to take effect. He also said an inter-Arab conference would be the quickest and most appropriate solution to the crisis. Gorbachev arrived Sunday evening after a three-day visit to Spain, where he obtained $1.5 billion in guaranteed loans to help ease the transition away from a centralized economy. The trip was Gorbachev's first abroad since winning the Nobel Peace Prize earlier this month.

DOC.HEAD: Two British Bird-Watchers Missing, Feared Killed by Guerrillas
DOC.TEXT: The British Embassy in Lima confirmed Monday that two ornithologists missing in a drug-rich jungle area since June are feared dead. An Embassy spokesman made the statement in response to a Lima newspaper report Sunday claiming Shining Path guerrillas killed British bird-watchers Michael Alan Entwistle, 30, and Timothy Peter Andrews, 32, in the Upper Huallaga River Valley area on June 11. The spokesman was unable to confirm the newspaper report, but said the Embassy was in touch with police in the jungle city of Tingo Maria, 200 miles northeast of Lima, where the Britons were last seen. The spokesman said an Embassy press release issued in Tingo Maria two weeks ago brought forward two informants who remembered having seen the two Britons. One of the informants claimed to have seen one of the Britons taken away against his will by a large group of men, the spokesman said. Lima's daily La Republica, quoting Tingo Maria residents, said Sunday the guerrillas suspected the Britons of being U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agents. The two men traveled to the area June 1 to visit the Cueva de las Lechuzas cave, known for its variety of birdlife, about 18 miles west of Tingo Maria, according to La Republica. The Upper Huallaga Valley is a jungle area dominated by drug traffickers in league with Maoist guerrillas who provide protection in exchange for arms and money. Ten foreign tourists were killed by the Shining Path last year.

DOC.HEAD: Harvard to Sponsor AIDS Conference
DOC.TEXT: Harvard University said Monday it will sponsor the annual international AIDS conference in 1992, four months after threatening to cancel the forum unless the United States removed travel restrictions on people infected with AIDS. The conference, the principle forum for presenting scientific information on the fight against the disease, will go ahead in the last week of May 1992, school officials said. In June, the Harvard AIDS Institute threatened to withdraw as sponsor and cancel the conference to protest a U.S. policy that made AIDS infection one of several contagious diseases for which foreigners could be barred from the country. But under an immigration bill passed over the weekend, the U.S. government would be allowed to remove AIDS and other diseases from the medical list for which a person may be denied entry. The conference is expected to attract about 15,000 researchers, policy makers, community organizers and AIDS patients, Harvard officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Speaker's Death Said to be Terrorists' Mistake
DOC.TEXT: Moslem extremists assassinated Egypt's parliamentary speaker in a botched attempt to kill the interior minister, who they blamed for the deaths of 14 fundamentalists, a presidential source said Monday. Preliminary police reports, based on the confessions of 10 suspects who have admitted involvement in the Oct. 12 slaying, came to the same conclusion, according to sources in the Interior Ministry. ``According to their confessions they said they wanted to kill the interior minister,'' said the presidential source, who spoke on condition he not be identified further. Rifaat el-Mahgoub, speaker of the People's Assembly, his driver and four security men were killed when assailants opened fired as they drove in two cars by a luxury hotel on a corniche by the Nile. The source in President Hosni Mubarak's office said he is convinced Interior Minister Abdel-Halim Moussa was the target because Moussa usually followed the same route to his office that el-Mahgoub took that day. Shortly after the assassination, Moussa told reporters his car had been a few hundred yards behind the limousine carrying el-Mahgoub. Moussa at the time dismissed speculation the assassins' bullets were meant for him. Islamic fundamentalists twice in 1987 attempted to assassinate Egyptian interior ministers. One of the ministers was badly wounded. The presidential source said Monday that Moussa's car had actually passed the site of the assassination a few minutes before the gunmen struck el-Mahgoub's Mercedes. The two factors that saved Moussa, said the source, were that he chose not to ride in his black Mercedes that day and that his car was not accompanied by a motorcycle policeman because it was Friday, the Moslem Sabbath, and traffic was light. ``The ambush was waiting for a motorcycle followed by a black Mercedes. He (Moussa) went unnoticed,'' the presidential source said. ``Then came the unfortunate el-Mahgoub. It's sure that he was mistaken for Moussa.'' El-Mahgoub was technically the second-ranking official in Egypt, after President Mubarak. But there was no particular reason he would have been targeted, either by Moslem extremists or by foreign terrorists. The interior minister, on the other hand, is in charge of most security functions in Egypt. Early speculation focused on Iraqi or Palestinian agents, possibly in league with Egyptian religious zealots, in a conspiracy developed in Baghdad to punish Egypt for its anti-Iraq stand in the Persian Gulf crisis. Police still are not ruling out a possible Iraqi or Palestinian connection, the Interior Ministry sources said. They said large amounts of money were found with the recently arrested suspects. There have been no on-the-record pronouncements on the investigation into the slaying. But as pieced together so far, the Interior Ministry sources said, the attack appears to have been meant as revenge for police actions. In April, police killed 13 Islamic fundamentalists and wounded six in clashes in Fayoum province, 60 miles southwest of Cairo. Last month, unidentified gunmen killed physician Alaa Mohi el-Din, spokesman of the Islamic Gamaa, an umbrella organization for the militant Moslems. No one has been arrested in connection with the shooting, but the Gamaa blame the police. ``The Moslem extremists had threatened to take their revenge,'' one police officer said. ``The first suspect, who was arrested last Wednesday and identified the others ... said their aim was (to kill) the interior minister.'' Police on Saturday killed two suspects alleged to have been triggermen in el-Mahgoub's death. A police report said fingerprints in a car commandeered briefly by an escaping assassin matched those of a man wounded in Saturday's clash. One police officer said some suspects in the case are claiming they gave false confessions under torture. The prisoners are demanding medical examinations to confirm their torture, the officer said. Amnesty International, the London-based human rights group, and other rights organizations claim Egyptian interrogators use beatings and other torture against political detainees.

DOC.HEAD: `Civil War' Filmmaker Blames TV For Decline In Knowledge Of History
DOC.TEXT: Filmmaker Ken Burns, creator of the widely praised ``The Civil War'' public television series, says television is mostly to blame for a decline in high school students' knowledge of history. In a luncheon speech Monday at the National Press Club, Burns said television is ``substituting a distracting cultural monarchy'' for the cultural democracy and diversity that was promised when television was introduced. ``Television has equipped us as citizens to live only in an all-consuming - and thereby forgettable and disposable - present, blissfully unaware of the historical tides and movements that speak not only to this moment, but to our vast future as well,'' he said. ``This environment ensures that we have no history,'' Burns said. ``And by so doing, ensures that we have no future.'' Burns blasted television for offering Americans ``nearly the same thing everywhere ... on dozens of clone-like channels,'' and for ``conferring a kind of cultural peerage'' on a small group of TV commentators. ``Issues and ideas are merely pushed around the plate, never digested, by the same people ... engaged more with a subtle one-upmanship among themselves and their TV alter egos than with the advancement of our understanding,'' Burns said. ``In the worst of our television, we are addicted to personality, to the breathless embrace of celebrity, ensuring as we go a tyranny of the televised over the great mass of the un-televised,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Refusal Of Congress To Fund S&L Bailout Could Cost Billions
DOC.TEXT: Congress' refusal to provide more money for savings and loan bailouts will delay the closing of failed institutions for months and add millions, or even billions, of dollars to taxpayers' costs, analysts said Monday. Legislators' election-year squeeze left the Resolution Trust Corp., the bailout agency created last year, without the funds needed to close more than 300 insolvent or near-insolvent thrift associations. That means the institutions will continue to run losses, funding themselves with high-interest deposits. That in turn weakens healthy competitors by forcing them to raise their deposit rates, raising the specter of additional failures. ``It's going to cost us additional money. We're going to have to slow up the resolution of failed thrifts,'' L. William Seidman, chairman of the trust corporation, said in a telephone interview. He estimated the cost of a three-month delay at $250 million to $300 million. The Congressional Budget Office put it at $300 million to $400 million, while Bert Ely, a private analyst in Alexandria, Va., estimated it at $2 billion to $2.5 billion. The added costs, although spread over the life of the bailout program, will make it even harder for the government to meet the $500 billion deficit-reduction goal in the five-year program adopted over the weekend. The trust corporation, which had handled 287 failed thrifts through the end of September, has enough money left to pay acquirers to take over an additional 65 to 75 small institutions by the end of this year, according to spokesman Steven Katsanos. But that would still leave it with more than 100 S&Ls to handle on top of several hundred others judged to be near failure. Also, financing disruptions tend to discourage potential bidders and make it more difficult for the agency to hire the outside experts it needs, he said. ``The private sector doesn't adapt well to uncertainty about whether the bill is going to be paid,'' he said. The agency has already been forced to delay seeking acquirers for 18 large institutions until its funding is secure, Katsanos said. Congress' Sunday morning revolt against further spending left Bush administration officials and Democrats blaming each other for the expected consequences. Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas., chairman of the House Banking Committee, said Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady's refusal to testify in support of the administration's request ``created an unfortunate atmosphere'' for approval of more money. ``They've got to get out of that bunker over there in the Treasury and come over here and join the people,'' Gonzalez said in a telephone interview. However, Desiree Tucker-Sorini, deputy assistant secretary of the Treasury, said, ``The need for action and the consequences for failing to act were spelled out in great detail over a period of months by the (Treasury) secretary and others.'' Private analysts were unimpressed by both sides' arguments and likened the situation to 1988 and 1986 when political wrangling left the RTC's predecessor, the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp., short of money. ``It's a very sad comment on politics. ... It's a very lame excuse,'' said Ohio State University professor Edward J. Kane. ``They were playing a game of chicken to see who blinks at the last minute,'' Ely said. ``The House wanted Brady to come up and bow and scrape and he refused. ... Nobody blinked, so we ended up with a delay. A costly one.'' Brady told Congress by letter that the administration needed $40 billion to cover S&L losses through September 1991, in addition to the $50 billion provided by last year's S&L law. The Senate early Sunday had adopted a measure that would have provided $10 billion to the trust corporation, enough to keep it going until after Congress' scheduled return in January. However, the House adjourned without acting on a similar bill after Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., raised procedural objections that would have required adoption by a two-thirds vote. ``He just felt that bringing it up after midnight on the final night of the session was not the time to sneak ... new funding through,'' said Curtis Prins, staff director of Annunzio's House Banking financial institutions subcommittee. Gonzalez pledged speedy action by his committee when Congress returns. Until then, he said the administration could take advantage of a drafting error in last year's law which would permit it to borrow, short-term, an additional $18.8 billion. Treasury officials earlier hinted that they would borrow the additional money and were meeting Monday to discuss the option. Economist George Kaufman of Loyola University of Chicago said the financing delay, while unfortunate, may have the beneficial side effect of encouraging the trust corporation to more quickly sell the $160 billion in loans, real estate and other assets it has inherited from failed thrifts.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 60 Arrested During Protest in San Francisco
With AM-Bush
DOC.TEXT: Protesters against U.S. involvement in the Middle East burned flags and trashed a fast-food restaurant Monday, and police arrested more than 60 demonstrators. At least 200 protesters had gathered outside the Pacific Stock Exchange by 6 a.m., said police Sgt. Bob Crosat. They were met by between 100 and 200 officers, he said. The protesters chanted and carried signs, but when the crowd headed for Market Street, the mood changed, he said. When demonstrators arrived at a McDonald's restaurant, the violence began, Crosat said. ``They broke tables and windows and scattered food around,'' said Crosat. A couple of American flags also were burned during the 2{-hour protest. Sixty-one demonstrators were arrested for investigation of misdemeanor charges that included failure to disperse at an unlawful assembly, vandalism and trespassing, said Officer Dave Ambrose. The protest was sponsored by the Earth Action Network, which publicized the event as a legal, nonviolent ``pro-environment and anti-corporate demonstration and blockade'' of the Pacific Stock Exchange. The demonstration did not appear to be timed to coincide with President Bush's visit Monday to San Francisco. There was no mention of the president in organizers' news releases and little reference to him in the marches. While in town, Bush said he would not hesitate to use force in the Persian Gulf if provoked. ``History is replete with examples when the president had to take action'' without consulting Congress, he added.

DOC.HEAD: Blustery Wind, Cold Makes Advances in East
DOC.TEXT: Cold wind blew into the Atlantic Coast states on Monday, but temperatures hit near 80 on the central Plains. Strong northwesterly wind behind a cold front blew across New England and gale warnings were posted along the coast of Maine, New Hampshire, Massachusetts and Rhode Island. Afternoon temperatures were in the 30s in upstate New York and northern New England and the first freeze of the autumn is forecast for parts of the middle Atlantic Coast region. A frost advisory in effect into Tuesday morning was issued for coastal sections of southeastern Virginia, with a freeze warning covering the rest of southeastern Virginia. A freeze advisory also was posted for southeastern Maryland and southern Delaware. Frost and freeze warnings also were issued for northern North Carolina. In South Carolina, a frost warning was issued for the Piedmont and Midlands regions. A few showers lingered in the Northeast. A cold front racing across the north-central states spread cooler weather to that region with afternoon readings only in the 50s. But temperatures warmed into the 70s across the southern and central Plains, with readings near 80 as far north as northern Nebraska. Strong, gusty southerly wind prevailed from the southern high Plains to the middle Mississippi Valley. A low pressure area moving toward the northern Pacific Coast spread strong, gusty wind into Washington state and Oregon. Muskegon, Mich., hit a record low for the date of 22 degrees. Monday's low for the Lower 48 states was 18 at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Biologists Search For Dead Animals After Cyanide Spill Into River
DOC.TEXT: Millions of gallons of a dilute cyanide solution spilled from a gold refinery and biologists Monday searched along the Lynches River to see if it had harmed livestock or wildlife. Elsewhere, oil from a coke plant's discharge pipe spilled into the Monongahela River Monday at Pittsburgh, creating a shimmering, 4-mile-long slick, authorities said. Health and wildlife officials in South Carolina reported no fish kills or problems with animals that might drink from the river. The spill posed little threat to drinking water supplies but officials warned residents to keep animals from tainted water. About 11 million gallons of the solution of sodium cyanide had spilled by midday Monday into the Little Fork Creek after an earthen dam broke Sunday at the Brewer Gold Mining Co. The reservoir held about 13 million to 14 million gallons. The liquid contained only 50 parts of sodium cyanide per million, said Richard Carnes, director of the Chesterfield County Emergency Preparedness Division. Undiluted sodium cyanide would be fatal, but the spill created only a minimal health risk to people and animals because it would be significantly diluted after mixing with river water, said Thom Berry, a spokesman for the Department of Health and Environmental. However, the cyanide wasn't the only threat from the spill. ``Our concern right now is not so much the cyanide but levels of copper we're seeing in the discharge,'' Berry said. Some copper compounds also can kill aquatic life, he said. The sodium cyanide solution began spilling Sunday afternoon from a holding pond at Brewer, officials said. Brewer uses sodium cyanide to separate gold from ore. The holding pond is about 2,000 feet from the Little Fork Creek and two miles from Lynches. Carnes said recent heavy rain in the area might have weakened the dam. Crews worked to diverted remaining chemical in the reservoir into Brewer's discharge treatment system to be neutralized with chlorine and hydrogen peroxide, Berry said. Brewer officials did not return telephone calls Monday. Wildlife and health officials took water samples from the river along a series of stations along the river, said Berry. Marine biologists in three boats covered the Lynches, creeks and tributaries in search of dead fish, said John Evans of the state Department of Wildlife and Marine Resources. Game biologists searched the banks for deer, fox, racoon and waterfowl, he said. The nearest municipality that draws from the water for its drinking supply is the city of Georgetown, along the coast about 110 miles from Jefferson, Berry said. The mine began operation in 1987 and was fined by the Environmental Protection Agency in March for failure to promptly report a spill of up to 1,800 gallons of liquid containing sodium cyanide, authorities said. That stemmed from a March 1988 spill in which a 2-inch line carrying sodium cyanide solution ruptured. In Pittsburgh, the slow-moving oil spill stretched 4 miles from the LTV Steel Co. plant to the downtown Point State Park, where the Monongahela and Allegheny rivers join to form the Ohio River, said Betsy Mallison, a spokeswoman for the state Department of Environmental Resources. As a precaution, water plants serving about 38,000 customers in West View and RobinsonTownship were advised to test their water for fuel, said Gina Pferdehirt, a spokesman for the Allegheny County Health Department. ``It's beginning to break up. We don't feel the water supplies are threatened,'' Ms. Mallison said. LTV spokesman Mark Tomasch said the company was unable to determine whether the fuel came from its coke plant or from another company that uses the pipe.

DOC.HEAD: Bush: `No Hesitancy' in Using Force if Saddam Provokes
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday ``we'd have no hesitancy at all'' to use military force in the Persian Gulf if provoked by Iraq and indicated he feels no obligation to get Congress' approval. ``History is replete with examples where the president has had to take action,'' Bush said. Apparently referring to the U.S. invasion of Panama, Bush said, ``I've done this in the past, and certainly, somebody mentioned provocation, we'd have no hesitancy at all.'' Bush said he was not trying to prepare the country for war. ``I'm just doing my job as president of the United States,'' he said. ``I'm not preparing anybody for anything. I'm as determined as I've ever been that this aggression will not stand.'' Bush spoke at an airport news conference in San Francisco after campaigning for Republican Sen. Pete Wilson in his race for governor. Later, he flew to Oklahoma City to appear at the Cowboy Hall of Fame with Bill Price, the GOP candidate for governor in Oklahoma. Shrugging off his slump in the polls, he accused Democrats of trying to win elections through ``tax the rich, class warfare kind of garbage.'' ``I think people know that this Congress is controlled by the taxers, by the liberal Democrats,'' Bush said in a sharply political attack eight days before Election Day. Meanwhile, Secretary of State James A. Baker III was echoing Bush's tough gulf statements in a speech in Los Angeles. ``We are exhausting every diplomatic avenue to achieve (a peaceful) solution without further bloodshed,'' Baker said. But he added, ``Let no one doubt: We will not rule out a possible use of force if Iraq continues to occupy Kuwait.'' The White House policy in the Persian Gulf has won strong bipartisan support in Congress, although there is a growing feeling that Bush should consult lawmakers before sending troops into any combat. More than 200,000 American forces have been deployed to the gulf after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said last week that as many as 100,000 more troops may be dispatched. The gulf crisis will be at the top of the agenda when Bush meets with congressional leaders at the White House on Tuesday. The president also is to consult with Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who just returned from the Middle East. Bush appeared unmoved by demands that Congress should be asked in advance before he sends troops into action. ``I know the authorities that a president has,'' Bush said. ``I'm working to try to get this matter resolved peacefully. We have a lot of force there and they're well trained, they're highly motivated and that alone is sending an enormously strong signal to Saddam Hussein.'' Bush also said the Soviet Union remains aligned with the United States against Iraq. He said Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ``is holding just as firm as he can. And that's good, you see, because that sends a strong signal that the free world is united against this dictator.'' The Oklahoma stop concluded a five-day campaign trip that took Bush as far west as Hawaii while Congress was wrapping up a $490 billion deficit-reduction agreement. Bush said he had felt politically restrained while the agreement was being put together but now is taking off the gloves. ``I don't like being on the defense,'' he said. ``I like being on the offense.'' The president will hit Democrats again in a speech in Washington on Tuesday and then hit the road Thursday for nonstop campaigning until the election. Bush has paid a big political price because of his changes on taxes and because of Democrats' efforts to portray him - and other Republicans - as defenders of the rich. ``I'm used to that kind of demagoguery and so I'm out here now on the campaign trail laying it to rest,'' Bush said. ``I've got to get that in focus because they've been getting away with this tax the rich, class warfare kind of garbage that they always resurrect at election time.''
