Amid sharp Republican divisions on taxes and the budget, Bush's popularity has dropped below 50 percent in the polls, the lowest of his presidency. ``These polls don't mean anything to me,'' Bush said. ``The American people are fair,'' he added. ``They know I'm against taxes.' In the budget negotiations, Bush resisted increasing the tax load on the rich but in the end finally agreed to raise the tax rate on the highest income brackets to 31 percent, from 28 percent now. The package also chips away at high-income taxpayers' itemized deductions.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Agency Warns Of Injuries From ``Slap-Wrist'' Bracelet
DOC.TEXT: A popular toy known as the ``slap-wrist'' bracelet may cause hand and wrist injuries to children, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Monday. The wrist bracelet is a thin strip of metal covered by woven fabric or paper. The toy wraps into the bracelet when the wrist is struck with the bracelet. The commission said the toys have passed tests given to items with sharp edges. But the panel said it is concerned that, over time, the fabric or paper covering the thin metal may tear, exposing the user to a sharp metal edge. As a result, lacerations may occur. The panel said parents should alert children to the potential danger and should examine the toys frequently. In the event a tear occurs, the toy should be discarded. The commission said it is continuing its investigation into the toy to see if further action is warranted. The commission is responsible for product safety.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Warns Iraq Not to `Lay A Finger on Israel'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to ADD Israeli stopover not on Baker agenda, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir warned Iraq on Monday not to ``lay a finger on Israel'' lest Saddam Hussein ``pay a terrible price for his blunder.'' Shamir told Jewish fundraisers at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Jerusalem, ``Our very presence in this region, thanks to our strong will and capacity, (has) been and continues to be a force for stability, a barrier that prevented many military adventures and much more violence.'' He reassured the audience that Iraqi President Saddam's attempts to coax Israel into the conflict in the Persian Gulf would fail. ``Saddam Hussein must surely know that if he lays a finger on Israel he will pay a terrible price for such a blunder,'' Shamir said. ``This attempt to drag us into the present conflict ... will not succeed.'' Earlier, Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai announced economic reforms that included an additional military budget of a quarter-billion dollars in light of the gulf crisis, Israel army radio said. Saddam has repeatedly threatened to torch Israel with binary chemical weapons. His first threat came in April when he said he would to use chemical weapons in answer to an Israeli nuclear attack. He later said an American attack would also lead to an attack on Israel. The Israeli government has taken these threats seriously and has distributed gas mask kits to the general public. Meanwhile, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said he does not expect to visit Israel on his trip to the Middle East and Europe starting Friday. Baker, who will use the trip to consult on the gulf crisis, told a gathering in Los Angeles a stopover in Israel would leave the impresion there is a linkage between the Arab-Israeli conflict and the gulf crisis. ``We are very anxious that there not be a linkage,'' Baker said.

DOC.HEAD: Issues of Booze, Spouse Abuse Fly in U.S. Senate Race
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 5th to include poll in AM-Political Briefs, a0691
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Minnesota Governor, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The campaign manager for Republican Senate candidate Hal Daub raised more questions about Democratic Sen. Jim Exon's drinking habits, and Daub's wife denied allegations that her husband had abused her. Jim Putnam said Sunday that Daub's campaign has been receiving reports from people who have seen Exon appear intoxicated. Putnam said Exon's explanantion that medication he had taken years ago for gallbladder problems may have made him appear tipsy was insufficient. ``Now perhaps there is a medical explanation for this. But it certainly cannot all be written off to a gall bladder condition,'' Putnam said in a statement. In response, Exon campaign chairman Charles Pallesen called the news release ``a disgusting collection of falsehoods.'' ``These actions are unfortunately becoming commonplace from a campaign that is broke, in debt and floundering in the polls,'' Pallesen said. Exon's lead has increased to 26 percentage points, according to a poll taken last week by the Omaha World-Herald. According to the poll, Exon was the choice of 55 percent. Twenty-nine percent said they would vote for Daub. In an Aug. 28-30 survey this year, Exon was ahead by 16 points. Cindy Daub, meanwhile, released a letter saying there is no truth to stories that her husband has abused her. She said Exon should apologize for remarks that she said gave the issue national prominence. The spark that enlivened Nebraska's Senate campaign with issues of alcohol and spouse abuse came from former Sen. John Tower of Texas. During an Oct. 11 visit on behalf of Daub, Tower told reporters that Exon had a reputation as ``one of the two or three biggest boozers in the Senate.'' Putnam said Exon should give the Daub campaign and the news media authorization to check the senator's hospital records, insurance carrier and Medicare. ``Only through a careful examination of insurance records will the extent of the senator's true medical condition be known to the public,'' Putnam said. Pallesen said Exon released information about his health in an Oct. 17 letter from his physician in Washington, D.C., Dr. Robert Krasner. Krasner wrote that Exon underwent gallbladder surgery in 1985 and took prescription painkillers for the condition. Once the rumors about Exon had been raised, Daub's personal life also came under scrutiny. Daub, who served four terms in the U.S. House and and ran unsuccessfully for the Senate in 1988, was asked about a 1978 incident in which he suffered a stab wound in his home. Daub had said he fell and stabbed himself in the arm but rumors of a domestic incident persisted. After Daub called on Exon to release his medical records, Exon suggested that Daub release his ``family records,'' a veiled reference to the domestic rumors. In a letter to Exon dated Saturday and addressed to Exon's Washington office, Mrs. Daub told Exon, ``When you held a news conference and implied that my husband beat me up which resulted in me going to so-called shelters, that was the most heinous personal attack possible and unbecoming of a United States senator.'' Exon denied attacking the Daubs. ``I have made no accusations and spread no rumors about her or her husband,'' Exon said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Moody's Warns Tax Initiatives Threaten Bond Ratings in Six States
DOC.TEXT: Tax initiatives in six states could result in reduced bond ratings at state and local level if passed by voters in the Nov. 6 election, a Wall Street bond rating agency warned. Moody's Investors Service said tax initiatives in Colorado, Massachusetts, Montana, Nebraska, Oregon and Utah could, if approved, lower the confidence financial advisers have in those states. ``They do introduce uncertainty,'' said George Leung, a Moody's analyst. ``This year, I think certainly it's reflective of the mood - the discontent amongst voters, and also reflective of economic conditions.'' Moody's said in a report released last week that the initiatives ``could have serious consequences for state and local governments and result in reduced bond ratings.'' ``In all of these states, with the possible exception of Utah, many questions remain about how the proposals would be implemented,'' Moody's said in a report last week. It said courts and state legislatures would probably have to resolve the ambiguities. Bond ratings are used as a guide for investors. Lowered bond ratings can result in higher interest payments for borrowing. Most states back their bonds with the full faith and credit of the state, making payment of debt the highest spending priority. Financially ailing Massachusetts already has the lowest bond rating in the country. Bond rating agencies have warned that passage of a proposal to roll back certain taxes and fees there to 1988 levels could drop the state's rating from its current level of Baa to junk bond status. In Colorado and Oregon, the tax initiatives set more restrictive limits on property taxes, other revenue sources and municipal debt. In Montana, the initiative would replace all sales, income and property taxes with a trade charge on business and financial transactions. One Nebraska initiative would impose a cap on annual expenditure growth while another would change the manner in which schools are funded. The Utah initiative would remove some items from the sales tax base. Moody's warned that municipal bond ratings also could also suffer if the initiatives pass. ``If Montana's initiative succeeds, all ratings in the state would immediately be placed under review because the measure calls for a massive restructuring of state and local revenues for both operations and debt service,'' Moody's said. Montana and Oregon currently have ratings of Aa and Utah has a rating of Aaa on general obligation bonds, which are backed by the state's full faith and credit. Moody's does not have a general obligation bond rating for either Colorado and Nebraska, because the states do not issues such bonds, Leung said. The Massachusetts initiative would reduce the personal income tax rate, eliminating a surcharge collected in fiscal 1990 and 1991, and would roll back other state taxes to their August, 1989 levels. If it passes, the initiative will cost the state an estimated $1.28 billion in 1991 and $2.55 billion the following year. Opponents of the Citizens for Limited Taxation proposal in Massachusetts have argued the measure would gut state government programs. Howard Foley, president of the Massachusetts High Tech Council, a 200-company business association that co-sponsored the CLT petition, said the warning should have come two years ago, when the state's bond rating was still high. ``I think the biggest problem is the continuing overspending of what we don't have,'' Foley said when asked about the prospect of a bond rating reduction. ``Perhaps if that option wasn't available, we'd pay more attention to balancing our books.''

DOC.HEAD: `Godfather Part III' Will Be Ready by Christmas, Studio Says
DOC.TEXT: ``The Godfather Part III'' will be released this Christmas, Paramount Pictures said Monday, ending speculation that the troubled sequel to the Corleone family saga would not come out this year. After a weekend screening of an unfinished print of the last chapter in writer-director Francis Ford Coppola's trilogy, senior Paramount executives elected to release the film Dec. 25 to approximately 1,800 theaters nationwide. ``The Godfather Part III'' originally was to open Thanksgiving, but a variety of production delays forced its postponement. The first two installments in the trilogy won nine Academy Awards and grossed $800 million. The latest film, expected to cost about $50 million, is the most anticipated holiday release. The sequel, which picks up the Corleone family two decades after 1974's ``The Godfather Part II'' left off, stars Al Pacino, Diane Keaton, Andy Garcia and Coppola's own daughter, Sofia. In the film, Don Corleone (Pacino) attempts to legitimize his family's investment businesses, which once hinged on gambling. The original ``Godfather'' opened in 1972. In a statement, Coppola said: ``After one of the most intensive production schedules in my career, I am deeply satisfied that `The Godfather Part III' has come together in a way that gives me great pride.''

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Upholds Ruling On Black Voters' Rights
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADD two grafs for background on runoffs; no pick up. ^With AM-Scotus Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday let stand a ruling involving black voters' rights that forces Norfolk, Va., to change the way city council members are elected. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by city officials on a ruling that the at-large system used since 1918 in city council elections violates black voters' rights. At the same time, the justices left intact the way Sagauche County, Colo, elects its governing board despite claims by Hispanic residents who say their political clout is being blunted illegally. The court also asked the Bush administration for its views of an appeal by a rural Arkansas county's black voters who say the election system used in party primaries and countywide general elections is racially biased. In the Norfolk case, a federal appeals court panel ordered the city to switch to a single-district election system that will ``remedy the vote dilution arising out of the at-large election system.'' The Norfolk City Council has seven members, elected to staggered four-year terms. Elections for three or four of the council seats are held every two years. Candidates with the most votes citywide win, and do not need a majority of the votes cast. A group of black voters and the local chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People sued in 1983, contending that the at-large system illegally blunted the political clout of black voters. Norfolk, one of Virginia's largest cities, is 35 percent black in population. Blacks also comprise 35 percent of the city's registered voters. The city council did not have a black member until 1968, and since then has had one black member most years. The NAACP and black voters who sued said if city council members were elected from seven single-member districts, black voters would be in the majority in three of the seven districts. The Colorado case centered on how Saguache County's three commissioners are elected. No Hispanic has ever won a contested election in the county even though Hispanics comprise 41 percent of the population. The three commissioners must reside in different districts, but elections are countywide and not confined to the district in which a candidate resides. The still-pending Arkansas case involves a law under which a candidate for a political party's nomination or for a countywide office must get a majority of the votes cast. If no candidate wins an outright majority, a runoff election is held two weeks later between the top two vote-getters. The justices were told that Arkansas is one of 10 states employing such a system, ``all of them in the South and all of them with a long history of purposeful racial vote dilution.'' The other states were identified as Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, Texas and Oklahoma. The runoff system, as it operates in Phillips County, Ark., was challenged as illegal by black voters who say their voting power is being diluted. Blacks comprise 47 percent of the voting-age population in Phillips County, but no black candidate in modern times has received the Democratic or Republican nomination for, or been elected to, any countywide office. The Justice Department in August sued to overturn Georgia's majority vote runoff system, saying it has ``a chilling effect on black political participation.'' Some political observers say eliminating runoffs could help Republicans in the South and Southwest. Blacks and Hispanics would win more Democratic primaries, they say, only to lose general elections to GOP candidates backed by white voters who had supported white Democratic primary candidates.

DOC.HEAD: Educator Calls for National Standards
DOC.TEXT: A top educator on Monday said the country needs a ``national education index'' to serve as a benchmark for tates to measure student achievement and pinpoint failing schools or ineffective local leaders. Ernest Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, insisted during a ``Fortune'' magazine seminar of businessmen, educators and governors that the nation is ``more than ready for a national policy in education.'' ``The message - it seems to me - is absolutely clear. After years of vigorously defending local school control, the nation is now supporting - indeed almost demanding - national leadership in education, while still maintaining vitality at the local level. ``It's time to go beyond goals - important as they are - and begin to talk more precisely about education standards and how progress toward national objectives can be measured.'' State must have clearly defined goals, an assessment procedure requiring annual progress reports from schools, and clearly defined methods of intervention in case a school is failing, he said. As part of intervention, Boyer said a state might put a school on probation or assign a senior adviser to the school who would spend time working with teachers, counselors and administrators. The state also should be given the authority to remove a principal, superintendent or even a local school board. A state might even close a school - ``a strategy of last resort,'' he said. ``Local school control is crucial, but it's insufficient. In the end, students must be served, and if a school, for whatever reason, does not provide an effective education, state officials have both a legal and moral obligation to intervene,'' said Boyer. The index also should include: -School completion rates of students in every state. This category would include a look at each student's proficiency in English and mathematics, performance on general knowledge tests and whether a state gives priority to writing. -The condition of teaching. States would be judged on whether they have a plan for attracting outstanding students into teaching, special strategies to attract teachers in math and science and requirements for training that include sabbaticals, fellowships and teacher institutes. Teacher salaries also would be considered. -The schools' climate as it relates to the quality of buildings, classrooms and laboratories, as well as class size. -Financial support of schools. States' per-student expenditures and other costs would be compared regionally so that cost-of-living can be considered. Equity in school finance would be a key consideration. -How schools are governed. States must have clearly defined goals, as well as intervention methods in case of a failing school. Boyer sidestepped the issue of who should be in charge of the national evaluation of school performance, noting that both Congress and the National Governors' Association have been haggling over the issue. The NGA has set up a special board to handle the task and Congress has passed two bills creating panels.

DOC.HEAD: Government Trust Plummets to 6 Percent in Soviet Poll
DOC.TEXT: Less than one in 10 Soviet respondents in a new poll expressed full support for their leaders and half said they had no confidence at all. The poll by the independent All-Union Center for Public Opinion indicated that support for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his government, headed by Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov, has hit the lowest point since Gorbachev took power in 1985. The poll, released by the independent news service Interfax, found only 6 percent of respondents gave full support when asked, ``How much do you trust the national leadership now?'' Thirty-two percent expressed qualified support and 50 percent had no confidence at all. The rest had no opinion, Interfax reported. The results were based on answers by 1,356 people in 11 regions across the country, Interfax said. However, it gave no margin of error and didn't say when the survey was done. There was no answer to phone queries at the center late Monday. A pol conducted last summer by the liberal weekly Ogonyok put support for Gorbachev's Communist Party at 30 percent, below the Red Army, the Russian Orthodox Church and the national Supreme Soviet legislature. The latest poll was released two weeks after Gorbachev was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for helping end the Cold War. In contrast to his worldwide popularity, Gorbachev's domestic standing has been sliding for years, even more severely the last year as shortages have worsened and nearly all the 15 republics have declared some form of sovereignty. The poll also asked whether the emergency powers given to Gorbachev by the Supreme Soviet last month will ``help stabilize the country's economy.'' More than half - 54 percent - said they doubted the presidential decrees would have a significant effect. Nearly one-fifth said they thought the powers would help, and the remainder had no comment. Gorbachev has issued about a half-dozen decrees so far, including ordering a crackdown on black marketeers and demanding that state-run manufacturers and suppliers fulfill their contracts with state-run businesses. Officials have accused ``speculators'' of siphoning off the supplies for resale at high prices on the black market. A majority of respondents also said they expected open hostilities to break out in the Gulf, although only 2 percent thought fighting would escalate into a Third World War with the United States, Interfax reported. Fifteen percent were optimistic that a peaceful settlement could be reached, and 23 percent expressed no opinion, it said.

DOC.HEAD: No Bond For Escapee Accused Of Killing Girl Found Under Bed
DOC.TEXT: A prison escapee charged with raping and murdering a little girl found dying in a laundry bag under his bed is a ``clear and present danger,'' a judge said Monday in ordering him held without bond. Alcides Quiles, 27, faces charges of first-degree murder, kidnapping and sexual assault in the apparent strangling Sunday of Joanna Noda, who would have turned 2 years old Wednesday. The victim was found the second time police searched Quiles' quarters. ``He took the police into his apartment not once, but twice,'' marveled Detective Ronnie Ilhardt. ``And he sat right there while they were looking. But when the body was found, he ran out the door.'' Three years ago in Hartford, Conn., Quiles was charged with raping a 6-year-old friend of his son, leaving the boy beaten bloody and unconscious in the snow. The resulting publicity led two women, one of whom was stabbed in a robbery the same day, to identify him as their assailant as well. Quiles was sentenced to 18 years in those cases, but escaped in August by climbing over a fence topped with razor wire at a minimum-security prison in Enfield, Conn. He had been transferred to the prison in June, two years after he was sentenced. He made his way to Miami and rented a room under an assumed name, police said. He appeared Monday before Dade County Judge Murray Meyerson, and was quickly denied bond on the murder charge. ``This court finds you are a clear and present danger,'' the judge said. ``To protect the community, you will remain in custody. No bond for you, Mr. Quiles.'' Joanna disappeared Sunday morning, triggering a frantic search by neighbors and police in her family's working-class neighborhood. Quiles watched the search from his doorway across a fence from the Noda home, and told her family that Joanna was bound to turn up, said her cousin Tanya Lopez. ``He said, `She's not in here. You can check if you want,''' said Tanya, who helped in the search. ``And she was under the bed - she was dead under the bed.'' Police were approached during the search by a woman who said she had seen a man running down the street after the little girl. Joanna's father had apparently left a yard gate open when he rushed into his house to answer the telephone. Joanna then left the house and slipped through the gate to chase a chicken down the street. The woman witness told police that Quiles chased Joanna in what appeared to be an attempt to keep her from running into the street, but then took the little girl's hand, according to the police report. After talking to the woman, investigators returned to interview Quiles again. Quiles told police a bag they spotted under his bed contained dirty laundry, but the officers decided to check it. After Quiles fled when the body was found, he was caught after a short chase. Joanna was still breathing when found, but was pronounced dead shortly afterward at Jackson Memorial Hospital. Joanna's father, Rolando Noda, grabbed his shotgun and ran toward the police car where Quiles sat handcuffed after his arrest, but an officer stopped him and persuaded him to put the gun away. ``I was blind with rage,'' Noda said later. Joanna's sister, Mary Cecilia Noda, 7, said she could not understand the death. ``I feel bad. I don't know, I just feel like doing something to that man for what he did to my sister,'' she said. Connecticut authorities made a formal request for his extradition Monday, but prosecutors said any such action would wait until after Quiles' trial here.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Votes to Strike Mention to Warsaw Pact from Defense Law
DOC.TEXT: Parliament on Monday unanimously voted to strike out any reference to the Warsaw Pact in its defense law, state radio said. The unicameral legislature also agreed to lower the term of military service for draftees from 18 months to 12 months, and make corresponding cuts for those opting for ``unarmed military service,'' or civilian service. Hungarian politicans serving in the nation's first democratically elected government in more than four decades have served notice that they intend to pull out of the alliance, Soviet led before the wave of democracy ended East Europe's communist era. As in Czechoslovakia, Soviet troops stationed for decades are in the process of pulling out. Hungary plans to reduce its own armed forces by more than 30 percent after the initialing of a Warsaw Pact-NATO deal later this year on cutting conventional weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Suspended Student Holds Teacher, Students Hostage
DOC.TEXT: A 17-year-old high school student held a classmate hostage at gunpoint Monday after taking over a classroom and then freeing his teacher and five other students, officials said. The student, Eli Dean, made no demands and fired no shots. Negotiators were communicating with him over the school's intercom system, said state police Sgt. Marvin Jenkins. ``The important thing is we don't want anybody injured and we don't think he does either,'' Jenkins said. The rest of the 643-student school was evacuated onto the school football field. Hostage negotiators were at the school, and two state police chaplains were flown in. Members of Dean's family also were present, including his father, Robin, a civilian employee of the state police. Jenkins said snipers were positioned around the school, but that officials were keepings their options open. ``We're not making a move ... We're not in any great rush to do things,'' he said. The student, a senior, had been suspended from school twice during the past two weeks. He returned to the school late Monday morning with a handgun, officials said. Dean let his teacher leave first, and then later let most of the students go. The youth's stepfather, Rocky Williams of Charlestown, said he believed Dean had taken his .44-calibre pistol to the school. State police said they did not know what type of weapon the boy had. Williams said his stepson was suspended about two weeks ago after he accidentally set off a fire alarm. He was suspended again last week for breaking a window, Williams said. ``He was falling behind in his school work and was upset,'' his stepfather said. Police refused to speculate on Dean's motives. ``Maybe the fact that he's 17 years old is as much reason as anything,'' Jenkins said.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Releases Document on the 1962 Missile Crisis
DOC.TEXT: The Cuban government Monday released a document on the 1962 missile crisis and reiterated its bitterness over the Soviet decision 28 years ago to remove the missiles without consulting with Cuba. The government news agency Prensa Latina, in a dispatch monitored in Mexico City, ran a description of the events it said was culled from a 200-page secret document that Fidel Castro's government just released. ``Twenty-eight years after the October Crisis that pushed the world to the brink of nuclear war, the Cubans maintain their claims from the era and reproach Nikita Khrushchev for having exluded them from secret conversations,'' the article begins. There appeared to be little new in the document, and its release seemed to be in the nature of nursing an old grudge at a time when relations between the Soviet Union and Cuba have hit a post-revolutionary low. Although the Soviet Union is still providing aid to Cuba, the Soviet press recently has published a series of revealing, unflattering reports, including a rare portrait of Castro's personal life that said he has 32 houses, a security contingent of 9,700 and five children by his ``present wife.'' Cuba has dedicated a new monument on the launch site for the rocket that shot down an American spy plane during the crisis, Prensa Latina reported in a separate dispatch Monday. The monument contains a rock wall surrounded by palm trees, symbolizing the decision of Cubans to defend their territory, it said. In the summer of 1962, the Soviet Union began installing 42 medium-range nuclear missiles in Cuba. U.S. spy planes detected the missiles, and the United States began a naval blockade of Cuba. Tensions peaked when Cuba shot down a U-2 spy plane on Oct. 27; Khrushchev submitted to President Kennedy's demand the missiles be withdrawn. In newly released excerpts of his memoirs, Khrushchev called Castro a ``hothead'' who wanted the Soviet Union to attack the United States during the crisis. Castro denied that story. The document released Monday said the Soviet Union had sent a delegation to Havana in May 1962 to discuss installing the weapons as a means of discouraging the United States from attacking the island. Cuba accepted the plan in June after a meeting of the political leadership, including Castro, his brother Raul Castro, Ernesto ``Che'' Guevara, Osvaldo Dorticos, Blas Roca and Emilio Aaragones, it said. The weapons, medium-range R-12 missiles, began arriving after Raul Castro visited Moscow in July and signed a secret agreement, according to the report. About 43,000 Soviet soldiers, officers and specialists were sent to Cuba in connection with the deployment, it said. The Soviet general in charge and his second-in-command had orders to use the missiles ``only in case of aggression by the United States and only under orders from Moscow,'' the report said. The document, whose origins and author weren't specified, expressed bitterness at Khrushchev's neglecting to warn Castro of his decision to pull back the missiles. ``Since the missiles had been installed under a military agreement between the Soviet Union and Cuba, it is totally normal that, if something changed, both sides be consulted,'' the report said. ``Even if the hypothesis of lack of time is accepted as the cause for Cuba not having been consulted, Khrushchev's answer to Kennedy could have been: `We are in agreement with removing the rockets if the Cubans' demands for security are satisfied and, of course, if they participate in the negotiations,''' it added. Kennedy pledged in a secret agreement that the United States would not attack Cuba. But Castro said the guarantee was insufficient unless accompanied by withdrawal of naval and economic blockades, an end to CIA-funded harassment, and closure of the U.S. navy base at Guantanamo. ``Today, 28 years after the crisis, the .. points expressed by Fidel Castro still apply. The Cuban-U.S. conflict is not resolved,'' Prensa Latina said.

DOC.HEAD: Arts Endowment Drops Non-Obscenity Pledge
DOC.TEXT: The National Endowment for the Arts has quietly dropped a controversial requirement that grant recipients sign a non-obscenity pledge, now that Congress has voted to scrap explicit restrictions on the kinds of art eligible for federal subsidies. The pledge, instituted by endowment chairman John E. Frohnmayer late last year, has spawned three federal lawsuits charging that it violated the Constitution's free-speech guarantees. At last count, 16 artists and arts institutions refused to sign the pledge and forfeited more than $318,000 in endowment grants last year. The endowment made no formal announcement of Monday's action, but agency officials confirmed that the pledge had been withdrawn and would not be required as a condition of receiving grants for the 1991 fiscal year, which began Oct. 1. These officials would not permit use of their names. Last year, Frohnmayer ordered all grant recipients to promise in writing they would not violate a congressional ban against endowment support for works that ``may be considered obscene,'' including depictions of homosexual or sadomasochistic activities, sexual exploitation of children or ``individuals engaged in sex acts.'' Endowment officials said they did not know if the pledge covering last year's grant recipients would be repealed retroactively. If last year's grant recipients are still bound by the pledge, said constitutional lawyer Floyd Abrams, he will continue to press his lawsuit against the endowment on behalf of the New School for Social Research, which is challenging the non-obscenity pledge in U.S. District Court in New York City. ``It is hard to believe the NEA would persist in a policy so plainly rejected by Congress for the future,'' Abrams said in a telephone interview from New York. ``If they insist on requiring this oath for fiscal 1990 (grants), an ultimate judicial resolution will be required,'' Abrams said. Shortly before it adjourned last weekend, Congress junked the obscenity ban it imposed on the arts endowment a year ago and voted instead to leave judgments of obscenity to the courts. The proposed new law awaiting President Bush's signature would require the endowment to recoup its grant money from any recipient who is later convicted of violating obscenity laws. The bill omits any explicit obscenity restrictions, saying only that obscenity lacks artistic merit, is not protected speech under the Constitution and ``shall not be funded'' by the endowment. The measure does require that grant awards take into consideration ``general standards of decency and respect for the diverse beliefs and values of the American public.'' The bill also extends the endowment's statutory authority for three years, with a first-year budget of $175 million, a $4 million increase over last year's current spending. It approves a Republican-backed request that the state share of endowment grant money be increased from 20 percent to 35 percent over three years. The National Campaign for Freedom of Expression, a non-profit lobbying organization representing artists and arts supporters, denounced the new proposed law as a ``more insidious form of censorship'' than the old obscenity ban. Joy Silverman, acting director of the group, said the bill would transform the endowment chairman into ``the federal government's primary arts censor,'' stifle artistic creativity and foster ``official art.'' ``The new mandate of this NEA will be not to support art, but rather to ensure no one is offended by art,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Businessman's Six-Year Battle With Soviets Ends in Settlement
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has settled an American businessman's lawsuit with an undisclosed sum and acknowledgement that an allegation he was a spy was based on ``past misunderstandings.'' An attorney for Palo Alto businessman Raphael Gregorian said Monday the atmosphere of perestroika, or openness, in the Soviet Union helped resolve the bitter international dispute. Attorney Jerry Kroll said both sides agreed to keep their financial agreement confidential. A settlement agreement, approved by U.S. District Judge David Kenyon last week and delivered to atorneys Monday, said ``the parties wish amicably to put an end to the disputes between them arisen from past misunderstandings ...'' Kroll said that language was critical to Gregorian, who believes it absolves him of Soviet accusations that he was a spy. Gregorian ran a $10-million-a-year business selling medical equipment in the Soviet Union until he was ousted from the country in 1984 amid allegations printed in the newspaper Izvestia that he was a spy. The Soviets refused to return or pay for medical equipment Gregorian left behind when he was forced out. In a unique legal move, he sued Izvestia for libel and the Soviet government for breach of contract. He contended the timing of his ouster indicated it was retaliation for the U.S. arrests of Svetlana and Nikolay Ogorodnikov in a spy case involving former FBI agent Richard W. Miller. The lawsuit took a colorful path through the courts with Gregorian first winning by default when the Soviets failed to respond. When Kroll began seizing Soviet assets in the United States to satisfy a $463,000 judgment in Gregorian's behalf, the Soviets hired attorneys to fight back. The Soviets were backed by the U.S. State Department, which said Gregorian couldn't sue the Soviet Union because of the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act. Eventually, Kenyon dismissed libel portions of the case, but ruled the Soviets owed Gregorian $163,165 for the medical equipment left in Moscow. An appeals court reversed that decision and sent the case back to Kenyon in 1989 for a new trial. The settlement precludes any new trial. ``I'm very pleased about the outcome,'' Kroll said. ``Just the fact that they admit it was a misunderstanding clears my client's good name.'' He said the seeds of the settlement were planted when he met last year with Gennady Gerasimov, spokesman for Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. He subsequently met with Soviet Vice Consul Oleg Tischenko in San Francisco, taking with him a copy of Gorbachev's book ``Perestroika.'' ``I pulled out the book and said `I read your boss' book and I think what we're doing in this case is inconsistent with perestroika,''' Kroll said. ``He seemed to agree.'' He said Gregorian had put his life on hold while the lawsuits were pending. ``He's glad that his name has been cleared,'' Kroll said. ``He's now working on other business opportunities.''

DOC.HEAD: 120,000 Israelis Call General Strike on Tuesday
DOC.TEXT: About 120,000 Israelis called a general strike Monday that the workers hope will silence radio and television, halt trains and planes, stop mail delivery and paralyze the operations of government offices. The strike, called by unions of engineers, technicians and academics, will start Tuesday and continue indefinitely until wage demands are met. The unions are demanding that wage agreements reached with the public sector include employees of government-owned companies, while the Finance Ministry wants the two kept separate. The unions also demand the Finance Ministry drop a move to cut extras and want increased pension funds. It was unclear as to exact numbers and what percent of an increase the unions wanted. The Finance Ministry insisted government companies already in the red could not afford to pay employees more. Yaakov Danon, head of the wage division at the Ministry, said the unions' demands could not be met. Many government-owned companies have fallen into debt this past year and tough layoffs have created much discontent.

DOC.HEAD: Canine Controversy Raises Hackles in House of Commons
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with government winning measure; picks up 11th graf pvs, `The dog-registration...'
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, whose parliamentary majority is usually as faithful as Lassie herself, srvived a dogfight Monday night in the House of Commons to defeat a measure for stray canines. Legislators voted 274 to 271 to reject a compulsory dog registration plan aimed at dealing with an estimated half-million abandoned dogs who roam and foul the streets. The compulsory plan by the opposition Labor Party and animal welfare groups was aimed at registering Britain's 7 million dog owners and tagging the animals. The vote drew intense interest in Britain, a nation of animal lovers. Government ministers bitterly opposed the plan, proposing instead to raise fines and give more powers to local authorities to pursue offenders. But large numbers of lawmakers from Mrs. Thatcher's Conservative Party supported the measure. Mrs. Thatcher usually enjoys a 100-vote margin in Commons. Traditional British reserve went to the dogs as the two sides duked it out. ``The debate could have taken place only in this country, and in a nation reared on Greyfriars Bobby and Thomas Hardy's dog Wessex,'' The Times wrote in an editorial. On Monday, the Royal Society for the Protection of Animals placed a graphic full-page ad in The Daily Telegraph. It showed a mountain of dead dogs over the message: ``Registration is better than extermination.'' In April, the pro-registration forces narrowly lost a Commons vote in favor of compulsory registration. In the biggest revolt of this Parliament by Conservative lawmakers, 50 of them defied their leaders to vote with the opposition and 46 abstained. The government's hundred-vote majority shrank that night to 12. Then, on Oct. 23, the unelected House of Lords voted to incorporate a national registration plan into the Environment Protection Bill. After Monday's vote, the bill will go back to the House of Lords for a final vote. The dog-registration crusade was led by one of Mrs. Thatcher's own partisans, Dame Janet Fookes, who has championed it for 15 years. An estimated half-million abandoned dogs roam and foul the streets of Britain. The dog-registration campaign gained urgency from several well-publicized incidents in which children were mauled. According to recent polls by the Royal Society for the Protection of Animals, 94 percent of people who are aware of the dog registration issue support it, and 84 percent of local authorities favor some form of compulsory registration. Police, farmers, vets, and other major organizations directly with dog welfare and control have also backed registration. ``I think the government is in danger of losing it,'' Dame Janet said of Monday's vote. In 1988, the government abolished dog licenses costing less than a dollar, arguing that the fees cost more to collect than they raised in revenue. Dame Janet said that program was ineffective anyway. She advocates the registration of both dog and owner for an initial fee of around $38. The funds raised would finance a national warden system. Dogs would be marked with tattoos or microchip implants for easy identification. Government ministers say registration would be ignored by the dog owners who now cause the problems, and the fee would be just another burden on the poor. Government proposals include transferring responsibility for rounding up strays from police to local councils, fining owners for dogs without collars and identity tags, and creating a specific offense of letting a dog stray.

DOC.HEAD: Police, Islamic Fundamentalists Clash
DOC.TEXT: Police and Islamic fundamentalists exchanged tear gas and firebombs Monday in a running battle in the center of the Tunisian capital, witnesses said. There were no injuries reported. The demonstration by 300 members of the banned Islamic movement An-Nahda appeared aimed at the release of a leader, Ali Larridh, arrested Saturday for holding a meeting not permitted by law. Police arrested several demonstrators after dispersing them with tear gas, witnesses said. The protesters first hurled stones and then crude firebombs at police cars, setting one ablaze. It was the first reported use of the gasoline-filled bottles in weeks of clashes between police and the fundamentalists, who wish to be allowed to run for public office.

DOC.HEAD: Police Chief May Call For Investigation
DOC.TEXT: The city police chief says an internal investigation will precede any request to involve state law enforcement officers in the case of three female dancers who wrestled nude in gelatin at a police night spot. The dancers entertained Saturday at the Police Club, which was being used by a separate, unrelated organization. Police Chief Charles Austin said the outcome of the internal investigation will determine whether he will ask State Law Enforcement Division to decide if any obscenity laws were violated. Austin said he also will conduct an internal investigation to see if any police had prior knowledge that nudity would be part of the entertainment when the Police Club was rented by an organization called the Men's Luncheon Society. ``If anyone on the force had prior knowledge, then I have a serious problem with that,'' Austin said. A member of the society who attended the party, Hayne Hasell, said about 200 men watched the gelatin wrestling. The Police Club is operated by a private organization of the same name made up of Columbia police personnel. Austin said an organization with as much visibility as the Police Club ought to have guidelines to make sure its facilities are used properly. He said he never has been a member of the Police Club, but does approve of the group. ``That's the sad part about this,'' Austin said. ``It's a very legitimate group. Those guys have done a lot of good, such as having Christmas parties for kids.'' The Men's Luncheon Society is not connected with the Police Club, City Manager Miles Hadley said. He said a police officer's brother reserved the facility for the group.

DOC.HEAD: Council Demands Iraq Pay for Human Rights, War Damages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf `Senior military' to UPDATE with meeting ends without statement. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `U.S. Ambassador...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council voted Monday to hold Saddam Hussein's regime liable for human rights abuses and war damages during its 3-month-old occupation of Kuwait. The vote was 13-0, with abstentions by Cuba and Yemen. It was the 10th resolution condemning Iraq since Saddam's troops overran Kuwait on Aug. 2, and it warned of unspecified further action if Iraq does not obey the council. Senior military officers from the five permanent Security Council members met to discuss implementation of the sanctions, but the meeting ended early in the evening and no statement was issued. U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering delivered a warning of possible independent U.S. action. ``It is the solemn duty of every state to protect its citizens. My government takes this responsibility most seriously,'' Pickering said in his council speech. ``We join the council in this demand and we urge the government of Iraq to comply. But I want to underscore one point. ... The United States will do that which is necessary to meet its obligation to its own citizens.'' Abdul Amir Al-Anbari, Iraq's ambassador to the United Nations, rejected the resolution. He said the Security Council was applying a double standard in dealing more harshly with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait than with Israel's occupation of Arab territories. Pickering said the Iraqi speech was ``the greatest pack of distortions, lies and bizarre tales that I have ever seen. It was like bringing the fox in to advise on how to guard the henhouse.'' The resolution also demands that Iraq allow foreign governments to send supplies to their diplomats in occupied Kuwait City. The United States and Britain are the only Western nations with embassies still operating in Kuwait. The resolution, which cites violations of the Fourth Geneva Convention, also hints at a future war crimes inquiry. There was no specific mention of a tribunal or reparations. The resolution did not establish a mechanism for collecting compensation, but said all states should assemble information about losses of life, injury and torture, loss of revenue, damage and loss of property. The military meeting, the highest-level in many years at the United Nations, included Lt. Gen. Michael Carns, director of the Joint Staff of the United States, and Col.-Gen. Bronislav A. Omelichev, first deputy chief of the Soviet Army. The Soviet Union consistently has sought revival of the Security Council's Military StaffCommittee, and has said it only would join an international military action in the gulf under a U.N. umbrella. During the Security Council meeting Monday, Ethiopia's envoy declared: ``Iraq shall be held accountable and, indeed, responsible for the lawlessness of its occupation forces and face the attendant consequences.'' Ambassador Tesfaye Tadesse told the council, on behalf of the Non-Aligned Movement and the Organization of African Unity, that Iraq has refused to comply with the will of the international community. ``There is not the slightest indication from Baghdad of any change of heart,'' he said. The council is left with no choice, he said, ``but to send a message that the unity and resolve of the council to end the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait is as strong as ever.'' The resolution demands that Iraqi forces stop mistreating and oppressing Kuwaiti and other nationals. It demands that Iraq ensure immediate access to food, water and basic services for Kuwaiti nationals and foreigners in Kuwait and Iraq, including diplomatic missions in Kuwait. Western diplomats said privately that this could be the last resolution exhorting Iraq to obey its resolutions and indicated the council would adopt a more action-oriented posture. The council has been acting under Chapter 7 which provides for Security Council sanctions and even collective military action against member states which threaten international peace and security. The council already has invoked Article 41 but has not exhausted its non-military provisions, which include interruption of economic relations and of rail, sea, air, postal, telegraphic, radio and other means of communication. Article 42, the next step envisoned by some members, calls for ``such action by air, sea or land forces as may be necessary to maintain or restore international peace and security, (including) demonstrations, blockade and other operations by air, sea or land forces of members of the United Nations.'' The Security Council includes the five permanent members with veto power: the United States, Britain, China, France and the Soviet Union; and 10 non-permanent members: Canada, Colombia, Cuba, Ethiopia, Finland, Ivory Coast, Malaysia, Romania, Yemen, Zaire.

DOC.HEAD: Freed Hostage Says Americans, Britons in `Bad Shape'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to UPDATE with plane carrying hostages landing in France, new figures for number on board, former hostage's statement, detaisl. Picks up graf 14th pvs, `Mitterrand said ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A returning French captive on Monday urged the United States and Britain to do something for their hostages in Iraq and Kuwait, because they are ``in very bad shape.'' ``Please take them away. They cannot carry on much longer,'' said the woman, one of 263 French hostages and 19 other Westerners who flew to freedom on an Iraqi Airways jet. Also on board were the last seven diplomats from the besieged French Embassy in Kuwait. ``We want to tell the United States and Britain to do something for their hostages. They are in very bad shape,'' the French woman said. She spoke on condition of anonymity at Baghdad airport. The chartered Boeing 747 arrived at midnight at Charles de Gaulle-Roissy airport. Most of those aboard were males, clad in T-shirts and business suits. A former hostage in Kuwait who identified himself as Father Sanchez said conditions were especially difficult for Western captives held at strategic sites to ward off military attack. ``They are never free, never able to walk around,'' he said. ``There are ready to crack.'' Of his own captivity, he said: ``Three years like that and I would die.'' Other hostages said Iraqi troops in Kuwait were gradually crushing the Kuwaiti resistance and that sounds of gunfire indicating clashes have grown less and less frequent. About 60 French citizens also believed to have been in Iraq and Kuwait were not on board. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said some chose to stay behind and others may have managed to leave on their own. Isabelle Renior, the Foreign Ministry officer in charge of the hostage case, said that one French citizen of Italian oriigin was prevented from leaving Iraq but had no further details. ``I can say now that all French citizens who wanted to go home have gone home,'' said Andre Janier, the French charge d'affaires in Iraq. Baghdad announced last week that it would allow all French hostages to leave. The move was widely interpreted as an effort to split the international alliance against Saddam Hussein. France has stressed that it did not negotiate for the freedom of its citizens, and has demanded that all foreign hostages be freed. ``I express the joy of all the French people to those coming home,'' President Francois Mitterrand said. ``But we will rejoice fully only when the other hostages can return to their own countries.'' The Iraqi Airways plane picked up evacuees in Kuwait City in the early afternoon before flying to Baghdad, where hundreds of hostages celebrated with beer and whiskey as the plane landed. Nine Greeks, four Britons, two Filipinos, one German and one Spaniard were also on board, officials at the Baghdad airport said. About 2,000 journalists and relatives cheered the aircraft's arrival in Paris. Authorities closed one of the two main terminals, forcing dozens of scheduled flights to reroute. Mitterrand spoke at a joint news conference with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev after signing a cooperation agreement between the two countries. Gorbachev said U.N. sanctions against Iraq should be intensified, and suggested that Saddam is beginning to yield to economic pressure. He also said Saddam would be making a mistake if he expected a split in the international alliance against him. ``I think it's unacceptable to have a military solution, but President Hussein should not indulge in speculation,'' Gorbachev said. ``We want to do step by step everything that ensures that sound logic prevails, and you can't call what they (Iraq) have done anything other than adventurism.'' Gorbachev said Saddam's position may have shifted, and suggested he might be receptive to a new inter-Arab initiative, possibly led by Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Harvard to Sponsor AIDS Conference
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `The conference ...' to CORRECT spelling of principal. Picks up 3rd graf, `In June ...'
DOC.TEXT: Harvard University said Monday it will sponsor the annual international AIDS conference in 1992, four months after threatening to cancel the forum unless the United States removed travel restrictions on people infected with AIDS. The conference, the principal forum for presenting scientific information on the fight against the disease, will go ahead in the last week of May 1992, school officials said. In June, the Harvard AIDS Institute threatened to withdraw as sponsor and cancel the conference to protest a U.S. policy making AIDS infection one of several contagious diseases for which foreigners could be barred from the country. But under a revised immigration bill passed by Congress over the weekend, Health Secretary Louis Sullivan would have the authority to remove AIDS and other diseases from the medical list for which a person may be denied entry. Sullivan has repeatedly said there is no reason to exclude people with AIDS, because the disease is not passed casually, but only by exchanes of blood or body fluids or by sexual contact. The measure went to President Bush, who has indicated he will sign it as early as this week. The conference is expected to attract about 15,000 researchers, policy makers, community organizers and AIDS patients, Harvard officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Minnesota Republicans in Disarray in Picking Grunseth's Successor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4 grafs for 11th graf, `Secretary of ...' to UPDATE with Grunseth running mate refusing to withdraw. Picks up 12th graf, `Graves said ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MP1
DOC.TEXT: A sharply divided state Republican Party scrambled Monday to pick a new gubernatorial candidate after Jon Grunseth stepped down because of allegations of sexual misconduct. With just eight days before the election, Sept. 11 primary runner-up Arne Carlsn hopes to parlay his week-old write-in campaign into the GOP ballot spot. Leaders of the party's ruling conservative faction balk at that, believing that Carlson is too liberal. But with time so short, some in the anti-Carlson camp agree their options are limited in their effort to unseat Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich. ``Pressure is really mounting to go with Arne,'' said Frank Graves, a member of the Republican National Committee and one of Carlson's biggest critics. ``The thing that really worries me the most is with two liberals on the ticket (Perpich and Carlson) I'm afraid a lot of conservatives are going to stay home,'' Graves said. ``If they stay home it hurts our candidates for constitutional offices and our legislative candidates.'' Grunseth withdrew Sunday night, citing ``enormous pressure'' from allegations that he encouraged teen-age girls to swim nude with him nine years ago and had an affair during both of his marriages. He has denied the pool-party claims and said the affair ended before he married his second wife in 1984. An Oct. 19-21 poll, conducted after the pool-party allegations, showed Carlson leading Perpich 51 percent to 41 percent. But Graves said Monday it's far from a sure thing that Carlson could win a head-on race against Perpich on Nov. 6. Neither Perpich nor his spokesman, Ray Bohn, returned a call seeking comment Monday. Perpich declined to comment Sunday about Grunseth's withdrawal. A leader of the Republican party's conservative faction, 3rd Congressional District Chairman Jim Mullin, said a ``certain number'' of anti-abortion Republicans will vote for Perpich because Carlson supports legalized abortions and Perpich does not. Further complicating the question is the fact that party officials themselves aren't sure what procedure to use in naming a replacement for Grunseth. The party's 14-member executive committee is to meet Tuesday evening to decide whether it has the power to name a successor. Later Monday, Grunseth campaign official Elam Baer said Grunseth's running mate, Sharon Clark, has decided not to withdraw and ``as far as we're concerned, she is the Republican candidate for lieutenant governor.'' But Secretary of State Joan Growe, the state's chief election officer, said her office has concluded that Clark is no longer a candidate. ``Our position is if one person on the team withdraws, then the team no longer exists,'' Growe said. Growe said that if the party concludes there is no legal machinery to pick a new candidate so soon before the election, state law calls for the primary runner-up - Carlson - to go on the ballot. Graves said he wants the executive committee to name a candidate, regardless of what legal advice party leaders receive. ``I would recommend that we reject any notion of not doing anything, of not taking any action,'' he said. ``My position is that the state executive committee should name someone, even if it's Carlson.'' But Graves said he will push to have a conservative candidate named. In August, Graves termed Carlson ``not a Republican'' but rather ``an opportunist who changes his views to fit the latest public opinion polls.'' ``What I said then was the truth and it remains the truth,'' Graves said Monday. ``Probably the only thing that has changed is that I probably would prefer to have Arne Carlson in there than than Rudy Perpich.'' State GOP Chairwoman Barb Sykora said she's concluded that ``the only sensible option is the option that looks like we are legally bound to: Support Arne Carlson to the best of our ability and beat Rudy Perpich.'' Carlson said he's confident that party leaders will conclude that he should be on the ballot. He also said he's trying to reach out to conservatives to bring them into this campaign. However, he said he's continuing his write-in effort until the ballot spot is decided. U.S. Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, the party's titular leader, has called for Republicans to unite behind Carlson. ``We can't bring a new candidate on at this point,'' said Boschwitz, who had encouraged Grunseth to step aside and who is also seeking re-election. Growe said Republicans have until 5 p.m. Friday to get a new candidate on the ballot.

DOC.HEAD: Sudan Denies Famine Exists, Refuses Food Relief
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with Sudan official rejecting relief assistance, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The chief government economist on Monday angrily denied reports that millions of the African country's citizens face starvation, and said Sudan would refuse relief even if there was famine. Col. Salah al-Deen Karar, chief of the ruling junta's economic affairs committee, told the official Sudan News Agency: ``We will never accept any food assistance, even if famine is declared in Sudan.'' On Sunday, the military junta leader, Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir, charged that foreigners were spreading false warnings of famine to make the government look bad. ``Sudan is not suffering from any famine in whatever form,'' el-Bashir said. ``Those who speak of famine in Sudan are only seeking to tarnish and create difficulty for the government.'' Karar charged that international relief agencies were ``responsible to a great extent'' for Sudan's current shortfall in grain supplies, because they have bought large quantities of Sudan's staple sorghum on the open market to feed refugees, he said. This resulted in price increases for sorghum that put it beyond the means of many Sudanese who otherwise would have been able to buy food, Karrar said. Karar said that if relief organizations want to help the country and feed people displaced by hunger, ``they should bring their food from outside Sudan.'' Witnesses testified in Congress last week that a horrendous drought is coming to Sudan, and urged the junta to announce a famine emergency so an international relief operation can proceed. Roger Winter, director of the U.S. Committee for Refugees, a private group, said famine ``of biblical dimensions'' threatens as many as 11 million Sudanese. Andrew Natsios, the U.S. government's top relief official, accused el-Bashir's government of being ``increasingly indifferent if not overtly hostile to the relief efforts.'' U.S. officials have long accused the government, which seized power in a military coup 16 months ago, of preventing food from reaching the south, where rebels have been fighting for autonomy since 1983. Karar said Sudan no longer depends solely on rain-fed projects but also is banking to a greater extent on lands in central Sudan irrigated by Nile River water. ``A million feddans (acres) of sorghum have been cultivated this year in the irrigated areas,'' he said. ``This is expected to yield 700,000 tons in addition to the harvest of central Sudan's rain-fed areas.'' The foreign press is reporting untrue famine stories to ``demoralize the Sudanese and ridicule the government's slogan `We eat from what we cultivate,''' Karar said. Junta leader el-Bashir acknowledged that Africa's largest country has food shortages caused by late and insufficient summer rains. But he claimed the shortfalls will last only until December, when the winter harvest comes in. ``One has to confess about the food gap of which some regions suffer, mainly North Kordofan and Darfur in the west,'' el-Bashir said. In the last two months, more than 10,000 people in those sprawling regions of western Sudan have migrated in search of food to makeshift camps near Khartoum. Relief works here say it is early to speak of devastating famine. But without a massive relief effort, they say, millions will be at risk by next spring or summer as this fall's harvest becomes depleted before the next one is ready. The strongman's comments did not quantify the extent of the current food gap. Speaking to visiting journalists last week, Agriculture Minister Ahmed Ali Genaif put the grain shortage at a million tons. On Sunday, Sudan News Agency quoted drought-stricken Darfur's deputy governor as saying: ``The situation is reassuring, and no famine is imminent as reported by the Western media.'' The agency also reported that Col. Faisal Medani Mukhtar, governor of neighboring Kordofan, had disclosed arrangements to meet an estimated grain shortage of 300,000 tons in his region. Mukhtar told the agency that 200,000 tons of sorghum and wheat already were shipped to Kordofan this month from other parts of Sudan.

DOC.HEAD: Suspended Student Holds Teacher, Students Hostage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with standoff ending. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `The youth's ...'
DOC.TEXT: A 17-year-old high school student held a teacher and six students at gunpoint in a classroom Monday, gradually freeing them before surrending to police eight hours later. The student, Eli Dean, made no demands and fired no shots, and negotiators communicated with him over the school's intercom system during the standoff, said state police Sgt. Marvin Jenkins. Dean, a senior, had been suspended from school twice during the past two weeks. He returned to the school late Monday morning with a handgun, officials said. The rest of the 643-student school was evacuated onto the school football field. Police said Dean surrendered about 7:20 p.m. EST after releasing his final hostage, believed to be a male cousin. Hostage negotiators were at the school, and two state police chaplains were flown in. Members of Dean's family also were present, including his father, Robin, a civilian employee of the state police. Jenkins said snipers had been positioned around the school. Dean let his teacher leave first, and then freed the students, nearly all of them individually. The youth's stepfather, Rocky Williams of Charlestown, said he believed Dean had taken his .44-calibre pistol to the school. State police said they did not know what type of weapon the boy had. Williams said his stepson was suspended about two weeks ago after he accidentally set off a fire alarm. He was suspended again last week for breaking a window, Williams said. ``He was falling behind in his school work and was upset,'' his stepfather said. Police refused to speculate on Dean's motives. ``Maybe the fact that he's 17 years old is as much reason as anything,'' Jenkins said.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selected in Ruby Gun Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with jury seated, details. Picks up 8th graf, `The gun ...'
DOC.TEXT: A jury was seated Monday in a trial to decide who is the rightful owner of a .38-caliber Colt Cobra revolver Jack Ruby used to kill presidential assassin Lee Harvey Oswald. The case before Dallas County Probate Judge Robert E. Price could end 23 years of legal wrangling between Ruby's heirs and Jules Mayer, a lawyer who knew Ruby and was named executor of the Dallas nightclub owner's estate. But with the twists and turns the case has taken through the judicial system since Ruby died Jan. 3, 1967, nothing is certain. The six-person jury selected Monday was expected to hear opening statements Tuesday. The court is dealing with the questions of how to distribute Ruby's assets and whether to remove Mayer as executor. Mayer still practices law at age 82. Attorneys for Ruby's brother, Earl, were expected to question Mayer's ability to handle the estate in light of his advanced age. Potential jurors were questioned about their views on mandatory retirement and a person's professional effectiveness beyond a certain age. The most valuable asset in the estate is the .38-caliber Colt Cobra Ruby used to kill Oswald in the basement of the Dallas City Jail two days after President Kennedy's assassination here in 1963. Ruby was convicted of murder in 1964 and sentenced to die in the electric chair. A Texas appeals court overturned the conviction in 1966, citing reasons that included failure to move the trial from Dallas. Ruby died at age 55 before a new trial could be held. For years since then, Mayer and Earl Ruby have been fighting over ownership of the gun Jack Ruby bought for $62.50 in a Dallas gun shop. The gun is stowed in a bank safe deposit box. Mayer estimates it could bring $125,000 on the collectors' market. Whatever its value, Mayer contends money from sale of the gun should go to pay off Ruby's debts. He says they include the $65,000 it has cost him to handle the estate, including the expense of fighting Earl Ruby's lawsuits. Earl Ruby, of Boca Raton, Fla., who is also acting on behalf of his sister and a nephew, counters that Mayer is trying to profit from the estate. He wants the estate liquidated to pay off his brother's debts and ``wipe the slate clean.'' He also claims that Jack Ruby gave him deathbed instructions to tear up the will in which he had named Mayer executor. Apart from the coveted gun, the estate consists largely of the clothes and jewelry Ruby wore when he shot Oswald, and some personal papers. Earl Ruby said Monday that if he loses, he will ``go home and cry a little bit'' but will not appeal. Regardless of the trial's outcome, it's unlikely to be the last word on the gun matter. Last year, the Internal Revenue Service stepped into the case claiming that Ruby owed $17,000 when he died. That amount, the IRS said, has grown to $86,010 with interest and penalties. The state of Texas also claims the estate owes it $1,227 in back taxes. Earl Ruby says the IRS sacrificed any claim by waiting 22 years to act on it. Price has set a trial for February to hear the IRS claim.

DOC.HEAD: Immigration Bill A Boon To Irish
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of illegal Irish immigrants in New England, New York and other places will have the chance to become legal citizens under provisions of an immigration bill awaiting President Bush's signature. In all, the bill could provide more than 80,000 permanent residency visas to Irish immigrants by the turn of the century. That's roughly double the number of Irish visas granted throughout the 1980s. The visas would be available to those living in Ireland or illegal aliens living in the United States. ``Our offices in New York have been pretty well inundated over the last couple of weeks from prospective applicants,'' Sean Minihane, a lobbyist for the Irish Immigration Reform Movement, said Monday. ``In Boston particularly there will be a collective sigh of relief.'' Irish illegal aliens are concentrated in the Boston and New York metropolitan areas. New York City, northeastern New Jersey and southwestern Connecticut account for roughly 70,000 illegal or ``undocumented'' Irish residents, according to Minihane. The Boston area has an estimated 25,000. Other pockets of Irish residents include Chicago, Hartford, Conn., Philadelphia and San Francisco. Existing immigration law has cut off the supply of visas granted to Ireland at well below the actual demand. The current immigration formulas favor visa applicants who have recent-immigrant relatives already living in the United States - countries such as Cambodia, Vietnam and Mexico. The new bill would substantially boost the number of immigrants allowed into the United States each year, especially those with job skills. President Bush has said he supports the legislation. White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen said the bill could be signed into law as early as this week. The bill would boost the current limit of 490,000 immigrants a year to 645,000 through the 1994 fiscal year. After that the limit would be 675,000 per year. Irish advocates told of illegal aliens unable to travel to Ireland to attend a family funeral for fear they would not be allowed to return to the United States. They told of skilled professionals and artisans forced to tend bar or mind children because they could not enter the job market. ``You had young women forced to work as nannies or as waitresses because they couldn't teach here, although they were teachers in Ireland,'' said Frank Costello, who works on Irish and immigrant issues for Boston Mayor Ray Flynn. ``That was a waste of a tremendous amount of talent and education that could be put to our use.'' In Ireland, there remains the problem of a flourishing education system turning out skilled graduates to an economy with 17 percent unemployment. ``The Irish government is delighted with this legislation,'' said an official with the Irish embassy in Washington, who asked not to be named. ``By most economic forecasts, we will be stuck with the problem of emigration until the next decade. We are providing new jobs but not at a fast enough rate.'' Immigrants from Italy and Poland are among the other countries expected to benefit from the legislation. But for the next three years, Ireland would be the only country with a guaranteed number of visas - 16,000 per year for a total of 48,000. After 1994, up to 7,700 Irish would receive visas annually under a ``diversity'' provision of the bill designed to offset the unfairness of past immigration formulas. In addition, Irish could apply under the traditional categories of family ties and employment. For the latter half of the decade, Ireland could reach the maximum allowable total for any country in a year, 20,000. Those numbers compare to the roughly 3,000 to 5,000 Irish visas issued per year in the early 1980s and about 7,500 in the latter part of the decade.

DOC.HEAD: French Hostages Freed; Bush, Baker, Shamir Make Hawkish Statements
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to ADD further Baker comments on hostages in Iraq, Saddam statements in CNN interview, minor editing. No pickup ^LaserPhotos DHA1,2
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of French citizens arrived in Paris late Monday after leaving Baghdad on a flight to freedom following a three-month ordeal in which they had been held hostage in Iraq and occupied Kuwait on the orders of Saddam Hussein. President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III warned the United States would be quick to attack Iraq if provoked. Israeli Prime MInister Yitzhak Shamir said Iraq would pay a ``terrible price'' if it ``lay a finger on Israel.'' There was no indication whether the unusually hawkish remarks, in separate speeches Monday, were made in coordination or meant to respond to any specific threat from Iraq. The U.N. Security Council voted to hold Iraq liable for damages caused by its takeover of Kuwait. Later, officers from the five permanent council members met to discuss the sanctions in one of the highest-level military meetings at the United Nations but the session ended without a statement. In Paris, throngs of family members and journalists cheered as the chartered Iraqi Airways Boeing 747 carrying 263 French citizens and 19 other Westerners touched down at Paris' Charles de Gaulle-Roissy airport at midnight. Among the Frenchmen were the last seven diplomats who endured an arduous siege of their embassy in Kuwait. The Iraqi jetliner picked up more than 50 French evacuees in Kuwait City in the afternoon before flying to Baghdad, where hundreds of hostages celebrated with beer and whiskey as the plane landed. About 60 French citizens believed to have been in Iraq and Kuwait did not leave. A French spokesman said some opted to stay behind and others may have managed to leave on their own. Isabelle Renoir, the Foreign Ministry officer in charge of the hostage case, said one French citizen of Italian origin was prevented from leaving Iraq. She did not provide other details. ``I can say now that all French citizens who wanted to go home have gone home,'' French charge d'affaires Andre Janier said. Hundreds of Westerners remain in Iraq and Kuwait, some detained at strategic sites as part of Saddam's ``human shield'' against attack by the U.S.-led multinational force. Some of the French citizens freed Monday had been part of the shield. ``The Iraqis constantly move hostages from one site to another,'' said freed hostage Patrick Moniodde, a director of the French perfume company Caron. ``There was no hygiene,'' he said. ``Toilets were very dirty, but we always got medical care. Sure, Iraqis do not want to lose any hostages. We are free today, but it was terrible for others.'' Baker also offered new insights on the treatment of Americans being held in Iraq and Kuwait. ``These Americans are forced to live on vermin-ridden concrete floors. They are kept in the dark during the day and move only at night. They have had their meals cut to two a day. ... Many are becoming sick as they endure a terrible ordeal,'' Baker said. Baker is to travel to Saudi Arabia on Friday. Moniodde said he met at least a dozen American and British hostages and noted they were ``very depressed.'' The Foreign Ministry confirmed France will honor Iraq's demand to fill the jetliner with medicine for the return flight. Medicine is excluded from the U.N. embargo of Iraq and Kuwait. President Bush said the United States would ``have no hesitancy at all'' to use military force if provoked by Iraq and indicated he feels no obligation to get Congress' approval. But Bush said at a news conference in San Francisco he was ``not preparing anybody for anything. I'm as determined as I've ever been that this aggression will not stand.'' More than 200,000 U.S. troops have been sent to the gulf. Baker, in a speech released in Washington, said Iraq would suffer ``the most severe consequences'' if Saddam decides to use chemical or biological weapons. ``Let no one doubt: We will not rule out a possible use of force if Iraq continues to occupy Kuwait,'' he said. The U.N. resolution, the 10th since Iraq overran Kuwait on Aug. 2, was approved by 13 nations. Cuba and Yemen abstained. Abdul Amir al-Anbari, Iraq's ambassador to the United Nations, said the resolution ``will make it possible for those who advocate war, combat and aggression to explicitly say that they have exhausted all attempts to achieve peace, and that they have failed, and that the war option is the only option left.'' In previous resolutions, the Security Council has isolated Iraq with an economic embargo and permitted U.N. member countries to use warships to enforce it. The council also has demanded Iraq withdraw from Kuwait and release all hostages. The new resolution demands that Baghdad allow food, water and other supplies to be sent to Western diplomatic missions in Kuwait. The United States and Britain are the only Western nations with embassies still open in Kuwait. In August, Iraq cut off water and electricity to all embassies that refused to close and relocate in Baghdad. French President Francois Mitterrand welcomed the release of the hostages, saying: ``I express the joy of all the French people to those coming home. But we will rejoice fully only when the other hostages can return to their own countries.'' Mitterrand spoke at a news conference outside Paris with visiting Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Gorbachev said Saddam should not expect to split the international alliance opposed to his seizure of Kuwait. ``We must not permit the Iraqi regime to hope there will be a division, a weakening of positions,'' Gorbachev said, calling Iraq's use of hostages ``amoral.'' He said Arab nations might now be able to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis. ``It seems to me that the Iraqis could be ready for this,'' Gorbachev said. ``If we were to have an inter-Arab meeting, this would be the quickest way to a settlement.'' Gorbachev's Middle East troubleshooter, Yevgeny Primakov, met with Saddam on Sunday, and there was confusion about the success of his mission. Initial reports said Primakov made little progress, but on Monday Gorbachev said there were indications the Iraqi president was being more flexible.
