Later Monday, however, in a CNN interview, Saddam said that while the meeting was ``useful,'' he repeated he had no intention of ordering his forces to leave Kuwait. Saddam also said he hoped war would not break out but that Iran and Iraq, which fought from 1980-88, were ``the only armies with wide experience in fighting wars'' in the region. Crude oil rose $1.67 to $34.68 per barrel for December delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid concerns that Primakov's mission had failed. Saddam also told the Cable News Network it would be wrong to say nothing was accomplished by Primakov's visit. He said he told Primakov ``how the solutions could be reached to many of the issues in the region.''

DOC.HEAD: Bulk of Philippines Aid Up To Bush
DOC.TEXT: Congress has left the future of aid to the Philippines in the hands of the Bush administration, directing the transfer to that country of only about one fourth of the $681 million that could go there. The foreign aid bill sent to President Bush during the weekend gives him broad discretion in how to allocate billions of dollars in military and economic assistance to several countries for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. The president is expected to sign the $15.5 billion bill within the next few days and decide within a month how to dole out portions which Congress has not set aside for specific countries. Congress required that certain amounts be given to some countries, including Egypt and Israel, but allowed the president more discretion than in the past for others. The final version restores $60 million of aid that had been cut out of the bill for the U.S.-led Multilateral Assistance Initiative for the Philippines. That brought the total for the program to $160 million, the same as last year. The initiative is aimed at providing up to $10 billion in aid and loans to the Philippines from several countries over five years. Bush also has the authority to allocate an additional $40 million for the program as well as all or part of the $456 million he pledged in military and economic aid tied to the presence of U.S. military bases in the Philippines. Last year, the amount Bush pledged was cut by $96 million, bringing complaints from President Corazon Aquino and clouding current talks over the future of the bases. An additional $25 million each year is tied to the bases agreement, but it is provided under separate legislation in the form of housing investment guarantees. Altogether, Congress gave Bush authority to disperse more than $2 billion in aid that it did not designate for specific countries. But it cut about $700 million from his overall foreign aid request, leaving it to the administration which programs to reduce.

DOC.HEAD: 62 Flee Haiti Prison by Knocking Down Wall
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - Sixty-two inmates at a minimum security prison in western Haiti pushed over a crumbling prison wall and escaped, a radio station reported Monday. The break Sunday afternoon caused panic in the town of St. Marc, 48 miles west of Port-au-Prince, the independent radio Haiti Inter reported. Soldiers caught three of the 62 escapees but the rest fled through the streets, the radio said. An additional 21 prisoners remained behind. In June, the Lawyers Committee on Human Rights, a private U.S. group, visited the prison and reported the convicts were living in cramped, filthy conditions and were seldom fed.

DOC.HEAD: Aid To Zaire Goes Only To Non-Government Groups
DOC.TEXT: Congress has cut off all military aid to the central African country of Zaire and required that any other assistance go only to non-government groups because of alleged corruption and human rights abuses. The restriction in the foreign aid bill that passed both houses of Congress during the weekend includes a provision that will allow aid to groups that work with the Zaire government on humanitarian programs. The bill also allows funds for an ongoing child survival program which the U.S. Agency for International Development is operating with the Zaire government. U.S. aid to Zaire last fiscal year totalled close to $54 million, including $4 million in military help. The bulk went to food and development programs. The bill for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1 does not designate specific amounts for programs in Zaire, but leaves it up to the administration to decide how much to designate. President Bush is expected to sign the foreign aid bill within the next few days. A congressional report accompanying the legislation cited ``numerous reports from reputable human rights organizations detailing a continuous pattern of human rights abuses by Zairian security forces.'' Amnesty International accused Zaire in a report last month of continued violations by government security forces, including violent repression of government opponents. The report said that although abuses have diminished in recent years, incidents of banishment, torture and detention without charge or trial are being uncovered. President Mobutu Sese Seko, who has ruled the country for 25 years, has promised political reforms. In April, he gave citizens the power to form political parties and trade unions. But the report by the Senate Appropriations Committee said optimism about reform in Zaire was fleeting and has been followed by delays and brutal attacks by Mobutu's security forces against pro-democracy youths. The Zaire government said that a May 11 incident involving Lubumbashi University students left one dead and 13 injured, but news reports in Europe said the death toll was between 50 and 150. ``The committee does not believe it is in the interest of the United States to provide financial support to a corrupt government that continues to flagrantly violate fundamental human rights,'' the congressional report said. ``While the committee recognizes the dire needs of the Zairian people who are among the poorest in the world, it cannot support aid that legitimizes or supports the Mobutu regime,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Rejects Mandela Request for Aid
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela said he was disappointed at Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's rejection Monday of a request for $25 million in aid to the African National Congress. Kaifu told the ANC deputy president that Japan cannot grant the aid because it does not give assistance to political parties. Instead, he offered money to South African groups working to improve living conditions in South Africa, news reports said. In addition, blacks would be eligible to come to Japan for occupational training under U.N. auspices. Mandela, who was freed in February after more than 27 years in prison, is to make a rare speech by a non-head of state in Parliament on Tuesday. He arrived Saturday for a six-day visit. In his 50-minute meeting with Kaifu, Mandela said the ANC wanted the money to help 20,000 political prisoners due to be released soon by the South African government, the news reports said. Mandela said other countries have pledged money to the ANC, and he hoped Japan would make an exception in its funding rules, the Kyodo News Service reported. The report quoted an unidentified Foreign Ministry official. Kaifu told Mandela that Japan has given $1.4 million worth of assistance this year to black South Africans, Kyodo reported. Mandela was asked in a television interview to comment on the controversy over a slur against blacks last month by Japan's justice minister, Seiroku Kajiyama. Mandela said ``this is a matter which I would like to leave in the hands of the leaders of this country.'' Kajiyama provoked protests in Japan and in the United States when he compared prostitutes in Tokyo to blacks in America who ``ruin the atmosphere'' of neighborhoods they move into. He later apologized and was reprimanded by Kaifu but was allowed to keep his job despite calls for his resignation. Japan has banned direct private investment in South Africa since the 1960s and does not have an ambassador in Pretoria, although it maintains diplomatic relations with South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Japan in Dialogue with U.S. Blacks, Jews, Ambassador Says
DOC.TEXT: Japan's ambassador to Washington said Monday he would welcome more teaching in Japanese schools about the concerns of such U.S. minorities as blacks and Jews. ``I can say categorically that anti-Semitism has no roots in Japan,'' Ambassador Ryohei Murata told a gathering of the American Jewish committee in what was described as the first speech by a Japanese envoy in Washington to a Jewish group. ``Many Japanese are really ashamed'' of the recent slur against African-Americans by their country's justice minister, he added later in answer to a question. Both Murata and his hosts agreed that all concerned have recognized and are addressing the problem of a knowledge gap about each other on the part of the Japanese and the Israelis, and the Japanese and American Jews, African-Americans and other U.S. minorities. Meanwhile, Japanese-Israeli relations are expanding, said Murata. ``We know quite a lot about the holocaust,'' in which millions of Jews were killed in World War II, ``but there is no systematic teaching or education about it,'' the ambassador said. ``I would welcome more efforts be made to enhance understanding and knowledge about how the Jewish people suffered.'' ``We have been discussing with African-Americans'' increasing awareness of minority issues in the United States, he added. Murata said that as ambassador, ``I worked rather hard'' dealing with the uproar in the United States stirred by Japanese Justice Minister Seiroku Kajiyama's remark in September comparing American blacks to prostitutes moving into and spoiling residential neighborhoods. He said he had met with leaders of the Congressional Black Caucus and the National Association for Advancement of Colored People, who have threatened a consumer boycott of Japanese imports. Kajiyama apologized for his words and was publicly reprimanded by Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. ``We should take steps so we can have more constructive relations with minority people in the United States,'' said the ambassador. One reason many of his countrymen are insensitive to their concerns, he said, is because Japan itself is such a homogenous society with only very small minority groups. As for anti-Semitism, he said, the problem was ``almost total lack of knowledge'' in Japan about Jews, providing unwarranted prominence three years ago for several books with ``inaccurate portrayals of Jews and Judaism. Some of those books sold well at one time but that phenomenon does not exist any longer.''

DOC.HEAD: Eagle Helps Himself to Hunter's Dead Duck
DOC.TEXT: For an alert eagle it was fast food, Alaska-style. After a morning of unsuccessful hunting on the Mendenhall wetlands near Juneau, Gary Gunstrom finally dropped his first duck of the season Sunday. As his golden retrievers dashed after the bird, a mature eagle swooped down and stole it. ``He just snatched that thing and didn't even pause,'' Gunstrom said. ``The one dog couldn't believe it.'' It was the only duck Gunstrom saw all day, but he doesn't begrudge the eagle an easy meal. ``No, he can have it,'' said Gunstrom, a biologist with the state Department of Fish and Game. ``It was worth the trip just seeing that happen. The sort of thing that can only happen up here.''

DOC.HEAD: Eight Theater Groups Receive Grants for U.S., European Productions
DOC.TEXT: Eight theater companies will receive grants from AT&T to present three new works and three adaptations of classics next year in regional theaters in the United States and one theater in Europe. The grants were announced Monday by AT&T. Among the artists involved in the three AT&T OnStage Classics presentations are actress Diana Rigg, who will appear in a London revival of ``All for Love,'' a rarely produced Restoration tragedy by John Dryden, and Robert Wilson, who will design and direct a production of Henrik Ibsen's ``When We Dead Awaken'' in Cambridge, Mass., and Houston. ``All for Love'' will be presented by the Almeida Theater in London for a limited engagement beginning April 30, 1991. ``When We Dead Awaken'' will be performed at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., in February and the Alley Theater in Houston in May. The third classic adaptation will be a modern-day version of Shakespeare's ``The Winter's Tale,'' done by the Cornerstone Theater Company. The ensemble troupe that will tour 12 states and perform outdoors in such cities as New York, Washington, Boston and Miami next summer and fall. The amount to be spent on the classics presentations was not disclosed, but AT&T will spend $180,000 on new play development, the company said. Receiving grants under AT&T's ``New Plays for the Nineties Project'' were: - The Old Globe Theater in San Diego, $50,000, to present ``The White Rose'' by Lillian Garrett. The play, which opens Jan. 17, 1991, concerns a group of anti-Nazi students in World War II Germany. - The Denver Center Theater Company in Denver, $50,000, to present ``Back to the Blanket'' by Gary Leon Hill. The play looks at the 1890 Indian massacre at Wounded Knee. It opens May 17, 1991. - Center Stage in Baltimore and the La Jolla Playhouse in La Jolla, Calif., $40,000 each, to co-present a play entitled ``The Heliotrope Bouquet by Scott Joplin and Louis Chauvin.'' The play, written by Eric Overmyer and called ``a lyric theater poem,'' opens Feb. 20, 1991, in Baltimore. It will be performed in California next August.

DOC.HEAD: Former U.S. Attorney General William French Smith Dies at 73
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Smith served ...' to CORRECT spelling of Orr's first name to Verne, sted Vern, and include names of Bloomingdale and Tuttle; SUBS 10th graf, `A member ...' to CORRECT that Smith graduated from Berkeley, sted UCLA. SUBS 2 grafs for 8th graf, `Attorney General ...' to UPDATE with comment from Reagan; Picks up 9th graf pvs, `Norman Barker ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Smith-Profile.
DOC.TEXT: William French Smith, one of Ronald Reagan's kitchen cabinet confidants who helped make the former president a millionaire and served as his first attorney general, died Monday of cancer. He was 73. Smith led the Reagan administration's conservative shift on a number of issues affecting domestic policy, notably civil rights. Under his influence, the administration took a more laissez-faire attitude toward antitrust law, even though it presided over the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Co. A Navy officer during World War II, Smith later became Reagan's personal attorney, helping guide the investments that made the former actor a millionaire. Smith served as the informal chairman of the president's kitchen cabinet, a group of California millionaires who saw Reagan socially and helped pick his first Cabinet. Others in the group included Justin Dart, Walter Annenberg, Verne Orr, William Clark, Alfred Bloomingdale and Holmes Tuttle. Smith was surrounded by his family when he died at the University of Southern California's Kenneth Norris Jr. Cancer Hospital, where he was admitted Oct. 2, said spokeswoman Betsy Bates. Ms. Bates said that at the request of the family, the hospital withheld details on Smith's cancer. ``William French Smith served his country with the greatest dedication and distinction,'' Reagan said in a statement. ``As attorney general, he brought talent, wisdom, and the highest integrity to the Department of Justice. ``Nancy and I are deeply saddened today,'' he said. ``We have lost a dear friend, who we will always remember with the greatest respect and affection.'' Norman Barker, managing partner of Gibson Dunn & Crutcher, the prestigious Los Angeles law firm Smith joined after leaving the Navy in 1946, said Smith's ``list of accomplishments go on and on and on.'' Smith was the firm's specialist in corporate relations with labor. A member of an old New England family, Smith was born Aug. 26, 1917, in Wilton, N.H., and raised in Boston. He graduated from the University of California at Berkeley in 1939 and received his law degree from Harvard in 1942. Smith was appointed the 74th attorney general of the United States in 1981 and served until 1985. He was followed by Edwin Meese III. At his confirmation hearings, the publicity-shy Smith responded to virtually every question by saying he would have to study the matter. Early in his tenure, a magazine story quoted an administration official as calling him a ``somnambulist,'' or sleepwalker, a description that rankled him. But if he started slower than his predecessors, Smith altered more department policies more sharply than any attorney general in a generation. Among the changes in which he played a key role were the appointment of the first woman, Sandra Day O'Connor, to the Supreme Court; legislation overturning a 100-year-old ban on military aid to civilian law enforcement; relaxation of rules against corporate mergers, which had not been changed in 15 years; and halting the Justice Department's advocacy of mandatory busing to desegregate schools and of hiring and promotion goals to remedy job discrimination. Solicitor General Kenneth Starr, who served as a partner in Smith's law firm and later as his chief of staff in the Justice Department, called his former law partner and mentor ``an immensely gifted lawyer with marvelous sound and wise judgement and unfailingly kind and thoughtful.'' ``It was one of the ironies of his tenure that it was a tenure characterized by such far-reaching and profound change in the direction of the federal legal system ... (that) it was done in a quintessentially quiet, prudent and lawyer-like fashion,'' Starr said. Terry H. Eastland, a former aide to Smith and later the Justice Department's chief spokesman under Meese, said Smith was ``someone who was concerned about getting the law right, about doing the right thing in a particular instance.'' Eastland, now a conservative commentator and legal affairs writer, and Starr credited Smith with formulating the Reagan administration's response to the growing drug problem. The regional task forces for the Drug Enforcement Administration were set up under Smith's leadership. ``He was one of the early proponents of the proposition that drugs are causing crime,'' Starr said. ``He felt strongly about that.'' Former Appellate Judge Robert H. Bork, whose Supreme Court nomination was defeated by the Senate in 1988, called Smith ``a very thoughtful man'' who played a low-key but important role in picking judges for the federal bench. ``Since he was the one who talked me into becoming a judge, I happened to think he is a good judge of judges,'' said Bork, who was appointed to the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia by Reagan. Smith was one of 60 patients being treated at the Kenneth Norris Jr. hospital, which specializes in experimental treatment, Ms. Bates said. She did not know if Smith was undergoing experimental treatment. The hospital is associated with the University of Southern California and is one of 24 comprehensive cancer centers in the nation designated by the National Institutes of Health.

DOC.HEAD: State Attorney General's Theft-by-Deception Trial Enters Second Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The trial ...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with prosecution resting its case, other details; Picks up 4th graf, `Ms. Christie ...' INSERTS 4 grafs after 8th graf, `The defense ...' to UPDATE with new testimony. Picks up 9th graf, `Among the ...'
DOC.TEXT: State Attorney General Steve Clark proposed marriage and got his engagement ring returned to him over dinners paid for by the state, his former fiancee testified Monday. Carrie Christie, an Atlanta lawyer, testified about more than a dozen meals and trips she took with Clark in 1986 and 1987. The trial of Clark, 43, on a charge of theft by deception, entered its second week Monday. Three of his former girlfriends, including a former fiance, testified about hotel bills and lavish meals that Clark paid for using a state-issued credit card. The prosecution rested its case Monday. Defense attorney Bill Bristow said he would ask the judge to dismiss the case Tuesday. Failing that, he planned to call Clark to the stand, he said. Ms. Christie said she traveled to Washington, D.C., twice to meet Clark while he prepared to argue on the state's behalf before the U.S. Supreme Court. She said she also traveled to San Francisco and New Orleans with Clark. She said he arranged dates with her in Atlanta while he was on a stopover to catch another flight to attend to state business elsewhere. Ms. Christie also told the jury that Clark routinely jotted notes on the back of his Visa receipts after dinner. That testimony could be key because Clark has claimed he made mistakes in his record keeping while trying to update his expense claims 60 to 90 days after the fact. The prosecution says Clark used a state-issued Visa card to wine and dine family, friends, girlfriends and political supporters. He could be sentenced to 20 years in jail and fined $15,000 if convicted. The defense argues that the seven elected officials whose titles are in the state constitution, including Clark, are exempt from state spending laws and regulations. A state auditor testified Monday that Clark received $14,000 over two years from lawyer Ed Miller to pay his rent and a utility bill. Miller listed Clark as a guest at seven state-paid meals worth $1,414. Prosecutors are attempting to show Clark used state money to woo political and personal contributors. Cheryl Pruett of Germantown, Tenn., who works in a bank, said she spent the night with Clark at a Memphis hotel, and the defense said records show the state paid for the room and food service. Ms. Pruett also said she was in Hawaii with Clark in December 1986 when he used a state credit card to pay $571 for a lunch after a wedding. Karen Aufdenberg of Little Rock, who recently left a job at the Little Rock Chamber of Commerce, testified that Clark paid for at least eight meals with her that he billed to the state. Among the state-paid meals Ms. Christie testified about was an August 1986 dinner at an Atlanta restaurant. Clark wrote on his expense forms that Georgia Attorney General Michael Bowers attended the meal to discuss medical fraud investigations. Ms. Christie said Bowers was not at the meal and state business was not discussed. She said it was her first date with Clark. During a March 1987 weekend in Washington, where Clark and several staff members went to prepare for the Supreme Court appearance, Ms. Christie said he proposed to her over a state-paid meal. In August 1987, Clark and Ms. Christie had dinner in Atlanta. The meal was written off to the state, but Ms. Christie said the main thing that was discussed was her decision to break off the engagement. They dated occasionally after that, she said. Clark's attorney, Bill Bristow, got Ms. Christie to acknowledge that state business or law was discussed at some of the meals. She was a law student at the time. She said the main topic at any meal with Clark was his ambition to be governor. Dozens of people Clark listed as guests at state-paid meals say they didn't eat with him. Some say they picked up the tab. Clark bought fancy food, expensive wine and courted women with the credit card, according to some of the 126 witnesses who testified last week. Bristow has said none of that is against the law for a man who is on the job 24 hours a day.

DOC.HEAD: Court Awards Benefits to Widow of Alcoholic Brewery Worker
DOC.TEXT: The widow of a brewery worker who became an alcoholic taking advantage of free beer at work is entitled to workers' compensation benefits, an appeals court said in a ruling issued Monday. Ruling on the case of Casimer A. Gacioch, who worked at the Stroh Brewery Co., the state Court of Appeals said alcoholism is like any disease and workers are entitled to compensation if the work environment aggravates their condition. While Gacioch was predisposed to alcoholism before the brewery hired him, he was not an alcoholic when he got the job, the court said. The circumstances of the job shaped the course of Gacioch's disease, the court said, ``aggravating and accelerating the underlying alcoholic predisposition to the point of uncontrolled addiction, thus constituting a personal injury'' under worker compensation laws. Gacioch drank only three or four beers on weekends when he began working on the assembly line at Stroh's in 1947, said Norton Cohen, an attorney for Gacioch's widow, Wanda. Stroh's policy, following a 300-year-old European tradition, permitted workers to drink all the beer they wanted during breaks, and that contributed to Gacioch's alcoholism, Cohen said. By the time he was fired in 1974, Gacioch was drinking 12 bottles of beer a day, Cohen said. Gacioch died in 1977 when his hospital bed caught fire while he was smoking. At the time he was being treated for severe liver problems caused by his drinking. His widow could receive $106 a week in workers' compensation benefits. An attorney for the brewery failed to return a telephone call seeking comment.

DOC.HEAD: 8th Game of Chess Showdown Adjourned
DOC.TEXT: The eighth game of the world championship chess match was adjourned Monday, and observers said challenger Anatoly Karpov had the edge on titleholder Garry Kasparov. Play was to resume Tuesday at 5:30 p.m. when Kasparov's 41st move is unsealed and played. Kasparov had appeared to have an advantage throughout the game, but Karpov was one pawn ahead when the game adjourned and leading grandmasters said he had the better position on the board. Karpov had a similar advantage after Friday's Game 7, his only victory so far. Then, too, observers felt Karpov was in a superior position on the board when the game was adjourned because of his extra pawn. Kasparov conceded the game Saturday, leaving the pair tied 3{-3{ in their $3 million showdown. A player gets one point for a victory, and each player gets a half point for a tie. Each player has now won once, with the other five games ending in draws. The first player to reach 12{ points wins the championship. Kasparov, who dethroned Karpov in 1985, would retain his title if the match ended in a 12-12 tie. The first 12 games are being played in New York and the remainder will be played in Lyon, France. The winner will get $1.7 million and the loser will get $1.3 million.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Pastor, Church Members Sentenced for Beating Man
DOC.TEXT: A minister and two church members accused of trying to ``beat the devil'' out of a depressed man were sentenced Monday to two years' probation and 200 hours of community service. District Judge Mickey Pennington also ordered the Rev. James D. Price, 43, pastor of the First Assembly of God Church, and church members Robert L. Nixon Jr., 43, and Alvin R. Nixon, 32, to each pay a $1,500 fine, $600 restitution and court costs. The three were convicted last month on charges of false imprisonment. Ray Weimers, 44, testified that they restrained and beat him in January as part of a religious rite. The beating left Weimers with facial scratches and bruises and a separated right shoulder. Dr. Ricardo Castillo, who treated Weimers, said his patient was depressed and had confided to Price about marital and financial problems. Castillo testified that the pastor told Weimers he was feeling badly because he had the devil in him and needed to be exorcised. The three faced a maximum possible sentence of 10 years in prison and $5,000 fines.

DOC.HEAD: Surviving Year One
PART III: Born Too Soon and Too Small: The Legacy of Poor Prenatal Care
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto NR1 of 10-24; Series Logo
DOC.TEXT: The cost of America's failure to ensure that pregnant women receive proper care can be calculated in the millions of dollars. But it also can be measured in the tortured body of an infant born too soon and too small, as Mitchell Landsberg finds in the last of a three-part series, ``Surviving Year One.'' ---

Eric could almost fit in his father's hand, if his father were there to hold him. He is so small, so weak, so sick - a little boy pushed into the world far before his time. He is kept alive by machines. Machines make Eric breathe, and machines keep Eric warm. Machines feed him and machines record his heartbeat, his pulse rate, his temperature. He lives in a sterile glass crib, surrounded by banks of blinking lights, tangled in a webbing of tubes and splints and bandages. His eyes and his mouth open and shut, and he writhes gently. For all the machinery, it is human suffering that contorts his face and a human will that keeps his tiny heart beating. It shouldn't have been this way. Eric was born six months into his mother's pregnancy, without benefit of meaningful prenatal care or decent nutrition, and most likely with the damaging effects of drugs. Now Eric, like his sister before him, is in the neonatal intensive care unit at the Children's Hospital of New Jersey. Here, in the corroded core of one of America's poorest cities, doctors and nurses struggle daily to save babies who enter life too soon, too sick and too small. ``This is so typical,'' says social worker Debbie Beacher, who has just finished listening to Eric's mother recite her story of drug abuse and homelessness. ``An unwed mother, young, a drug abuser, has a baby born prematurely that ends up in this unit.'' It is like this around the nation, in cities big and small, in places like the Hospital for Sick Children in Washington, D.C., and Valley Children's Hospital in Fresno, Calif. ``We're seeing a growing need for our kind of hospital in just the past few years,'' said Dr. Edna Leung, a pediatrician at the Hospital for Sick Children. ``It's sad. We enjoy what we do ... but we just wish we could make some of these problems go away.'' The problems won't go away, and their legacy is children like Eric. Society pays, and the costs are enormous. It costs about $600 to administer prenatal care to a woman during the nine months of a normal pregnancy. Drug treatment for a crack addict costs about $5,000. Without prenatal care, without drug treatment, the risks of a woman delivering a premature, low birthweight child increase dramatically. And so do the costs. It costs an average of about $25,000 to treat a low birthweight infant - one under 5.5 pounds. For extremely low birthweight babies, under 1.65 pounds, the average is more than $100,000. That's an average. Some cost far more. Once, the point would have been moot - such tiny babies would have died at birth. But medicine has made tremendous strides in saving them. Between 1980 and 1987, the infant mortality rate in the United States dropped by about 20 percent. During the same period, the percentage of infants born to mothers who had no erly prenatal care scarcely changed, and the percentage of low birthweight infants actually increased. Since birthweight is the single most important indicator of infant health, the meaning is clear: Children are being born sicker than ever, and medicine is using superior technology to keep them alive. In Fresno, Dr. Nadarasa Visveshwara has been treating a baby that weighed exactly 1 pound at birth. The child's mother, who is on Medicaid, had received very little prenatal care. The baby is now six months old. The medical bills have topped $750,000 and probably will be around $1 million by the time the child is released from the hospital. The prospects for the child ever enjoying a productive life, Visveshwara said, ``are very poor.'' Does he ever ask, is it wise to save such children? ``Almost all the time,'' he said, ``because we hesitate to produce an infant who will be a burden to the parents and to society, and who won't be able to lead a productive life. ... But the baby always gets the benefit of the doubt.'' Eric, whose real name is being kept confidential, weighed slightly more than 2 pounds at birth. In 1960, his odds of surviving infancy would have been about one in 10. Today, they are better than 50-50. His medical bills are around $100,000 and climbing, and his parents have no ability to pay. His birth was costly, but not in financial terms alone. There is an incalculable cost in pain and suffering, in emotional distress and social disruption. These are statistics for extremely low birthweight infants, those somewhat smaller than Eric: - 90 percent will suffer respiratory problems. - 70 percent will have brain hemorrhages. - 80 percent will have heart problems. - 50 percent will have liver problems. - 5 percent to 10 percent will be blind. - 2 percent to 3 percent will die of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome. Of those who survive, 40 percent will be mildly handicapped, 40 percent will be severely handicapped and 20 percent will be normal. There's more. Premature infants are much more likely than other children to have cerebral palsy. They are much more likely to have learning disabilities later in life. And children who spend their infancy in a hospital will have difficulty bonding with their families, a trait also widely attributed to children exposed to drugs in the womb. The longterm emotional costs are yet unknown. ``There's just not that closeness, and these kids have more difficulty when we get them home,'' said Dr. John H. Niles Jr., president of the Medical Society of the District of Columbia. ``They're just not the joy that a baby should be.'' ``It's like a Vietnam kind of thing,'' Niles added. ``These kids have been in a battle, and there are going to be some scars. And society is going to pay for those scars.'' The easiest way to avoid the scars, most people believe, is to make prenatal care widely available and do whatever it takes to get women to take advantage of it. The most commonly repeated statistic about prenatal care is that every $1 spent on it will save $3.30 in future medical costs. Dr. Shyan Sun, director of neonatology at the Children's Hospital of New Jersey, is a skeptic. He shuffles through a file drawer to pull out a list of everything his patients have going against them. They are poor, they are young, they are unmarried, uneducated; they abuse drugs, they drink, they smoke. ``One cannot naively believe that prenatal care alone will solve the problem,'' Sun insisted. ``I am not optimistic that we will make a difference in the near future. We still have to take care of all these social problems.''

DOC.HEAD: NEWARK, N.J.: social problems.''
DOC.TEXT: It is a daunting prospect, as Eric and his mother illustrate. Eric's mother, who asked that she be called Jane, is 25 years old. She was born prematurely herself, and says her mother, her brothers and sisters all were born prematurely too. She is a small woman, with sharp features and a dull stare. Eric is her fifth child - all have been born prematurely and small. ``My 2-year-old, he came home on a heart monitor, so I dealt with that,'' she says matter-of-factly. ``And my 6 year-old, when he came home he was having seizures. ... My oldest one, he was the biggest of everybody. He was 4 pounds, 13 ounces.'' Jane was living in a homeless shelter during her pregnancy with Eric. She says she tried to get prenatal care, but the doctor ``had an attitude'' and lectured her about eating corn chips. She didn't go back. She insists she stopped doing drugs before her pregnancy; her social worker says that's a lie. Since Eric was born, the hospital has had to ask the police to pick up Jane every time it needs her consent to perform surgery. ``I hate to come here,'' Jane says. ``It gets depressing, seeing all those babies like that. God forbid I get attached to him and he dies, then I've got a real emotional problem there. I'm not saying I don't love him, but I just don't like seeing him like that.''

DOC.HEAD: Getting Help From a Reluctant State
With PM-Surviving Year One III
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Kelly Crockett snuggled next to his mother, too young to do much of anything except eat, sleep and cry. Too young to know that he is starting life a step behind most other babies. Despite city-wide efforts to improve health care services and lower Indianapolis' sky-high infant mortality rate, Joseph's mother struggled to get caseworkers at the Marion County Welfare Department to extend Medicaid to her fourth child. ``They don't care, or they don't want to care,'' said Lisa Carter, 24. ``It's too much of a headache for them. It's almost as if you're asking them for $20 out of their pocket.'' Joseph was born prematurely; he was delivered at 36 weeks by emergency Caesarian, and weighed 5 pounds. And it took seven weeks before Joseph was added to the welfare rolls, before he could receive Medicaid, Aid to Families with Dependent Children, food stamps. In the interim, the pediatrician and hospital didn't press for payment, but Miss Carter had to pay for his food and transportation to the doctor herself. Joseph's father tried to help, but judging from the support he gave Lisa during her pregnancy, she knows she couldn't count on him. Nor could she count on the welfare department. The conscientious caseworker who handled her file for two years recently quit. With her departure returned the threats that the family's Medicaid and Aid to Families With Dependent Children would be cut off because of improper paperwork. But then, Miss Carter says her Medicaid coverage has been taken away twice - both times unjustly, she believes. Miss Carter was 5 when her mother was murdered, but she overcame that to become an A student in school. At 16, her first child, Taron Smith, was born, but she overcame that to graduate from high school. Two years later, she was working toward an associate's degree in secretarial sciences when her grandmother became ill. She quit school to care for her and never returned. At 19, her daughter Shenika was born, weighing just 4 pounds, 12 ounces. Miss Carter had become a single, teen-age mother with two young children, and she couldn't find a way out. ``I'm not stupid, but I have had plenty of tragic situations in my life,'' she said. ``But I can't use that as a crutch.'' In Indiana, a family of four must be living below 32.7 percent of the federal poverty level, bringing in less than $385 a month, to be eligible for Medicaid and AFDC. Only Alabama, Arkansas, Louisiana, New Mexico, North Carolina, Texas and West Virginia have stricter standards. For pregnant women and children under 6 years old, the picture is brighter because of federal mandates. In April, Congress required all states to provide Medicaid coverage to pregnant women and young children with family incomes below 133 percent of the federal poverty level, $1,972 per month for a family of four. Miss Carter feeds, clothes and shelters her family on child support she receives from the children's fathers and on her $405 in monthly AFDC payments, the state's maximum payment for a family of five. Thirty-six states have higher payments. Even a part-time job at minumum wage would boost her income above the state's limits. She and her oldest child would be ineligible for Medicaid and the whole family would lose its AFDC and food stamps. Still, Miss Carter has goals. She's looking for a job that pays enough to take care of her four children. She wants to return to school. ``My situation is not something that's good for my baby or my other three babies,'' she said. ``I want to help myself, but I need support. And I don't have any.''

DOC.HEAD: IMF, in Search of More Space, Building New Home for Neighboring Church
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The International Monetary Fund, which pumps billions of dollars into debt-plagued economies around the world, is taking on a project closer to home - building a new church for a small congregation that's been its neighbor since 1973. Some time in the next few weeks, the IMF expects to close a deal to acquire the quarter-acre property of the Western Presbyterian Church, bringing to a close negotiations that began in the 1960s. In return, the fund is buying a new site, a few blocks away, where it will build Western Presbyterian a new, slightly larger home with a kitchen for feeding the homeless. It will move the church's English Gothic sanctuary, fieldstone by fieldstone and stained glass window by stained glass window, and rebuild it as part of the new structure. Not only that, it will provide Western Presbyterian with an endowment, reported to be $4 million, to do such things as construct housing for the homeless and help two congregations in Ghana build churches. All in all, counting acquisition costs and an $8.5 million construction budget, the deal totals around $22.5 million. So how did a church with about 135 worshipers on a good Sunday come into such a bonanza? One might say by being in the right place at the right tim. In the 1960s, the IMF, a specialized agency of the United Nations with the mission of stabilizing currency exchange, found itself short of space and in need of a new home. It found the location it wanted, three blocks from the White House and next door to the World Bank. ``Since the block was residentially zoned at the time, the only way the IMF could get the bulk and density it wanted for an office building was to offer forth a plan that contemplated developing the entire block,'' said James B. Kaiser, IMF projects manager. There was just one problem. The Western Presbyterian congregation didn't want to move from the block. The church, started in 1855, was already in its third home. Its first was a warehouse not far from the new site. After a few years there, the congregation built a new church across the street from its present structure. It moved to its current location in 1935. ``The sanctuary is gorgeous, and they didn't want to lose that,'' said the Rev. John W. Wimberly Jr., pastor of Western Presbyterian. Also, they might have had to move out into the suburbs, where land prices are somewhat cheaper. ``There was considerable sentiment about the symbolic value of having the building located here, in the middle of what people call the Wall Street of the World,'' Wimberly said. So the IMF proceeded to develop the rest of the block, finishing one phase in 1973 and the second 10 years later, with the church nestled into a U-shaped green space. Meanwhile the fund's staff continued to grow. It now numbers about 2,000 from 100 countries. Since only 1,700 could be squeezed into the building, the agency paid an estimated $3 million a year to lease office space for the other 300. ``It came to our attention a couple of years ago that there had been some changes that would make it more favorable for us to reopen negotiations,'' said Kaiser. The church was growing, too. When Wimberly became its pastor in 1983, he said, there had been about 90 people in the congregation and most of them were over 65. Now about half of the 135 worshipers are 45 or younger. Western Presbyterian began feeding the homeless, and now feeds about 200, using a kitchen designed for potluck suppers. It threw open its doors for noontime meetings of Alcoholics Anonymous and groups grappling with drug problems. The church was still reluctant to move, and the IMF asked if there were any conditions under which the congregation might consider it. Western Presbyterian listed some: -They wouldn't leave the neighborhood. -IMF would have to rebuild the sanctuary as it was. -They would need a commercial kitchen to feed the homeless. -They wanted air conditioning and underground parking, neither of which the present church has. -IMF would pay the lawyers and the architects. -The job would be done in phases, so the congregation would not miss a day of worship or the homeless miss a meal. -IMF would create an endowment to enable the church to expand its mission. ``We debated it at great length and finally took a vote and the vote was 2-1 in favor of making the move,'' Wimberly said. The executive board of the IMF also approved. Architect David Cox said it is hoped that construction can start in the spring and be completed in about two years. Kaiser said IMF hopes to start work on its expansion at that time. ``The fact the IMF was willing to take the sanctuary with us, I think, was at the crux of it,'' said Wimberly. ``We could say, `When you go down there, you're not going to be worshiping in some glass palace or something.' People become very, very involved with the place where they worship. It is a beautiful sanctuary. There is something very humble in its beauty that kind of matches a lot of the people that worship here.''

DOC.HEAD: Private Lawyers Work as Volunteer Prosecutors To Clear Drug Cases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: King County Superior Court is no longer hooked on drug cases, thanks partly to private lawyers who served as prosecutors without cost to the taxpayers. About a dozen ex-prosecutors and 30 relatively new lawyers helped clear a backlog of 512 felony cases, most involving possession of illegal drugs or intent to sell, court officials said. ``It was a signal success, no question about it,'' Prosecuting Attorney Norm Maleng said. ``We're going to continue to have the private bar involved on a pro bono basis.'' Precise statistics have not been compiled, but Maleng said the conviction rate appeared to be just slightly less than the 80 percent for cases handled by staff prosecutors. Pro bono work, in which private lawyers are paid by their firms or simply agree to handle cases without a fee, has long been common in criminal law. Only recently, however, has the practice emerged as a potential panacea to the volume of drug cases that plague prosecutors nationwide, said Richard L. Wintory, director of the National Drug Prosecution Center for the National District Attorneys' Association in Alexandria, Va. San Diego has a well-established pro bono prosecutor program, and for nearly two years the Delaware state attorney general's office has had a ``lend-a-prosecutor'' agreement with a New York law firm. Across Washington state, a similar effort has been mounted in Spokane. The Delaware program is being challenged in the appeal of a drunken-driving conviction in Court of Common Pleas in Wilmington. Wintory said publicity on Seattle's crash program this summer drew so much interest that he has begun a survey of prosecutors in 115 jurisdictions nationwide to identify other helpful programs. Drug case filings have more than doubled in many of the nation's 4,000 prosecutors' offices, but ``we haven't had anywhere near this increase in prosecutor resources,'' he said of Seattle's program. The attraction for most participants and their employers to the volunteer prosecutor program is accelerated trial experience. In addition, some former prosecutors who left for higher pay in the private sector miss their old work. Jesse Franklin, two years into private practice after five years in Maleng's office, returned part-time for his first experience in directing other lawyers. He supervised about 10 cases. ``I love doing the supervising. I get a kick out of it, partly because I enjoy being a prosecutor so much,'' he said. ``You kind of relive some of your old war stories.'' Reaction from defense lawyers has ranged from muted demurrals to the legal challenge in Delaware. ``It's sort of a novelty to be doing it for the prosecution,'' said Bob Boruchowitz, director of the non-profit Seattle-King County Defender Association. ``The defense side is much more in need of resources than the prosecution,'' Boruchowitz said. ``The pressure it put on our lawyers, the strain on our lawyers, was significant. Many of our lawyers were on back-to-back trials.'' Presiding Judge Charles V. Johnson said he was more concerned about overloading the 15 regular judges during the program, which ran from July 25 to Aug. 31. Part-time service on the bench was enlisted from 22 superior court judges from other counties, three lawyers who served as pro tem judges and 14 court commissioners, judges from appellate and other courts and retired jurists. ``We effectively had 12 additional judges,'' Maleng said. ``From our standpoint the program was a success, an outstanding success,'' Johnson said. Boruchowitz contended the Seattle program resulted in trials by volunteer prosecutors hungry for litigation in cases that usually would have been settled with plea bargains. Wintory, however, said temporary prosecutors could ease pressures to allow guilty pleas on reduced charges as an alternative to dismissal for lack of preparation or failure to meet speedy trial requirements. Kathryn Mauk, hired fresh out of law school by a firm that handles mostly insurance cases, said she changed her career focus after spending about a quarter to a third of her time as a temporary prosecutor this summer. She won a conviction in her first case, a five-day trial on a charge of possession of drugs with intent to deliver. Charges were dismissed in another case because of an improper arrest, and three others ended in guilty pleas. ``It's exhilarating. It's challenging,'' she said. ``It moves quickly. You have to think on your feet. You have to be `on.' It's a different kind of high.''

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of Oct. 22-29:
DOC.HEAD: Newsroom Employees Decide To Continue Daily News Strike
DOC.TEXT: Daily News reporters and photographers wavered, but then decided Oct. 28 to remain on strike rather than take up an offer to cross picket lines and reclaim their jobs. ``We're willing to give the strike more time,'' reporter Paul LaRosa said. ``There's no point in going back now.'' The News, hit by a walkout Oct. 25 by nine of its 10 unions, had said striking workers were welcome to return to their old jobs at any time as long as permanent replacements had not been hired. A group of about 40 reporters and photographers belonging to the 750-member Newspaper Guild sent a delegation to discuss the matter with Guild President Barry Lipton. Some complained the Guild's strike was called on the basis of a false report that replacements had already been hired to fill reporting slots. ``There's a lot of anger at the Guild leadership,'' said striking reporter JoAnne Wasserman. But after the meeting, the group decided to stay on strike. No new talks were scheduled. The News said it planned to replace the strikers permanently. The Daily News, the nation's second-largest metropolitan daily, has published a paper each day since the strike began but conceded it is having trouble delivering the paper. Home delivery was spotty and many newsstands were not getting the newspaper. ``We have not been hitting all distribution points as of yet,'' John T. Sloan, the newspaper's chief spokesman, said Oct. 28. ``We will soon.'' He also accused strikers of intimidating dealers and removing papers from newsstands. Strikers have burned several delivery trucks and vandalized others. About 20 strikers have been arrested since the strike began, most on disorderly conduct charges. Workers at the A & S Stationery store in Brooklyn said club-wielding men had seized all 300 copies of the Sunday edition of the News and scattered them in the gutter. ``I can't take the paper or they will kill me,'' said one of the store's owners, Ali Najeli. The New York Times quoted an unidentified management source as saying many drivers had become lost. The News said in a statement that it published and distributed more than 1.2 million Sunday papers in the city and surrounding suburbs, exceeding the previous day's press run by 500,000. The News normally prints 1.46 million Sunday papers. The 71-year-old daily has been in a financial tailspin for a decade. The News has lost about $115 million and seen daily circulation slip by about 700,000 since 1980. It recently lost its standing as the nation's largest metropolitan daily to the Los Angeles Times. The strike began when 60 drivers at the News were replaced in a dispute over whether a driver would be allowed to monitor a conveyor belt while sitting down. The other unions followed suit. The unions claimed management provoked the crisis, which followed 10 months of often stormy talks on contracts to replace those that expired in March.
DOC.HEAD: Tribune Reports 39 Percent Earnings Decline
DOC.TEXT: The Tribune Co. reported a 39 percent decline in after-tax profit for the third quarter due to operating losses at its Canadian paper mills and the New York Daily News. The company said Oct. 22 that net income fell to $38.2 million, or 52 cents a share, from $62.7 million, or 81 cents a share, during the same period last year. Revenue slipped 0.5 percent to $588 million from $590.7 million. Newspaper operating profit fell 15 percent for the quarter to $48.4 million from $56.7 million last year, due to losses at the Daily News. The company attributed the losses at the Daily News to weak economic conditions in the New York market and what it calls a ``burdensome cost structure,'' which was at the heart of long labor negotiations that boiled over into the strike Oct. 25. Profits for the remainder of the newspaper group, which includes the Chicago Tribune and The Orlando (Fla.) Sentinel, were down slightly, the company said. For the third quarter, the company's Quebec and Ontario Paper Co. reported a loss of $8.3 million, compared to a profit of $15.2 million last year. Strikes by the Canadian Paperworkers Union shut down the Quebec newsprint mill for 31 days and the Ontario mill for 47 days. For the first three quarters, net income was down 27 percent at $127.9 million, or 1.73 a share, from $174.8 million, or $2.27 a share, last year. Revenue rose 2 percent to $1.83 billion from $1.79 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Third-Quarter Earnings Down at Times Mirror, Knight-Ridder
DOC.TEXT: Times Mirror Co. said Oct. 24 its third-quarter after-tax profit dropped 40.2 percent from a year ago, while Knight-Ridder Inc. reported its net earnings slipped 3.2 percent from 1989 results that included a one-time gain. Times Mirror said falling classified and retail advertising in the Los Angeles Times as well as at its newspapers in the economically troubled Northeast contributed to the declie. Knight-Ridder said that its newspaper operations were softer than expected and that the newspaper ad revenue environment has worsened steadily. The company said its earnings from continuing operations were up from last year, excluding one-time gains on asset sales in 1989.

Los Angeles-based Times Mirror earned $41.9 million, or 33 cents a share, on revenue of $895 million for the three months ended Sept. 30. That compared with $70.1 million, or 54 cents per share, on revenue of $873.9 million a year earlier. During the first nine months, profit fell 40 percent to $134.8 million, or $1.05 per share, from $223.9 million, or $1.73 per share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 3.7 percent to $2.68 billion from $2.58 billion. In addition to the ad decline at the Times and the continuing softness of advertising at newspapers in the Northeast, the newspaper publishing division suffered from higher newsprint costs, Chief Executive Robert F. Erburu said. ``Our non-advertising dependent businesses, led by our professional publishing operations, turned in solid third-quarter performances and should achieve revenue and earnings growth through the remainder of the year,'' Erburu said in a statement.

Miami-based Knight-Ridder earned $36.6 million, or 73 cents a share, in the three months ended Sept. 30, compared with $37.8 million, or 72 cents a share, a year earlier. Earnings per share were up because there were fewer outstanding. Revenue rose 5.5 percent to $570.5 million from $541 million. The 1989 results included a $4.2 million gain from the sale of television stations. Earnings from continuing operations this year were up 7.7 percent if that gain was excluded from the comparison. Operating profit in the newspaper division was up 5 percent to $82.4 million, while the business information services division had an operating profit of $3.9 million compared with $2.5 million a year earlier. Robert F. Singleton, chief financial officer, said the newspaper division results were helped by inclusion of one more Sunday this quarter than last year. For the first nine months, Knight-Ridder earned $107 million, or $2.10 a share, down 42.2 percent from $185.2 million, or $3.53 a share, a year ago. The 1989 results included a gain on the sale of a newspaper. Revenue rose 3.6 percent to $1.72 billion from $1.66 billion. Profit from continuing operations was up 12.8 percent from a year ago, the company said, if gains on the sale of the Pasadena (Calif.) Star News and the TV operations in 1989 were excluded from the comparison.
DOC.HEAD: Earnings All Off at Capital Cities-ABC, Washington Post
DOC.TEXT: Capital Cities-ABC Inc. said Oct. 23 its third-quarter net profit dropped 11.3 percent from a year ago, largely due to losses on coverage of major league baseball by its 80 percent-owned ESPN cable TV network. The Washington Post Co. reported a 16.2 percent decline in its after-tax profit, citing weakness in its region's newspaper ad market. New York-based Capital Cities-ABC said it earned $71.7 million, or $4.16 a share, in the three months ended Sept. 30, compared with $80.8 million, or $4.56 a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 10 percent to $1.21 billion from $1.10 billion. Operating income fell 8 percent to $143.9 million, including a 15 percent decline in broadcasting and a 9 percent increase in publishing. The company also warned that earnings for the fourth quarter will be down from a year ago because of significantly weaker advertising demand at its ABC Television Network and eight TV stations. The ABC Television Network reported modest profit improvement for the third quarter as its ratings improved and ad demand was up in prime time. Earnings from television and radio operations also rose moderately, the company said. But income from video operations fell sharply because of losses at ESPN in its first year of baseball coverage. The company did not specify the amount of the loss but executives said it was comparable to the $20 million loss in the second quarter. ESPN won the right to telecast abou 175 regular season baseball games this year, and losses had been anticipated when audience ratings were below expectations in a slow ad environment. For the first nine months, Capital Cities-ABC earned $320.3 million, or $18.45 a share, up 5 percent from $303.7 million, or $16.97 a share, in 1989. Revenue rose 11 percent to $3.83 billion from $3.45 billion. The company said ad demand at its ABC Television Network and its TV stations had been ``significantly weaker in the fourth quarter than for the first nine months of 1990.'' As a result, it said it expected fourth-quarter earnings to decline from the $10.33 a share reported for the last three months of 1989. Geoffrey Johnson, a securities analyst for Argus Research, said he had expected the company to earn $12.50 a share for the fourth quarter. ``They are a well-run operation but sometimes there is nothing you can do,'' he said. The Washington Post Co. said it earned $37.5 million, or $3.14 a share, in the third quarter, compared with $44.8 million, or $3.50 a share, for the third quarter of 1989. Revenue edged up 1 percent to $348.7 million from $346.3 million. Newspaper revenue fell 7.1 percent in the quarter as ad volume fell 14.7 percent at The Washington Post. Revenue rose 7.4 percent at Newsweek and 14.1 percent in cable operations, while broadcasting revenue was flat. For the first nine months, the company earned $132.5 million, or $10.90 per share, down 9.7 percent from $146.8 million, or $11.44 per share, last year. Revenue rose 1 percent to $1.07 billion from $1.06 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Murdoch Says News Corp. Earnings Will Rise
DOC.TEXT: Rupert Murdoch told a shareholders meeting Oct. 23 he expects News Corp. Ltd. to increase earnings despite uncertainties in some of its major markets. He did not estimate earnings and would not comment on the company's short-term debt problems, which have depressed News Corp.'s stock price in recent weeks. Short-term debt soared last fiscal year to $2.30 billion from $396 million. Total debt rose to $8.21 billion from $6.13 billion. In an interview the day before the shareholders meeting, Murdoch said News Corp. would concentrate on film and electronic media, rather than the newspapers and magazines he used to build the company. Newspapers and magazines now account for about 70 percent of News Corp. profits. In the fiscal year ended last June 30, News Corp. reported that earnings dropped 75.5 percent to $267 million, largely because of losses at Murdoch's Sky-TV satellite broadcasting business in Britain and a pilot strike at the half-owned Ansett Australia airline. Stockholders approved a resolution allowing directors to issue limited-voting shares. Murdoch wants to be able to issue such shares so the company can raise funds without diluting his 45 percent stake in the company. On Oct. 3, Murdoch merged four of his Australian newspapers into two around-the-clock productions, a move that reflected increasingly tough times in the Australian media business.
DOC.HEAD: Infotech May Sell Businesses; Confirms SEC Investigation
DOC.TEXT: A media concern with stakes in Financial News Network and UPI announced a management shakeup Oct. 24 and disclosed financial problems that could result in the sale of its businesses. Infotechnology Inc. also confirmed it is under investigation by the government but declined to say why. Infotechnology named Alan Hirschfield and Allan Tessler interim co-chief executives. They will ``serve as a restructuring team to address FNN's and Infotech's financial problems'' and explore options that could include the sale of some or all company businesses, Infotechnology said in a statement. It also said the cash flow of Infotechnology and FNN was ``insufficient to meet operating expenses'' or cover some debts. Infotechnology said it was renegotiating $20.7 million in loans for itself as well as $49.5 million in loans to FNN. In addition, both were trying to reschedule lease payments for $161 million worth of equipment. Infotechnology owns 47 percent of FNN, which provides 24-hour stock quotes, business news and sports information on 3,500 cable television systems that reach more than 35 million homes. Infotechnology also owns 97 percent of UPI. Hirschfield and Tessler have been involved in several business restructurings, Infotechnology said. Hirschfield is a former chief executive of 20th Century Fox and Columbia Pictures; Tessler is chairman of International Financial Group Inc., Ameriscribe Inc. and International Controls Corp. The two replace Earl Brian, who had been chief executive and will continue as ``non-executive chairman'' of the FNN and Infotechnology boards. On Oct. 22, Infotechnology disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that the SEC had ``issued a formal order of investigation with respect to the company'' under federal securities laws. Infotechnology spokeswoman Amber Gordon declined to say why the company was under investigation, but said it was cooperating. The SEC, which polices the nation's securities markets, does not comment on any investigations as a matter of policy. On Oct. 23, Infotechnology was sued by shareholders, who claimed executives issued false and misleading information about the companies' finances. The suit filed in Manhattan's federal court represents all people and entities who bought the company's stock between Sept. 28, 1989, and this Oct. 1, when both FNN and Infotech announced they were unable to meet a deadline for completing financial statements for the fiscal year that ended June 30. The lawsuit said the stock's price fell to $3 a share on Oct. 1 from its previous close of $5.75. ``Had plaintiff and the members of the class known of the materially adverse information not disclosed by defendants, they would not have purchased Infotech common stock at the artificially inflated prices that were paid,'' the lawsuit said.
DOC.HEAD: Byline Strike Staged in Dayton, Ohio
DOC.TEXT: Union members at the Dayton Daily News, who have been without a contract since January 1989, staged a one-week byline strike to protest pay and other issues. A statement from the Dayton Newspaper Guild on Oct. 22 said its members had ``waited patiently for more than two years without receiving a contractual pay raise while Dayton Newspapers Inc., publisher of the newspaper, has repeatedly resorted to tactics designed to undermine and destroy our union.'' Publisher Brad Tillson said the company continued to bargain in good faith for a contract. ``We respect the right of our editorial employees to withhold their names from their work. But we feel that the issues will only be resolved through efforts at the bargaining table and not through job actions,'' he said. The byline strike ended Oct. 27. The guild represents about 180 reporters, editors, photographers and other workers.

DOC.HEAD: Price Hikes Planned for Wall Street Journal, Barron's
DOC.TEXT: Dow Jones & Co. Inc. said Oct. 25 it will raise the newsstand price of The Wall Street Journal to 75 cents a copy from 50 cents on Dec. 3, giving it the highest cover price for a leading national daily newspaper. The move comes at a time when newspaper company profits are slumping, but opinions were mixed on whether the Journal's move would prompt other papers to risk circulation losses by raising prices. At USA Today, one of the Journal's chief competitors, Larry Lindquist, senior vice president for circulation, said the paper had no plans to increase its cover price of 50 cents in 1991. Dow Jones also is boosting the annual subscription price for the Journal by 7.8 percent to $139 from $129, effective Jan. 2. It said the price increases reflect higher transportation and other publishing costs and rising newsprint and postage rates. Earlier this month, the company announced a 17.5 percent drop in its third-quarter earnings, due in part to a decline in ad revenue. It later disclosed a cost-cutting plan that included a freeze on capital spending and total salaries, postponement of a new magazine, and a reduction in the number of special reports in the Journal. While several special-interest daily newspapers sell for more than 50 cents a copy, the American Newspaper Publishers Association said the Journal would be the first general-interest daily paper with a newsstand price of 75 cents. The newsstand price of the Journal has been 50 cents since April 1984, when it was raised from 40 cents a copy. Subscription rates were last raised two years ago. The Journal has the largest daily circulation of any U.S. newspaper, averaging nearly 1.86 million copies in the six months ended Sept. 30. Roger May, a spokesman for Dow Jones, said newsstand purchases account for less than 300,000 in sales or less than 20 percent of the total. He said newsstand sales fell slightly after the 1984 price increase but circulation eventually recovered all lost ground. ``We can't predict what the impact of this increase will be but the outlook for the long term is that we will gain back whatever we lose,'' he said. Everette Dennis, executive director of the Gannett Center for Media Studies at Columbia University, characterized the Journal as a special case with a relatively affluent audience that could well afford to pay the extra quarter for the daily paper. But others said that with a weak advertising market putting a drag on newspaper revenues throughout the country, more increases could be on the way. Joseph Lorfano of the American Newspaper Publishers Association said the single-copy price of newspapers has been rising steadily, reaching an average of 30 cents per copy last year, up from 25 cents in 1987. May said 64 newspapers including the Journal have cover prices of 50 cents a copy, up from only four at that figure in 1985. Dow Jones also said it was raising the newsstand price of Barron's National Business and Financial Weekly to $2.50 a copy from $2 effective with the Dec. 3 issue. The annual subscription price will rise to $109 from $99 effective with the Jan. 7 issue. Barron's last raised its newsstand price in January 1989 and its yearly rate in January 1990.
DOC.HEAD: Use of Sketch Brings Protests, Apology
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper apologized to the Islamic community after a front-page sketch described as depicting the prophet Mohammed triggered dozens of angry phone calls and a protest outside its offices. Protesters called the sketch sacrilegious because no authentic portraits of the prophet exist. ``The Sentinel regrets running the picture. We meant no offense to the Islamic community,'' Editor Robert H. Wills said in a front-page story Oct. 23. The picture was used with a wire service report that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein supposedly claimed to have received a message from the prophet in a dream. The newspaper said the picture was taken from a file incorrectly labeled ``Mohammed.'' The Sentinel did not say who the sketch actually depicted. M.A. Cheema, former president of the Islamic Center of Milwaukee and a member of the Islamic Society of North America, said pictures and statues of historic religious figures are prohibited in Islam. The newspaper reported receiving dozens of telephone calls and a letter from the Islamic Society of Milwaukee. The letter, signed by society president Muhammad Y. Khan and Bassam Sayad, chairman of community outreach, said the group was outraged. ``The prophet was never portrayed during his lifetime, and paintings created in future years falsely misrepresent him and are extremely offensive to the vast majority of Muslims,'' the letter said. About a dozen demonstrators carrying signs marched outside the newspaper the night of Oct. 23 to protest the use of the sketch.
DOC.HEAD: Fake Newspaper Headline Used in Political Fight
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Guy Hunt is airing a television commercial that features a fake newspaper headline mentioning Democrat Paul Hubbert, but a Hunt aide said Oct. 24 the ad was not meant to be deceptive. The commercial begins with a photograph of Hubbert, former head of the Alabama Education Association. An announcer says: ``Governor Guy Hunt's efforts to improve education have been opposed time and again by this man - Paul Hubbert.'' A newspaper story is then briefly superimposed over Hubbert's face, with the headline ``Hubbert Kills Hunt's Education Reform Package.'' A freeze-frame look at the newspaper story shows it really is about budget problems at the U.S. Postal Service. The bogus headline was electronically pasted on top of the story. A Hunt spokesman, Terry Abbott, said the commercial is not meant to deceive people into believing a newspaper actually printed the headline shown on the TV screen. Abbott said the headline is only a ``dramatization'' of Hunt's claims about Hubbert. Karen Cartee, an advertising professor at the University of Alabama, said the fake headline tactic could be a serious blunder, given reporters' increased scrutiny of political ads. ``That's like handing the newspapers and Hubbert a loaded cannon,'' Ms. Cartee said. ``I'm shocked because . . . it's very rare for political ads to be (outright) deceptive. They just don't do it because it's stupid politics. ``If you're called on it, and made to look like a liar, you're going to lose,'' she said. ``Negative ads have to be truthful to work.''

DOC.HEAD: Gun Salute, Flag Raising Marks Hostage's Birthday
DOC.TEXT: The birthplace of hostage Terry Anderson marked the hostage's 43rd birthday Oct. 27 with a flag raising, a gun salute and the singing of ``Happy Birthday.'' About 40 people, including 12 of Anderson's cousins, turned out at City Hall for the gun salute and flag ceremony, then walked to a park to join 500 others. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was abducted by Moslem extremists in Beirut on March 16, 1985. He is the longest-held of the 13 Western hostages in Lebanon. Anderson was born in Lorain and grew up in Batavia, N.Y., where supporters decided against cake and singing to mark his birthday because of the crisis in the Persian Gulf. ``This year because of the new crisis it just seemed inappropriate,'' said Anne Zickl, an organizer of past celebrations for Anderson in Batavia. In Lorain, Anderson's cousins placed a large yellow ribbon on the City Hall flagpole. Then they walked to nearby Veterans Memorial Park, joined 500 people gathered for the city's annual Halloween parade and sang ``Happy Birthday.'' A bust of Anderson sculpted by artist Louis Dlugosz was placed Oct. 26 in Batavia's City Hall, alongside a scrapbook of local events held in Anderson's honor over the past six years. Residents signed the scrapbook as they viewed the bust at City Hall, where they picked up small yellow ribbons and bumper stickers reading ``Bring our hostages home from Lebanon.''
DOC.HEAD: Mayor Calls for Ad Boycott To Protest Stalled Union Talks
DOC.TEXT: The City Council is weighing a plan to withhold city advertising from The Burlington Free Press until the paper's management renews talks with the union representing the paper's workers. Publisher Donna Donovan said the proposed boycott would hurt union members, who include advertising sales representatives. Mayor Peter Clavelle went before the council on Oct. 22 and said that Gannett Co. Inc., which owns the newspaper, drains dollars from the local community. He urged councilors to ``send a strong message'' to the newspaper that ``we won't support you economically until you serve this community better than you have been doing.'' Councilor Gene Bergman offered the resolution and said he hoped it would be discussed at the next meeting, scheduled for the night of Oct. 29. Talks between the paper and workers represented by the Graphic Communication International Union have been stalled since last Dec. 7, when they broke down after 14 negotiating sessions. Workers had voted to unionize the previous April. The two sides differ on estimates of how much advertising the city buys from the newspaper. Clavelle put the annual amount at $67,000, while Donovan said it is closer to $30,000.
DOC.HEAD: Deputy Marshal Sues Superiors Over Speech Rights
DOC.TEXT: A deputy marshal who said he was disciplined after being interviewed for a newspaper story filed suit alleging violation of his First Amendment rights. Richard H. Emmons filed the federal civil rights suit Oct. 23 to stop the Orange County marshal's office from enforcing regulations relating to free speech. He seeks an undisclosed amount of monetary damages. In his suit, Emmons alleges he received an unjustified reprimand for complaining about safety and security in county parking lots around the Civic Center in Santa Ana. He criticized county officials in the article. Emmons also said he has been the subject of unwarranted internal affairs investigations since the article appeared.
DOC.HEAD: State To Place Ads in Newspapers on Light-Rail Measure
DOC.TEXT: The state will buy space in newspapers to inform Portland-area voters about a light-rail bond measure because the information was left out of voter information packets. State Elections Director Jack Graham said Oct. 23 the ads will contain a one-page supplement to information booklets known as Voters' Pamphlets. The secretary of state's office failed to place information on the bond measure in Voters' Pamphlets mailed to households in some areas, officials said.
DOC.HEAD: Foundation Renews Grant for Reporting Center
DOC.TEXT: The Knight Foundation has approved a grant of $832,734 to the University of Maryland to renew financing for the Knight Center for Specialized Journalism for three years. The center offers one- to two-week courses on covering such areas as nuclear power, business and finance, economics, cancer, U.S. demographic shifts, biotechnology and the war on drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Pioneer Press Ends Afternoon Edition
DOC.TEXT: The Saint Paul Pioneer Press will end afternoon publication Nov. 9. The move is expected to eliminate about 30 jobs. Mary Junck, publisher and president, said circulation of the evening paper had dropped to 29,000 from a high of 121,000 in 1972. Morning circulation of the paper has soared, she said. ``Like newspaper readers in other parts of the country, most of ours want their newspaper in the morning,'' Junck said Oct. 23. A poor economic outlook for 1991 also led to the decision. ``The conversion to AM enables the Pioneer Press to focus all its resources on the morning and Sunday editions. We're positioned very well to be even more competitive and increase our circulation at an even faster pace,'' Junck said. The Twin Cities' other evening newspaper, the Minneapolis Star, was discontinued in 1982. Newsroom reductions will be through attrition and a voluntary early retirement program, the newspaper said.
DOC.HEAD: Boehm Says He Made a Mistake by Staking Out Newspaper Building
DOC.TEXT: State Tax Commissioner John Boehm said he erred in staking out a newspaper building to see who among his employees had gone there to complain that he was stifling their free speech at work. ``In retrospect, I made a mistake,'' Boehm said Oct. 25. ``It was an error in judgment.'' Earlier this month, a dozen Department of Revenue employees went to the Journal-Star Printing Co. building to talk to a reporter. Boehm acknowledged that he and his deputy commissioner drove around the building, which houses the Lincoln Journal, The Lincoln Star and Lincoln office of The Associated Press. A day later, Boehm distributed a memo to department administrators. It dealt with whether employees could be disciplined for insubordinate remarks during staff meetings about the governor, a department head or other supervisors. Three of the employees who went to the newspaper building said Oct. 25 that they felt department employees put their careers in jeopardy if they disagreed with Boehm or criticized the administration of Gov. Kay Orr. They said Boehm's surveillance increased their worries. ``Their fears are unfounded,'' Boehm said. ``I went there because I had been told that maybe 40 or 50 department people were going to be there and I was curious. I wasn't taking names.'' Boehm said none of the employees who talked to reporters would be subject to disciplinary action for speaking out.
DOC.HEAD: Paper Carrier Allegedly Burglarized Out-of-Town Customers
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper carrier has been accused of burglarizing the homes of subscribers after they notified him to suspend delivery while they were out of town. Dwayne L. Young, 32, who delivered the Austin American-Statesman in an area west of the University of Texas campus, was charged with burglary of a habitation, burglary of a motor vehicle and criminal mischief. Police said he is suspected in about 30 residential break-ins and 20 burglaries of vehicles, the newspaper reported Sept. 26. Police have recovered about $11,600 worth of stolen property from the burglaries, which date to last December. Young was not an employee of the newspaper but was one of about 650 independent contractors who deliver the American-Statesman, the paper said. He has delivered newspapers since August 1989.
DOC.HEAD: American Publishing Eyes Two Texas Papers
DOC.TEXT: American Publishing Inc., a subsidiary of Hollinger Inc. of Toronto, said it will buy the Port Arthur News and The Orange Leader from Cox Enterprises Inc. The proposed sale is subject to approval by the boards of both companies.
DOC.HEAD: Photographer Wants $10,000 From Governor's Campaign for Use of Photo
