DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE - The kibitzers this night include a playwright from Spain, a drug dealer, a Queens housewife, a master chess player from Harlem, a biker and assorted yuppies. They are in a hotel next door to the old theater where Garry Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov sit hunched over their chessboard. They watch the action on closed-circuit TV and debate the players' every move, their politics, their diet, their very nose scratchings.

Chess notes from a witness who doesn't know a Nimzo-Indian opening from a hole in his sock: In world-title chess, the kibitzer, not a piece of carved wood, is king. Garry Kasparov is defending his world title against Anatoly Karpov in the absolute silence of the old Hudson Theater, lately sunk from the grandeur of the opening of Eugene O'Neill's ``Strange Interlude'' to Times Square porno flicks, but now resurrected for King's Pawn openings. The only, infrequent, sound is ``sh-sh-sh-sh.'' An observer corks off into snores. He is immediately poked awake from three directions. An elderly spectator noisily un-brownbags a sandwich. An usher ushers him out. But next door in the Hotel Macklowe, which owns the Hudson and is chess headquarters, hundreds, thousands debate the players' every move, their politics, their diet, their very nose scratchings. The Macklowe is a tower of babble from the lowest patzer (German: ``to make a mess of things'') to the highest grandmasters. Many tongues. All at once. Some 150 chess fans are crowded in a windowless lecture room of the Macklowe to hear Roman Dzindzichashvili (luckily, he answers to either ``Roman'' or ``Dzindzi,'' pronounced Gingi) analyze the contest from closed-circuit TV. ``Kasparov will never make that move, never,'' says Gingi, wielding his pointer at the TV screen. ``He will never do it without first visiting bar.'' Gingi, a rumpled Russian emigre with the hairdo of an astrakhan sheep, once No. 6 in the chess world and twice U.S. champion, speaks English with no ``the's.'' Kasparov, after deliberating longer than the average Ice Age, makes ``that move.'' The kibitzers genially boo Gingi. ``I boo you back.'' Gingi survives the storm, bets a lollipop on Karpov's next move with Mark Rubinstein of Brooklyn. Gingi's gambit declined. Mark is up beyond his bedtime. He is 11. ...Karpov, after another Ice Age, moves a bishop... Anybody can kibitz, which may be the allure of this sport, if it is a sport. Walter Mittys can fantasize they aced Ivan Lendl at Wimbledon. Or faked a free safety out of his jock to catch one from Joe Montana in the end zone. But these are only the fields of dreams. In Gingi's lecture room many fans ponder on their pocket chessboards the same imponderable Kasparov-Karpov ponder. They are in the game! Tonight's kibitzers (games start at 5:30 p.m. and run five hours) in Gingi's room include a playwright from Spain; a drug dealer who shall be nameless; a Queens housewife; a motorcycle type in leather jacket with a pile of Bud cans growing at his feet; Jerald Times, 27, a master from Harlem; assorted briefcased yuppies; one other woman; Rafael Knopler, who told them back home in Israel he had to go to New York on business; and Ben Heller, also from Queens, torn between the game and the latest train he can catch before Manhattan's streets turn mean. He keeps glancing nervously at his watch. ``Do these guys ever cheat?'' asks the only other woman present. ``I'm hired by International Chess Federation, not National Enquirer,'' Gingi answers. ....Kasparov's knight to square c4... Kasparov, in the finest tradition of chess, hates Karpov, thinks he's ``evil, a creature of darkness.'' Karpov, 37, was a favorite of the pre-Gorby Kremlin. Kasparov, 27, half Jewish and all Armenian, was not. In fact, he's red hot for democracy. He pasted a pre-Revolution Russian flag on his side of the table. Karpov protested. Kasparov counterprotested Karpov's hammer and sickle flag. Both flags went. A draw. The two have played 120 games before this 24-game world championship. Garry has won 17, Anatoly 16, the other 87 were draws. There is a partition under the table separating their feet. Kicking is out? ...Karpov bishop to a6... Other than Bush-Gorbachev and perhaps some hostile Wall Street takeovers, this match is the only summit encounter conducted in business suits. This is misleading. Chess takes no prisoners. Ben Franklin said of chess etiquette: ``You should not sing nor whistle nor look at your watch nor make a tapping with your feet.'' Wilhelm Steinitz, an Austrian world champ 1886-94, once spat at his opponent. ``A perfect porcupine,'' said a contemporary of Steinitz, known as a poor loser and worse winner. ``Wherever you touched him was a sharp point.'' Aran Nimzovich, deviser of the Nimzo-Indian, once swept the pieces off the board, crying: ``Why must I lose to this idiot?!'' He also did knee bends and stood on his head while his rival was trying to concentrate. Emanuel Lasker, German world champ 1894-1921, would exhale ``a virtual gas attack'' of cigar smoke across the table. One tournament organizer protested that Lasker smoked the finest Havanas away from the chessboard but switched to stinking nickel rockets in competition. The Russian world title holder Michael Botvinnik, 1946-57, used to train by having a sparring partner blow smoke in his face during practice. When Siegbert Tarrasch challenged Lasker in 1908, he began and concluded his dialogue with the champion thusly: ``I have only three words to say to you in this match: `Check and mate.''' In keeping with the lowest level of sportsmanship at the highest level of chess, Tarrasch, as have many others, blamed his defeat on poor health. The match, held in Dusseldorf, was too close to debilitating sea air, he complained. Dusseldorf was, and presumably still is, 170 miles from the nearest coast. ...Kasparov puts a rook in play... ``Are both sides still equal?'' a kibitzer asks Gingi. ``One side is equal. Other has advantage,'' the grandmaster hedges without elaboration.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
NEW YORK: without elaboration.
DOC.TEXT: One-upmanship is an essential part of the kibitzer's arsenal. A heavy European accent delivering profundities that mean nothing helps. If you say Kus-PAR-off (correct) and he says KAS-par-off, he's obviously a patzer. He says AL-eck-ein (Alexander Alekhine was a universally despised world champion, drunk, lecher and anti-Semite between the world wars and an immortal who ``fidgeted like a dog on an ant hill'') pronouncing it something like the name of the Tigers' Hall of Fame right-fielder, Al Kaline. If you say it right, Al-YEKCH-in, you are a grandmaster and he is a nikulturny. ...Kasparov makes a move to no discernible pattern... ``There may be something sneaky in Kasparov's mind,'' says the lady from Queens. ``This absolutely sneakless move,'' says Gingi, sipping a soda. Kasparov is known for a relentless attacking style, Karpov for defense in depth like the Russians defending Moscow from Napoleon. One columnist has said Garry has been all but ``berserk'' in earlier matches even though to the untrained eye he has been as immobile as Rodin's ``Thinker,'' except for minor league twitchings and ear pulls. ...Karpov's men are in a Gligoric Variation, Kasparov's with a knight split wide... Kasparov, who has the highest number of rating points in the history of chess, has the type of mind that could do a Sunday crossword puzzle in his head. He holds that head in his hands, fingers splayed around his ears. Hand then adjusts a sleeve of his black suit. Recrosses legs. Pinches nose. Cups chin in hand. Makes bipod of forearms, resting nose on clasped fingers. Glares down athis men only inches away like drill inspector at Parris Island reviewing recruits. After 23 minutes... ...Kasparov knight to f4... Queens housewife: ``Why do they take so long?'' Gingi: ``They don't want to play nearly best move. They want to play best move. They take time because they have time.'' In a 41-move game it would take 1,000 billion generations to play every possible combination at a fraction of a second per move. We're getting there. Chess is a game of memory, technique, imagination and intuition. The top grandmasters know an infinitude of moves, from the Maroozy Bind variation of the Sicilian Defense to Queen's Gambit Declined. The French Poisoned Pawn. The Velimirovic Attack. They constantly study past games of their opponent and masterpiece games of the ages: Anderssen's Immortal in London, 1851; the Pearl of Zandvoort, Max Euwe versus Alekhine in 1935; Frank Marshall's 23rd move at Breslau in 1912. All the while, said Saviely Tartakower, an Austrian grandmaster earlier in this century: ``The blunders are there, all waiting to be made.'' ...The queens of both Kasparov and Karpov are dead... ``Chess kept me out of trouble,'' says Jerald Times, the young Harlem master. ``I was a good kid, but it gave me pride in intellect. A ballerina has to stretch her body. Same thing in chess. It stretches your mind.'' Times has survived a broken ghetto home, got to college, now teaches poetry to the homeless, dropouts, kids in the violent classrooms of the city. Chess, he says, takes more exertion than full-court basketball. In summers he plays chess in Harlem parks until early morning. His rapid articulation pauses when he considers what other Harlem kids have done in parks in New York. Chess. ...The freewheeling end game has begun... ``Why does Kasparov always use the King's Indian defense?'' asks Ben Heller. ``Because he knows it. It works for him,'' says Gingi. ``You have job. You go to it every day. Why don't you change?'' Heller leaves for his train. Gingi says it looks like a draw. ``No draw,'' says the Queens housewife. ``I want my $25 bucks worth.'' In 1924, the Soviet Union's Third All-Union Congress decided chess was ``a weapon in the struggle for a higher cultural level'' and made the game a vehicle to show the world the superiority of communism. The Soviet Union has held the world title since 1946 with but one exception. That was the American Bobby Fischer who brought rudeness, neurosis, brilliance and prize money to an all-time high in winning the title from Boris Spassky in Iceland in 1972. Fischer thereupon turned his back on multimillion-dollar gates to lead a demonic, reclusive life among the derelict hotels in the Los Angeles area. Half Jewish, he has reportedly become an ardent admirer of Adolf Hitler. But Kasparov-Karpov can thank Fischer's histrionics for making the $3 million prize money for their match possible. Eccentricity if not madness is a not uncommon end game for chess players. Paul Morphy of New Orleans blazed briefly in the 1850s and is considered one of the best ever. Later he took to wandering the streets claiming his friends turned enemies and were trying to steal his clothes. A Polish grandmaster named Frydman stripped during a tournament and ran through the hotel crying ``Fire!'' Steinitz went mad. Perhaps the most ``normal'' of the very greatest was Jose Raul Capablanca, a Cuban who played basketball while at Columbia College and once was late for a match having just left the bed of the mistress of a grand duke. Examples of mental turmoil coupled with the intricacies of the game give a popular impression that chess is a game for weirdo geniuses. But a team of Russian psychologists made a study and found no relationship between chess and general intelligence. Capablanca, who was put on the payroll of the Cuban foreign office and posted as a goodwill ambassador to wherever he had a tournament, said of the game which he found as effortless as his love life: ``To play chess requires no intelligence at all.'' ...Gingi is right. Karpov offers a draw, leaving the match 3-2 for Kasparov with seven more games to go at the Hudson and 12 more if needed in Lyons, France... Mark Rubinstein goes to the souvenir room to browse through chess books and T-shirts. ``It was boring,'' he kibitzes. Could he take the champ? ``In three years,'' says Mark, an 11-year-old Monday quarterback plotting moves on his board of dreams.

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE - Three hundred years after it was founded as a trading post by the British East India Company, Calcutta is a city of appalling filth and poverty, 12 million people struggling just to survive. Despite all, as one Indian journalist once wrote, Calcuttans ``love their wretched city with the same passion as a mother loves her sick child.''

It's already hot and steamy at 6 a.m. as Calcutta goes through its morning rituals. Joggers trot past the marble Victoria Monument and the members-only Mohammadan Sports Club. The trimmed grass of the nearby Calcutta Race Course is wet from the overnight monsoon rains. Sheltered under the Hooghly Bridge a mile away, women cook a meager breakfast over a fire of dried cow dung for a gaggle of children, some naked, some in rags. Hundreds of people bathe in the sluggish brown water of the Hooghly River. Devout Hindus, blessed by a nearly naked priest, stand waist-deep in the river dipping copper bowls of spices and flower petals into the water. Later their women will return to the river steps with the laundry to slap the clothes clean on the stone. Fifty yards upriver, near the flower market where servants of the rich buy garlands of fresh marigolds and hibiscus, street dwellers defecate into the water. But the river is holy, an arm of the Mother Ganges and, therefore, cannot be unclean. Across the river, in a sprawling conglomerate of slums called Howrah City, children splash under the hand pumps which supply water for drinking and washing. People politely avert their eyes from others using the open sewage canals between the shacks. In an hour the roads will be choked with traffic, and the air will begin to thicken with a blue haze of exhaust fumes. For a few Calcutta residents, today may be a relaxed day at the club. For millions of others, the day will bring another test of survival. Everyone in the city will go without city-supplied electricity for at least two hours. The hit-and-miss telephones will create hours of frustration. Roads, pitted and impassable after a heavy monsoon, will trap tens of thousands of cars like flies in a spider web. Calcutta is 300 years old this year. Job Charnock, an agent of the East India Company, founded the trading post on the Hooghly on Aug. 24, 1690, near the village of Kalikata, named for Kali, the feared goddess of power and destruction. It was, until 1912, the capital of British India, the second city of the British Empire after London, a city that pandered to the pleasures of the great men of the Anglo-Saxon world. Today Calcutta is in decay. Its Gothic Victorian-age buildings are crumbling and blackened with grime and mold. Shanties sprout like weeds in the sidewalk cracks. Even Calcutta's stately clubs look shabby. Walls are peeling at the Saturday Club, where wealthy Indians sip gin and tonic on the veranda overlooking grass tennis courts. The once-white uniforms of the bearers, as the waiters are called, are stained and gray with age. Decades of migration from impoverished villages and from neighboring Bangladesh have swollen Calcutta's population to 12 million. City services are collapsing, concedes Hassia Abdul Habib, the speaker of the West Bengal state legislature. ``The roads are mind-boggling. Communications are horrible. You can phone London directly, but you can't phone your next-door neighbor,'' he says. Calcutta, he adds, ``is coming to a boiling point.'' At the same time, Calcutta throbs with life. It is the home of a vibrant Bengal culture, poetry and experimental theater. ``Bengalis are not business people,'' says Ajay Chatterjee of the Calcutta Municipal Development Authority. ``They love literature, songs, drama. They are not pragmatic or practical.'' Calcutta fostered all three of India's Nobel Prize laureates: poet Rabindranath Tagore in 1913, physics researcher Chandrasekhara V. Raman in 1930, and Mother Teresa, a naturalized Indian citizen who won the 1979 Peace Prize for her work with the destitute. Perhaps only Calcutta, with its appalling poverty and capacity for survival, could have given rise to the phenomenon of Mother Teresa. Forty years ago the Yugoslav-born Catholic nun began to scoop up the dying homeless from the gutters and rescue them from an anonymous death. Her mission for the poor has spread to 92 countries. From the start, wealth and deprivation have coexisted in these inhospitable surroundings. Built on mosquito-infested delta land 80 miles above the Bay of Bengal, Calcutta suffers temperatures above 100 day after day in summer. The drenching rains of the monsoon season, from July to September, bring only humidity, not relief.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
CALCUTTA, India: not relief.
DOC.TEXT: British author Geoffrey Moorhouse called it an act of lunacy to build a city here. ``Everything in Nature was against it.'' Robert Clive, who turned the East India Company into an empire for England in the 1750s, called Calcutta ``the most wicked place in the Universe.'' Mark Twain, who visited in 1896, said the weather was ``enough to make a brass doorknob mushy.'' Calcutta's reputation also is stained by corruption and unending political intrigue. That, too, is nothing new. Lord Cornwallis, who was made governor of India after his surrender at Yorktown in the American War of Independence, wrote from his headquarters in Calcutta: ``Every native of India, I verily believe, is corrupt.'' With all its faults, most Calcuttans are intensely loyal. ``Bengalis love their wretched city with the same passion as a mother loves her sick child,'' wrote Khushwant Singh, a leading Indian author and journalist. ``We know all about our problems, but I love Calcutta,'' said Yvonne de Silva, who runs a private bus service. ``It bugs me that people come to Calcutta and take pictures of our garbage and our streets. Why don't they take pictures of their own garbage?'' Thousands of people live from the refuse which the city can't collect fast enough. Some sift through it for peelings or chicken skins for soup, competing with crows, cattle and pariah dogs. Ragpickers search it for anything to sell. Women collect, dry and shape the droppings from the brahman cattle, which roam freely. Others sweep up coal dust, wet it and roll it into balls of black mud called gril that also can fuel a cooking fire. Looking down from her second-story veranda, Sheila Lahiri pointed to a shantytown that had sprung up opposite her apartment on Ballygunge Road, a street of elegant residences. ``Could you believe this was possible 15 or even 10 years ago?'' said Mrs. Lahiri, whose father, Lord Sinha, was given a hereditary seat in the British House of Lords. Authorities long ago gave up the idea of tearing down the slums and focused instead on alleviating the misery. Calcutta used to have 1,000 deaths a year from cholera, but the disease was brought under control by water filtering and installing 20,000 public hand pumps in the slums. Calcutta has always been the refuge for the poor and displaced of eastern India. Waves of immigrants came with every ethnic upheaval, famine or war. The population more than doubled from 4.4 million in 1950, to 9.2 million in 1975. While the city grew, its resources shrank. A silting of the Hooghly virtually killed the port, which just 40 years ago received nearly half of India's imports. Recession, labor strife and political terrorism in the 1960s persuaded many businesses to leave. Fifty years after the government shifted to New Delhi, the economic center of India has gravitated to Bombay. The Communists, now 13 years in power, blame the policies of the federal government in New Delhi for giving the state less than what they say is its share of national funds. About 300,000 people have no home other than the pavement, according to some estimates. Stretched out on dirty rags or on the hard stone, they sleep undisturbed by the trucks and cars roaring past. They have an average weekly income of less than $5.55, said a study by the Institute of Local Government and Urban Studies. Thirteen percent of the street dwellers work as rickshaw pullers, earning an average 66 cents a day. It's the last major city on earth where men pull passenger carriages like human horses. The study estimated that 43 percent of the city's residents live in huts in squatter settlements, refugee colonies or slum neighborhoods, known here as a bustees. But an outsider walking through even the deepest slums of Howrah senses no anger, nor danger. ``Life is hard here. These people have nothing to look forward to,'' said Bettina Borgmann, a German doctor who volunteered to spend her summer vacation in a slum clinic. ``But the people surprise me. Most seem quite happy. They are content with what they have. Just look at the children playing outside with whatever they can find. I have never felt uncomfortable here.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Star Watch: Pop Musicians Play the British Crime Twins in Film
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: England makes its own contribution to the gangster movie cycle with ``The Krays,'' about the twins who ruled the London underworld during the 1960s. The stars are Gary and Martin Kemp, known to the music world as leaders of the pop group Spandau Ballet. The Kemp brothers were recently in Los Angeles to promote the movie. They are obviously not criminal types. Nor are they twins, having been born two years apart. Yet in ``The Krays,'' they provide a scary portrait of evil, and they could easily pass for twins. Offscreen, you can tell the difference. Gary, 30, is the older brother, the major force behind the Spandau Ballet, guitar player and writer of the group's hit songs; he plays Ronald Kray, the vicious twin. Martin, just turned 29, is the handsomer brother and bass player; he's Reggie Kray. While the Kemps have shared the bandstand since the founding of the Spandau Ballet, they haven't acted together since childhood. ``The first time we ever worked together was when I was 8 and Gary was 10,'' said Martin. ``We played in a BBC television production as brothers. From there we did a bit on television, not always together. We were child actors for 10 years. Then we started the Ballet.'' ```The Krays' seemed like a wonderful opportunity to work together again as actors,'' added Gary. ``It was something very special to work on the idea of becoming twins. Even though we're only two years about, we have our differences. I do think that brothers don't have the same kind of telepathic connection with the subconscious that twins have. ``It was a unique thing to work on, the same that an actor would go through self-analysis to become a character. We had to analyze our own relationship to become twins. It's very cheap psychotherapy.'' Ronnie and Reggie Kray began their professional careers as boxers, drifted into the protection racket in the East End, then moved into the club world. Like New York gangsters in the 1930s, they operated a series of nightclubs and hobnobbed with such luminaries as Frank Sinatra, Judy Garland and Tony Bennett. The Kemps and their gang continued their grip on the London underworld until both were convicted of murder in 1969. They are serving 30-year prison terms. ``It was the closest England ever came to having organized crime,'' said Martin. ``The Mafia never really infiltrated Britain. Ronnie and Reggie actually controlled the biggest part of London that has ever been controlled by individuals. ``The nicest thing about the movie is that we were asked to play a lot more than just two-dimensional gangsters. We were asked to actually get under their skins, to show those guys when they were home relaxed and not just outdoors with their pals and putting on a show as gangsters.'' ``We certainly don't have the sibling rivalry that the Krays had,'' remarked Gary. ``I'm always pleased to see Martin do well; I don't feel any competition between us. And vice versa. We found within the twin relationship - and I'm not condemning all twins - there's always one who really could not exist without the other partner. ``In the case of the Krays, it was Ronnie. Ronnie couldn't handle any real relationship outside the one he had with his brother. One of the worst things for Ronnie came when his brother gets married and starts another relationship. His bitterness toward that woman drove him more toward violence.'' Gary and Martin Kemp have been performing most of their lives, first as actors, then musicians. Gary appeared in the film ``Hide and Seek'' and in BBC's ``Plaything.'' Martin played in series such as ``Rumpole of the Bailey'' and ``Dixon of Dock Green.'' The Kemps made their debut with the Spandau Ballet on Nov. 17, 1979, and a year later issued their first recording. For 10 years their soft rock has been one of Britain's best-known exports. The brothers often go their separate ways - Martin is on his way to a movie in Australia, ``The Girl Who Came Late.'' But they always return to their music. ``There are five people in the world who can make that particular sound, which millions of people enjoy,'' commented Gary. ``So it should always be there to come back to.''

DOC.HEAD: Nashville Sound: Mark O'Connor's Fiddle Is His Duet Partner
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Fiddler Mark O'Connor has played on Grammy-winning albums and become one of the most sought-after instrumentalists in the music business. But the master musician doesn't think he's mastered anything. ``What I'm doing is the best I can at this time. The day when I get something mastered would be the day I'd have to quit doing it,'' he says. The 29-year-old O'Connor describes an intimate, almost poetic relationship with his fiddle. It is a pairing that has made him virtually peerless for his versatility. ``You establish this relationship as a duo. You work together hand-in-hand and try to make it come alive,'' he says. ``If you respect your instrument, it can give a lot back to you. Music is an inner thing you try to achieve. The relationship becomes intense.'' O'Connor can be heard playing as a sessions musician on countless albums recorded in Nashville. He has released nine albums of his own, first for Rounder Records and more recently for MCA Records. The Country Music Foundation has just issued the LP ``Mark O'Connor: The Championship Years.'' The cuts include his winning performances between 1975 and 1984 at the National Old Time Fiddler's Contest in Weiser, Idaho. He's even given a command performance of sorts. About 10 years ago, he was a guest at former President Ronald Reagan's ranch in California where he performed as one of the country's top young musicians. He played ``Sweet Georgia Brown'' during an appearance that became part of a special on public television. ``I was about as nervous as I've ever been,'' the soft-spoken O'Connor recalled in an interview. ``I was almost white as a ghost. But as an American musician, it was one of the most rewarding things you could do.'' O'Connor, a native of Seattle, taught himself to play fiddle at age 11 by watching others. Naturally gifted, he was also proficient on the guitar, banjo, mandolin and dobro. But the fiddle became his instrument of choice. ``It seems like I'm a little bit more naturally expressive on it,'' he said. He has made concert tours with the rock-fusion band Dixie Dregs and with jazz master Stephane Grappelli. He played on Michael Brecker's Grammy-winning jazz LP in 1989, ``Don't Try This at Home,'' and collaborated with James Taylor on Taylor's album ``Never Die Young.'' He has won Frets Magazine's best instrumentalist award six times. O'Connor has played on just about every style of record possible. ``The variety of it is amazing,'' he said. ``The bulk of it is country, and there's a lot of alternative things: jazz, folky, pop, contemporary Christian. ``Music is so much a part of my being that I just walk around with melodies in my head all day long.'' O'Connor, who does not sing, says he loves all musical styles if they are played well. ``I try to play these different styles and I learn a lot from every style. It almost helps me play the opposing style better. I don't get so wrapped up in the style or the idiom that I reject others. I adapt.'' Even though he plays almost every day, he said he's still learning and searching for perfection. ``I feel like my mind is divided. One-half of it teaches the other half. So one-half of it is constantly looking for new ideas and new things to pick up. Then I train and teach myself those things. ``The most rewarding part is improvisation, playing from the inspiration of the moment and not knowing what you're going to do. It's a little bit mysterious and magical. What it really is is on-the-spot composition. You're letting it all out on the line.'' O'Connor doesn't think he'll ever get tired of playing. ``Sometimes I do get tired of playing in the situations I'm playing in. This happens more than tiring of the music itself. I don't want to do one type of thing too many times. I'm always looking for the ne approach.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: John Oates of Hall and Oates and Bob Weir of the Grateful Dead took a 200-mile trip in August, riding mountain bicycles through national forests in Montana. Oates says it changed his ideas about national forests. ``I thought you set up a camp and Smokey the Bear keeps you from setting forest fires,'' he said. ``Through a friend in Montana I heard about massive clear cutting going on in national forests. ``What we found was depressing and enlightening. A lot of forest is being cut at a rate that cannot sustain continued growth. A lot is exported to foreign countries. We went through a borderline area, not devastated completely. It borders a wilderness area. The delicate balance of the wildlife habitat is completely altered.'' Oates said he planned to take his information to Washington and seek a ``citizens' bill'' to protect national forests. Oates and Weir were accompanied on their bike trip by friends and some members of the Alliance for the Wild Rockies who want to designate part of the Rocky Mountain chain as a wilderness area. ---= PARIS (AP) - A rare collection of historic china, including pieces that once graced the tables of Marie Antoinette, goes to the auction block next month at the Georges V Hotel. The pieces were gathered over three decades by Camille Le Tallec, 85, one of France's most celebrated ceramists, who has decorated dinnerware for European royalty and Tiffany eggs for American connoisseurs. His collection - more than 1,000 pieces in every size and color imaginable - tells the history of china craftsmanship over three centuries and across Europe. He began collecting rare pieces to learn the techniques used by the famous masters at Sevres and Nevers, renowned for the purity of their form, color and design. One of the least expensive items for sale is a saucer that could fetch $150, while a rare 16th-century china clock adorned with flowers and human faces is estimated at $60,000. Among the most prized items are an 18th-century water jug made for Madame Du Barry bearing her initials, a piece from Marie Antoinette's dinner service that experts had thought to be lost and a water pitcher and basin dating from the Revolution - one of the few pieces ever done in its particular shade of lavender. The china will be sold Nov. 6-9, and can be previewed starting Nov. 3. ---= OXFORD, Miss. (AP) - Jas Obrecht, associate editor of Guitar Player magazine, has completed his research on early blues music for his book, ``Early Blues: The Music Before Robert Johnson.'' The magazine editor has written about such blues superstars as John Lee Hooker, Buddy Guy and B.B. King and has just published a book titled ``Blues Guitar: The Men Who Made the Music.'' Obrecht said his current research focuses on the infant years of blues music and on its more obscure originators. The new book will contain a two-compact-disc set of blues songs in the back cover. ``It's an innovative marketing idea,'' Obrecht said. ``The CDs will be done by Yazoo Records and I'll personally select the tracks on the discs.'' Obrecht said the book will be available around Christmas 1991. ---= BURBANK, Calif. (AP) - Johnny Cash, Aretha Franklin, Billy Joel and Quincy Jones - who share a total of 46 Grammy Awards among them - will receive the 1990 Grammy Legends Awards from the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, Inc. The awards will be given during the second annual Grammy Legends Tribute, a two-hour primetime CBS-TV special for broadcast later this year. The event will be taped before a live audience in New York on Dec. 5. The Grammy Legends Awards honors an artist's ongoing creative contributions and influence in the recording fields. ---= LOS ANGELES (AP) - The landmark Smithsonian Institute exhibition, ``Crossroads of Continents: Cultures of Siberia and Alaska,'' opened Oct. 21 at the Gene Autry Western Heritage Museum, and continues through Feb. 24, 1991. Developed jointly by the Smithsonian and the Soviet Academy of Sciences with the aid of the International Research and Exchange Board, ``Crossroads'' includes many early amd important archeological and ethnographic collections from Siberian, Aleut, Eskimo, Athapaskan and Northwest Coast peoples. The nearly 600 artifacts in this exhibition - including kayaks, harpoons, ivory carvings, beadwork, masks, drums, clothing and weapons of war, as well as journals and photographs - demonstrate the elaborate arts, cultures and history of the peoples of the North Pacific Rim from 20,000 years ago to the present. The exhibition is the first jointly curated Soviet-North American exhibition ever organized.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Nov. 1, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Man Doesn't Regret Temporary Flirtation With `Fountain of Youth'
DOC.TEXT: Robert Bensing doesn't feel cheated by his brief flirtation with an age-reversing hormone that some fancy may be the doorway to a futuristic Fountain of Youth. In fact, the 72-year-old retired chemist has found his joints no longer ache constantly with arthritis and his skin is firmer, giving him the appearance and vitality of a man much his junior. ``I feel a little more energetic,'' said Bensing, who relishes being called ``son'' by a friend about his age and now can spend more time gardening. He stopped taking the hormone more than 1{ years ago, and doctors predicted the age-reversing symptoms of his therapy would fade within a few months. ``Theoretically, I lost all that, but I don't feel that I did,'' Bensing said recently his rural Waukegan home. ``Since the benefits didn't go away, I don't feel cheated. It was worth it. If it contributes to the advancement of medical knowledge, we don't feel cheated.'' For a year, Bensing injected himself three times weekly with the human growth hormone. Within six months of the first treatment, he could unscrew bottle caps with ease, mow the law without tiring easily and sit through lengthy car trips - all of which would have been difficult months earlier. Tests revealed the hormone treatments helped shrink body fat, restore lean body mass lost through aging and increase the thickness of Bensing's skin. ``I noticed right off he was doing things much faster,'' said Bensing's wife, Alice, 57. ``He was more willing to go places and do things than before.'' The growth hormone taken by Bensing and 19 other older male volunteers is a synthetic version of one produced naturally in humans. As one ages, the natural production of the hormone fades and eventually stops, researchers have learned. Daniel Rudman, an endocrinologist at the Medical College of Wisconsin in suburban Milwaukee and director of the experiment, said researchers have determined the hormone injections reversed aging in the body composition of elderly men by as much as 20 years. Rudman and his fellow researchers reported this summer in the New England Journal of Medicine that the hormone increased lean body mass in patients by 9 percent, decreased fat tissue by 14 percent and thickened skin by 7 percent. It does not, however, affect failing eyesight, hearing loss or degeneration of brain cells. The improvements strictly involved the patient's body mass. Rudman, 62, was among a group of physicians in the 1960s who used human growth hormone to treat abnormally short children. He decided to experiment with the hormone on the elderly after watching his parents grow old and frail in a nursing home. The hormone, once only available by extraction from human corpses, now is produced through genetic engineering. But regular treatment costs $14,000 a year for adults. Experts warn it is too soon to determine the severity of side-effects or whether the hormone could be produced cheaper and more readily. Most of the men in the experiment have declined to talk publicly since the study was published, some at the advice of the Medical College of Wisconsin. Bensing, one of the first volunteers for the study, said the hormone lessened the crippling effects of arthritis, prompted a quicker recovery from a cataract operation and appeared to make a crushed spinal disk a bit sturdier. ``There's a guy my age starting to call me `son,' '' Bensing said. ``They said, `You look great.' '' When he began treatment, Bensing was told the possible side effects included an increase in blood pressure or blood sugar. But his only complaint was a numbness in his wrists, which he attributed to pressure from skin and muscle growth. It stopped once the therapy ceased, he said. But Bensing, who lost hearing in one ear while an Air Force engineer in World War II, said he was disappointed the hormone didn't help that. Mrs. Bensing, who was born with cerebral palsy, said she too would like to one day receive the hormone. ``I've had limitations all my life,'' she said. ``I can see so many benefits for women, osteoporosis and other problems in the aging process.'' Rudman, whose research was carried out at veterans' hospitals in North Chicago and Milwaukee, said the hormone didn't appear to significantly improve bone density, reverse brain cell loss, cure failing vision or affect life span. Its value may lie in helping the chronically ill or older people prepare for or recover from major medical operations or illnesses, he said. Dr. Axel G. Feller, who helped in the experiments at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in North Chicago, said researchers are not prepared to recommend groth hormones for the aged. ``We don't have the whole picture,'' Feller said. Results of the experiments on the elderly, which began in 1980 and are continuing, may make therapeutic applications of the hormone available within five years, Rudman said.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Nov. 1, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Gray Hair No Handicap to Michigan Politicians
DOC.TEXT: Age rarely stands in the way of success at the ballot box in Michigan, despite Gov. James Blanchard's highly publicized decision to dump his 78-year-old running mate. Statewide elected officials include not only Martha Griffiths, who was 70 when she was elected to her first term as lieutenant governor, but Democrats Secretary of State Richard Austin, 77, and Attorney General Frank Kelley, 65. Both are running for new four-year terms. ``No one has suggested to me that I should not run again, for any reason,'' said Austin, seeking his sixth term. ``My personal view is that voters generally do not regard my age in any way. They're concerned about how well I perform in the office.'' Austin's Republican opponent, state Rep. Judith Miller, 54, of Birmingham, said she has no plans to question his fitness for office at 77. ``From my perspective, whether you are young or old should not be the determining factor in how you function. It's the kind of thing I don't believe is a legitimate issue.'' The fact that the issue of fitness was raised with Griffiths, but not with Austin, irked her. The long-time champion of women's rights complained the governor never would have booted her if she'd been a 78-year-old man. Blanchard removed Griffiths from the Democratic ticket Aug. 24 after two terms, saying he no longer considers her ready to step in and assume the governor's duties at a moment's notice. Age was not a factor, he said, but he declined to elaborate on his reasons. Griffiths, who feuded publicly with Blanchard for weeks about the breakup of their political partnership, said he told her she could be on the ticket if she released her medical records and tax returns. She refused, but told reporters her health is good. Griffiths' only obvious problem is her hearing. At a news conference responding to Blanchard's removal of her from the ticket, she lost her hearing aid. She and her husband searched for it on the floor behind the podium, retrieved it and put it back in her ear, but she still had difficulty hearing questions. The former congresswoman keeps a busy schedule speaking to women's groups and presiding over the Michigan Senate. But senators complained she was cranky and lectured them like schoolchildren. Under Michigan's constitution, the lieutenant governor acts as governor whenever the chief executive is out of state. That has happened 18 days so far this year. The secretary of state is next in line. Austin was acting governor for a week in 1988 when Blanchard and Griffiths were at the Democratic National Convention. Austin oversees 185 offices around Michigan whose 2,000 employees issue driver's licenses, sell license plates and register voters. His schedule runs 12 to 15 hours a day with no annual vacations, said his scheduler, Ann Johnson. He looks lean and fit and credits that to habits developed as an athlete, which included time as high school track team captain. ``Hurdles were my favorite event,'' he said. ``Somehow, I can still visualize myself skimming over those hurdles. I wouldn't try it today.'' Austin walks six to eight miles every Sunday to keep his legs in shape. ``That's half the battle,'' he said. Age is less of a hurdle for incumbents like Austin than challengers, said David Rohde, professor of political science at Michigan State University. ``It's much easier for the electorate to be convinced the person is qualified to serve regardless of age if the person already is serving,'' he said. But the fitness of an elderly person for office is an individual matter, just as it is for younger candidates, he said. ``Partly it depends on how visibly capable and vigorous the candidate is.'' In Florida's Democratic primary for governor, Bill Nelson, 48, tried to make age an issue, calling for a ``new generation of leadership.'' His opponent, Lawton Chiles, 61, won the primary, and age has not been an issue in the general election. Austin declined to comment on the Blanchard-Griffiths fuss, which seems to have faded as a political issue as the governor nears the end of his campaign for a third term. Blanchard, 48, replaced Griffiths with Olivia Maynard, 54, director of the state Office of Services to the Aging. Republican challenger John Engler, 42, sought to capitalize on the booting of Griffiths by adding gray hair to his ticket - 66-year-old Sen. Connie Binsfeld.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Nov. 1, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Age No Barrier to Adirondack Hikers
DOC.TEXT: At 73, Helen Menz thought she had scaled her last mountain. After all, she'd climbed the 46 highest peaks of the Adirondacks. She decided a climb up 4,159-foot Phelps Mountain last summer would be her farewell to high-peaks hiking. Age had finally caught up with her, she thought. Then a weekend hike on Wright Mountain proved her wrong. After letting her son and grandchildren hike up the trail ahead of her, she hit upon her own pace by walking then resting, walking and resting. ``First thing I knew, I was on top,'' said Menz, who lives in the Albany suburb of Loudonville. ``I finally owned up to the fact that you have to go at your own pace.'' Menz is not unique. Older climbers are common in the Adirondacks all the way up to the high peaks. Dozens past their supposed prime are proving that regularly scrambling up rocky crags and thwacking through prickly brush is not exclusively for the young. ``You can do it until you're fairly old,'' Menz said. ``If you sit down and say I'm finished, well then you are finished.'' Menz said she likes to hike with all three generations of her family at least twice a year. The only other nod to age is a walking stick she carries to absorb some of the shock her knees no longer can. ``Age is no limiting factor,'' said Ed Hixson, a surgeon from Saranac Lake. ``It's an extremely good thing for older people.'' Hixson, who has done a bit of climbing himself from the Adirondacks to the peak of Mount Everest, said hiking is a healthy alternative for people who can no longer handle jogging or team sports. He warns though that prospective hikers should get a complete check-up before putting the extra stress on the cardiovascular system. Hixson, by the way, said most people ``would be amazed'' by the number of older people climbing the Adirondacks. Older hikers run into the least trouble on the trails because they generally bring a lifetime of experience with them. ``Most older people who hike have hiked all their lives,'' he said. At 66, Chuck Bennett has been hiking in the mountains only six years, but he has packed in a lifetime of climbing, making about 300 ascents. Bennett, a retired General Electric worker, figures he goes high-peak hiking two or three times a week. Thursdays are given over to the ``Crooked Caners,'' a loosely knit group of hikers who regularly hit the trails of the Adirondacks and nearby areas. The only membership rule is that there are no rules. Named after the crooked cane each member is presented with, ``Caners'' are mostly in their 60s. They've been hiking weekly the past six years - rain or shine or even snow. ``No matter what the weather is, we go out,'' said Priscilla Hayes, who at age 46 is the youngest of the group. A recent hike to the Hudson Gorge brought out 15 of the 50 or so Caners. An off-and-on drizzle made the trail mucky and clouds of flies clustered around the hikers heads. Hikers broke their brisk pace only to spy a deer that crossed the path or check spores on the back of fern fronds. ``It's nice to have a space where you can revive your spirit,'' said Pat Collier, 61, who has been climbing the range almost all her life and seems to know the mountains personally. Six of her seven children have followed her footsteps - literally - and made it to the top of each Adirondack peak. ``I never knew why I climbed. There's something alluring about the peaks. There's something spiritual,'' said Grace Hudowalski, who at 84 has stopped climbing but remains the Grand Old Lady of Adirondack hikers and the first woman to scale all 46 of the highest peaks. Hudowalski said she writes more than 500 letters a year congratulating, and advising hikers and climbers of all ages. ``When you talk about mountains, you get very personal with people,'' she said.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Nov. 1, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Hucksters Bombard Mail Boxes of Elderly
DOC.TEXT: Older people are being warned against companies that offer worthless ``protection'' for their Social Security benefits and promote other schemes that essentially provide ``nothing for something.'' A senior consumer alert issued by the American Association of Retired Persons in cooperation with the National Association of Attorneys General says the results promised in mailings that often resemble government communications are anything but guaranteed. ``Instead, they are schemes that provide the consumer with nothing for something,'' the consumer advisory said. It says the misleading advertising in the mailings generally falls into one of the following categories: - Misrepresenting the company as a U.S. government agency. - Charging for services the Social Security Administration provides for free. - Selling so-called ``required'' items such as laminated Social Security cards. - Using scare tactics to spur fund-raising efforts, suggesting, for example, that failure to donate will prevent the group from lobbying to ``save'' Social Security benefits. - Conducting ``highly suspicious'' sweepstakes contests to lure older consumers into buying other services. The consumer alert noted that legislation under consideration in Congress would permit postal authorities to declare unmailable letters that could reasonably be seen as implying a government connection which does not exist. This would supplement regulations issued by the Department of Health and Human Services authorizing civil monetary penalties against companies sending such mailings. The advisory also noted that there are companies operating nationwide that offer ``protection'' for federal benefits. ``Without commenting further on the quality or honesty of their services, it is important to note that none of these companies is affiliated with a government agency, and that most are private, profit-making companies,'' the alert said. The Social Security system provides free to anyone on request a personalized statement of earnings and provides a method for correcting errors. But the consumer advisory said companies use the form requesting this service as a marketing tool and, for a fee, collect it from older citizens and mail it to the Social Security Administration for processing. ``Some of these companies even employ outrageous scare tactics in soliciting business - such as warning that `an illegal alien may be using your (Social Security) number to work illegally in this country' or that `someone may be fraudulently collecting benefits meant for you.''' Another approach offers to help a senior citizen apply for Social Security benefits for an unnecessary $15 fee. Still another offers a gold-embossed, plastic-laminated ``lifetime'' Social Security card, claiming it can be used for check cashing. The consumer advisory noted that the paper Social Security card is good for a lifetime and can easily and cheaply be laminated. ``The substitute card provided by the `protection' service cannot be used for any official purpose, such as check cashing, thus making it an expensive and useless purchase,'' the advisory said.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Nov. 1, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: `People Are Funny' Star Enjoying Lecture Circuit
DOC.TEXT: From train-hopping hobo to television celebrity, it's been a remarkable journey for Art Linkletter, who says he never intended to get into show business in the first place. ``I was studying to be an English professor,'' said Linkletter, 78. ``But as they say, life is what happens to you while you're making other plans.'' Adults remember Linkletter as the practical joker on NBC's ``People are Funny.'' His ``House Party,'' also known as ``The Linkletter Show,'' ran 24 years on radio and TV, until 1969. Linkletter often made kids the centerpiece of his routines, keeping a straight face while they made embarrassing revelations about their parents. ``Family is the key. We had a traditional family,'' he said. ``My wife was a private person, taking care of the children, family and house. I was the breadwinner. I had the fortress of my home, so I could go out and battle the demons.'' And who were these ``demons?'' Linkletter says everyone from unscrupulous competitors to thieves, drug-pushers and other threats to family health and happiness. Hoping to shield his loved ones, Linkletter said, he developed a career that would enable his wife to stay at home. But he found there are no guarantees in life. Linkletter's 20-year-old daughter, Diane, jumped to her death from her sixth-floor Hollywood apartment in 1969 while under the influence of LSD. Three months earlier, the husband of his oldest daughter shot and killed himself. In 1980, his 35-year-old son, Robert, was killed in a car accident. ``Life is not fair . . . not easy,'' he said. ``Outside, peer pressure can wreak havoc with the nicest families. So that's the part that's a gamble. ``But I'm an optimist. Even though I've had tragedies in my life, and I've seen a lot of difficult things, I still am an optimist.'' Linkletter's own childhood had its share of struggles. Born Arthur Gordon Kelley, Linkletter's preacher-father ``drenched me in religion'' and forced him to take odd jobs during the Depression, he said. So at 16, Linkletter left and became a hobo, hopping trains across the West, working where he could. Several years later, Linkletter returned home and entered San Diego State College, where he got his first taste of broadcasting. He went on to national radio and finally television. Today he is recognized as the dapper silver-haired man who sells therapeutic Contour Chairs, one of which he owns and occasionally uses. ``The little kids don't know me generally,'' Linkletter said. ``Mothers come up to me in airports with children and say, `Jimmy, this is Art Linkletter,' and the poor kid looks up and says, `Who's he?' ``Of course, there was a time when every kid in America knew me.'' Linkletter doesn't seem to mind that his star has faded a bit. He owns a home in plush Bel-Air. The view from his Wilshire district office takes in the skyscrapers of downtown Los Angeles. He spoke with a visitor at a big desk topped with family photos and a statue of an American bald eagle. He gives 75 to 80 lectures around the country each year. His name appears on 23 books, including the best-sellers ``Kids Say the Darndest Things'' and ``Old Age is Not for Sissies.'' His next book is tentatively titled ``How to Make Your Child into a Human Being.'' Following his daughter's death, Linkletter began a nationwide campaign against drug abuse. He continues to speak out against drugs and said his faith in Christianity has grown. Lois, his wife of 54 years, continues to live the traditional lifestyle, spending time with her children and grandchildren. She said the key to their long marriage and prosperity was the absence of competition. ``What he's good at, I'm not,'' she said, as she wallpapered her home with her daughter Sharon. ``His rise to the top was gradual. For us, it was a part of our lives.'' Sharon, 44, said growing up as a Linkletter was at times perplexing. She recalled feeling awkward at a public school because she was a famous child. She later transferred to a private school. ``I think as an adult, unfortunately, a lot of the years growing up were taken for granted,'' she said. ``It didn't seem odd to me to be on TV Christmas shows. But as an adult, I saw what an incredible life we had.'' She now looks at her father as a man who ``made a whole rainbow out of his life. He turned lemons into lemonade, and rain into rainbows.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Nov. 1, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: At 73, China's Oldest Fashion Model in Prime of Life
DOC.TEXT: Xu Xuejing looks much like other plump Chinese grandmothers in gray cotton slacks and button-up sleeveless blouse, her steel-gray hair pulled severely back in a knot at the nape of her neck. And that's just the idea for China's oldest fashion model. Due to convention and lack of choice, older Chinese women tend to favor almost identical outfits - white tunics or blouses, black or gray baggy pants, earrings and severe haircuts or buns. They are often elegant in their simplicity but rarely fashionable. Beijing's debut into world fashion as a major textile exporter, however, has brought with it a growing sense of style for Chinese women. Designer Lu Shiying established the Beijing Fashion Model Team for Middle-aged and Elderly People in 1987 after noticing during a visit to Japan that older Japanese women continued to care about fashion long past 40. ``Older people here tend to wear black, white, gray and blue. We look like old feudal grandmothers,'' said Mrs. Xu, 73. ``It's not that we don't love beauty, but we just don't dare to make ourselves beautiful.'' Mrs. Xu, the daughter of a wealthy Shanghai industrialist, has survived world war, civil war and revolution. During the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution, she and her husband, who comes from a similar family background, were branded enemies of society. Through it all, she retained the refinement of her upbringing - an asset that helped make her a fashion model at 70, which she decided to try after a daughter saw an ad in a newspaper, she said. After she retired from teaching music at 55, Mrs. Xu said, ``I would just lay on the bed day after day. And I suffered so many illnesses that my husband prepared my grave and was just waiting for me to die.'' Getting out and making new friends has given her a new lease on life, she said. ``These experiences have given me an emotional backbone,'' Mrs. Xu said. ``I haven't been really sick for three years.'' A pioneer for her age group, Mrs. Xu said her modeling skills are self-taught. ``I can't move like a young person, so I had to figure out for myself how to walk to suit my image and appearance.'' And her husband, for the first time, has learned to cook for her. She models at least once a week, often for high-level groups, including the National People's Congress, the country's legislature. The styles are designed for her age group. Below-knee, A-line coats and dresses with high collars feature heavily in Lu Shiying's designs. Sharing the catwalk with young models less than half her age can be a real trial. ``But, what do you know, we older models get the most applause,'' she said. ``People tell us that our beauty is different. We represent China's elderly.'' ``My legs and eyes are bad,'' she said. ``I'm old and ugly. But my heart is young.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Nov. 1, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: What Do You Know About Retirement Planning?
DOC.TEXT: Retirement planning tops the list of consumers' financial concerns for the new decade, according to a recent survey by the College for Financial Planning. Additionally, concerns over skyrocketing health care costs and long-term health care planning are on the rise, the non-profit institute said. Take the quiz below to determine how knowledgeable you are about your retirement and long-term health care needs. Select one answer for each question. The quiz was prepared by Janet Walsh, an academic associate at the college. 1. Michael Middleclass, age 45, plans to retire at 65. At the time of his retirement, he would like to have the purchasing power equivalent to $50,000 a year in today's dollars. Assuming an annual inflation rate of 4 percent, approximately what annual income would Michael need in the first year of his retirement? a. $80,000 b. $95,000 c. $110,000 d. $135,000. 2. The maximum annual individual benefit from Social Security in 1990 is approximately a. $5,000 b. $11,000 c. $16,000 d. $20,000. 3. In 1988, the average daily cost of skilled care in a nursing home was approximately a. $45 b. $72 c. $90 d. $115. 4. According to a 1985 study by the Health Care Financing Administration, Medicare pays what percentage of the national spending on nursing home care for people older than 65? a. 2 b. 15 c. 40 d. 65. 5. According to the 1985 HCFA study, Medicaid pays what percentage of the national spending on nursing home care for people older than 65? a. 5 b. 21 c. 46 d. 72. 6. Most Medicare supplemental insurance policies (Medigap) will provide substantial benefits for extended stays in a skilled, intermediate or custodial care facility. a. True b. False. 7. The average life expectancy of a person who is currently age 65 is a. 15 years b. 20 years c. 25 years d. 30 years. 8. A husband and wife who own their residence as joint tenants may exclude from taxation up to $125,000 of gain on its sale if certain requirements are met. One is that at least one person must be how old or older? a. 50 b. 55 c. 60 d. 65. 9. A durable power of attorney continues to be effective even after the principal becomes incapacitated. a. True b. False. 10. An individual may avoid the 10 percent penalty tax on distributions from a qualified retirement plan, prior to age 59{, by electing to receive the distribution in a series of substantially equal periodic payments over his or her life expectancy. a. True b. False. --- ANSWERS: 1. c; 2. b; 3. b; 4. a; 5. c; 6. b; 7. b; 8. b; 9. a; 10. a.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Nov. 1, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Seeds Can Be Saved and Used Another Year
DOC.TEXT: Most leftover flower or vegetable seeds are quite useable for another season in the home garden. Saving seeds from your own plants can be a different ball game. But either way, a few rules point the way to success or indicate why it's not worth the effort. Vegetable seeds that are fairly simple to store at home for three to five years include tomato, pea, bean, lettuce, beet, cabbage, cauliflower, radish, carrot, cucumber, watermelon, squash, spinach and eggplant. Long storage also is possible for flower seeds such as marigold, zinnia, pansy, petunia, verbena and alyssum. Onion, sweet corn, parsley, strawflower and candytuft are among those with the shortest shelf-lives. The technical details of seed saving fill countless books, and, as in all human endeavors, there can be varying degrees of success. In general, the fresher the seed the better the germination. However, home gardeners are not likely to notice much difference from held-over seeds and probably will need to thin excess seedlings, as always, if they follow the seedpacket's planting instructions. A simple test of seed viability is to put a pinch of seeds from a packet on a moist paper towel, fold the seeds inside and keep the towel moist for fiitethru 10-29 0313
DOC.HEAD: PM-Canada-Church Shootings, 1st Ld-Writethru, a0508,0365
Man Opens Fire In Church Basement, Wounds Seven People
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with victims questioned,
DOC.TEXT: description of suspect. Pick up 5th graf pvs, ``Vaillancourt said..'

A gunman opened fire in a crowded church basement, wounding seven of the 300 people gathered for a social event. Detectives questioned the victims today to try to determine the motive. Police Constable Bruno Vaillancourt said three women and four men were shot and wounded, but none critically. The shootings occurred early Sunday at a Jamaican-Canadian gathering at St. Pascal Baylon Roman Catholic Church. Police did not identify the gunman or the victims, but said the suspect was a man in his mid-20s. Constable Charles Morrisseau said the investigation is proceeding slowly because many witnesses were reluctant to talk to the police. ``Nobody wants to say anything,'' he said. Vaillancourt said three people already had been taken to the hospital by the time police arrived at the church shortly after 1:30 a.m. Sunday. The most seriously injured person suffered a bullet wound behind the ear. The others were wounded in the abdomen, hands and feet. While the police said they did not know the reason for the shootings, the church pastor suggested rival gangs might be involved. The Rev. Louis Levasseur said fighting among rival black groups has been a problem for the eight years he has been at the church. The elderly priest also said the problems only occur when English-speaking black groups rent the hall for special events. ``We rent the hall to Latin-Americans, Asians and Haitians and never have any problems,'' Levasseur said. The race and language of the group that rented the hall at the time of the shootings were not immediately reported. ``This is not the first time there have been gunshots and people hurt,'' said Levasseur. Shots were fired in the hall five or six months ago, but no one has been injured in about a year and a half, he said. He suggested the church may have to stop renting the hall to English-speaking black groups ``at the risk of being labeled racist. ''

Kansas Gas and Electric Co. has agreed to a $1 billion buyout offer from Kansas Power and Light Co., possibly dodging a hostile takeover bid from a third utility. Under an agreement announced Sunday, Kansas Power and Light will pay $32 in cash and stock for each share of KG&E, which would value the deal at about $1.04 billion. Kansas City Power and Light Co. had offered $27 per share, or about $875 million, for KG&E, but had been rebuffed by the utility's management, which contended the unsolicited bid was illegal and inadequate. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The federal deficit soared to $220.4 billion, the second highest ever, in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, the Treasury Department reported. It was the 21st straight year in which the government spent more than it took in. The fiscal 1990 red ink was 43.7 percent more than the $153.3 billion imbalance last year. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Iraq has used American and other hostages in Kuwait to wire oil refineries with plastic explosives that, if detonated, would wipe out the emirate's entire refining capacity, Bush administration sources said. Explosives also have been placed at other vital oil installations, including pipeline pumping stations, oil processing centers, oil wells and loading terminals, said administration and oil industry sources speaking on condition of anonymity Friday. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Oil zigzagged wildly on the futures market, closing down more than $1 per barrel after a rally based on war fears ran out of steam and traders began selling. Light sweet crude, the key grade of oil, fell $1.24 Friday to $33.01 per barrel for December delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Oil had gone to a high of $35.40 per barrel before the selloff began. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Aetna Life and Casualty Co. announced a restructuring plan, including layoffs, to tighten operations and save hundreds of millions of dollars. The Hartford, Conn.-based insurance company also announced a 51 percent drop in third-quarter earnings that included a one-time, $60 million charge for costs associated with the reorganization. Analysts said the restructuring may help both Aetna and the ailing insurance industry. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Even if Congress agrees on a massive deficit-reduction plan, the nation's deficit is still expected to hit a record $250 billion this year and the $3 trillion federal debt will continue to swell. Analysts said many Americans are probably unaware that the $250 billion deficit-reduction plan - which Congress and the Bush administration spent months feuding over - will rein in deficit spending but won't eliminate it. --- DETROIT (AP) - Executives from the United Auto Workers union and Ford Motor Co. signed a three-year contract as the union and Chrysler Corp. continued work on their agreement. UAW President Owen Bieber and Ford Chairman Harold Poling were the first of more than a dozen bargainers on both sides of the table to sign the new contract. Bieber refused to comment on the talks with Chrysler, the last of the Big Three automakers to settle with the UAW. --- LONDON (AP) - An administrator called in to rescue debt-ridden Polly Peck International PLC said he was optimistic the British food and electronics conglomerate will survive. The administrator said he believed there was plenty of opportunity to restructure the company, though he admitted it could end up ``somewhat different'' than its present form. Polly Peck owns such diverse brands as Del Monte fruit and Sansui stereos. --- STAMFORD, Conn. (AP) - Giant Stuff-A-Pumpkins, 260-gallon plastic leaf bags with black pumpkin faces, are the rage this Halloween season, ornamenting millions of lawns across America. ``We don't have any trees in our yard, so we went out one night and robbed the leaves of the people next door,'' said Betty Brown, a West Hartford mother of three whose family of Stuff-A-Pumpkins peer down from her front-porch roof. The bags are made by Stamford-based Sun Hill Industries Inc. ---

The stock market dropped sharply Friday, unsettled by worries about the banking industry and prospects in the Persian Gulf. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 48.02 to 2,436.14, finishing the week with a loss of 84.65 points. The dollar was mixed and gold fell. Soybean futures prices fell below $6 a bushel. Grain futures also closed lower. Oil futures weakened, precious metals fell and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Beating The High Cost of Delivering: Magazines Doing it Themselves
LaserPhoto
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Magazine publishers say they've found a way to beat the high cost of delivering: They're doing it themselves. A few small alternative magazine delivery systems have popped up over the last few years, but now one of the industry's heavy hitters - Time Warner Inc. - has entered the picture. The publishing industry says if Time's system prospers, more companies could follow and eventually provide significant competition for the U.S. Postal Service. ``There's no question what the motivation here is,'' said George Gross, an executive vice president of the trade group Magazine Publishers of America. ``By building a distribution system you are saying to the Postal Service that while there is no alternative now, in time there will be.'' The magazine industry has been complaining for years that rising postal rates have been cutting into their profits. Postmaster General Anthony Frank has acknowledged that postal rates have increased beyond general inflation, and he has vowed to slow the pace. But the Postal Service maintains it can do a better job of delivery than alternative systems such as Publishers Express, for which Time Warner is the managing partner. Eight other equity partners are involved in the project. Begun in Atlanta last year on a trial basis, Publishers Express now is delivering more than 100,000 magazines, catalogs and advertisement packages a month to more than 80,000 households within five ZIP codes. The company has set a goal of 200,000 pieces a month to 100,000 households by the end of the year. From a suburban Atlanta facility, delivery crews sort 24 titles - including Time, Sports Illustrated, TV Guide, the Atlantic Monthly and Playboy - and deliver them in sealed packages before dawn each day. Publishers Express cannot use mailboxes under federal law. The magazines and catalogs are delivered to doorsteps or left at the base of a mailbox. ``If you look at the magazine business, distribution is the only cost we don't have control over,'' said Howard Rosen, president of Publishers Express. ``But it's very tough to tell the post office you don't like their pricing structure. They'd say, `Fine, but you've got nowhere else to go.' '' Since 1970, Rosen said, the cost for second class postage - which is the rate for newspapers and magazines - has risen 811 percent compared to a general inflation rate of 209 percent over that time. Third class postage - the rate for most catalogs - has gone up 364 percent, he said. The Postal Service puts the figures a bit lower: 767 percent for second class and 247 percent for third class. Nonetheless, Rosen said, ``It's too cost prohibitive to distribute our products through the post office.'' In addition to titles published by Time Warner, the distribution service has contracted with other magazines and catalogs to deliver their products, Rosen said. The titles in the designated ZIP code areas are automatically distributed through Publishers Express, though consumers may request that the Postal Service take over their service. Postal Service spokesman Bob Hoobing said costs may be higher but service is reliable. ``The fact of the matter is, we have people who are career workers delivering the mail. We think we're more reliable,'' he said. Hoobing declined to speculate on the impact of such alternative delivery services. He said about 6.5 percent of the 161.6 billion pieces of mail handled last year by the Postal Service was second class. If future postal rate increases continue to pinch, ``there will be more magazines saying (to Time) we want to join you,'' said Gross, of the Magazine Publishers of America. Kofie Q. Dadzie, an assistant marketing professor at Georgia State University who specializes in distribution systems, said an operation such as Time's would have to handle an enormous amount of material to make its costs competitive with the post office. ``I'd be interested in finding the cost analysis that said it would be cheaper,'' Dadzie said. ``I'm surprised.'' Rosen declined to disclose Publishers Express' income, but he acknowledged the distribution system must expand if it is to do the job of the post office at a lower cost. ``Clearly at the scale we're at, we are not in a competitive price situation with the post office,'' he said. ``We need to double our volume. It can be reached within the next year or two.''

DOC.HEAD: Halloween Doesn't Frighten Consumers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Despite a slowing economy and talk of a recession, consumers haven't been spooked out of spending money for Halloween. All Hallows Eve, the largest money grossing holiday behind Christmas, is a ``recession-proof'' business, say costume manufacturers and retailers. ``Halloween remains good during all times, whether there's an economic slowdown or not,'' said Howard Beige, vice president of sales at Rubies Costume Company Inc. in New York. ``During an economic slowdown people may purchase fewer major appliances and take fewer trips. But when it comes to spending money on themselves or for a party they do. Halloween survives recessions very well.'' Fifty million Americans are expected to celebrate Halloween this year, estimates Hallmark, the holiday and greeting card giant in Kansas City, Mo. They'll spend $400 million for costumes and accessories and up to $2 billion once candy, pumpkins and other items are included, Hallmark said. The company said that's slightly more than what was spent last year. Adults are one reason for the financial success of Halloween, which dates back to 700 B.C. and the Druids who believed the souls of the dead returned to mingle with the living on this one night of the year. Halloween is the second most popular adult party occasion behind New Year's Eve and adults account for 25 percent of all costume sales, Hallmark said. ``Halloween is a party occasion that's continuing to grow,'' said Hallmark spokeswoman Sherry Timbrook. ``A recession or slow economy won't interfere. People will still seek out fun and fantasy.'' ``It's so darn important to have a good time, especially during bad times,'' said Jack Sheehan, owner of the Costumer, a 73-year-old costume shop in Schenectady, N.Y. ``My mother used to tell me that during the depression they'd go without meat for a week to be able to go to a movie on Saturday night,'' Sheehan said. Glenn Sanders, a psychology professor at the State University of New York at Albany, said hard times do make the idea of fun more important. He also said having a good time on Halloween doesn't involve spending a lot of money. ``It's not just that people want to have fun. There's not much cost associated with Halloween,'' Sanders said. ``People want to have fun with expensive cars, but that's something that's very much tied to the economy and whether there's a recession. Halloween involves a small amount of money relative to Christmas or other entertainment decisions people will make.'' Manufacturers and retailers seem to have no apprehensions about business. Rubies, which manufactures costumes and other Halloween merchandise, introduced 250 new products this year. ``We've seen a moderate increase over last year's sales. Halloween seems to be selling well,'' said Beige, although he declined to release sales figures. Hallmark said its stores are devoting the same amount of space to Halloween merchandise this year as they did last year. ``People put an emphasis on entertainment. They're not willing to sacrifice entertainment for themselves,'' said Philip Morris, president of Morris Costumes in Charlotte, N.C., which distributes costumes and Halloween wares across the country. But just in case, some producers are offering an economy line of merchandise. ``We are offering a lower-price range of costume accessories to capture more of the market at the lower end,'' Beige said. Sheehan, whose store carries many of Rubies products, said he has noticed some prudence among consumers this year. He said he'll sell more Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle costumes at $14.98 than he will at $27. ``These lower-priced options exist because of the hard economic times,'' he said. ``But the volume of business we have makes up for the fact that we're selling less expensive costumes.'' Sheehan, who also rents costumes for theatrical productions, said most of his costumes sell for $25 to $35. Rented costumes for adults fetch $40. Latex masks for $29.95 are another big chunk of Halloween sales. This year Saddam Hussein, Ayatollah Khomeini, Fidel Castro and Gorbachev masks are selling well. Outselling all these, however, is the ever-popular Richard M. Nixon mask. ``It's that shyster image that's made it popular,'' Morris said. Halloween producers and retailers insist they aren't likely to suffer this year, but admit things aren't as they used to be. ``The crazy spending of the 1980s is gone. When the dust settles, not all of us will be here,'' said Sheehan, whose annual sales total about $1 million. Sheehan believes the slowing economy will force many of the nation's leading chain stores to cut back on the amount of Halloween merchandise they sell. He said that will allow specialty stores to recoup business they lost when chains jumped on the Halloween band wagon in the last decade. ``Halloween is over retailed. Maybe a recession will be a correcting factor,'' Sheehan said. Regardless, he said sales at Halloween will always be strong because consumers are spending money on themselves. Morris agreed. ``With Christmas, consumers may cut back on things they're going to buy or the amount they'll spend. The expenditure is not for themselves,'' he said. ``Halloween is. It's escapism, and it's fun.''

DOC.HEAD: Coffee, Tea or Download?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: You can fly, but you can't hide. Business people who think the best part of air travel is that their office can't find them are in for a disappointment. The technology is here to track you down. Applications were due last week to the Federal Communications Commission for new systems to provide telephone service to commercial aircraft. Within the next two years, telecommunications companies say, not only will air passengers be able to place phone calls, they'll be able to receive them, alng with facsimile messages and data from portable computers. Some companies describe it as ``the office in the sky.'' McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. and Hughes Network Systems on Tuesday said they had formed a limited partnership to build and operate a nationwide phone and data system for commercial aircraft. The new service, called Clairtel, would involve 80 ground stations located around the United States to provide radio links with aircraft, McCaw spokesman Bob Ratliffe said. Clairtel and GTE Airfone Inc. were among companies that filed for permanent licenses for the aircraft systems by the Oct. 22 deadline, said Jay Jackson, engineering assistant to the FCC's chief of mobile services. Jackson said he did not know all the companies that applied and would not have a count on the applicants for several days, but he expected applications from five to 10 companies. All are expected to get licenses if their paperwork is in order, he said. GTE Airfone, a subsidiary of Stamford, Conn.-based GTE, is the largest operator of airborne pay phones, with 1,300 installed on planes owned by 17 U.S. and Canadian airlines.
