It was the first to enter the market, on Oct. 15, 1984, under an experimental license from the FCC, spokesman Kevin Petschow said. Airfone uses a portable phone based on an aircraft bulkhead or, in newer versions, at passenger seats. Each plane has a radio transmitter-receiver and a computer that handles billing and selects one of 90 GTE ground stations in North America and Hawaii to establish a radio link. Outside the United States, the phones work off Comsat's satellite service. It's not cheap. Calls anywhere in the United States or Canada are $2 a minute, plus a $2 setup charge per use. So far, calls can only be placed from the aircraft to the ground. The licenses applied for last week initially will only permit air-to-ground service, Jackson said. But both GTE Airfone and Clairtel have loftier ideas. Petschow said Airfone plans to have a ``second-generation'' system in operation by 1992. That will allow calls from the ground to the aircraft, from one plane to another, and personal computer hookups, fax transmissions and message services, he said. Information hotlines, stock information services and other features also might be added, he said. ``Imagine all the things you do in your office, you can do in an aircraft,'' Petschow said. GTE Airfone also plans to offer ``cabin management services'' for air carriers, allowing them to monitor inventory and bill credit cards over phone links, he said. Ratliffe said Clairtel at first would install a system similar to GTE Airfone's, but eventually wants it to be more a part of McCaw's cellular system. McCaw, based in the Seattle suburb of Kirkland, operates one of the nation's largest cellular networks, with ownership positions in more than 100 markets across the country. The ultra-high-frequency radio bands for cellular phones are near those assigned to the aircraft phones, so it may be possible to have a cellular phone that can receive both, he said. McCaw is working with other cellular companies to develop a North American network. With a nationwide switching system, it will be possible to dial a cellular phone number in Seattle, for instance, yet find that phone wherever it might be in the nation, Ratliffe said. Eventually, he added, that could include aircraft. ``Let's say I'm on the plane to Miami,'' Ratliffe said. ``It would ring on the plane. That's what we're trying to get to.'' Clairtel also envisions computer data transmissions, pager messages, faxes and other advanced services. Ratliffe said there's the potential to deliver video entertainment to passengers' seats, and for phone-toting passengers to dial up drinks or food from the aircraft galley. Jackson, however, has his doubts about how far the sky-high office might fly, especially if all that high-level talk means more work for the cabin crew. ``I don't think airlines want their attendants becoming a secretarial service for passengers on the aircraft,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Experimental Tax-Free Zone in Louisiana Doing Well
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Louisiana has been giving sales tax back to foreign shoppers for a year now, but while state officials are thrilled to see more tourists, some of the visitors are frustrated with red tape. The experimental tax-free shopping program has returned $1 million in taxes to foreign tourists, who spent $13 million at the 1,000 participating stores, officials said. The state figures the vistors' money has brought in $2 to $4 million in tax revenue from increased economic activity since the program started last Nov. 1. Hotel, restaurant and transportation taxes are not refunded. Officials had expected each foreign shopper to spend about $300 on tax-exempt purchases. However, it's turned out to be almost triple that and six times what the average U.S. tourist spends, said Jerry Merlino, head of the program. ``For every 1 percent we increase international visitation to Louisiana, the state would gain $3.5 million in taxes on money spent on . . . goods and services not eligible for tax refunds,'' said Karen Kelly, marketing and sales director of the program. The weakened dollar, which gives foreign tourists more spending power in this country, has helped bring shoppers, officials acknowledge. But the sales tax rebate, which in New Orleans amounts to 9 percent, has given Louisiana an edge, they say. While the tourists are spending money, some are leaving angry. ``I need my refund now,'' one man argued during 20 minutes of haggling with the refund clerk at the airport redemption center. ``It wasn't explained to me before I began shopping that I wouldn't be able to get my money immediately,'' said the man, who would not give his name to a reporter. ``I wanted the cash for when I traveled. Instead I have to wait for them to mail it to me.'' Officials said it could take 4 to 6 weeks for mailed refunds to reach their destinations. Jessica Nguyen, an employee at the refund center, said such complaints are common. ``Tourists read the information booklet wrong or misinterpret the way the tax is calculated,'' she said. ``That's when they leave dissatisfied.'' At least one traveler found problems in the stores, too. Linda White, an American citizen living in Germany, said getting a refund didn't seem to be worth the effort for a German companion of hers. ``At one store, everything went smoothly. But to fill out the vouchers we needed to go to the fourth floor of the store and our purchase was so small that we decided not to expend the energy. ``In another store, one person told us all you have to do is show your receipts to get your refund. Another said the same thing, but when we get to the refund center we're met with an entirely different set of rules,'' she added. But for all the gripes, Merlino has success stories: the Central American man who spent 10,000 on shoes, the Colombian sea captain and three sailors who spent $40,000 on electrical equipment, two Paraguayan women spent $11,000 on stock for their boutique and a group of Canadians abandoned their Florida vacation to go shopping in Louisiana. Early estimates showed 46.2 percent of the participating tourists were from Mexico. France and Canada ranked second at 19 percent and Japan third at 14 percent. Merlino said growing numbers are coming from Central and South America, England, Australia and West Germany. ``The word is spreading like wildfire,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Kansas Gas and Electric Agrees to Merge With Kansas Power and Light
DOC.TEXT: Kansas Gas and Electric Co. has agreed to a $1 billion merger with Kansas Power and Light Co., in a move that could frustrate a hostile takeover effort by another regional utility company. By becoming a wholly-owned subsidiary of Kansas Power and Light, KG&E would escape being acquired by Kansas City Power and Light Co., which had been offering $27 a share in an $875 million tender offer. The merger agreement was unanimously approved by directors of both companies, according to a joint statement released Sunday by the utilities. ``After carefully reviewing all options, (management) has concluded that this merger serves the best interest of the company's shareholders, its customers and employees,'' said Wilson Cadman, chief executive officer of KG&E. ``In reaching its decision, the board determined that the friendly combination with the Kansas Power and Light Company was not only attractive to our owners, but the two company's people and assets fit together well, permitting us to better serve our customers,'' Cadman said. In the consolidation, each share of KG&E common stock will be converted into a total of $32 in cash or Kansas Power and Light stock, the utilities said. ``If KG&E stockholders wish all cash, we can accommodate that up to $432 million,'' Cadman said. ``If they want all stock, we can accommodate that, or a combination of each.'' John E. Hayes Jr., chairman of Kansas Power and Light, said the utility ``started to look at the consequences of company ownership as soon as KCPL announced the hostile bid'' in July. On Sept. 11, KG&E announced that it was negotiating with a third party as a means of rebuffing the takeover attempt. It had been widely believed that KG&E was looking for a ``white knight'' as KCPL persisted. In response to the merger announcement, KCPL spokesman Turner White said: ``This is the thing that's been anticipated for a long time. We need to evaluate exactly what the transaction is with respect to ours.'' Excess generating capacity of KG&E had been thought to be the main reason for KCPL's interest in the takeover. KCPL has a rapidly growing customer base and KG&E has enough excess capacity that could serve as many as 100,000 additional residential customers. Hayes said the merged utilities would make available to KCPL enough generating capacity to ``fulfill their customer needs into the late 1990s ... at market rates.'' Hayes also said customers of KG&E would benefit from a $15 million rate reduction to be sought once the merger is final. ``We believe that the combined companies will provide even more efficient and higher quality service, not only to our current customers, but also to new business attracted to the area by the availability of abundant energy at reasonable costs,'' Hayes said. KG&E has characterized KCPL's tender offer as illegal and inadequate. KCPL has extended its tender offer three times, reporting earlier this month that about 44 percent of the KG&E shares had been tendered. If the deal with Kanas Power and Light is completed, KG&E would continue to maintain its headquarters in Wichita, Hayes said. No layoffs for either company were expected. The merger was subject to approval from state and federal regulatory authorities. Kansas Power and Light is based in Topeka and does business as KPL Gas Service Co. It has about 1 million customers in Kansas, western Missouri and northeastern Oklahoma and had revenues of $1.1 billion in 1989. KG&E of Wichita has about 250,000 customers in south-central and southeast Kansas. It had revenues of $533.4 million last year.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Reports Loss of $214 Million for Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. today reported it lost $214 million in the third quarter, nearly offsetting the $251 million it earned in the first six months of 1990. The loss, which amounts to 95 cents a share, was a little less than expected by Wall Street analysts, and stemmed mainly from incentive costs and lower production caused when minivan plants were retooled. The earnings report came as Chrysler faced a midnight expiration of a contract it negotiated with the United Auto Workers union in 1988. During the third quarter of last year, Chrysler earned $331 million, or $1.42 a share. The 1989 results were boosted by a one-time credit of $309 million from the sale of a stake in Mitsubishi Motors Corp. of Japan. Chrysler said the third-quarter 1990 loss came on revenues of $6.5 billion, down 14.5 percent from $7.6 billion during the July-September period last year. The company's third-quarter losses were softened by $83 million in earnings for Chrysler Financial Corp. That profit, a record for any third quarter in Chrysler's history, compares with third-quarter earnings last year of $76 million. For the first nine months of the year, Chrysler earned $37 million, or 17 cents a share, compared with $983 million, or $4.21 a share, during the same time last year. Revenue fell 15.4 percent to $23 billion from $27.2 billion. ``We anticipated 1990 would be a tough year for Chrysler and for the industry, so we launched a major cost-cutting program over a year ago,'' company Chairman Lee Iacocca said today. ``We didn't anticipate the Gulf Crisis, the federal budget fiasco or the continued escalation in the incentive wars, so we've increased our cost-reduction goals to $2.5 billion over two years.'' Iacocca has set the target for June 1991. Chrysler took its minivan plants in St. Louis and in Windsor, Ontario, out of service for a month to retool for 1991 models, damaging profits by reducing wholesale sales to dealers. Minivans and, to a lesser extent, Jeeps are the bases for Chrysler's profits. The company also is being hit by high incentive costs. The Big Three would like to end the cash rebates and low-interest financing, but each is waiting for another to take the first step. Ford Motor Co. reports its earnings Tuesday, the same day General Motors Corp. releases its third-quarter profit figures for its major subsidiaries and the day before it reports corporate earnings. Analysts have speculated Ford's earnings will be about 47 percent below the $255 million it earned during the quarter last year, and GM's will be half of the $248 million it made during the period last year. Collectively, third-quarter earnings for the Big Three were expected to be about 80 percent lower than last year. Ford's and GM's overseas earnings continue to sag, analysts have said, hurting their corporate profits. Nearly all of Chrysler's operations are in the United States.

The stock market edged higher today in a subdued response to Congress's passage of a federal budget plan. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 7.92 to 2,444.06 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 520 up, 398 down and 475 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 20.42 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Over the weekend the House and Senate approved a measure designed to curtail the government's budget deficit, which reached a near-record $220.4 billion in the fiscal year ended last month. President Bush has said he would sign the bill, ending a prolonged period of wrangling. With that uncertainty out of the way, talk has increased that the Federal Reserve might soon take steps toward at least a slight easing of its monetary policy. But analysts noted that serious problems remain in the government's fiscal outlook. In addition, investors were confronted this morning with new increases in world oil prices. Among actively traded blue chips, American Telephone & Telegraph rose ] to 33}; International Business Machines \ to 106~; General Electric ] to 50~, and Philip Morris [ to 46}. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained .35 to 167.06. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .20 at 291.19. On Friday the Dow Jones industrial average fell 48.02 to 2,436.14, finishing the week with a loss of 84.65 points. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 3 to 1 on the NYSE, with 369 up, 1,153 down and 451 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 130.19 million shares, against 141.46 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Reports $214 Million Loss, Contract Talks Continue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with earnings, newspaper reports. Picks up 3rd graf, `Chrysler, the . . .; SUBS 7th-8th grafs pvs, `Meanwhile, Chrysler ...' with 4 grafs to ADD details on earnings report, quotes from Iacocca. Picks up 9th graf, `The UAW ...' A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. today reported a $214 million quarterly loss as contract talks with the United Auto Workers neared a midnight deadline. The third-quarter loss nearly wiped out the $251 million the automaker earned in the first six months of 1990, Chrysler reported. The loss, which works out to 95 cents a share, was a little less than expected by Wall Street analysts, and stemmed mainly from incentive costs and lower production when minivan plants were closed for retooling for 1991 models. Bargaining was said to be going slowly for the contract that covers 63,000 employees. Among the major issues were pensions and health care. The tone at the talks reportedly turned nasty Sunday. The Detroit News in today's editions quoted an unidentified bargainer as saying UAW President Owen Bieber confronted Chrysler's Anthony St. John, vice president for employee relations. ``If you want a strike, you'll get it,'' Bieber told St. John, Chrysler's chief bargainer. Chrysler, the nation's No. 3 automaker, has been under pressure since the union on Friday gave notice that the contract extension under which it has been working since mid-September would expire tonight. The union has scheduled a meeting of its 200-member Chrysler bargaining council for Thursday, during which the local presidents and bargaining committee chairmen could get an update on the talks, review a tentative agreement or discuss strike strategy. Chrysler made $331 million, or $1.42 a share, during the third quarter of last year. Those profits were boosted by a one-time credit of $309 million from the sale of a stake in Mitsubishi Motors Corp. of Japan. ``We anticipated 1990 would be a tough year for Chrysler and for the industry, so we launched a major cost-cutting program over a year ago,'' company Chairman Lee Iacocca said today. ``We didn't anticipate the Gulf crisis, the federal budget fiasco or the continued escalation in the incentive wars, so we've increased our cost-reduction goals to $2.5 billion over two years,'' Iacocca said. Iacocca has set the target for June 1991. The UAW has reached three-year contracts with General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. and has said it wants Chrysler to sign the same pattern agreement, with minor alterations. But the autmaker has said it may not be able to afford such a contract. The pattern agreement calls for, among other things, lump-sum payments to current retirees and surviving spouses, a method for increasing pension payments for workers who retired before Oct. 1, 1979, and increases in the amount future retirees will get. Of the Big Three automakers, Chrysler has the highest proportion of retiree costs. It has nearly one retiree for every active worker. There are about 1.4 active workers for each retiree at GM and about 1.5 for every Ford retiree. When bargaining began in mid-July, Chrysler also said it needed help from the UAW to cut health-care expenses, which cost the company about $684 million last year. The pattern agreement has no change in health-care provisions.

DOC.HEAD: Richest to Pay the Most, But Everyone to Feel Effects
DOC.NOTE: EDs: UPDATES throughout to include effective dates. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT:
The tax bill that Congress passed over the weekend will touch nearly every segment of the American public. Most Americans will pay higher taxes, but on their purchases rather than on their earnings. The bite will be relatively light for all but the well-to-do. Those with incomes over $200,000 a year will see their federal tax liabilities rise by an average of 6.3 percent. Many of the 70 million couples and individuals with incomes under $20,000 will get a slight tax cut, thanks to expansion of the earned-income credit for poorer, working families with children. The National Taxpayers' Union, a nonpartisan organization that campaigns for lower taxes, estimated the bill will boost the taxes of a $30,000 household by an average of $109. The union, which figured all households in a certain income bracket, regardless of size, said a $40,000 household will pay $166 more. At $50,000, it will pay an extra $214; $70,000, $277 more; $100,000, $542 more, and households at the $225,000 level will face an average tax increase of $3,572. Here are major provisions, most of which will take effect Jan. 1: GASOLINE: Raise the 9-cent gasoline tax to 14 cents a gallon and the 15-cent diesel tax to 20 cents on Dec. 1. A motorist driving 10,000 miles a year in a car that gets 22 miles per gallon will pay about $23 more. ALCOHOL: Effective Jan. 1, double the beer tax to 32 cents a six-pack; raise the $12.50-a-gallon tax on 100-proof liquor by $1, or 20 cents a fifth; raise taxes on most wines, including table wine, which will go from 3 cents a 750-milliliter bottle to 21 cents. TOBACCO: Raise the 16-cent cigarette tax by 4 cents in 1991 and another 4 cents in 1993. Snuff, cigars and other tobacco will face 25 percent tax increases each year. AIR TRAVEL: On Dec. 1, raise to 10 percent the 8 percent tax on airline tickets, which had been scheduled to drop to 4 percent at year end. The average round-trip ticket, which costs about $300, will increase by $6. TELEPHONES: Make permanent the 3 percent tax on local and long-distance phone service, which otherwise will expire Dec. 31. LUXURIES: On Jan. 1, impose a 10 percent tax on the portion of the price of cars above $30,000; boats above $100,000; jewelry and furs above $10,000 and private planes above $250,000. A $40,000 car, for example, will face a luxury tax of $1,000. TAX RATES: Effective Jan. 1 (for tax returns to be filed in 1992), raise to 31 percent the 28 percent top income tax rate paid by the 600,000 couples and individuals with the highest incomes. That will raise taxes on singles making more than about $125,000 a year and couples with incomes above the $200,000 range. Cut to 31 percent the 33 percent rate that as many as 4 million upper-middle-income people pay on part of their earnings. This will reduce taxes for single people with incomes between about $60,000 and $125,000 and couples between about $100,000 and $200,000. However, other parts of the bill will take back that tax cut in most cases. Raise from 21 percent to 24 percent the alternative minimum tax, which is paid by fewer than 100,000 high-income people with large amounts of deductions that otherwise could reduce tax liability to near zero. CAPITAL GAINS: Tax profits from the sale of investments at a maximum rate of 28 percent. This will provide a break for those investors who now pay a maximum rate of 33 percent. There is no deep across-the-board cut in capital gains taxes as President Bush has demanded. ITEMIZED DEDUCTIONS: On Jan. 1, reduce by 3 percent the value of certain itemized deductions that may be written off against adjusted gross income over $100,000. Only 97 percent of deductions will be allowed against the portion of income above $100,000; thus the allowable deduction will be reduced by $300 for each $10,000 of income above $100,000. The restriction will not apply to deductions for medical expenses, casualty losses or investment interest. The provision will affect about 2.5 million couples and individuals. EXEMPTIONS: On Jan. 1, reduce personal exemptions - which now are $2,050 for a taxpayer and each dependent - as adjusted gross income rises above $100,000 for a single person and $150,000 for a couple. This will raise taxes for people at those levels. The exemptions will be reduced by 2 percent for each $2,500 that income exceeds those thresholds. The exemptions will be lost once income tops $225,000 (single) or $275,000 (couple). LOW-INCOME: Effective Jan. 1, increase the earned-income tax credit, which benefits about 5 million low-income working families with children, as a way of offsetting some of the higher excise taxes. MEDICARE TAXES: On Jan. 1, increase to $125,000 the $51,300 maximum annual wage to which the 1.45 percent Medicare tax applies. This will affect about 8 million wage-earners. The tax is withheld as part of the Social Security tax and paid by employees and employers. MEDICARE PREMIUMS: Starting Jan. 1, raise the $28.60 monthly premium for Medicare Part B insurance to $29.90 next year and $46.20 by 1995. About 30 million elderly and 3 million disabled people are enrolled in Part B. MEDICARE DEDUCTIBLE: Also on Jahn. 1, raise to $100 through 1995 the present $75 deductible, which beneficiaries must pay before Medicare starts paying for doctor bills. SOCIAL SECURITY: Require the 3.8 million state and local government workers not covered by a public pension to pay Social Security taxes starting next July 1. ENERGY INITIATIVES: Starting Jan. 1, provide $2.5 billion worth of tax incentives for increasing U.S. oil and gas exploration and production. EXPIRING BENEFITS: Increase through 1991, at a five-year cost of $5.9 billion, 11 targeted tax breaks that are expiring. Principal beneficiaries include workers who receive tuition aid or group legal services from employers; businesses that hire the poor; investors in low-income rental housing; self-employed people who buy their own health insurance; businesses that increase spending for research; and low-income people buying a first home. BUSINESS: Retroactive to Sept. 30, raise taxes on life insurance companies by $8 billion. Extend for five years an expiring 0.2 percent surtax that employers pay for unemployment insurance. Raise the interest rate corporations must pay on overdue taxes, effective Jan. 1.
PROVISIONS DROPPED= The final bill dropped several provisions that had been the subject of intense negotiations. They included: A new tax on home heating oil; forgoing next year's scheduled ``indexing'' adjustment of tax brackets and exemptions, which protects against inflation; requiring that veteran state and local government workers pay the Medicare tax; imposing a surtax on millionaires; and allowing a special break to high-income people who donate appreciated art works to museums.

DOC.HEAD: Newsroom Employees Decide to Continue Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with seven grafs to RECAST lead to CLARIFY meeting involved 40 Guild members but others also continuing strike. Picks up 8th graf, `No new ...' Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Averting a split among the Daily News' newsroom employees, a group of reporters and photographers decided to remain on strike today rather than take up an offer to cross picket lines and reclaim their jobs. ``We're willing to give the strike more time,'' reporter Paul LaRosa said Sunday. ``There's no point in going back now.'' The News, hit by a walkout last week by nine of its 10 unions, had said striking workers were welcome to return to their old jobs at any time as long as permanent replacements had not been hired. A group of 40 reporters and photographers belonging to the 750-member Newspaper Guild sent a delegation to discuss the matter Sunday with Guild President Barry Lipton. Some complained that the strike was called on the basis of a false report that replacements had already been hired to fill reporting slots. ``There's a lot of anger at the Guild leadership,'' said striking reporter JoAnne Wasserman. But after the meeting, the group decided to stay on strike. The Guild represents reporters, photographers and office workers. It could not be immediately determined how many Guild members are honoring the strike. No new talks are scheduled. The News has said it plans to replace the strikers permanently. The Daily News, the nation's second-largest metropolitan daily, has published a paper each day since the strike began Thursday night but conceded it is having trouble delivering the paper. Home delivery was spotty and many newsstands were not getting the newspaper. ``We have not been hitting all distribution points as of yet,'' John T. Sloan, the newspaper's chief spokesman, said Sunday. ``We will soon.'' He also accused strikers of intimidating dealers and removing papers from newsstands. Strikers have torched delivery trucks and vandalized others. About 20 strikers have been arrested since the strike began, most on disorderly conduct charges. Workers at the A & S Stationery store in Brooklyn said club-wielding men had seized all 300 copies of Sunday's News and scattered them in the gutter. ``I can't take the paper or they will kill me,'' said one of the store's owners, Ali Najeli. The New York Times quoted an unidentified management source as saying many drivers had become lost. The News said in a statement Sunday that it published and distributed more than 1.2 million papers in the city and surrounding suburbs, exceeding Saturday's press run by 500,000. The News normally prints 1.46 million Sunday papers. The 71-year-old daily has been in a financial tailspin for the past decade. The News has lost about $115 million and seen daily circulation slip by about 700,000 since 1980. It recently lost its standing as the nation's largest metropolitan daily to the Los Angeles Times. The strike began Thursday night when 60 drivers at the News were replaced in a dispute over whether a driver would be allowed to monitor a conveyor belt while sitting down. All but one union followed suit. Members of the Typographical Union have continued working because they have guaranteed lifetime jobs. The unions claimed management provoked the crisis, which followed 10 months of often stormy talks on contracts to replace those that expired in March.

DOC.HEAD: Merrill Lynch Announces Management Shakeup
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 3rd graf to ADD estimate on savings, uppicks 4th graf pvs: The spokesman . . . ; SUBS 10th graf to CORRECT typo in name to Zeikel; uppicks 11th graf pvs: Two current . . .
DOC.TEXT: Merrill Lynch & Co. today announced a broad-based management shakeup that should help the nation's largest securities firm rein in costs but may result in the loss of several hundred jobs. The move includes establishing six core business divisions that will replace the two-sector structure that has been in place since 1984. The new divisions, each with a new executive vice president, are: private client, asset management, insurance, investment banking, debt markets and equity markets. While a Merrill spokesman said the restructuring is not ``a layoff-driven process,'' he added that the firm is ``committed to reducing our cost base wherever possible.'' The move is expected to save the firm ``tens of millions of dollars'' over an unspecified period of time, he added. The spokesman said that the new vice presidents ``are going to go forward to see where they can consolidate support operations.'' While there are no specific layoffs targeted, he did say that some jobs could be eliminated where there are redundancies. ``It's possible over the next several months that they will reduce the work force by several hundred,'' he said. Earlier this year, a top Merrill executive told analysts that under a worst-case scenario - that is, if business conditions continue to deteriorate - the firm would consider furloughing 10 percent of its staff. At the peak in 1987, Merrill's payroll totaled 50,000; the firm currently employs 39,000. The spokesman noted that over the past year Merrill has been ``resizing our businesses as market conditions required. That process will continue, and we expect to be even more focused under the new structure.'' The six new divisions will not operate autonomously. Under the two-sector structure, Merrill's individual-investor operations were separate from its capital markets group, which failed to foster cooperation between the two groups, reports said. The newly elected executive vice presidents are Barry Friedberg, 49, who will head investment banking; David Komansky, 51, equity markets; Roger Vasey, 54, debt markets, and Arthur Zeikel, 58, asset management. Two current executive vice presidents will head the other core business divisions: John Steffens, 49, private client, and Thomas Patrick, 47, insurance. Separately, two current executive vice presidents will head new support divisions. They are Jerome Kenney, 49, corporate strategy and research, and Herbert Allison Jr., 47, finance and administration. All will also serve on the firm's executive management committee. ``The new structure elevates key strategic ares of opportunity, further streamlines the organization, and elevates the role of our core line managers in directing business strategies and contolling costs,'' said Merrill Chairman and Chief Executive William Schreyer and President Daniel Tully in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Philadelphia Hotel Tax Foes Lose Battle
DOC.TEXT: Opponents of a Philadelphia hotel room tax lost a Supreme Court appeal today. The court, without comment, rejected arguments the tax unlawfully interferes with interstate commerce and unfairly discriminates against those who live outside the city. Among those challenging the tax were members of a libertarian group called Liberty Forum, a Wall Street Journal editor and a business consultant. They said the tax violates their rights by forcing them to contribute to the construction of a proposed $523 million Philadelphia Convention Center. The Philadelphia City Council, authorized by a state law, raised the tax in 1986 on hotel room rentals from 3 percent to 5 percent. The rate is to go to 6 percent after substantial completion of the convention center. The higher taxes are to help finance the center's construction, although most of the money for the project is to come from other sources. Challenging the tax were Liberty Forum members John Famularo and Linda Morrison of Philadelphia; Wall Street Journal editor John Fund, who lives in Jersey City, N.J.; Richard Broglino, a business consultant from Lexington, Mass.; and Stuart Kessler, a New York City architect. They said the tax is unconstitutional because it applies only to those who stay at a hotel 30 days or less. The great majority of hotel patrons subject to the tax are out-of-state residents, they said. A Pennsylvania state court upheld the tax last year. The state court said the higher taxes paid by those challenging the levy are ``minimal when compared to the prospective good to be achieved by both (city) residents and visitors alike.'' The case is Morrison vs. Pennsylvania Convention Center Authority, 90=377.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Lower On Good Crop Weather
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, mainly reflecting good fieldwork weather in most U.S. agricultural areas. Dry conditions allowed Midwestern farmers to harvest more of their corn and soybeans over the weekend and mild temperatures in the Great Plains were beneficial for newly planted winter wheat, analysts said. Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said farmer sales of corn and soybeans increased slightly over the weekend, which prompted further selling of futures contracts this morning. Corn and soybean harvesting is expected to proceed at a rapid pace this week before precipitation returns to the Midwest this weekend. Traders will get an update on the harvest in a weekly Agriculture Department report scheduled for release after the close. In early trading, wheat futures were 2{ cents lower to { cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.61} a bushel; corn was } cent to 1 cent lower with December at $2.27 a bushel; oats were 1} cents to 2{ cents lower with December at $1.17} a bushel; soybeans were { cent to 3} cents lower with November at $5.92{ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork futures fell sharply, reflecting weak cash markets. Live cattle were .07 cent to .30 cent lower with December at 77.57 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .22 cent lower with November at 87.17 cents a pound; live hogs were .13 cent to 1.20 cents lower with December at 51.75 cents a sound; frozen pork bellies were 1.45 cents to the permitted daily limit of 2 cents lower with February at 60.97 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled mixed on Friday. Pork futures fell.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Rig Count Increases by 18
DOC.TEXT: Louisiana led the way this week as the number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States rose 18 to 1,107, an industry report said Monday. The toolmaker Baker Hughes Inc. reported the latest count was up from 1,010 a year ago. Last week, the count improved by 33 to 1,089. Louisiana added nine rigs for the week, while Oklahoma, Wyoming, California, North Dakota, Pennsylvania and Texas also added rigs. Counts in other major producing states remained unchanged. Baker Hughes has kept track of the rig count since 1940. It is a widely watched index of drilling activity and represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil, not those producing oil. At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the count reached a peak of 4,500. But the rig count plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Back Up As Soviets Fail to Sway Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices shot up more than $1 per barrel today as traders expressed concern over the apparent failure of Soviet diplomatic efforts in the Persian Gulf. In early trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil was up $1.49 to $34.50 per barrel on contracts for December delivery. Later delivery contracts were all trading higher in light volume. ``There was a lot of speculation over the weekend that there could be some progress made,'' said Peter Beutel, an oil analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. ``Whether it's true or not, people are saying this may be the last chance before some military action is necessary. The thinking is if the Soviets can't get Iraq to change, who can?'' The Soviet Union and Iraq had once had close ties, but the Soviets nonetheless lined up with the rest of the global community in condemning Iraq for its invasion and occupation of neighboring Kuwait in August. Soviet Middle East troubleshooter Yevgeny Primakov met with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein in Baghdad on Sunday and was said to have made little progress in resolving the crisis. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze had suggested a day earlier that Iraq may have softened its stand. But after Sunday's talks between Primakov and Saddam, Shevardnadze said he saw no reason for optimism. Some traders were taking things easy today as they waited to see an interview with Saddam that Cable News Network was to air this evening, according to Brendan Dolan, a broker with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Even though oil was higher this morning, traders said the market did not seem to have the strong momentum that has at times sent it surging. Early in today's session, crude was up as much as $1.84 per barrel, but it began losing some of that ground late in the morning. As crude moved up, so did futures contracts for refined petroleum products. Home heating oil was up 4.30 cents to 92.55 cents a gallon for November contracts, with all later delivery months trading higher. Unleaded gasoline contracts were higher for all delivery months, with November delivery contracts rising 4.23 cents to 95.70 cents per gallon. Natural gas was down 0.3 cent to $2.445 per 1,000 cubic feet on December delivery contracts. Most later contracts were trading lower.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
DOC.TEXT: Domestic coal production totaled 21 million tons during the week ending Oct. 20, up 2.2 percent from the 20.5 million tons produced in the previous week, the U.S. Department of Energy reported Monday. The U.S. coal industry produced 19.7 million tons in the same week last year, according to the department's Energy Information Administration. Wyoming ranked first among the 26 coal-producing states with 3.7 million tons produced. Kentucky was second at 3.42 million tons and West Virginia was third at 3.40 million tons, the agency said. Domestic coal production so far this year is 819.7 million tons, 6 percent ahead of last year's production at this time. The week's production accounts for bituminous and lignite coal.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Permits Company To Pay Suppliers
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has ruled Southland Corp. can pay bills owed its suppliers and keep its 7-Eleven convenience store chain operating while it goes through bankruptcy reorganization. The special order allows the Dallas-based Southland to pay $220 million to vendors for beer, chips, soft drinks and other supplies. Judge Harold Abramson approved the order Friday. Southland incurred the debts before it filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act last Wednesday. The judge approved a ``deposit of payment'' with the court in an amount equal to the outstanding debts, said Southland spokeswoman Cecilia Stubbs Norwood on Sunday. Vendors in return agreed to continue offering Southland normal credit terms while the company struggles to emerge from reorganization. Ms. Norwood said vendors can be forced to return payments to Southland if they refuse to offer customary from the bench for the first time today, about half an hour into the ninth oral argument of his new tenure. Souter asked two questions in a case in which the court is to decide whether federal officials should have additional authority to deny temporary legal status to immigrant farmworkers. The questions centered on how long farmworkers who believe their rights have been violated must wait for administrative hearings. And Souter asked a few other questions in the following case, one in which the court must decide whether passengers on international flights may sue airlines for the emotional distress they allegedly suffer in near-crashes that cause them no physical harm. Souter, who joined the court Oct. 9, had not spoken from the bench through eight hours of argument sessions. For the record, his first words from the bench came at 10:31 a.m.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Instruments Introduces Laptop, Laser Printer
DOC.TEXT: Texas Instruments Inc. on Monday joined competitors who have unveiled lightweight laptop computers featuring an increasingly popular microprocessor. The new notebook-size computer, called Travelmate 3000, costs less than one with a similar chip announced two weeks ago by Compaq Computer Corp. The Texas Instruments machine has less memory than Compaq's LTE386s-20, but it's lighter at 5.7 pounds and has a bigger screen. In addition, the TI machine includes the DOS operating system, which costs extra on the Compaq model. DOS is used on International Business Machines Corp. computers and compatible models. An operating system is the base layer of software that controls a computer's internal functions. Dallas-based Texas Instruments will make the computer at its plant in Temple, about 130 miles south of Dallas. The company also announced production of new laser printer at the plant. The brain of the new laptop, which will be available in November, is a less costly version of Intel's 386 microprocessor called the 386SX. The computer measures 8.5 by 11 by 1.8 inches and has a 10-inch diagonal display and one floppy diskette drive. A unit with a 20-megabyte hard disk drive has a list price of $5,499, while one with a 40-megabyte hard disk drive lists for $5,999. The comparable models made by Houston-based Compaq cost up to $6,999, and weigh 7.5 pounds. Epson America Inc. and the Grid division of Tandy Corp. also offer laptops based on the 386SX chip. The new laser printer, called microLaser XL, prints up to 16 pages per minute. Three models, priced from $3,449 to $4,499, are available. The printer is built for IBM-compatible computers, but a $145 device will allow it to be used with Apple Computer Inc. machines.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Finished Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished mixed after light trading on London's Stock Exchange Monday, with investors unwilling to take positions in an uncertain marketplace. Investors were kept on the sidelines by the unresolved situation in the Middle East and concerns about the outlook for global equity markets and British corporate profitability, traders said. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 1 point, or 0.05 percent, at 2,062.1 at the close. The Financial Times 30-share index rose 1.6 point to close at 1,600.0. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 0.32 point to close at 1,102.44. Volume was a light 300 million shares compared with 367.3 million shares Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Nickled and Dimed to The Poorhouse
DOC.TEXT: Nickels and dimes add up to real money, as taxwriters know and taxpayers soon will learn. It's a big country, and every penny counts when multiplied by millions of people. If you're a beer drinker, for example, you'll be taxed 16 cents more for every six-pack you buy - not too bad, you say, until you get around to the multiplication. That additional 16 cents doubles the total federal tax on the six-pack, bringing the tab on a two-pack-a-week drinker to more than $33 in a year. To which you might have to add a sales tax and a bottle or can deposit. You probably drive a car as well, and it isn't at all unusual that you might average 250 miles a week or 13,000 miles a year, and that your vehicle gets about 25 miles to a gallon. That means your buggy consumes 10 gallons a week or 250 gallons a year, on which you'll be paying a 14-cent-a-gallon tax of $1.40 a week or nearly $73 a year, not counting what your state might add to the bill. In an effort to avoid such tabs, you might think of leaving the car behind and traveling by air on your vacation, but you still will take along Uncle Sam. Effective Dec. 1, the ticket tax goes to 10 percent from 8 percent. You might say this nibbling at your wallet could drive you to drink, but even then you won't escape. The tax on a bottle of table wine rises to 21 cents from 3 cents, and for a fifth of whiskey to nearly $2.15. Cigarettes offer no relief either, because you'll be paying an additional 4 cents a pack after January 1, which would add nearly $15 a year to your bill if you're a pack-a-day user. Taxes such as these slip up on you deceptively; the units are in pennies but the multiples are in dollars, and when applied so many times to so many things in life, they tend to mount into the hundreds of dollars. For Uncle Sam, who multiplies the tax on each individual by millions of individuals, the total tab is in the multibillions of dollars. By such means does ``tax freedom day'' get pushed back. Back in 1945, says the Tax Foundation, you finished paying your obligations to Uncle Sam by April 1. From New Year's until that date, in theory, you were working for Sam. By 1965, freedom day was delayed until April 28, and this year it occurs around May 5, meaning the average taxpayer labored 125 days to finance his indigent uncle, a gentleman attuned more to spending than restraint. That might be irritating, you might say, but at least you have some of the year's paycheck left for yourself. Yes, but the trend is ominous, and budget summitry isn't likely to change that trend. For the sixth time in nine years the White House and Congress used summitry in an attempt to reduce the federal deficit. To date, says the foundation, ``a summit-arranged budget has never even reduced the deficit below the level of the summit year.'' In short, don't expect freedom day to occur much earlier next year. The 1990 cost of running Congress itself rose 10.6 percent over 1989, bringing the price tax to $2.3 billion. That's the trend. You might need no reminder of it than the hole in your pocket and the extra days you spend working for Uncle Sam.

DOC.HEAD: Barclays to Close 110 Branches, Cut 1,800 Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Barclays Bank PLC said Monday it plans to streamline its domestic retail branch operations over the next five years by closing 110 offices and trimming 1,800 staff through attrition. The office cuts, mostly in urban centers, amount to slightly more than 4 percent of Barclays' network of 2,600 retail bank branches in Britain, while the staff cuts represent 1.5 percent of its total domestic workforce of 87,000. Barclays said 1,300 of the jobs would be cut from clerical staff, and the rest from management. Britain's major commercial banks have been moving to trim staff and unprofitable branch operations in the past year in an effort to cut operating costs and squeeze greater profit out of existing revenue.

DOC.HEAD: Honeywell Announces System to Link Manufacturing, Air Temperature Controls
DOC.TEXT: Honeywell Inc. on Monday announced a computer system that will allow companies to combine the control of their manufacturing processes with their air conditioning and heating systems. Honeywell says the new system could cut energy costs, reduce waste and improve efficiency. Companies that would benefit most are those whose products are extremely sensitive to temperature, air quality, humidity and other environmental factors. Among them are computer-chip makers, pharmaceutical manufacturers, food processors and textile firms, Honeywell said. ``Our most visionary customers have been asking for the capability to integrate systems,'' said Joe E. Chenoweth, president of the Honeywell division that developed the technology. ``Simply put, it allows companies to better understand and control their manufacturing environments and, as a result, to be more productive and competitive.'' The Minneapolis-based company makes controls for manufacturing processes as well as heating and air conditioning systems. It also makes security systems and equipment for the space and aviation industries.

DOC.HEAD: Corn Futures Rise on Soviet Purchase Talk
DOC.TEXT: Corn futures prices rose slightly Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid rumors of Soviet buying interest, but other grain and soybean futures finished modestly lower. The weak corn rally marked a renewal of speculation that the Soviet Union is in the market for U.S. corn to complete its commitment to buy 1 million metric tons by the end of the year. The Soviets bought 350,000 metric tons of U.S. corn earlier this fall. They are required to buy another 650,000 metric tons this year to honor their long-term grain agreement. The market talk on Monday was that the Soviets might have bought 500,000 metric tons, said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. The other markets were pressured by perceptions that dry, mild weather would allow soybean harvesting to advance in the Midwest and benefit newly planted winter wheat in the Great Plains. At the close, wheat futures were 1{ cents lower to 1{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.61\ a bushel; corn was unchanged to 1 cent higher with December at $2.28} a bushel; oats were } cent to 1{ cents lower with December at $1.18{ a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cents to 4{ cents lower with November at $5.90{ a bushel.

The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up about 20 points in early trading, was down 18.07 at 2,418.07 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Up As Soviet Diplomatic Efforts Fail
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices moved above $34 per barrel in light trading on the futures market Monday, amid concerns that a Soviet peace effort in the Persian Gulf had failed. ``It was perhaps one of the last-ditch efforts to get a peaceful resolution,'' said Christian Gohler, a vice president with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. ``As a result, the market moved higher.'' Light sweet crude oil rose $1.67 to $34.68 per barrel for December delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Contracts for later months also settled higher. Traders said Monday's session was one of the quietest they could remember in the volatile weeks that followed Iraq's invasion and occupation of Kuwait in August. Although there was no strong news to move the market, prices opened higher and held their ground on reports of the unsuccessful Soviet efforts to find a diplomatic solution to the crisis. ``There was a lot of speculation over the weekend that there could be some progress made,'' said Peter Beutel, an oil analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J. ``Whether it's true or not, people are saying this may be the last chance before some military action is necessary. The thinking is, if the Soviets can't get Iraq to change, who can?'' The Soviet Union and Iraq once had close ties, but the Soviets nonetheless lined up with the rest of the global community in condemning Iraq for its attack on Kuwait. Soviet Middle East envoy Yevgeny Primakov met with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein in Baghdad on Sunday. Following those talks, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said he saw no reason for optimism in the gulf. Some traders stayed on the sidelines Monday as they waited to see an interview with Saddam that Cable News Network was to air Monday evening. Oil prices hit their lows for the day on the Merc when players learned from an excerpt of the interview that Saddam was apparently refusing to rule out the idea of a diplomatic resolution to the crisis. ``He was saying peace was still possible,'' said Ed Kevelson, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Crude's increase early in the day was mirrored in the futures prices for refined petroleum products. Home heating oil settled 3.11 cents higher at 91.36 cents a gallon for November delivery. Contracts for later months all closed higher. Unleaded gasoline settled up .96 cent at 92.43 cents per gallon for November, with other delivery months trading higher. Natural gas futures were off for the day, with the December contract falling 1.4 cents to $2.434 per 1,000 cubic feet.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar settled mostly higher on world currency markets Monday, but traders complained that dealings were dull. Gold prices advanced after falling overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $373.70 a troy ounce, up $2.80 from Friday's close. Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $373.65, up $2.65 an ounce. Traders said that despite the advance, the dollar remained within its current trading range. With no fresh news to direct trading, ``there was no reason to sell and no reason to buy,'' said Robert Ryan, a senior trader at the Bank of New York. At midday the Federal Reserve bought $1 billion in Treasury bills while the federal funds rate, the interest rate charged on overnight loans, was at 7} percent. The move signaled to the financial markets that the Fed had eased by \ point. Though lower interest rates usually are bearish for the dollar because they diminish the value of dollar-denominated securities, traders discounted the Fed's action. ``The market had been anticipating an easing, and the dollar had been falling on that,'' said Earl Johnson, a vice president at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago, noting that any easing already had been discounted in the currency markets. The Fed had made an easing of its credit policy contingent on the passage of a budget measure. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 127.35 Japanese yen from 128.50 yen at Friday's close. Later in London, it was quoted higher at 127.80 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 128.65 yen, up from 128.25 yen on Friday. In London, the British pound fell to $1.9525 from $1.9555 late Friday. In New York, one pound cost $1.9490, less expensive than Friday's $1.9565. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates included: 1.5220 German marks, up from 1.5130; 1.2920 Swiss francs, up from 1.2810; 5.0930 French francs, up from 5.0670; 1,140.50 Italian lire, up from 1,134.00; and 1.1635 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1644. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday's rates included: 1.5170 German marks, up from 1.5155; 1.2865 Swiss francs, up from 1.2795; 5.0775 French francs, up from 5.0740; 1.7090 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7083; 1,136.75 Italian lire, up from 1,135.50; and 1.1640 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1653. Gold fell in London to a late bid of $372.75 a troy ounce from $373.75 late Friday. In Zurich, gold fell to $372.50 an ounce from $373.40. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.80 an ounce to close at $371.16. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.127 a troy ounce, up from $4.050 on Friday. But in London the metal slipped to a late bid of $4.10 a troy ounce, from $4.14.

Over the weekend the House and Senate approved a measure designed to curtail the government's budget deficit, which reached a near-record $220.4 billion in the fiscal year ended last month. With that uncertainty out of the way, talk has increased that the Federal Reserve might soon take steps toward at least a slight easing of its monetary policy. But analysts noted that serious problems remain in the government's fiscal outlook. In addition, investors were confronted Monday with new increases in world oil prices.
