DOC.HEAD: Merrill Lynch Overhauls Management Structure; Layoffs Expected
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs, `Merrill's stock. . . to UPDATE with closing stock price; PICKS UP 8th graf pvs, `The six. . .
DOC.TEXT: Merrill Lynch & Co. announced a sweeping management overhaul Monday that could lead to several hundred job cuts at the nation's biggest securities firm. The reorganization replaces Merrill's separate consumer and capital markets groups with six business divisions, eliminating a structure in place since 1984. It also creates a mechanism for Merrill to replace company chairman and chief executive William A. Schreyer, who is to retire in 1993 at age 65. Schreyer took over Merrill in 1985. Analysts said the move reflects a renewed emphasis on individual investors and other clients over the creation of new products. Investment banking fields such as junk bonds and merchant banking created large profits in the mid-1980s, but have slumped in the last three years. ``Everybody has next to nothing or negative profits on the institutional side,'' said Perrin Long, an industry analyst with Lipper Analytical Securities Corp. Schreyer and Merrill President Daniel Tully said in a statement that the new structure will focus management ``as closely as possible on meeting the needs and exceeding the expectations of the key client groups we serve.'' Merrill's stock fell 87{ cents Monday to close at $16.75 on the New York Stock Exchange, after dropping $1.75 on Friday. The stock closed on Oct. 16 at $16.12{, its lowest level since the first quarter of 1980. The six new business divisions, each run by an executive vice president, are private client, asset management, insurance, investment banking, debt markets and equity markets. Each will operate under the full Merrill name. Merrill spokesman Fred Yager said the reorganization was not designed to reduce staff, but that several hundred jobs may be reduced in the next several months as support staff operations are consolidated. Merrill has 39,000 employees, down from a peak of 50,000 in 1987. A top Merrill executive told analysts earlier this year that if business conditions continued to deteriorate the firm would consider furloughing 10 percent of its staff. The restructuring was the second at Merrill this year. The firm in January took a $470 million charge against earnings to pay for an overhaul that included about 3,000 layoffs and the shutdown of several business lines. Merrill earlier this month reported third-quarter earnings of $46.1 million, or 38 cents a share. That was down 38 percent from the second quarter but 6 percent higher than an especially weak 1989 third quarter. Yager said the latest restructuring is expected to save Merrill ``tens of millions of dollars'' over an unspecified period of time. The firm will continue to evaluate its businesses under the January restructuring, he said. The six new divisions will operate within the overall management of the firm. Under the two-sector structure, Merrill's individual-investor operations and capital markets group operated autonomously. John Steffens, 49, an executive vice president in charge of Merrill's consumer markets operation, will run the private-client division, which deals with individual investors and small- and medium-sized business. One other executive vice president, Thomas Patrick, 47, currently chief financial officer, will head the insurance division. The newly elected executive vice presidents are Barry Friedberg, 49, who will head investment banking; David Komansky, 51, equity markets; Roger Vasey, 54, debt markets; and Arthur Zeikel, 58, asset management. The apparent loser in the shuffle is Jerome Kenney, 49, who headed the capital markets division since 1984 and will run a new support division in corporate strategy and research. Another executive vice president, Herbert Allison Jr., 47, will head a support division on finance and administration. All will serve on the firm's executive management committee, which will assist in the search for a successor to Schreyer.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Reports 3rd-Quarter Loss
With AM-Auto Talks, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES in 17th graf with closing stock price.
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. reported a $214 million third-quarter loss Monday, a performance that would have been worse without record earnings at the company's financial subsidiary. The earnings report, which showed Chrysler did better by loaning money than by building and selling cars, underscored its difficulties as the No. 3 Detroit automaker negotiates with the United Auto Workers to reach a new contract. Chrysler is the last and weakest of the Big Three to negotiate with the UAW and has said it can't be as generous as rivals General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. Chrysler reported a third-quarter loss of 95 cents a share, compared to $331 million, or $1.42 a share, in the 1989 quarter. That period included a one-time, $309 million credit from the sale of some stock in Mitsubishi Motors Corp. Chrysler now holds an 11 percent share of the Japanese automaker. The company said the loss stemmed partly from the cost of cash rebates and other incentivies aimed at selling cars, as well as the costs of a one-month shutdown for retooling of Chrysler's two minivan plants, which make some of the company's best-selling vehicles. By contrast, Chrysler Financial Corp., which handles consumer car loans, earned $83 million in the quarter ended Sept. 30, its best performance ever. The third-quarter loss came on revenues of $6.5 billion, down 14.5 percent from $7.6 billion recorded in July through September last year. For the first nine months of 1990, Chrysler earned $37 million, or 17 cents a share, compared with $983 million, or $4.21 a share, last year. Revenue fell 15.4 percent to $23 billion from $27.2 billion. ``Chrysler lost a little less in the third quarter than I expected,'' said auto analyst David Healy of the investment bank Barclays de Zoete Wedd, noting that Chrysler Financial ``did a good deal better than I expected.'' Healy also noted that Chrysler does not plan to close its St. Louis I assembly plant as soon as expected. Last year, Chrysler targeted a September 1990 shutdown, but since pushed the closing back to May 1991, the end of production for the Chrysler LeBaron coupe and convertible and the Dodge Daytona. Healy said Chrysler Treasurer Jerry York told Wall Street analysts Monday that the company's cost-cutting pace has accelerated now that 1991 models are in production. Much of the saving is tied to more efficient manufacturing operations for the 1991 models, which officially debuted Oct. 1. York also said incentive costs for the automaker should begin to ease. ``It was about $1,200 (per vehicle) for the second quarter and $1,250 for the third quarter,'' Healy said. ``It will be maybe a little less than that in the fourth quarter.'' Chairman Lee Iacocca blamed a variety of events for the third-quarter loss. ``We anticipated 1990 would be a tough year for Chrysler and for the industry, so we launched a major cost-cutting program over a year ago,'' he said in a statement. ``We didn't anticipate the Gulf crisis, the federal budget fiasco or the continued escalation in the incentive wars, so we've increased our cost-reduction goals to $2.5 billion over two years.'' Iacocca has set the cost-cutting target for June 1991. Chrysler stock rose on the earnings report, but fell back to close at $11, down 12{ cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. Ford was expected to announce third-quarter earnings Tuesday. They were projected to be slightly more than half of the $477.1 million the company earned during the period last year. General Motors Corp. reports major subsidiaries' earnings Tuesday and corporate earnings Wednesday. The No. 1 automaker is expected to show a 50 percent drop in third-quarter earnings from the 1989 level of $516.9 million.

DOC.HEAD: Manville Third-Quarter Profits Down 39 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Manville Corp. said Monday its third-quarter profits tumbled 39 percent, in part because of a decline in the domestic construction market. Manville, a building products and natural resources company, reported net income of $24.5 million, or 17 cents per share, compared with $40.4 million, or 30 cents per share, in the same 1989 period. For the three months ended Sept. 30, Manville said net sales rose 4.7 percent to $576 million from $550 million a year ago. Manville Chairman and Chief Executive Tom Stephens said the company's domestic paper business remained steady, but ``we're feeling the effects of softening in the domestic construction markets.'' Manville said the start-up of new operations hurt earnings. Manville in the third quarter acquired Visypack Pty. Ltd., an Australian folding cartons maker. Earlier this year, Manville acquired DRG Cartons Ltd., a British cartons maker, and Fiskeby Board AB of Sweden, a supplier of boxboard products. The company charged $4.8 million in legal and other professional fees for restructuring a trust fund formed as part of Manville's 1988 bankruptcy court reorganization to compensate asbestos disease victims. Under the resturcturing, announced in September, Manville agreed to inject up to $520 million over seven years to help the autonomous Manville Personal Injury Settlement Trust meet more claims. The trust has run out of cash and all payments to victims have been frozen. Manville, once the nation's largest asbestos maker, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in 1982 because of mounting lawsuits by victims of lung cancer and other respiratory disease. Manville no longer makes asbestos. In the first nine months of 1990, Manville reported earnings of $102 million, or 75 cents per share, down 15 percent from $120 million, or 91 cents per share, in the same 1989 period. Net sales in the nine-month period were $1.66 billion, up from $1.62 billion in the year-ago period. Manville manufactures building products, fiberglass and industrial insulation products, paper and wood products, packaging, roofing systems and filtration and minerals. The company has more than 18,000 workers at more than 50 plants and seven mining interests worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Recalls 127,000 T-birds, Cougars for Pollution Fix
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. said Monday it is recalling 127,000 1987 Ford Thunderbird and Mercury Cougar cars with 3.8-liter V-6 engines because of excess exhaust emissions. Testing by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and Ford indicated that the cars produced unacceptable levels of carbon monoxide at high altitudes and hydrocarbon levels at low altitudes, the company said. Owners are being notified by mail to bring the affected cars to dealers, who will install a vacuum retard valve and change ignition timing to correct the problem, at no cost. Ford said vehicles built for sale in California and Canada weren't affected.

DOC.HEAD: Multiple Reasons Seen for Murdoch Magazines' Suspension of Men's Life
DOC.TEXT: Murdoch Magazines has blamed a weak economy for its decision to suspend publication of Men's Life magazine after one issue. Some magazine industry analysts suspect the heavy debt load carried by the magazine company's parent, News Corp. Ltd., also played a big role in the decision to halt publication of the magazine. Executives at several magazines aimed at segments of the men's market, meanwhile, said Monday they are staying the course despite what they concede is a tough advertising climate. Men's Life was launched in September, targeted at men aged between 40 and 50 years old with moderate incomes. The first issue carried a cover photo of a woman in a baseball catcher's gear to illustrate a story ``Safe at Home'' that said most men would remarry their wives if given a second chance. Other stories asked ``Do we all become our fathers?'' and ``What is it about blondes?'' Murdoch Magazines President Leslie Hinton said in annoucing the suspension last Friday that reader response to the first issue was encouraging but added it was ``too costly to go ahead in the present economic environment.'' He said the magazine would be back ``when the economy improves.'' Men's Life was one of several general interest men's magazines that were either started or repositioned in recent months. The magazines Manhattan Inc. and M were merged into M Inc. and the nightlife magazine Details was overhauled to appeal to young men. A proposed magazine called Men was sold to the company that publishes the 2{-year-old title Smart, which becomes ``Smart . . . for Men'' in January. Mitchell Fox, publisher of Details, said the Conde Nast Publications Inc. magazine has sold 250 pages of ads for the first five issues since its September relaunch as a men's magazine and that circulation has exceeded its 100,000 guarantee. ``We are certainly not going to pull the plug,'' he said. Susan Lodge, publisher of M Inc. aimed at affluent, middle-aged men, said she sympathized with the backers of Men's Life. ``It's a terrible time to be starting a magazine,'' she said. She said her Capital Cities-ABC Inc. publication benefited from having two subscriber lists and advertiser lists to use for the repositioned magazine. ``We have every positive sign going for us in a very difficult business climate,'' she said. John Reidy, media analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co., said the tough advertising environment was mainly responsible for the suspension of Men's Life. Publishers Information Bureau recently reported that advertising volume was down 3.3 percent for the first nine months of the year at the 172 magazines it tracks. Ad pages were down 4.5 percent in September alone. Reidy doubted the decision had much to do with the $8 billion debt at News Corp., the Australian-based parent of Murdoch Magazines. He said the $10 million or so that it would cost to make a success of Men's Life would not mean much in the context of that debt burden. But Martin S. Walker, an analyst for Periodical Studies Service Inc., said the suspension does reflect the corporate financial position of News Corp. ``Sure, it's a drop in the bucket but it is one more drop. They just don't want to start investing in new things right now,'' Walker said. Murdoch's Hinton was unavailable Monday for elaboration on Friday's suspension of Men's Life. But he denied through a spokesman published reports that the magazines Seventeen or Premiere were up for sale. ``None of the Murdoch Magazines are for sale,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Moves To Ban Ingredients In Diet Drugs
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 2nd graf to name brand involved in July action; INSERTS 2nd graf, Aside from, noting no brand names given; INSERTS 3rd graf, The action, to note certain food uses are safe; SUBS 4th graf, The agency, to delete redundant words ``the ingredients,'' ADDS graf on schedule of rulings. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration wants to ban the use of 111 ingredients in non-prescription diet drug products, including one it says presents a safety hazard. That ingredient is guar gum, which is extracted from plant matter. Three months ago, FDA told the distributor of one brand of diet table, Cal Ban 3000, that contains guar gum to stop distributing the tablets because it had received 17 reports of users suffering from obstruction of the esophagus. Aside from those tablets, the agency did not give brand names of products affected. The action does affect guar gum use in small amounts in foods where it poses no health hazard, foods such as cheese, salad dressings and ice cream, the agency said. The agency said the 111 ingredients had not been proven effective in diet products. The ban includes alcohol, corn syrup, dextrose, kelp, pineapple enzymes, rice polishings, saccharin, salt, sodium bicarbonate, vitamin C and wheat germ. FDA said it had given manufacturers opportunities to prove the ingredients were effective but that it had received no significant information. The proposed ban will be published in Tuesday's Federal Register along with another proposed ruling that calls for a warning on general over-the-counter drugs containing water soluble gums like guar gum. That, said FDA ``is also a result of reports of esophageal obstruction following ingestion of diet and laxative products containing these ingredients.'' Products containing such substances, including guar gum, psyllium, and the like, would have to carry labels warning users to take them with adequate fluid and to avoid them totally if the user had ever had difficulty swallowing. The agency said it would receive comment on its proposals for 60 days, and any action would not be effective until six months after its eventual decision.

DOC.HEAD: Pork Futures Post Limit Losses As Demand Fades
DOC.TEXT: Hog and pork belly futures prices plunged their daily limits Monday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, reflecting a sharp downturn in pork demand and expectations for higher hog production in the fourth quarter. On other commodity markets, cattle futures also fell; oil futures rose; precious metals rose; copper retreated; and grains and soybeans were mixed. Hog futures settled .18 cent to the limit 1.5 cents lower in Chicago with the contract for delivery in December at 51.45 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.95 cents to the limit 2 cents lower with February at 60.95 cents a pound. Cash hog prices dropped about 1.5 cents a pound as packer buying interest slackened amid perceptions that retailers plan fewer pork specials in the coming month, analysts said. The sell-off also corresponded to a seasonal decline in consumer demand for bacon. Bacon demand typically peaks in the warm-weather months, a phenomenon that some analysts link to increased consumption of bacon-lettuce-and-tomato sandwiches. Phil Stanley, an independent trader and market consultant for DEC Futures Inc. of Lincoln, Neb., said expectations for larger hog production in the fourth quarter also weighed on the market. He said the sell-off was exaggerated by speculators. Further profit-taking may have reflected end-of-the-month selling by players who needed cash to pay commission fees, said Dale Durchholz, livestock analyst with AgriVisor Services Inc. of Bloomington, Ill. Cattle futures also retreated on the Chicago Merc in line with lower cash cattle prices. Live cattle futures settled .55 cent lower to .10 cent higher with December at 77.32 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent to .58 cent lower with November at 87.07 cents a pound. Oil prices shot up more than $1 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange as traders expressed concern over the apparent failure of Soviet diplomatic efforts in the Persian Gulf. ``There was a lot of speculation over the weekend that there could be some progress made,'' said Peter Beutel, an oil analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. ``Whether it's true or not, people are saying this may be the last chance before some military action is necessary.'' Light sweet crude oil settled 60 cents to 167 cents higher with December at $34.68 a barrel; heating oil was 2.35 cents to 3.34 cents higher with November at 91.36 cents a gallon; unleaded heating oil was .64 cent to 2.6 cents higher with November at 92.43 cents a gallon. Gold and silver futures rose strongly on New York's Commodity Exchange in a rally that many analysts regarded as a technical correction after the sharp decline of the last four weeks. Gold futures ended $2.10 to $2.80 higher with October at $373.70 a troy ounce; silver was 7.7 cents higher across the board with October at $4.127 a troy ounce. Corn futures prices rose slightly on the Chicago Board of Trade amid rumors of Soviet buying interest but other grain and soybean futures finished modestly lower. The weak corn rally marked a renewal of speculation that the Soviet Union is in the market for U.S. corn to complete its commitment to buy 1 million metric tons by the end of the year. The Soviets have bought about 402,000 metric tons of U.S. corn so far this year, according to the Agriculture Deparment. They were rumored on Monday to have bought another 500,000 metric tons, said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. After the close, the USDA reported that exporters sold more than 320,000 metric tons of U.S. soybeans to unknown destinations. Another 265,000 metric tons of foreign soybeans were sold to unknown destinations, the USDA said. The USDA also released its weekly crop-progress report, which showed 72 percent of the U.S. soybean crop and 64 percent of the corn crop harvested as of Sunday. The agency said 86 percent of the winter wheat crop was planted as of Sunday. Wheat futures ended 1{ cents lower to 1{ cents higher with December at $2.61\ a bushel; corn was unchanged to 1\ cent higher with December at $2.28{ a bushel; oats were } cent to 1 cent lower with December at $1.19 a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 4} cents lower with November at $5.90{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Insurance Industry Task Force Proposes Tougher Regulatory Process
DOC.TEXT: Minnesota insurance companies would face some of the strictest financial requirements in the country under industry-supported recommendations announced Monday by the state commerce commissioner. ``There isn't a crisis out there now, but there are troubled companies,'' Commissioner Thomas Borman said in releasing a report from the Minnesota Insurance Solvency Task Force. The regulations are intended to boost consumer confidence in Minnesota insurance companies and prevent insolvencies, which cost the industry millions of dollars in payments to state guaranty funds. The chief change would limit junk bond holdings to 15 percent of a company's assets - the country's most stringent restriction on low or unrated debt securities, Borman said. New York's 20 percent limit is currently the most restrictive, he said. Another proposal would require insurers to mark down the value of ``distressed'' real estate and real estate loans to market values. Those reports would be filed with the commissioner's office, forming the basis for possible targeted examinations. Borman said he knows of no other state requiring such reports. A third recommendation is for companies to follow a new formula in reporting their capital structures, requiring them to account for risks related to underwritings and investments. Generally, the formula would require additions to capital ``as a company invests in riskier assets,'' Borman said. Utah has a risk-based capital formula and New York is studying one. To enforce the proposed changes, Borman said he would like at least 30 more insurance regulators on his staff, more than tripling its size at an annual cost of roughly $1.5 million. Minnesota insurance executives on the task force said the industry would be willing to pay for the added expense in the form of increased fees, but Borman will first seek an appropriation from the Legislature, he said. The changes could be enforced against the 104 insurance companies based in Minnesota and out-of-state companies applying to do business here, Borman said. Out-of-state companies already doing business in the state wouldn't be held to the new regulations, but they may be targeted for review if they are not meeting revised standards, Borman said. ``I am certain that poorly managed companies will feel pain based on the recommendations of the task force,'' Borman said. He said the changes are proposed as a way to target ``high-flying'' insurance companies who invested heavily in the 1980s in junk bonds and commercial real estate. Such early government intervention could avert the kind of trouble suffered in the savings and loan industry, Borman said. ``We're dealing with this in a forward-looking way,'' Borman said. ``What you had in the savings and loan industry was after the fact. They really reacted under a crisis mentality.'' More than 30 percent of junk bonds issued in the 1980s were purchased by U.S. life insurance companies, many of whom also are long-term lenders in commercial real estate, Borman said. The proposed changes should not lead to higher premiums, said task force member Robert P. Gandrud, president and chief executive officer of Lutheran Brotherhood, a Minneapolis-based life and health insurance company. ``We either pay now in improved regulation or we can pay later. We see it as an investment in insolvency prevention,'' Gandrud said. Borman said the state has the authority to suspend insurance licenses and halt sales of a company until problems are cleared up. He said he did not know how many companies in the state would have to sell junk bonds or make other changes in capital structure to conform with proposed changes. Susan Mead, a spokeswoman for Minneapolis-based Northwestern National Life, said the law should put Minnesota-based insurers at a competitive advantage. ``The consumers can feel that if they have policies from a Minnesota company they are pretty safe,'' she said. Borman said he may immediately adopt some of the regulatory guidelines proposed by the task force. But he said there would be a public hearing on the limits regarding junk bonds because it would require legislative action. The task force was made up of four commerce department officials and top executives from 10 Minnesota-based insurance companies.

DOC.HEAD: Remain Weak in September
DOC.TEXT: A widely followed index of construction activity remained stagnant in September, another piece of evidence that the broader economy is heading into a recession, the company that compiles the index said Monday. The Dodge Index of construction contracting stood at 147 in September, basically unchanged from the 1990 low of 146 reached in August. By contrast, at this time last year, contracting for new construction was at an all-time peak, 25 percent stronger than the latest rate. The Dodge Index is a seasonally adjusted indicator of future construction activity, published by the F.W. Dodge Division of McGraw-Hill, the nation's leading source of construction information. The index uses 1982 as its 100 base and represents the value of all newly started construction. George A. Christie, vice president and chief economist for F.W. Dodge, said the index shows ``the construction sector, which has often served as a leading indicator of general business activity, seems to be supporting the growing belief that the economy is heading into recession, or may already be there.'' The trend shows starts of new construction projects have fallen for four consecutive quarters, leaving most parts of the country far behind last year's pace, he said. ``As work in progress is brought to completion, spending and employment in this key industry is drying up,'' Christie said. The value of new nonresidential building contracts totaled $83.6 billion in September, up 8 percent from $77.5 billion in August. Residential building contracts totaled $104.7 billion, up 1 percent from a month earlier, and the value of nonbuilding construction, such as public works projects, fell 10 percent from a month earlier to $43.2 billion, F.W. Dodge said.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Posts Record 3rd-Quarter Sales
DOC.TEXT: The Boeing Co.'s third-quarter profits rose 56.2 percent on strong sales and high margins for commercial aircraft, the aerospace company said Monday. Boeing posted profits of $378 million, or $1.10 a share, on record sales of $7.176 billion. In the same period last year, the company had profits of $242 million, or 70 cents a share, on sales of $6.356. Boeing said it was still losing a substantial amount of money on its defense and space work but the losses are projected to be less than 1989's loss of $474 million. Two weeks ago,United Airlines placed the first 34 firm orders for the all-new widebody 777 jetliner. It took options for another 34. It also ordered 30 747-400 jumbo jets and took options for a like number. If all 128 planes are delivered, the deal would be worth more than $22 billion, the largest commercial jet buy in history. Despite the nod from one of its longest and best customers, Boeing's board of directors had to give its formal approval to build the new twinjet. It did so Monday, even as busloads of employees were being brought to an enormous hanger at Boeing's Flight Center for the ``all-team meeting'' of Boeing Commercial Airplane Group's New Airplane Division. The meeting was more of a pep rally with marching bands, cheerleaders and cowbells. Frank Shrontz, Boeing chairman and chief executive officer, was greeted with a standing ovation when he announced the board's decision. ``We clearly have the right product at the right time. What's important is to develop it in the right way,'' Shrontz said. Boeing officials refuse to say how much they are spending on the 777, but industry analysts have estimated anywhere from $2 billion to $5 billion. Shrontz said Boeing eventually plans to have 8,000 to 10,000 people working on the jet. But he said overall company employment of about 102,000 in the Seattle area may not increase because of cutbacks on defense programs. This year alone, Shrontz said, Boeing has transferred about 2,200 workers from its defense segments to commercial aircraft. Shrontz said 1990 sales are projected to be about $27.5 billion, compared with $20.6 billion in 1989. Boeing has had problems on several defense programs, including the second-generation short range attack missile, the avionics for the Navy's new P-3 patrol plane, and Saudi Arabia's Peace Shield air defense program. Shrontz said progress has been made in resolving cost and schedule problems on government programs and the recent reorganization of Boeing's defense and space segments should improve results in the future. Boeing had a total firm order backlog of $86.3 billion on Sept. 30, compared with $80.6 billion a year before. For the first nine months of 1990, Boeing had net earnings of $1.07 billion or $3.09 a share on sales of $20.58 billion, up from earnings of $598 million or $1.73 a share on sales of $15.429 billion. Including a one-time restatement for income tax purposes, the 1989 net earnings would be $896 million or $2.59 a share.

DOC.HEAD: Brady Says Economy Not in Recession
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf: ``We're in,'' to CORRECT that speech to a college group, not at the college. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said Monday the nation's economy has expanded at a 1.5 percent annual rate during the first nine months of the year. An aide said later that Brady did not have advance knowledge of third-quarter growth figures, which will be released Tuesday by the Commerce Department, and was merely making a general point that the economy was still expanding. Brady said some parts of the economy are ``in bad shape.'' ``We're in a period of slower growth,'' but not a recession, he said in an appearance in Easton, Md. to Friends of Washington College in nearby Chestertown. ``But fundamentally, our economy is strong,'' he said. ``And in the first nine months of this year it grew 1.5 percent. ... That means very simply that the gross national product of the United States was 1.5 percent greater in 1990 than it was in 1989.'' A tape recording of his remarks was made available here. The GNP expanded at a 1.7 percent annual rate in the first quarter and initial estimates of second quarter growth were 1.2 percent which amounted to a 1.5 percent rate for the first six months. The Commerce Department later revised second-quarter growth to just a 0.4 percent rate for a six-month annual rate of 1.0 percent. Assistant Secretary Roger Bolton, asked about Brady's remarks, said the secretary meant that the economy had been growing at a 1.5 percent rate and was not in a recession. Brady was not available for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Pennzoil's Third Quarter Earnings Down
DOC.TEXT: Pennzoil Co.'s 1990 third quarter earnings dropped 25 percent, partly because higher crude oil prices cut into refining revenue, the oil company said Monday. Third quarter net income this year totaled $26.4 million, or 66 cents per share, compared to $35.4 million, or 87 cents per share posted a year ago, Pennzoil said. The earnings decline came despite a 13.5 percent increase in third quarter revenues, which were $615.4 million compared to $542.3 million for the same period last year. James L. Pate, Pennzoil president and chief executive, said higher crude oil costs caused by the Persian Gulf crisis reduced operating income for the company's refinery division. ``Pennzoil's motor oil sales in the third quarter were at an all-time high, but we were unable to adjust product prices to fully recover the surge in crude costs,'' he said. In the oil and gas segment, improved oil revenues were offset by reduced gas revenues reflecting lower prices and sales volumes, Pennzoil said. ``In contrast to higher crude prices, natural gas prices and demand were down in the third quarter. Since Pennzoil is a major producer of natural gas, our earnings were negatively impacted by this situation,'' Pate said. He said colder weather should improve gas prices and demand. For the nine-month period ending Sept. 30, Pennzoil's net income was $63.8 million, or $1.62 per share. Net income for the same period in 1989 was $206 million, or $5.36 per share. The year-to-date earnings include an after-tax gain of $86.8 million on the sale of Burlington Resources Inc. common stock. Revenues for the nine-month period were $1.7 billion this year and $1.8 billion in 1989.
